HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

A U.S. Agency Issues Warning on Heart Drug
The United States Heart, Lung and Blood Institute said that a drug sold by Pfizer and Bayer to treat high blood pressure and heart disease should be used "with great caution, if at all," and that the safety of related drugs taken by millions of Americans was unclear.
The warning applied to large doses of the short-acting form of nifedipine, one of 10 drugs called calcium channel-blockers that are taken to control blood pressure and relieve angina pains. As a class, the drugs are the most widely prescribed in the nation. Pfizer and Bayer disputed a study on which the warning was based. [Page A1.]
 
US Air Shakes Up Pricing
US Air has radically changed its pricing for flights that connect major East Coast cities and Pittsburgh to most cities in northern and western New York State. While the new fare structure means savings and added flexibility for some fliers, some weekly commuters must pay fare increases of 75 percent. [D3.]
 
Income Up as Spending Dips
Consumer spending increased only two-tenths of 1 percent in July from June even though personal income surged seven-tenths of 1 percent, the fastest pace in six months. The weak spending increase, which analysts attributed to a rise in personal debt, provided fresh evidence that economic growth would be sluggish. [D2.]
 
A Ruling Against Life Partners
A Federal judge has ruled that Life Partners, a company that is the leader in the business of selling life insurance policies of terminally ill people, has been violating securities laws and must change its practices. [D3.]
 
Republic Talks With Brooklyn Bank
Republic New York was said by a person familiar with the negotiations to be holding preliminary talks about acquiring Brooklyn Bancorp, a savings-bank company. [D2.]
 
Dollar Falls on Profit Taking
The dollar fell against most leading currencies as traders took profits from Wednesday's jump in the dollar. It fell to 97.38 yen from 99.11 yen on Wednesday and to 1.4672 marks from 1.4781 marks. [D4.]
 
The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond fell to 6.64 percent, from 6.69 percent, bolstered by indications of a slowing economy. [D13.]
 
Insurance Regulation Faulted
A study of 278 members of insurance committees in 10 state legislatures found that nearly one in five members had ties to the industry. The study says such links often thwart effective regulation of the insurance industry. [D3.]
 
Risks in Implant Negotiations
Efforts to reshape the $4.25 billion settlement on breast implants may soon veer off on a new course, a risky one for both women claiming injuries from the devices and the companies that made them. News Analysis. [D3.]
 
Marketers Discover Ripken
The closer that Cal Ripken Jr., the Baltimore Orioles' shortstop, comes to breaking Lou Gehrig's major league record for consecutive games played, the better he looks to Madison Avenue as a pitchman. The streak is generating demand for Ripken from national marketers like General Mills, to appear on boxes of its Wheaties, and General Motors, to help promote the durability of Chevrolet trucks. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D5.]
 
Insiders Sell; Lam Research Rises
When insiders sell lots of their company's stock, it often means the shares have peaked. But at Lam Research, insiders have been selling since the shares were at $30 and the stock is now at $60.25. Market Place. [D6.]

HEADLINE: CONFLICT IN THE BALKANS: THE ISSUES;
The Elements of Peace: Money, Land and Justice

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN 

DATELINE: ZAGREB, Croatia, Aug. 31

 BODY:
For the first time since the wars of Yugoslavia's destruction began in 1991, the way to an unlovely peace appears to be opening, but several extremely difficult issues remain.
The door to negotiation was opened over a fifth summer of war by several crucial developments: a new balance of power, inimical to the Serbs, rooted in the growing strength of the Croatian Army; a new wave of expulsions -- of Serbs from Croatia and Muslims from Serbian-held eastern Bosnia -- that virtually completed the slicing up of the former Yugoslavia into ethnically homogeneous zones; and the political victory, consummated this week after more than a year of maneuvering, of President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia over a much weakened Bosnian Serb leader, Radovan Karadzic. 
 These internal developments were complemented by equally important changes in Western capitals and in the United Nations command in Bosnia that have made a resolution of the war more likely.
In Sarajevo, Lieut. Gen. Rupert Smith replaced Lieut. Gen. Sir Michael Rose as commander of the United Nations forces in Bosnia and brought a complete change of style. General Smith pointed relentlessly to the fundamental contradiction of Western policy: The presence of United Nations peacekeepers in territory exposed to any NATO air strikes.
This patent roadblock to any coherent or effective approach had long served Western governments as a shield behind which to fudge their reluctance to take any action over the war in Bosnian. But by this month, with the removal of vulnerable peacekeepers, it had at last been cleared away.
In France, President Francois Mitterrand, a lifelong friend of the Serbs who was deeply hostile to any concerted military action against them, was replaced by Jacques Chirac, who has taken a different view of the war. President Chirac has now staked considerable political capital on ending the siege of Sarajevo.
In Washington, the growing threat of a withdrawal of United Nations troops (which would almost certainly require the dispatch of American soldiers to Bosnia) and of a lifting of the arms embargo on Bosnia (which would divide the Western alliance) abruptly focused the energies of the Clinton Administration on leading the quest for peace.
The result, this month, was that the process was abruptly galvanized because the Yugoslav crisis has shown that the European Union -- a single market but a still-fragmented political and military power -- still needs American leadership.
That leadership, for the moment, appears to be in place. But as serious talks on a settlement look set to begin, tremendous obstacles stand in the way of peace. "We are getting into a room at last," Richard C. Holbrooke, the chief American envoy, said today, "But the room is still dark."
Among the most difficult issues will be these:
EASTERN SLAVONIA Serbia remains committed to holding this oil-rich piece of Croatian territory that abuts Serbia. Its capture -- symbolized by the destruction of the town of Vukovar in 1991 -- involved an enormous expenditure of firepower.
Croatia wants the land back. The United States is proposing "freezing" the issue for three years, pending a final settlement.
SARAJEVO The Bosnian Serbs want part of the city as an ethnically pure Serbian zone. The Muslim-led Bosnian Government is deeply committed to preserving a single, undivided, multi-ethnic city under its control. It is also suspicious of Western proposals that the city come under United Nations control an an interim measure because this would suggest a surrender of sovereignty.
CONSTITUTIONAL ARRANGEMENTS The Bosnian Serbs want an independent state on the territory they control. The United States is offering self-rule and the possibility of a confederation with Serbia.
The Bosnian Government will almost certainly reject any settlement that does not preserve Bosnia as a single, independent state within its current borders, no matter what degree of autonomy the Serbs are given. Suggestions that the Serbs might ultimately be allowed to vote on secession from Bosnia will be rejected by the Government.
THE MAP The Bosnian Serbs want substantial changes in the current proposal for a division giving them 49 percent of the territory and the Muslims and Croats 51 percent. They want a wider corridor south of Brcko, the completion of the ethnic purification of Eastern Bosnia through control of Gorazde, and control of more cities and economic resources.
Strategically, they want the land to be coherent and self-sufficient, because they have an eye toward independence. The Bosnian Government is opposed to these changes.
WAR CRIMES Both Mr. Karadzic and Ratko Mladic, the Bosnian Serb military commander, have been named as war criminals by the International Criminal Tribunal in The Hague. The Serbs will seek an amnesty. The Bosnian Government will resist this and demand that all criminals responsible for the eviction and killing of hundreds of thousands of Muslims in 1992 be prosecuted.
ECONOMIC MEASURES The Bosnian Government will want a huge international injection of funds for reconstruction and will almost certainly demand financial compensation from the Serbs for "ethnic cleansing."
Money will certainly play a central part if the Muslims, who have suffered the most and are still the most vulnerable, are to accept a peace that leaves them with real control over only a small part of Bosnia.
SANCTIONS Serbia and President Milosevic will press for a complete lifting of international economic sanctions as early as possible in the peace negotiations. Bosnia will want the sanctions maintained for as long as possible as a guarantee that Serbian promises -- such as the withdrawal from land they now hold in Bosnia -- are fulfilled. The Serbs will have to give up a third of the land they hold if they are to reduce their territory to 49 percent of Bosnia.
Some American politicians will seek to tie sanctions to other issues, including the status of Kosovo, whose ethnic Albanians want independence from Serbia.

GRAPHIC: Photo: NATO planes on Wednesday bombed Bosnian Serb positions near Mount Jahorina, outside the Bosnian Serb stronghold of Pale. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: Where Have All the Bosses Gone? Off on Fridays, All Summer Long

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON 

 BODY:
So where is everybody? The calendar clearly says today's a workday, yet the empty offices -- especially those corner offices -- say it's an undeclared national holiday.
As Labor Day approaches, deputies and assistants who spent the month concocting imaginative cover stories for their chiefs finally get to scoot out themselves. Today's result, especially in places like New York that have tempting escape routes to mountains and shores, will be the summer's most casual Friday. 
 Next week will bring the season's most detested Tuesday. But by the beginning of this past week, even the city's advertising and public relations wizards ran out of high-flying slogans and spins to disguise their own empty calendars. "Clients are already saying, 'I'll speak to you next week,' and it's only Tuesday," said Tracey Donner, a senior account executive at Edelman Public Relations Worldwide. "People have Labor Day-itis."
A lot of companies, like Mobil, Sara Lee and many advertising agencies, have given up on summer Friday afternoons altogether. Better to cut most employees loose, they figure, than to watch casual Fridays turn into unscheduled holidays.
But just as the pay and wealth advantages of top executives and others in prime positions have widened in recent years, economists say, many of them have gained more freedom to work when they want, where they want, how they want. They stand on the sunnier side of a yawning, spreading "getaway gap."
For this reward, as for so many others, the bosses have a defense: they may be out of the office, but no matter how verdant the setting, they are always working.
"I'm in the Rockies, the chief operating officer is in Martha's Vineyard, and everyone else is at work," Richard A. Shaffer, the principal of Technologic Partners, a newsletter publishing company in New York, gloated over his cellular phone last Friday afternoon. Sure, he's working too, he said, but his labors don't interfere with his morning hikes.
Aides left behind, stuck answering the phones, had better not forget to cover for their bosses.
"He's gone home for the day," an assistant to Jim Wiggins, a first vice president and director of corporate communications at Merrill Lynch in New York, said last Friday afternoon. Pause. "Well, not home. He's left for the day."
An aide to Preston Robert Tisch, co-chairman of the Loews Corporation, also in New York, was evidently more practiced. "He's out at meetings," she said last Friday. A moment later, she admitted that he was flying off early to a preseason game in Charlotte, N.C., for the New York Giants, which he partly owns.
Jack Shakely, president of the California Community Foundation in Los Angeles, almost always takes Friday off or works from his home. "I have never found any resentment," he said.
Just ask Paul Vandeventer, his former executive vice president, as unresentful as can be. The boss works early in the morning, goes to charity events at night and often courts donors on weekends, he said. "No one felt any unfairness," Mr. Vandeventer agreed.
In Washington, however, complaining about unfairness is an official duty. "We're here and everyone else in Western civilization is on vacation," said Mary Ellen Glynn, a White House deputy press secretary, last Friday afternoon.
She was initially thrilled at having the run of the mansion. But only one reporter had stayed around, the venerable Helen Thomas of United Press International, and boredom set in. "Now it's changing from fun and excitement to surly," she said. The halls in the Old Executive Office Building were so empty, she added, "You could play golf there and not hit anybody."
Although no hard numbers show how likely today's executives are to take off in August or stretch their weekends, or how their employees carry on, several labor economists have stories or theories or both.
The most highly skilled and paid do work the longest hours, said Daniel Hamermesh, an economist at the University of Texas at Austin. "But when they want to go away they can go," he said. "And of course to get away you have to spend more money -- on second homes, vacations, the whole schmear."
You must also have an employer willing to buy you thousands of dollars of electronics or you must buy it yourself. "I'm up in Maine," said Janet L. Norwood, a senior fellow at the Urban Institute, a Washington think tank. "But I've got a fax machine and I've got E-mail and a computer, so I don't have any problems." Since late June, Mrs. Norwood, the former director of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, has taken only two quick trips back to her office from her summer home in Liberty, Me.
Executives and senior employees like Mrs. Norwood can electronically delete the line between work and vacation. "Obviously I don't work as hard being away from the office," she said.
Woe to the underlings back at the shop who take too literally an absent boss's expressed desire to stay on top of things. "I call in and ask how things are going," one Texas television executive said last Friday morning, vacationing but wearing a pager on his shorts. "The problem is, they insist on telling me."
Manual laborers can't hammer, dig or drill by fax or phone, so even in Dallas -- on an afternoon when the temperature reached 97 -- most put in a full day. "I'd rather be hot than hungry," said John Forsthoffer in midafternoon, glancing down from the scaffolding where he was laying brick for a new strip of stores.
His bosses hardly needed to escape their air-conditioned offices on August Fridays, in his view. "They don't have to take off -- they don't do nothing nohow," he said, as the rest of his crew traded elbow jabs and chortled.
To keep those doing nothing entertained last Friday, the AMC Highland Park Village 4 movie house in Dallas more than doubled the normal afternoon concession and ushering staff. Most of the viewers were men. "They're escaping from work, they're eating naughty things, they're happy," said Patricia Nelson, the theater's manager. "They go to see 'Under Siege,' 'Batman' -- you know, boy movies that their wives won't want to see."
Many New York artists and art gallery owners insist that they go to the Hamptons and work. Who's left in town? "You've got her," said Marci Silverman at the James Goodman Gallery last Friday. With business expected to be slow, the gallery on East 57th Street repainted its walls last week. No wonder only a few customers peeked in.
On Wall Street, the normal cacophony on the trading desks became a muffled whimper that day from the few left staring at silent phones and the empty chairs of managing directors. "We're just sitting here," a Merrill Lynch trader said. "All afternoon, things just keep getting slower and slower and slower." And this week, even slower.
In Hollywood, the executive excuse is that nobody's reachable from early afternoon Friday on the other coast, so with the time difference why bother coming in and trying? "They're all in the Hamptons," said Terry Press, senior vice president for marketing at the Disney studios, speaking from a remote but unspecified location. "I never find anyone in the afternoons."
This week, as Labor Day approached, the studios fell silent and dark well before Friday. "In Hollywood, when it's a three-day weekend or a four-day weekend, they start checking out on Wednesday," Ms. Press said.
A few bosses, like Bill Schreiber, president of the Beer Drinkers of America in Sacramento, Calif., have duties that will keep them at work today. His group, which lobbies against higher beer taxes, is preparing for the holiday by working with the police on a designated-driver program called Party Smart.
Mr. Schreiber admits that as a newspaper reporter in California, he used to call up Orange County officials before a holiday, then report how much taxpayers were spending on those who had sneaked away. "It was in the hundreds of thousands of dollars," he said. "Boy, were they mad."
But cry not for Mr. Schreiber today. He took Monday and Tuesday off.
 
Chart/Drawings:
 
GOLF -- The Pelham Bay/Split Rock Golf Course in the Bronx is about 30 percent busier on Friday afternoon than on other weekdays.
 
BEACHES -- Attendance is up 14 percent at Jones Beach on Fridays in August.
 
COMMUTING -- Ridership is up 50 percent on New Jersey Transit buses on summer Fridays from noon to 4 p.m.
 
RESTAURANTS -- At The Four Seasons in New York, the Fridays are quiet, but the managing partner, Alex von Bidder, said, "What an opportunity for someone who wants to enjoy the best table and the best service in a quiet restaurant.
 At the restaurants Vong and Jo Jo, the owner-chef, Jean-Georges Vongerichten, said: "We have much more wine on a Friday lunch. It doesn't look like people are going to go anyplace after that."

HEADLINE: License Law At Fish Market Is Challenged

BYLINE: By SELWYN RAAB 

 BODY:
A lawyer for 24 companies at the Fulton Fish Market said yesterday that he would seek a court injunction to block New York City from determining who can and cannot work at the market.
Under a new law that goes into effect today, the city has the power to license companies and employees and ban them from the market on grounds that they have criminal backgrounds or that they are linked to crime groups. The Giuliani administration proposed the statute, saying it was needed to rid the market in lower Manhattan of corruption and exploitation by the Mafia. 
 Gerald J. McMahon, the lawyer for the 24 companies, said that within two weeks he would ask for an injunction in State Supreme Court to prevent the city from enforcing the law until the courts rule on its legality.
"The legislation discriminates against many people in the market on the basis that they are Italian-Americans and that in some unproved way they are therefore connected to Italian-American organized crime," Mr. McMahon said.
Randy M. Mastro, chief of staff for Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, said yesterday that all employees at the market would have to apply next week for clearance to work there and that they would be subject to background investigations. Mr. Mastro said that 54 wholesale seafood dealers had registered recently for permission to operate at the market and that they had turned over lists of their employees to the city.
About 800 people are regularly employed at the market, city officials said. As the nation's largest wholesale seafood market, it is vital to the city's economy, generating about $1 billion a year in sales, salaries and related businesses.

HEADLINE: CHRONICLE

BYLINE: By ELAINE LOUIE 

 BODY:
On Sunday, the DALAI LAMA, the exiled leader of Tibet, will arrive in Atlanta on the first leg of a trip that will also take him to Houston, Boston and Washington. The International Campaign for Tibet, based in Washington, is sponsoring the 10-day trip, during which the Nobel laureate hopes to enlist the help of Government leaders, business leaders and human rights groups in the nonviolent struggle against the Chinese presence in Tibet.
"If Tibetans raise arms against China, it will be suicidal for the Tibetans," said a spokesman, Thubten Samphel of the Office of Tibet, which represents the Dalai Lama in the United States. 
 In Atlanta, the Dalai Lama will meet with CORETTA SCOTT KING at the Martin Luther King Jr. Center for Nonviolent Social Change and will speak at Emory University. In Houston, he will meet with people who are setting up businesses in China and, more recently, in Tibet, to urge them to employ Tibetans as well as Chinese workers.
"The Chinese government is encouraging foreign investment in Tibet, and this affects the population in Tibet, who are less skilled, and less hard-working than the Chinese," Mr. Samphel said. "He's going to advise Americans who plan to do business in Tibet that whatever business they do directly benefits the Tibetan people." If they set up a hotel, for example, the investors should employ and train Tibetan people, who have been left unemployed in the current economy, he said.
In Boston, the Dalai Lama will meet with Chinese scholars and dissidents, and in Washington he will talk with Government leaders. He will also have audiences for local Tibetan communities in Boston and Washington.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar's Rally Stalls as Traders Buy Back Yen in a Correction

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar fell against most leading currencies yesterday after traders sold dollars and bought back some of the yen they had unloaded on Wednesday when Japan's banking crisis flared anew.
"The other day the whole world was selling yen and now we've seen a huge correction," said Debra Larsen, assistant vice president at Commerzbank. 
 The selloff took many traders by surprise. The dollar's recent strength seemed to be bolstered after the Japanese Government on Wednesday closed down a credit union and prepared a rescue package for a regional bank. Investors were seen as wary of the yen because of the potential impact of the growing banking crisis on Japan's financial markets. On Wednesday, the dollar rose as high as 99.25 yen -- its highest since Feb. 10.
Yesterday, however, currency traders took profits on the dollar's gains. Some traders also cited disappointment at the dollar's failure to breach the 100-yen level as another reason for the selling.
Much of the dollar's drop came in Asian trading. The selling intensified, traders said, when it became apparent that central banks would not jump in and halt the dollar's slide. Many market participants were forced to join in to avoid sustaining heavy losses.
"Once the dollar started to fall, it just sort of fed on itself," said John McCarthy, manager of foreign exchange at ING Capital Markets in New York. "And the selling came in two waves: one in Asia and one in Europe."
When New York traders came in, they were somewhat wary of selling the dollar too aggressively amid fear the Federal Reserve would move to shore up the currency if it fell too far too fast.
"The perception that the central banks are committed to sustaining this dollar move is a powerful floor under us at this point," said Tim Fox, an economist at Credit Suisse.
In late New York trading, the dollar fell to 97.38 yen from 99.11 yen on Wednesday. The dollar fell to 1.4672 German marks from 1.4781 marks. The British pound rose to $1.5497 from $1.5452.
Despite the dollar's apparent correction from Wednesday's rally, the cuurency still has the potential to make a bid for 100 yen and 1.50 marks in the coming days, some traders said.
Many currency traders will look to today's United States employment report for August hoping that the report will confirm the view that the American economy is gradually gathering steam and that there is no reason for the Federal Reserve to lower short-term interest rates.

HEADLINE: Consumer Spending Gain Is Weak, Showing Caution

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31

 BODY:
Consumer spending increased only two-tenths of 1 percent in July from June even though personal income rose at the fastest pace in six months, the Commerce Department said today.
The weak increase in spending, which analysts attributed to a rapid rise in personal debt, provided fresh evidence that economic growth would be sluggish in coming months. "Consumers are showing a little more caution," said Cynthia Latta, an economist at DRI/McGraw-Hill in Lexington, Mass. 
 Indeed, spending on durable goods like cars, computers and kitchen appliances fell 1.8 percent in July, the department said. Also today, major chain stores reported disappointing back-to-school sales for August.
Consumers spent cautiously even as personal income surged seven-tenths of 1 percent in July. Hiring for the summer holidays by hotels, resorts and other companies in the service industry magnified the gain.
The figures were in line with expectations. Analysts surveyed by Bloomberg Business News had expected, on average, the Commerce Department report to show a spending gain of three-tenths of 1 percent and an increase in personal income of five-tenths of 1 percent.
Disposable income, the money left over after taxes, increased six-tenths of 1 percent in July.
In line with the downturn in spending on big-ticket items, the Commerce Department said in a separate report today that factory orders fell 1.3 percent in July, a larger decline than analysts had expected, as stockpiles of unsold goods increased for the 10th consecutive month. In June, factory orders fell a revised one-tenth of 1 percent.
Although July's decline in factory orders was the largest since April and the fifth in six months, much of the drop was linked to the seasonal shutdown of auto plants for model change-overs, the department said. Orders for industrial equipment and primary metals also fell.
Excluding transportation goods, orders fell three-tenths of 1 percent in July.
The economy appears to be facing several months of slow growth. Consumer spending, which accounts for two-thirds of the nation's economic activity, may slow further in coming months because household finances are under pressure from a steady increase in borrowing. "They've got to pay this off," said Richard Yamarone of Mountain Econometrics in Maplewood, N.J.
Today's spending report showed that consumers' interest payments to businesses, which are counted separately from overall spending, increased 1 percent during July. Consumer installment credit, led by large outstanding credit-card balances, has been rising for more than two years.
Slow job growth may be another drag on spending. The Labor Department said today that claims for unemployment benefits were unchanged last week from the prior week, at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 349,000. On Friday, the department is expected to report that the economy added about 145,000 jobs in August, according to a survey of economists by Bloomberg Business News.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Wheat Prices Soar on Extension Of European Union Export Ban

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Wheat prices jumped yesterday after the European Union said it would suspend subsidized wheat exports for another month.
The development will effectively keep European grain off the world market until at least Oct. 12, which means nations in need will be more likely to buy from the United States. 
 Prospective buyers who had held back, awaiting the scheduled Sept. 14 return of European wheat to the global marketplace, may now step up and buy American grain, said Susan Leighty, a grain analyst with Prudential Securities.
On other commodity markets, corn and soybean prices also rose strongly. The Commodity Research Bureau's index of 21 commodities rose 1.87 points, to 239.97, a new five-year high.
On the Chicago Board of Trade, wheat for September delivery rose 16.75 cents, to $4.4925 a bushel, the highest daily settlement for near-term deliveries since Aug. 1.
A European Union committee in Brussels suspended wheat export subsidies July 13 in hopes of lowering domestic prices by keeping more grain at home. Yesterday, the committee said that it had extended that suspension through Oct. 12.
Wheat prices have risen sharply this year in anticipation of dwindling stockpiles as a result of increased consumption and a smaller American crop. Both world stocks and American stocks of wheat will reach their lowest levels in at least 20 years by May 31, the end of the 1995-96 crop year, the Agriculture Department has forecast.
The Europeans may want to force world wheat prices higher so they can get more for their grain, said Dan Cekander of Fimat Futures USA Inc. in Chicago.
Corn and soybean prices rose strongly on forecasts for more hot, dry weather next week in the Midwest, which could reduce crop yields.
September corn rose 3.75 cents, to $2.955 a bushel, and September soybeans rose 7 cents, to $6.135 a bushel.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Slowdown Signs Lift Treasuries

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices surged yesterday, bolstered by indications of a slowing economy and by technical factors.
Still, many market participants stayed near the sidelines, awaiting the release today of the employment report for August. 
 The price of the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond rose 21/32 , to 103. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, fell to 6.64 percent, from 6.69 percent on Wednesday.
Bonds strengthened as several reports showed signs of a sluggish economy. The Commerce Department reported that consumer spending in July rose only two-tenths of 1 percent. After adjusting for inflation, it was essentially flat.
Donald J. Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Securities, said that indicated "a slow start for consumer spending in the third quarter."
In a separate report, the Commerce Department said factory orders fell 1.3 percent in July, a larger decline than analysts had expected.
In addition, the Purchasing Management Association of Chicago said its index of regional manufacturing activity was 49.3 in August, slightly lower than July's reading of 49.7, "demonstrating no improvement in business conditions in this crucial industrial sector of the country," Mr. Fine said.
The reports kept hopes alive that the Federal Reserve might make another cut in short-term interest rates this year.
Some buying in the afternoon was a result of several technical factors, Matthew F. Alexy, chief market strategist at CS First Boston, said.
One had to do with end-of-the-month adjustments by money managers whose portfolios are tied to indexes. Another involved investors squaring their positions ahead of the employment report today.
Some investors holding short positions -- that is, betting that the bond prices will fall -- were buying to limit potential losses ahead of the release of the employment data.
"This market is currently in an extreme position," Mr. Alexy said. "And tomorrow those shorting the market may have nowhere to hide if the employment numbers are weaker than expected."
The employment data are not the only economic report scheduled to be released today. The National Association of Purchasing Management will issue its report for August, and the University of Michigan releases to subscribers its consumer sentiment index for August. And that will be followed by Columbia University's leading inflation index.
The analysis of much of the data, however, is likely to take place on Tuesday after the long Labor Day weekend. Today, the cash market for Treasury securities will close early, at 2 P.M.
In futures trading, the December bond contract, which held above the price-support level at 11120/32 , broke above the 11214/32 resistance level on end-of-month book-squaring and lifted prices of longer maturities in the cash market.
Yesterday, the bond contract closed at 11224/32 after moving in a range between 1131/32 and 11126/32 .
Elsewhere, the Treasury auctioned $18 billion of 20-day cash management bills at an average rate of 5.58 percent. The bills are used to meet short-term borrowing needs beyond the money raised through the Government's regularly scheduled auctions. The 13-day cash management bill sold in May, the last time the Treasury sold these type of short-maturity bills, had an average rate of 5.85 percent.

HEADLINE: In America;
Power to the Banks

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT 

 BODY:
Bank executives tend to trip over one another in their haste to escape from areas like Harlem, and once gone they seldom look back. So people got a little overexcited recently when Chase Manhattan held an official opening day ceremony for the extravagantly named Chase Strivers Center at 251 West 135th Street.
Politicians were there to clap people on the back and declare to anyone who would listen that it was a great day. Chase executives distributed press releases proclaiming that the center would serve as an "economic anchor for Harlem." 
 According to the bank and local business officials, the Chase Strivers Center was the first new banking facility of any kind to be established in central Harlem in 38 years. That, they said, was cause for celebration.
Swell. But what exactly is this, uh, Strivers Center?
Are you ready? It is one 24-hour automatic teller machine. One.
And one telephone, which customers can use to ask about other Chase services. Just one.
The number of human tellers at the Chase Strivers Center is zero. But there is, at times, a human presence. For four hours each day a Chase credit officer is on the premises to help fill out applications for a mortgage or a loan.
That's it. That's what the excitement was about. Chase once bragged that "You have a friend at Chase Manhattan." At the Strivers Center, that friend can be hard to find.
Twelve days after the festivities for this single A.T.M., Chase Manhattan and the Chemical Banking Corporation announced that they would merge to create a banking behemoth with $297 billion in assets -- the biggest bank in the country.
"We are creating an absolute powerhouse," crowed the Chase chairman, Thomas G. Labrecque.
Mr. Labreque has the considerable benefit of viewing his powerhouse from the top. The view from the bottom is a different one altogether. Chase and Chemical plan to eliminate 12,000 jobs (about a third of them in metropolitan New York) and close 100 branches.
As this biggest of all American banks begins to enjoy the billions in savings it will realize from the merger, consumers should look out.
"The merger is obviously good for shareholders and obviously bad for consumers," said New York City Public Advocate Mark Green, who has been studying the banking system for several years. As banks have grown larger and more impersonal, the impact on consumers has been increasingly negative.
Banks are paying very low rates of interest, charging very high rates of interest, and imposing unconscionably high service fees on consumers. This is the way powerhouses do business. Banks earned record profits each of the last three years: $32.1 billion in 1992, $43.1 billion in 1993 and $44.7 billion last year.
Were any benefits passed on to consumers? Are you joking? A study by the U.S. Public Interest Research Group found that in the past two years banks have increased most fees for consumer accounts at rates that are double the rise in the consumer price index. And the biggest banks, according to the report, imposed the biggest fee increases.
Mark Green has come up with similar findings. He noted that an increasing number of bank customers are paying more in fees than they earn in interest on their accounts. "Except for the problems of crime and security," he said, "it would make more sense for them economically to keep their money in a mattress than in a bank."
Those who have reason to cheer the merger of Chase and Chemical are the top executives, the big shareholders, the lawyers. They live for the most part in a comfortable and efficient world, where the dollar sign rules all and the absence of greed can be viewed as a sign of mental instability.
Low-level employees and customers of modest means are a nuisance to these types. From their perspective, a pleasant 30-second conversation between a teller and a customer over money being saved for an upcoming wedding is inefficient, and therefore not to be tolerated. They would like to see the customer wedded to an A.T.M. and they'd like to see the teller gone.
That's powerhouse banking -- banking as it ought to be.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Mexico Bailout Needed U.S. Strings Attached

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Mexico: Who Was Right?" (Op-Ed, Aug. 25): Patrick J. Buchanan claims that recent United States-Mexico trade data show that both the North American Free Trade Agreement and the Mexican bailout were not in the U.S. economy's best interest. His analysis misses the real story. 
 While Mr. Buchanan is right that most Nafta advocates overstated its potential benefits to the United States in terms of exports and job creation, it is premature to judge whether or not there might be long-term benefits.
Only in several years, when all tariff cuts and other trade-liberalizing provisions take full effect, can the impact of Nafta be assessed. Mr. Buchanan's conclusion is based on the large trade deficit we are now running with Mexico -- which reflects the aftermath of the peso collapse, and is unrelated to Nafta.
The biggest mistake of the bailout was the manner in which it was structured. A number of major conditions should have been tied to the aid package, which would have reduced the pain and suffering in Mexico and limited the adverse impact of the crisis on the United States economy.
In particular, the Administration should have insisted that Mexico take steps to reduce its large trade deficits with Japan, China and Western Europe, which made up most of Mexico's current-account deficit that caused the crisis in the first place. Without such a condition, most or all of the adjustment that the cheap peso and Mexico's recession would cause would be with the United States, because we are the closest and largest market.
This is precisely what has happened -- these other countries are still running relatively large surpluses with Mexico, while the United States will have nearly a $20 billion trade imbalance with Mexico this year.
In addition, the Clinton Administration should have insisted that Mexico take steps to prevent the outflow of capital of its own citizens, thus slowing the loss of its international reserves, and permit foreign investment in its oilfields in order to increase oil exports.
It is to be hoped that the Administration will insist on these conditions before additional aid is provided to Mexico.
 
LAWRENCE CHIMERINE
Managing Dir. and Chief Economist
Economic Strategy Institute
Washington, Aug. 28, 1995

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: Mexico Bailout Needed U.S. Strings Attached;
Small-Business Boost<HE

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Patrick J. Buchanan's siren song against Mexico (Op-Ed, Aug. 25) is seductive, but he strikes the wrong chords. "Big Business" has had a presence in Mexico for a long time, and -- with or without Nafta -- has the resources to take advantage of Mexico's new open economy. It did not, and does not, need Nafta. 
 On the other hand, Nafta gave small companies like mine a real chance to compete in Mexico. It worked. We were able to increase our hiring and revenues by more than 200 percent.
Nafta had nothing to do with Mexico's financial crisis. Mr. Buchanan uses the International Monetary Fund report on Mexico's devaluation as proof that the American people were somehow had. The I.M.F. report itself misdiagnoses the galvanizing cause of the crisis by focusing only on a superficial symptom of the malady -- Mexican capital flight.
The devaluation was a confluence of many political and economic factors. Nevertheless, the I.M.F. report ignores the real trigger: the announcement by the Zapatistas, the guerrilla group pressing agrarian reform, that they had taken over 38 towns in southern Mexico. The announcement was false, but it did the damage. The "hot" money flew out of Mexico. Unable to sustain its meager reserves, the Mexican administration then devalued the peso.
Would-be Presidents like Patrick Buchanan who are running one-note campaigns based on bashing Mexico are poisoning our relationship with an important and strategic ally, and turning a best customer into no customer.
 
ALINA A. C. E. ALDAPE
San Francisco, Aug. 27, 1995
 
The writer is president, Americas Law Group, business lawyers.

HEADLINE: Mexico Bailout Needed U.S. Strings Attached;
No 'Overblown' Crisis

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "Mexico: Who Was Right?" (Op-Ed, Aug. 25), Patrick J. Buchanan states that a recent International Monetary Fund report suggests that the Mexican crisis was "overblown" and that "the world financial system was never in danger." The I.M.F.'s latest International Capital Markets report concludes just the opposite. 
 The report observes that there were significant contagion effects in the Western Hemisphere immediately after the Mexican crisis, and later in Asia in mid-January 1995. It concludes that the international financial package assembled at the end of January was essential both to limit the recessionary effects of the crisis on Mexico and to prevent the spread of the crisis to the rest of Latin America and other developing countries.
 
SHAILENDRA J. ANJARIA
Director, External Relations Dept.
International Monetary Fund
Washington, Aug. 25, 1995

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

G.M. and Chrysler Have Best Month of Year
General Motors and Chrysler said their sales surged in August to the highest levels this year, leading to shortages of new vehicles at dealerships.
 G.M. said sales of cars and light trucks rose 7.1 percent in August, to 446,394, led by a strong month in its Chevrolet division and higher sales to fleets. Chrysler said total vehicle sales rose 4 percent, to 170,557, for the company's third consecutive monthly increase. [Page 37.]
 
Profit Outlook Lifts Stocks
Stocks rose on optimism that the economy was growing enough to keep profits healthy through the end of the year, and gains in auto shares overshadowed a slump in technology issues. The Dow industrials surged 36.98 points to 4,647.54, the biggest one-day advance and highest close since Aug. 14. The S.& P. 500 index rose 1.96, to 563.84. For the week, the Dow rose 46.14 points. [37.]
 
The dollar drifted lower against the German mark in languid trading after economic data failed to give a clear reading on the health of the United States economy. The dollar slipped to 1.4622 marks and edged up to 97.47 yen. [32.]
 
The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond fell to 6.61 percent, from 6.64 percent. Traders said investors bought after a weak manufacturing report suggested slow growth and a chance of further interest rate cuts.[36.]
 
Wireless Contract Awarded
A telephone consortium that includes Nynex and Bell Atlantic has awarded a $1 billion contract to AT&T and Motorola to supply the group with hardware and software for a wireless communications system, including base stations and switching equipment. [36.]
 
Rockefeller Center Dispute
Rockefeller Center Properties, the real estate investment trust that holds the $1.3 billion mortgage on Rockefeller Center, filed documents in bankruptcy court indicating that it would oppose a bid by Tishman Speyer Properties to buy the center. [35.]
 
Former B.C.C.I. Official Sought
The Manhattan District Attorney's office has requested that Britain extradite Syed Ziauddin Ali Akbar, the former treasurer of B.C.C.I. Mr. Akbar, who was due to be released from a British prison yesterday, is suspected of extorting $15 million from the bank in August 1988. [36.]
 
Thieves Take Old Newspapers
As the price of newsprint skyrocketed in the last year, discarded newspapers suddenly took on real value, and municipal recycling officials say they are plagued by scavengers who cruise curb-side recycling routes before city trucks do. A scavenger then sells the papers for as much as $400 for one night's haul to the same recycling processors that would otherwise have bought them from the city. The effect is to deprive local governments of large sums of money. [1.]
 
A Union Fight in Detroit
Detroit is convulsed by a seven-week-old strike at the city's two newspapers, The Detroit News and The Detroit Free Press, by six unions. While members of other striking unions are generally standing firm, reporters, photographers and copy editors are crossing picket lines to return to work. Already, 124 Newspaper Guild members, or 45 percent of the 276 members at The Free Press, were said to have gone back to work. [5.]
 
Cotton Prices Up Again
Cotton prices advanced for a second consecutive session as traders grew concerned that deteriorating world and American crop conditions could lead to shortages. On the New York Cotton Exchange, cotton for December delivery, the active month, rose 1.9 cents, to 85.67 cents a pound. [32.]

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Off Against the Mark On Mixed U.S. Economic Data

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar drifted lower against the German mark in languid trading yesterday after economic data failed to give a clear reading on the health of the United States economy.
 Some additional light selling of the dollar came from traders who were adjusting their positions ahead of the Labor Day holiday on Monday. 
 In late trading in New York yesterday, the dollar slipped to 1.4622 marks from 1.4672 marks on Thursday. The dollar edged up to 97.43 Japanese yen from 97.38 yen.
 In early trading in New York, the dollar shot up to a high of 1.4725 marks after the Labor Department reported a rise in nonfarm payrolls that was much larger than expected. The report that the number of nonfarm jobs grew by 249,000 in August after a meager gain of 6,000 in July was initially viewed as bullish for the dollar. The report indicated that the economy was picking up steam, and that the Federal Reserve would be unlikely to lower interest rates soon to stimulate growth.
 Lower rates generally bode ill for the dollar as they tend to diminish the attractiveness of dollar-based interest-paying securities.
 But traders quickly turned around and sold dollars after analysts took a closer look at the report and realized that it might not have shown quite as much economic strength as the payroll number implied.
 "The market was really quite disappointed," said Amy Smith, currency strategist at the consulting firm IDEA. "It was really a mixed bag."
 Traders said the dollar was also hurt by a strengthening in the mark and Swiss franc.
 The mark was particularly strong against the French franc, rising on speculation about further splits within the French Cabinet after last week's resignation of Finance Minister Alain Madelin, traders said.
 Traders also sold dollars for Swiss francs as concern about tensions in Bosnia fueled demand for Swiss currency.
 "Switzerland is a historically neutral country," said Kevin Harris, international economist at MCM Currency Watch. "If you want a place to go when other parts of Europe are in trouble, you go to the Swiss."
 The dollar fell to 1.1967 Swiss francs yesterday from 1.2032 francs on Thursday.
 Traders noted that the dollar's moves yesterday were exaggerated as trading was extremely light ahead of the holiday weekend.
 Some traders said the dollar might head up to 100 yen and 1.50 marks in the near future but it might still run into problems on its climb.

HEADLINE: 3 SIDES IN BALKANS AGREE TO MEETING TO DISCUSS PEACE

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN 

DATELINE: ZAGREB, Croatia, Sept. 1

 BODY:
In what will be the first direct meeting of all three parties to the Balkan war in two years, the foreign ministers of Bosnia, Croatia and the Serb-dominated Yugoslav federation have agreed to meet in Geneva late next week to discuss a peace settlement.
The announcement of the meeting, made by the United States, came as NATO today suspended its air attacks on the Bosnian Serbs after a series of early-morning raids. The suspension, on the third consecutive day of the NATO onslaught, was ordered pending the result of talks between the commander of the United Nations forces in the former Yugoslavia and the Bosnian Serb commander. 
 Late today, it appeared that these talks, specifically related to the Serbian siege of Sarajevo, had been unsuccessful and that the air strikes were therefore likely to resume on Saturday, United Nations officials said.
The United States brokered the agreement to hold a meeting of the three parties to the war. Even the agreement amounted to a breakthrough in that it has long been impossible to get the parties into the same room. But deeply divisive issues of territory, governance and justice that defeated previous attempts to reach peace remain.
Never before, however, has the United States been as energetically involved in the quest for a settlement, the warring sides so exhausted, or the ethnic purification that has characterized the dismemberment of Yugoslavia into separate nations so advanced.
"The purpose of the meeting will be to develop basic principles for a settlement as a foundation for intensive negotiations aimed at achieving a peace agreement," Nicholas Burns, the State Department spokesman, said in Washington. He added that the talks were in the best interests of the parties and that the United States would do "everything in its power" to assist them.
In Belgrade, the Serbian capital, Assistant Secretary of State Richard C. Holbrooke, whose shuttle diplomacy this week led to the accord on a meeting, said, "The toughest issue is land -- that is what the war was about."
 The Serbs, who hold close to 70 percent of Bosnia and an eastern sliver of Croatia after four years of fighting, will be asked to surrender some of that land -- a demand that will meet stiff resistance.
The war has been largely about the Serbian contention, often backed by the ruthless killing and eviction of non-Serb civilians, that the internal borders of Tito's Yugoslavia could not be turned into international borders because that would maroon many Serbs in the newly independent countries of Croatia and Bosnia.
Lieut. Gen. Bernard Janvier of France, the United Nations commander, today met Gen. Ratko Mladic, the Bosnian Serb commander, in the town of Mali Zvornik on the Yugoslav border with Bosnia to discuss NATO's demand that all Serbian guns be removed beyond 20 kilometers -- 12.5 miles -- of Sarajevo.
The meeting began badly, United Nations officials said, with a tirade from General Mladic against the NATO attacks and a demand that all NATO planes leave Bosnian skies before the discussions begin.
The tone later became more cordial, but in the end General Mladic refused to accept all the demands set by General Janvier for a permanent stop to the bombing. It was not clear which Western demands had proved unacceptable to the Serbs.
These demands are being interpreted with different nuances in different Western capitals .
In effect, the officials said, General Janvier is demanding an opening of Sarajevo airport and the opening of roads into the besieged city as well as the withdrawal of Serbian guns.
Under the terms of an agreement reached in July between the United Nations peacekeeping force and NATO, both General Janvier and Adm. Leighton W. Smith, the American commander of NATO's southern headquarters in Naples, have to agree to call off the air strikes.
Thus both France and the United States are directly involved in the decision on whether to turn today's "pause" in the air strikes into a permanent halt.
"The operation is ongoing," said Chris Gunness, a United Nations spokesman. "We'll wait to see the outcome of the talks, review the situation and look at Serb compliance with our demands."
Other Western officials said General Janvier had proposed to General Mladic that the Serbs be given four days to remove their heavy guns from the Sarajevo area. The removal would take place under NATO's air surveillance and United Nations observation on the ground.
The guns were supposed to be removed or handed over to the United Nations in February 1994, after a mortar attack on the Sarajevo market that killed 68 people led to a NATO ultimatum. But the demand was hedged at the last minute to avoid NATO air strikes.
In the end, it has taken a second attack on the Sarajevo market, in which 37 people were killed on Monday, and the slow resolution over the last 18 months of differences between the United Nations and NATO, to bring about a renewed and apparently firm request that the artillery be removed.
There are an estimated 300 artillery pieces ringing Sarajevo, of which perhaps 10 percent have been hit in the NATO bombardment, United Nations officials said today. These guns have killed more than 10,000 people, mainly civilians, in the Bosnian capital over the last three and a half years.
The seeming failure of today's meeting between General Janvier and General Mladic posed a delicate problem for Western governments. Several more days of bombing might in the end lead to a reaction from what has been a largely passive Bosnian Serb army. But any decision to call off the NATO assault before it is clear that Sarajevo has really been relieved after 40 months of siege will irk the Muslim-led Bosnian Government.
British and French artillery belonging to the Rapid Reaction Force on Mount Igman near Sarajevo continued today to pound Bosnian Serb positions, particularly the Serbs' main barracks at Lukavica southwest of the Bosnian capital.
Even as the military situation around Sarajevo remained unresolved, the Bosnian Government and the Bosnian Serbs began posturing ahead of the peace talks. Haris Silajdzic, the Bosnian Prime Minister, ruled out a confederation between the Bosnian Serbs and Serbia -- an arrangement now offered by the United States.
"A confederation with Serbia, with the aggressor, with people who committed genocide, will not happen," he said during a visit to Germany.
In Pale, the headquarters of the Bosnian Serbs near Sarajevo, Radovan Karadzic, their leader, listed a number of towns he would never give up and insisted that the territory ultimately controlled by the Serbs be economically viable as an independent entity.
The American plan offers 51 percent of Bosnia to a Muslim-Croat federation and 49 percent to the Serbs, thus obliging the Serbs to give up about a third of what they hold.
"The biggest single problem at the moment is Sarajevo," Mr. Holbrooke said in Belgrade. The Serbs want part of the capital, but the Bosnian Government insists it remain a single, multi-ethnic city.
All these problems were on the table more than two years ago when the parties met repeatedly to discuss a peace plan prepared by Lord Owen of Britain and Cyrus R. Vance of the United States. They have not gone away; indeed they have festered.
But the war has also taken a terrible toll, the military balance is now more even, and many politicians in the Balkans seem to see the American decision to take center stage in the Yugoslav crisis for the first time since it began as crucially important and potentially decisive.

Monitors Reported Safe
 MADRID, Sept. 1 (AP) -- The five European Union monitors reported killed in Bosnia shortly after NATO bombings began this week are alive and well but still in territory held by the Bosnian Serbs, a Spanish Government spokesman said today.
On Thursday, the official Bosnian Serb press agency, S.R.N.A., quoted a Serbian official as saying all five monitors were out of danger and had left Serbian-held land.
Spain has not yet spoken with the three Spaniards in the group, but a spokesman, Alfredo Perez Rubalcaba, said the Government had "sufficient information from reliable sources to allow us to say that our fellow citizens are safe and sound."
The five monitors were reported to be in the eastern town of Visegrad.

HEADLINE: Liberian Foes Sit Together To Govern

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH 

DATELINE: MONROVIA, Liberia, Sept. 1

 BODY:
Liberia's three principal militia leaders were formally seated today on a new six-member Council of State whose mandate is to govern the country and lead it to democratic elections next year.
The seating took place in a ceremony in downtown Monrovia, the capital, where huge crowds converged in the steaming streets, listening to the proceedings over the radio or trying to catch a glimpse of the men who ripped their country asunder during six years of civil war but have now pledged to work together in governing it. 
 The ceremony represented a major victory for a regional diplomatic and military effort led by Nigeria and Ghana, which persisted even after the United Nations, the United States and many other would-be brokers seemingly threw up their hands in frustration over what only recently appeared to be a hopeless conflict.
President Jerry J. Rawlings of Ghana, speaking as chairman of the Economic Community of West African States, borrowed John F. Kennedy's famous exhortation "Ask not what your country can do for you, but what you can do for your country" and called on Liberians to set aside their quarrels and rebuild their shattered country.
Like other speakers, Mr. Rawlings called upon the international community to provide Liberia with urgently needed aid to disarm thousands of fighters and restore the economy. But he warned the new leaders that their only hope of seeing this happen was to "keep the faith with the democratic program."
Of the many speakers, it was Wilton S. Sankowolo, the council's new chairman and one of its three civilian members, who best succeeded in tapping into the emotions of the crowd that pressed into the vermilion hall decorated with red-white-and-blue bunting, a reminder of the American origins of this country as a colony established by freed slaves in the early 19th century.
Dressed in a flowing white gown, Mr. Sankowolo, a former university professor and newspaper columnist, briefly turned the ceremony into the likes of a Baptist prayer meeting as he mentioned the suffering that he, like most Liberians, had experienced during the war.
"I know what it means to dodge bullets and rockets," he said. "I know what it means to be incarcerated or killed for belonging to this or that ethnic group, or making the bad mistake of working for the Government. I know what it means to live in the bushes, in refugee camps and displaced centers, going without food for days. I know what it means to walk up and down the streets of Monrovia in torn clothes and shoes."
At this point, the audience, which had been locked in the call-and-response cadence of his speech, answering each line with an "Amen" or a "Yes sir," broke out in tearful cheers.
"I wouldn't say that this caught the international community by surprise, but we are greatly encouraged," said Dane Smith, President Clinton's special envoy to Liberia, which has long had special political and economic ties with the United States.
Liberians were nearly unanimous in applauding the installation of the new Government, which marked the end of a civil war that has killed more than 150,000 people, or about 6 percent of the population. But many remain wary about having militia leaders take over the reins of the state.
Liberia's history encourages such skepticism. The country's civil war was started in 1989 by Charles G. Taylor, one of the newly seated members of the governing council, with an avowed goal of ending the dictatorship of Samuel K. Doe.
As a Nigerian-led West African peacekeeping force intervened to halt Mr. Taylor's assault on Monrovia, his Libyan-backed army, the National Patriotic Front of Liberia, splintered into a growing number of rival, ethnically based militias.
If most revolutions are said to devour their children, many here have noted that Mr. Doe's seizure of power in 1980 seems to have regurgitated his. He led a coup by young noncommissioned officers from a political elite historically drawn from the descendants of American slaves.
Like Mr. Taylor, who served as head of a government procurement agency, the other principal militia leaders and members of the new council, Alhaji Kromah and George E. Boley, were in Mr. Doe's Government. Mr. Sankowolo, the new council chairman, was once Mr. Doe's chief of Cabinet.
On the streets of Monrovia today, however, the mood was clearly one of rejoicing rather than introspection and analysis.
Joining Mr. Taylor on his trip to Monrovia from his longtime base in Gbarnga were scores of his security personnel and fighters who, like Mr. Taylor, had not set foot in the capital since the war began.
"It has been five years since I have been to Monrovia and, man, I am happy," said Col. Emil Taylor, a National Patriotic Front fighter. (He is not related to Charles Taylor.) "I once made it most of the way to town, but I ran into some people I knew who said that members of the Ulimo militia were all around, and since they knew me, they would kill me.
"Well this morning I saw one of my old Ulimo enemies, and he ran over to me and said, 'My man, I'm going to cut off your foot.' But then we just started laughing, and we had a beer together."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Three militia leaders -- Charles G. Taylor, left, Alhaji Kromah and Georges E. Boley -- were sworn in yesterday as members of a council that is to rule until elections next year. A peace pact was signed on Aug. 19. (Agence France-Presse); Supporters of Charles G. Taylor celebrated yesterday as he formally joined Liberia's new Government. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Bond Prices Rise Despite Mixed Data

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices ended with solid gains yesterday in trading that was buffeted by data that gave a mixed reading of the economy.
Traders said there was a good amount of buying during the abbreviated trading session as investors, first driven to selling on a strong payroll report for August, came back to buy after a weak manufacturing report suggested slow growth and a chance of further interest rate cuts. 
 Bond futures trading, which influences the cash market, staged a strong short-covering rally by investors who had bet that prices would fall but but were forced to buy securities to limit their losses as the market firmed after early weakness. The price on the December bond futures contract shot up as high as 11318/32 , after trading as low as 11125/32 . In the cash market, the price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 15/32 , to 10315/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, fell to 6.61 percent, from 6.64 percent on Thursday. The market closed early yesterday, at 2 P.M., because of the Labor Day holiday weekend.
 Bond prices fell in early trading after the Labor Department released its employment data for August. The agency reported that payrolls rose by 249,000, far higher than market expectations. The unemployment rate, meanwhile, slipped to 5.6 percent, from 5.7 percent in July.
 But the apparent strength in the job market did not bother analysts and traders for long.
 Nancy Kimelman, chief economist for Technical Data in Boston, said: "Payroll numbers were stronger than economists expected, but the gain in August was partly the result of more and more schools opening earlier in the year.
 "And while the employment rate fell, it did so because the labor force shrank. The key areas of the economy where we wanted to see growth, growth was absent. There are signs that consumers are not spending."
 Treasury prices later rose, following a report from the National Association of Purchasing Management that was weaker than expected. The association said its index of business activity for August fell to 46.9 percent from 50.5 percent.
 The report indicated a reversal in August of the sharp increase that had been posted in July, noted Elliott Platt, director of research at the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation. He said the orders component of the purchasing managers' index was viewed with suspicion, given the weakness in the manufacturers' orders data.
 "That suspicion proved to be appropriate, as the orders component -- which is the largest component of the N.A.P.M. index -- experienced an extraordinarily sharp drop," Mr. Platt said, adding that the other components had declined, but to a lesser degree.
 Donald J. Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Securities, noted the complications in weighing the sum of the day's data.
 "Payroll headline numbers appeared to be strong, but after analyzing the data it was clear that payroll growth wasn't quite as buoyant as the headline number suggested," Mr. Fine said. "At the same time, however, there was no way one could categorize payroll growth as weak. But that was certainly not true when it came to the purchasing manager survey, which indicated clear-cut weakness in the industrial sector across the board."
 "After all is said and done," he added, "the mixed nature of all these numbers taken in concert indicates to me that while the economy is improving in the second half the improvement can only be described as moderate."
 Other data yesterday showed July construction spending up a strong 2 percent, to its highest level in two years.
 The University of Michigan's consumer sentiment index in August showed a rise to 96.2, on a final basis, from 94.4 in July, people who had seen the report said. The index is provided only to subscribers. The index confirmed previous gauges showing consumer sentiment at a healthy level consistent with economic growth, analysts said.

HEADLINE: Clinton Hails Veterans of War in Pacific

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: HONOLULU, Sept. 1

 BODY:
From an airfield that was bombed in the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor, President Clinton today paid tribute to the Americans who fought and died half a century ago in the war in the Pacific with "acts of heroism that will never be surpassed."
Beginning a weekend of ceremonies commemorating the 50th anniversary of the end of World War II, the President stood in a Humvee at Wheeler Field here and reviewed the troops -- 7,000 members of the armed forces, standing at attention under a hazy blue sky. 
 But in a reminder that even now another war rages in Europe, Mr. Clinton's first words were of the conflict in the former Yugoslavia and the announcement that representatives of Bosnia, Croatia and Serbia -- after two days of NATO bombing of Bosnian Serb targets -- have agreed to new peace negotiations in Geneva next week.
"This is a positive step forward, but much remains to be done," the President said. "No one should doubt NATO's resolve to prevent the further slaughter of innocent civilians in Sarajevo, in the other safe areas in Bosnia."
Then, as the wind tousled his hair sent the flags of a military color guard crackling, Mr. Clinton remembered the veterans of World War II who served in the Pacific.
"The World War II generation truly saved the world," said the 49-year-old President, the first of the postwar generation to reach the White House. "Our security, our prosperity, our standing among other nations, all these are the legacies of the men and women, the heroes before us whom we honor today."
Thousands of spectators looked on from bleachers and folding chairs set up on the dusty parade grounds, and many of them were survivors of the grueling air, sea and jungle battles of the Pacific -- the conflict that the historian John Dower called the "war without mercy."
At Mr. Clinton's urging, the veterans, now in their 70's and 80's, stood up, white-haired and wizened, some on canes. And the President singled out Robert Bush, who doffed his white cap and saluted. As an 18-year-old Navy corpsman on Okinawa, where the last and deadliest battle of the war took place, Mr. Bush braved a barrage of artillery and mortar fire to give plasma to a wounded officer. For his heroism, which left him blind in one eye, Mr. Bush won the Medal of Honor.
Mr. Clinton's appearance began a weekend of pageantry, parades and commemorations in Honolulu and across the nation marking the 50th anniversary of the day President Harry S. Truman called V-J Day, for victory over Japan.
On that day, Sept. 2, 1945 -- just weeks after the United States ushered in the nuclear age by dropping atomic bombs on Hiroshima and Nagasaki -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur formally accepted the Japanese surrender aboard the battleship Missouri in Tokyo Bay, bringing an end to World War II and marking the final defeat of the Axis powers.
Pointing to the United States' emergence from the war as a prosperous superpower, Mr. Clinton planned to use the weekend to call on Americans to pull together like the World War II generation to face the new challenges fostered by economic and technological change.
"Now it is for us to be true to your legacy of courage and devotion," the President said today, "to follow your lead in finding strength in America's diversity and unity in America's purpose."
On Saturday, Mr. Clinton is to speak at a commemorative service at the National Cemetery of the Pacific, honor the Navy aboard the aircraft carrier Carl Vinson and observe a moment of silence at the Arizona Memorial for the sailors and marines killed on that battleship in the attack on Pearl Harbor. And on Sunday he is to attend a commemorative service, sharing a stage with the Apollo 13 astronaut James Lovell, prominent World War II veterans and an Iowa elementary school teacher whose grandfather was one of five brothers who died in the Battle of Guadalcanal in 1942.
On Dec. 7, 1941 -- "a day which will live in infamy," President Franklin D. Roosevelt declared at a joint session of Congress the next day -- Japan propelled the United States into World War II with a surprise attack on Pearl Harbor, the major American naval base in the Pacific. The attack sunk or disabled 19 warships, including 6 battleships, destroyed about 150 aircraft and killed 2,403 soldiers, sailors and civilians.
The fighting ended on Aug. 14, 1945, when Japan accepted the Allies' demands of unconditional surrender, and the Japanese formally surrendered aboard the Missouri on Sept. 2.
In the 44 months between the United States' entrance into the war and Japan's surrender, the American armed forces drove Japan back from virtual control of the Pacific by winning hard-fought battles in jungles and swamps, in the air and on and under the sea. No battles were ever waged over greater distances and with longer supply lines than those in the Pacific. And the names of the battles still resonate in history: Bataan, Corregidor, Midway, Guadalcanal, Tarawa, Coral Sea, Leyte, Iwo Jima, Okinawa.
"Never before had the fight for freedom stretched across such a vast expanse of land and sea," Mr. Clinton said today. "And never before had the energies of the American people been so fully required or so fully joined."
He did not mention the use of atomic weapons, but he expressed appreciation for the apology extended last month by the Japanese Prime Minister, Tomiichi Murayama, for Japan's aggression. Mr. Clinton said Americans appreciate "the recent powerful words." Japan was one of many nations to send delegations to the weekend ceremonies, and Japanese and American veterans of the war plan to dedicate a friendship plaque on Monday.
Fifty years ago, Mr. Clinton said, a Navy radio man aboard a ship in Tokyo Bay sent a letter to his son in Texas telling him not to see war as a great adventure. The President quoted the sailor as telling his son, "Take it from me, it's the most horrible thing ever done by man."
"Veterans of the Pacific, " Mr. Clinton added, "because you were willing to undergo the most horrible thing ever done by man, freedom is the order of the day in most of the world 50 years later."

GRAPHIC: Photo: At Wheeler Field in Hawaii yesterday, President Clinton watched aircraft flying overhead in ceremonies marking the end of World War II. With him was Frank Greenway, left, a veteran; Brig. Gen. John Maher, second from right, the base commander, and Col. Lewis Millett, a retired Army officer. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: ABOUT NEW YORK;
Finding That Hard Work Doesn't Always Result in a Good Job

BYLINE: By David Gonzalez 

 BODY:
RICARDO FLORES spent a year mucking through piles of crumpled paper and broken glass, hoping to find a job at the bottom of it all.
 It's dirty work, but it beats going to the group home, which was the other option the 17-year-old high school dropout's father offered him. He chose a year of community service, cleaning up parks along with 15 other youths who graduated last night from Save a Generation, a Bronx-based program that blended boot-camp discipline, academics and counseling. They're proud to show society that even hard-rock kids raised on tough luck can do the right thing, go back to school and get back on track. 
 Now they're ready for a real job. The kind with benefits and vacations.
 But their pride is tempered by frustration, that despite keeping their end of the bargain, it's hard to find a job that doesn't require them to say, "Do fries go with that shake?"
 In the name of efficiency, Wall Street applauds a bank merger that may leave 12,000 people unemployed. And while teen-age joblessness has decreased in the first half of the year for the city, statewide adult unemployment jumped to 7.1 percent this month, its highest level in more than a year.
 Ricardo knows that it takes more to land a job than strong arms. He thinks that maybe he'll have to go to college, even though he'd rather have a construction job.
 "I'll take anything up," he said. "Contractor, lawyer or G-Y-N. Anything. No small stuff."

THE Rev. John Flynn was thinking big when he started Save a Generation a few years back, having decided that he had said the last rites too many times for people who weren't even old enough to be married. Walking through the streets of Crotona, he chatted with drug sellers and buyers and decided one thing would get them off the corner: Jobs.
 Silver-haired dreamer that he is, Father Flynn put together a program from existing opportunities, recruiting unemployed high school dropouts, mostly from the Bronx. For several months, youths attended a National Guard training program in Peekskill, breaking from the street culture and learning discipline. Back home, they would take jobs as Americorps volunteers, working 35 hours a week in the parks while earning a small salary and the promise of a $5,000 grant for college. Private donations increased their pay to $7 an hour, while 12 hours a week in classes and counseling improved their skills and confidence.
 But most of the youths who finished the rigorous program -- 10 dropped out -- have yet to land the jobs they had been working toward.
 Qiana Bing spent time walking down Fordham Road filling out job applications, but two months later she has yet to hear back.
 "It's not right," she said, taking a break from her park job. "This is harder than working in a store."
 Glenda Martinez decided to join the Air Force, partly because she could not afford to work and go to school at the same time.
 "The service gave me the best offer," she said.
 Jonathan Dwyer, Save a Generation's director, said there aren't enough jobs available, and that people may be reluctant to take a chance on youths who want to start over, despite some missteps in their pasts.
 "It's hard to find the entry-level jobs out there," Mr. Dwyer said. "With the mergers happening all over the place, these are economic times that seem to be benefiting the very few at the top and not worried about employing the many."

PERHAPS his training program could revise the lessons in skills training and add a course on the black arts of mergers. He is irked by the Rube Goldberg nature of the market: number crunchers push some computer buttons and rearrange spreadsheets that result in a deal that leaves some hapless family man walking down Flatbush Avenue scratching his head and wondering where his job went.
 "Jobs are not on the national agenda," Mr. Dwyer said. "It's not on the city agenda."
 But it is definitely on Russell Enmanuel's agenda, the sleek black one he carried at his side on appointments to learn about office work. A trip to an exchange floor was canceled when the other graduates failed to show. An earlier visit to a law office raised his hopes, but led to nothing.
 "They weren't offering any jobs," he said. "They said if they saw some openings they would look at our resumes. It felt like I didn't belong there. I wanted to belong."
 He is well dressed and eager. He knows computers. At 20, he knows he never wants to go back to flipping burgers for a living.
 The lunch crowd swept by him as he stood on the sunny corner of Liberty and Church Streets. He looked at them, loose ties and easy attitudes.
 "When am I going to have a chance to get a good job like this?" he said. "I'm told if you keep trying for the good ones, you find it sooner or later."
 He looked over to a Burger King restaurant on the corner.
 "That's not me. No more."
 He knows where he belongs.
