HEADLINE: Reports Show Weakness In Economy

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1

 BODY:
Despite a hefty expansion of August payrolls, the economic rebound has yet to gain momentum and the economy appears increasingly likely to need another round of interest rate cuts this fall, an array of Government and other data indicated today.
 The Labor Department's report on employment, wages and hours -- the first broad-based gauge of the economy's performance for the month -- showed that employers added 249,000 jobs, with a modest rise in factory workers ending a streak of four straight declines. 
 The unemployment rate, in the meantime, was essentially unchanged at 5.6 percent. A separate department survey found that both jobholders and the work force contracted.
 In addition, the Government index intended to predict the economy declined in July for the fifth time in six months, and corporate purchasing agents reported that factory activity dropped in August.
 Taken together, "these numbers come down pretty squarely on the side of ongoing sluggishness," said Kenneth T. Mayland, chief economist of Keycorp, a big Cleveland-based banking company. He said it was now a "virtual cinch" that the Federal Reserve would cut short-term interest rates at its policy meeting on Sept. 26. Others, however, said the Fed might defer action until November.
 After a yearlong series of increases, the central bank reversed direction in early July and made an initial cut after its drive to slow too-rapid growth late last year had taken hold firmly.
 The Clinton Administration responded cautiously to the employment report, which included declines in both the length of the workweek and in aggregate production.
 Based on what is known so far, the economy's growth will probably be "moderate" for the quarter that ends on Sept. 30, Joseph E. Stiglitz, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, said in a statement. This presumably means a pace faster than the spring quarter's 1.1 percent growth rate but short of the 2.5 to 3 percent pace beyond which most economists believe inflation would accelerate.
 The employment report seemed unusually challenging to its Wall Street interpreters. Initially, traders leaped to the conclusion that the expansion in payrolls of 249,000 jobs, which was surprisingly large, would inhibit further easing of monetary policy.
 But these fears waned as analysts digested the details of the report, which those at Merrill Lynch called "muddled, superficially stronger than expected but, on deeper analysis, fairly weak."
 A big factor in the swelling payrolls, which have risen an average of only 100,000 a month since March, was a 76,000 expansion for state and local governments. The department estimated that 40,000 of this rise reflected a growing trend for schools to reopen in August rather than in September, a phenomenon with which its process for seasonal adjustment has not kept pace.
 A downward revision cut July's job growth to 6,000, from the 55,000 initially reported, but this was exactly offset by an upward revision for June that transformed the gain for that month to 299,000 from 250,000.
 Some sectors did show improvement in August. Factories added 12,000 jobs after shedding 88,000 in July; the temporary help business rebounded by 44,000; there were sizable gains in health and social services, and employment in finance, insurance and real estate climbed 15,000, the biggest gain in more than a year.
 Jobs in the retail trade, however, were little changed, and construction was flat, the report also showed.
 Average hourly earnings, which had unnerved some analysts by surging 6 cents in both June and July, eased 2 cents last month, to $11.47. Average weekly earnings rose $2.98, to $394.57.
 The tally of households, on which the unemployment rate is based, showed 180,000 fewer jobs, but since the labor force shrank even more, by 307,000, the jobless rate edged down a tenth of a point, which the department considers statistically insignificant. The rate for Hispanic workers rose 1.1 points, to 9.9 percent.
 Geographically, the jobless rate edged up a tenth of a point in the Northeast, to 6.2 percent, and a tenth of a point in the West, to 6.9 percent. The rate eased by two-tenths of a point in the Midwest, to 4.5 percent, and by a tenth of a point in the South, to 5.5 percent.
 The decline in the Commerce Department's index of leading indicators amounted to two-tenths of 1 percent in July, erasing a June rise, which had been the only increase so far this year.
 "Both the leading indicators and the unemployment rate confirm that the slowdown is not over yet," said Gordon Richards, chief economist of the National Association of Manufacturers.
 Another sign of decline came from the National Association of Purchasing Management, which said its manufacturing index fell for the third time in four months, to 46.9 in August from 50.5 in July. A reading below 50 indicates that the manufacturing economy is generally declining.
 But in a bright spot among the reports released today, the Commerce Department said construction spending rose in July by 2 percent -- the strongest gain in two years -- with increases across the board for both private and Government projects.

HEADLINE: Video Keno Is In Doubt As a Judge Backs Trump

BYLINE: By GEORGE JAMES 

 BODY:
Lawyers for Donald Trump and New York State battled back and forth in court yesterday over the state's plans to introduce a keno-style lottery next week, leaving the game's future in question.
 Mr. Trump, who owns three casinos in Atlantic City, is fighting to stop the game, and a state supreme court justice in Manhattan issued a temporary restraining order yesterday preventing the state from introducing it on Wednesday as planned. The game, called Quick Draw, is to be played in bars, restaurants and other locations. 
 But the fight is far from over. The state quickly filed a notice of appeal yesterday, which automatically stayed the judge's order. In turn, Michael Armstrong, a lawyer for Mr. Trump, said he would ask an appellate court on Tuesday to once again block the state from starting up Quick Draw.
 Mr. Trump contends Quick Draw is a form of casino gambling, similar to playing slot machines, and would require an amendment to the State Constitution. A measure authorizing the Quick Draw game was passed by the Legislature in June as a way of balancing the budget, and proponents say it will raise at least $82 million a year.
 To play the game, some 2,000 computer terminals are to be set up in bars, restaurants, bowling alleys and Off Track Betting parlors. Players will select 10 numbers on a card and bet on each card. Every five minutes, a central New York State Lottery computer will pick 20 numbers that will be flashed on video monitors in the Quick Draw locations.
 Acting Supreme Court Justice Louis B. York said yesterday that he needed time to consider the issues "in an unrushed fashion," and asked Assistant State Attorney General Kevin Lamberson if the state would consider delaying Quick Draw.
 Mr. Lamberson said that a delay would cause "the loss of good will, the loss of revenue and serious damage to the image of the game."
 Nonetheless, the judge issued a temporary restraining order to prevent the state from starting the game until he could begin studying the case -- after the Labor Day weekend. "I'd gladly give up a normal weekend," he said. "But if I do that this weekend, my wife is likely to divorce me."
 Afterward, Mr. Trump, who said he was "gratified" by the decision, called Quick Draw "this crack video game" that would destroy the economic and social fabric by luring people to gamble.
 Mr. Trump dismissed the idea that he had filed the suit to protect his casino interests and block casino gambling in New York.

HEADLINE: G.M. and Chrysler Registered A Sales Surge During August

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Sept. 1

 BODY:
General Motors and Chrysler said today that their sales surged in August to the highest levels this year, leading to shortages for new vehicles at dealerships.
 Sales picked up from a slowdown in July, helped by lower interest rates and higher sales to government and rental agency fleets, analysts said. 
 "My guess is that what we're seeing is the beginning of a stronger second half," said David Bradley, an analyst with J. P. Morgan Securities.
 The General Motors Corporation said sales of cars and light trucks rose 7.1 percent in August, to 446,394 from 416,825, led by a strong month in its Chevrolet division and higher sales to fleets.
 The Chrysler Corporation said total vehicle sales rose 4 percent, to 170,557 from 163,858, for the company's third consecutive monthly increase.
 Shares of the two companies were higher today on the New York Stock Exchange. G.M. shares rose $1.375, to $48.50, and shares of Chrysler gained 87.5 cents, to $54.675. Shares of the Ford Motor Company, which will report sales next week, rose 50 cents, to $31.25.
 Several Japanese auto makers also reported United States sales today. The American Honda Motor Company said vehicle sales rose 3.1 percent, to 87,728. But Mazda Motor of America said sales plunged 29 percent, to 23,453, and Mitsubishi Motor Sales of America Inc. said sales slipped 5 percent, to 14,810. Toyota Motor Sales USA will report sales Tuesday.
 At G.M., Chevrolet sales rose to 214,132 from 194,225. Sales of Chevrolet Cavaliers rose 74 percent from last year. Lumina and Monte Carlo sales were up 60 percent.
 As many factories shifted to new-model production this summer, supply was a problem at dealerships like Trader Bud's Westside Dodge in Columbus, Ohio, where new-vehicle sales slipped by 25 units, to 175, in August.
"At the beginning of the month, we had no Caravans, we had no Neons and we had no Stratuses," said the dealer's sales manager, Vince Frustaci. "We're going to need more product."
 For Detroit's auto makers, the sales results were a bright spot in a year of unmet expectations. Assuming a 4.5 percent sales increase for Ford, the annual selling rate will reach 15.6 million, according to the Luckey Consulting Group.
 That far exceeds the annual sales rate of 13.7 million in July -- typically the slowest month of the year -- and 15.2 million in June. Sales matched December's 15.6 million rate. In March 1994, the rate reached 15.8 million.
 Late last year, the industry was projecting sales of 16 million cars and trucks this year, well above last year's 15.1 million. As the economy slowed, those forecasts were revised downward. Detroit's major auto makers are now unofficially predicting light-vehicle sales of about 15 million.
 The auto makers are hoping that the decline in interest rates since the Federal Reserve pushed down short-term rates by a quarter of a percentage point in July will help generate demand.
 At the same time, most auto makers continued to offer higher incentives, like cash rebates, to increase sales. Incentives represented an average of 14.8 percent of sticker price in August, compared with 14.5 percent in July and 6.8 percent in August 1994, according to CNW Marketing and Research, a consulting firm in Bandon, Ore.
 "Incentive programs brought a lot of people in," said Tim McCasland, a sales manager at Covert Buick in Austin, Tex. He said one popular program offered $1,500 cash back or 4.5 percent financing on Buick Riviera models.
 If Chrysler is a bellwether, consumers may not have as many bargains to choose from the rest of the year. The No. 3 auto maker, which led its competitors in raising incentives for most of the year, was the only one to lower discounts in August, said David Healy, an analyst at Burnham Securities.
 Chrysler's per-vehicle incentive costs dropped to $850 from the $1,035 average in the second quarter, as the company cleared dealers' lots of 1995 mini-vans.

HEADLINE: New York State's Jobless Rate Jumps to 7.1%

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
Employment levels in New York City, New York State and New Jersey were little changed in August, according to Federal data released yesterday. But the unemployment rate -- a measure of the number of people who have been unsuccessfully looking for jobs -- rose in New York State to more than 7 percent for the first time since April 1994.
 The monthly data showed that the unemployment rate rose in New York State to 7.1 percent in August from 6.2 percent in July, and fell in New Jersey to 6.6 percent in August from 6.8 percent in July. 
 Both states were among the four worst, in terms of unemployment, of the nation's 11 most populous. California, with August unemployment of 7.8 percent, was at the bottom, and Texas, with a rate of 6.7 percent, finished below New Jersey.
 Connecticut is not among the 11 states included in the monthly survey.
 Although the unemployment statistics provided little cause for cheer in the New York region, John L. Wieting, the New York regional commissioner for the Bureau of Labor Statisics, said they reflected volatile factors that did not provide a reliable long-term gauge of the region's economy.
 One such factor is the large number of teen-agers who left their summer jobs in August and began looking for other employment during the school year. Since the unemployment rate is based on a household survey, and counts only those who say they are employed or looking for work, the responses of young people can skew the August results.
 "We get a churning of the market in the summer months," Mr. Wieting said. Before a more reliable gauge of the job market can be determined, he added, "we need to see how the numbers settle out in the fall."
 In New York City, the August unemployment rate rose to 8.3 percent from 7.8 percent. But unlike the 11 states, for which the Government applies a seasonal adjustment to account partly for factors like the changes in the teen-aged work force, no seasonal adjustment is provided for New York City, making data for the city more volatile.
 August employment levels, regarded as a more accurate measure of economic performance, fell slightly in New York State and New Jersey from July levels.
 The number of employed people in New York fell by 56,000, to slightly more than 8 million. The number of those employed in New Jersey fell by 33,000, to slightly fewer than 3.8 million.
 The Federal report found that the slight employment decline in New York State occurred entirely outside New York City, where employment rose in August. It said the city gained 32,000 jobs, to slightly fewer than 3 million.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Cotton Prices Gain as Traders See Shortages in U.S. and China

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Cotton prices advanced for a second consecutive session yesterday as traders grew concerned that deteriorating world and American crop conditions could lead to shortages.
 China and the United States are the world's largest cotton producers and both crops are having problems. Insect blight and a lack of rain has lowered yields in Texas and the Mississippi Delta, while flooding has seriously reduced supply in Asia, agronomists say. 
 "All things considered, you can see why the market is so on edge," said Walter Spilka, an analyst with Smith Barney Inc.
 The Commodity Research Bureau's index of 21 commodities rose 1.25 points, to 241.22, the highest the index has been since October 1990.
 On the New York Cotton Exchange, cotton for December delivery, the active month, rose 1.9 cents, to 85.67 cents a pound
 An industry newsletter released yesterday predicted that the fall harvest in the United States would come in below the Agriculture Department's record estimate of 21.8 million bales largely because of continuing crop problems in the Mississippi Delta and Texas. Army beetworms, boll weevils, aphids and tobacco budworms have been especially bothersome this growing season, and crops in the Mississippi Delta and parts of the Southeast have gone weeks without appreciable rain.
 A different newsletter released earlier had indicated China's harvest might come in at 18.5 million 480-pound bales, a million lower than the latest Agriculture Department estimate. Disasters last year in Asia sent American cotton prices to highs not seen since the Civil War.
 Lumber prices tumbled on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange despite rising cash prices for the building material. Commission houses and local traders led the selling, which analysts attributed to profit taking after a strong week of gains.
 September lumber fell $5.20, to $282.50 for 1,000 board feet.
 Prices have rebounded in step with rising demand at lumber mills, prompted by increased construction and lower home-mortgage interest rates. But traders were leery of taking longer-term positions in light of losses suffered about this time last year, when prices began a steep decline that ended with the expiring September contract off $60 for 1,000 board feet.

HEADLINE: On a Weekend Roll, Rock Music Carves A Place in History

BYLINE: By JON PARELES 

DATELINE: CLEVELAND, Sept. 1

 BODY:
With pomp and feedback, the Rock-and-Roll Hall of Fame and Museum was inaugurated today. For this civic ceremony, Jimi Hendrix played the national anthem and Bob Dylan was quoted with reverence. As a big red ribbon was cut by an assembly that included Little Richard and Yoko Ono, speakers blared the Rolling Stones' "It's Only Rock-and-Roll (but I Like It"). In a celebratory parade, a high school band marched to the tune of "Respect" and an Elvis puppet 16 feet tall swiveled down the street.
It took more than a decade of fund raising and $92 million in public and private contributions, but rock-and-roll now has the grandest institution in its history. "You are changing the map of America," Ms. Ono proclaimed. "You are changing the map of the world." 
 The parade and ribbon-cutting were the beginning of a weekend-long party that will include an all-star concert at Cleveland Stadium on Saturday night, to be telecast on HBO at 7:30. The concert, which is expected to last four to six hours, is planned as a larger version of the annual Hall of Fame induction ceremonies, which bring rock's elders together with those who have learned from them. Bruce Springsteen is expected to sing along with Jerry Lee Lewis, Johnny Cash will join John Mellencamp and dozens of other performers will pay tribute to their influences and sing duets with their heirs.
Around the city, rock became a costume party. At one downtown hotel, the staff was dressed as pop stars, with Madonna working the registration desk and Little Richard parking cars.
The Rock-and-Roll Hall of Fame and Museum is a 150,000-square-foot building on the shore of Lake Erie, an assemblage of geometric shapes designed by I. M. Pei. It sets out to be both a tourist attraction and a scholarly resource. "Rock is an art form that has been with us now for over 40 years," said Dennis Barrie, the museum's director, as he inspected the exhibits on Thursday. "It has produced great musicians and great poets and has had an impact on everything from racial attitudes to clothing to drug use. It deserves to have its history and creators and perpetrators looked at."
In its planning stages, the museum faced skepticism not only from those who felt rock-and-roll was too frivolous for study, but from those who feared that institutionalizing rock would defuse its rebellious energy. "Museums should not have to be deadly," Mr. Barrie said. "We want to convey some of the energy and magic and attitudes of the art form. Having a museum doesn't rob the music of its future. It just preserves its past."
"Rock has always been trouble and has always been controversial," Mr. Barrie added. "This is not a sanitizing of rock-and-roll, and not a nostalgia trip without really looking at the issues."
The building includes a cylindrical theater and a rectangular one cantilevered over the lake; a tall box, and a wide-open entrance hall in the shape of a semi-pyramidal "glass tent," as Mr. Pei called it. Viewed from the lake side, it could be compared to a turntable with a jutting tone arm, though Mr. Pei preferred to describe the design as "forms in space."
The Hall of Fame itself is a hushed, darkened room at the top of a spiral staircase. Signatures of the 122 current members are etched into glass; monochrome video screens show the members' images and tidbits of information. But as Suzan Evans, the hall's executive director, explained, "The Hall of Fame is a permanent exhibit within the museum." The bulk of the museum is devoted to the complete history of rock, not just the accomplishments of the Hall of Famers, whose careers are required to date back at least 25 years.
The main exhibition area, about 75,000 square feet, is tucked into the embankment below street level, where visitors are greeted by a neon sign proclaiming "Roll Over Beethoven." Inside, film clips roll, video screens flicker and music plays everywhere through speakers and headphones. There are displays of flashy stage costumes and battered guitars, of handwritten lyrics by Jimi Hendrix and Bruce Springsteen and high school yearbooks for Roy Orbison and Queen Latifah. A piece of Otis Redding's private airplane, which crashed in 1967, is on display; under a spotlight, rotating in a clear cylinder, is Michael Jackson's first glittering glove.
The museum's upper stories hold additional and larger objects, including the original control-room equipment from Sun Studios in Memphis, a chunk of Pink Floyd's stage set from "The Wall" and, suspended overhead, four hand-painted Trabant cars from U2's "Zoo TV" tour. The museum also holds a radio studio, a cafe, a gift shop and cash machines shaped like juke boxes.
What makes the museum different from a display of memorabilia at a Hard Rock Cafe, organizers say, is that the museum puts the objects in context. "The exhibitions have a lot of content and information," said Ileen Sheppard Gallagher, director of exhibition and collections management. "We have a narrative about each exhibit or artist, or timelines to set the stage properly. If you want it, it's there, and if you don't want it, you can just look at the most visual, impactful things. We have the same mandates as other museums: to collect, preserve and educate. But we're doing them in the context of rock-and-roll."
For Ohioans, the Rock-and-Roll Hall of Fame is an investment in respect. Gov. George V. Voinovich calls it "an economic catalyst." In the past decade, Cleveland has rebuilt Gateway Stadium for sports, Playhouse Square for theater and Tower City as a retail complex. "The Rock-and-Roll Hall of Fame gives Cleveland and northeastern Ohio an international dimension," said Mr. Voinovich, who was Mayor of Cleveland during the hall's planning stages and a prime mover in its construction.
He said a market analysis had estimated between 600,000 and 900,000 visitors to the hall each year, including 225,000 out-of-towners, bringing the city between $74 million and $96 million annually.
Cleveland was chosen as the site of the Hall of Fame in 1986, when city and state politicians and business leaders made a strong pitch to the Rock-and-Roll Hall of Fame Foundation. The nonprofit foundation had been started by music-business leaders in New York in 1983. Ahmet Ertegun, the co-chairman of the foundation and the chairman of Atlantic Records, said that the idea arose when he was approached in 1982 to help with a pay-per-view awards program. But he wanted something more lasting than a television show. "I would only do it as a nonprofit thing, a really dignified foundation that would recognize the talents of the pioneers who created this music," he said.
Mr. Ertegun approached other music-business veterans, including Jann Wenner, editor and publisher of Rolling Stone magazine, and Seymour Stein, now president of Elektra Entertainment. Initially, Mr. Ertegun had envisioned buying a brownstone in New York to house a hall of fame and a music reference archive. In 1986, the foundation began to present annual ceremonies, naming about a dozen musicians and backstage figures to the hall. Other cities began approaching the foundation; Cleveland collected more than 600,000 signatures on petitions. On May 5, 1986, Cleveland was named as the site.
The foundation commissioned Mr. Pei to design the building, then budgeted at $26 million, and a site was chosen across from Tower City. But little money was raised until 1989, when Cleveland provided $20 million in tax-exempt bonds, $9 million in state funds and $13 million in corporate and private donations. The site was changed to a larger one in 1990, and the design was revised. In 1993, after the foundation raised about $8 million from the recording business, the State of Ohio guaranteed a $39 million loan, to be repaid through a surcharge on museum admissions and a hotel and motel tax. Groundbreaking took place in June 1993.
Both the foundation and the Cleveland sponsors had been primarily concerned with building the museum, not with what would go inside. Although it had collected some Janis Joplin and Jimi Hendrix memorabilia, major curatorial efforts did not begin until Mr. Barrie, who had presented a controversial exhibit of Robert Mapplethorpe photographs when he was director of the Cincinnati Arts Center, was named as director in September 1993. Two months later Jim Henke, a former editor at Rolling Stone, became chief curator.
Mr. Henke and his staff began calling on musicians, surviving relatives, collectors and institutions (including Graceland, the Victoria and Albert Museum and the Hard Rock Cafe) to glean artifacts. The museum's collections come exclusively from loans and donations. "I insisted on that policy," Mr. Wenner said. "I said, 'We can't afford to pay for anything, and if we start we're crazy.' Once we got involved in a game with Christie's and the collectors, it would never end."
The hall's more scholarly side is still in preparation. Its archive and research center will not open until next year. But in October it will hold a conference for elementary-school teachers. Robert Santelli, the hall's director of education, said he hoped to publish a journal, somewhere between academic pop-culture studies and the mainstream rock press.
Meanwhile, young music fans were bemused to see the older generation enshrining rock-and-roll's past. "Their parents didn't like the music they listened to, and now they've built a monument to it," said Elizabeth Hoskin, a 21-year-old college student watching the festivities. "Now our parents hate our music. Is that really going to change?"

The New York Times

SECTION: Section 7; Page 20; Column 1; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 978 words

HEADLINE: New & Noteworthy Paperbakcs

BYLINE: By LAUREL GRAEBER 

 BODY:

WHO WILL RUN THE FROG HOSPITAL?
By Lorrie Moore. Warner, $11.99.
 A woman coming to the end of her 30's and possibly the end of her marriage looks back on the bond she and her best friend shared when they were both 15. Her story is "a sad, witty, disillusioned fairy tale," Caryn James said here last year, and Ms. Moore's "richest work yet."
 

DAISY BATES IN THE DESERT
By Julia Blackburn. Vintage Departures, $12.
 She was difficult and determined, an almost compulsive liar and a wandering soul who finally found peace only in the bleakest regions of Australia. Daisy Bates, an Irish self-taught anthropologist who lived among the aborigines from 1913 to 1934, was not an easy person to capture, but Julia Blackburn has given her substance by searching for herself among the fragments of her subject's life. She "has given us both a fascinating exercise in biography and a rare, intimate glimpse into the biographer's imagination," Linda Simon wrote in the Book Review in 1994. Vintage Departures has also reissued the account of a woman's more recent journey into the heart of Australia. TRACKS, by Robyn Davidson ($12), chronicles the author's traversal of 1,700 miles of her native country's outback, which she made in 1977, in the company of four camels and a dog. In 1981 Sarah Ferrell, writing in The New York Times, called Ms. Davidson "a lively stylist" whose "analyses of her states of mind . . . are both convincing and engrossing." Australia is just as powerful a presence in the work of Rodney Hall, whose YANDILLI TRILOGY (Noonday/Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $16) takes place during the country's colonial era. "The Second Bridegroom," the first novel in the collection, is narrated by one of the slave laborers who tamed Australia's wilderness, a young British convict. In 1991 our reviewer, Judith Grossman, praised "the prodigal energy and ebullience of Mr. Hall's writing." In "The Grisly Wife" the storyteller is Catherine Byrne, an English missionary who came to Australia with her husband, an illiterate bootmaker and self-styled prophet. Hers is "a rich, wild" tale by "a thrillingly smart and juicy writer," Beverly Lowry said here in 1993. "Captivity Captive," based on a real turn-of-the-century murder case, features another tormented narrator, an octogenarian who was one of 10 abused children. His story is "harrowing and beautiful. . . . A book that makes demands on the reader's soul," Joyce Reiser Kornblatt said in the Book Review in 1988.
 
THE SHADOW OF THE PANTHER: Huey Newton and the Price of Black Power in America
By Hugh Pearson. Addison-Wesley, $14.
 In this study the bold leader of the Black Panther movement emerges as a brilliant strategist and a ruthless killer. The author analyzes the party's terrorist tactics and the role sympathetic whites played in its fame. Last year our reviewer, Bob Blauner, called the writing of the book "a courageous act," in which Mr. Pearson sometimes achieves "the excitement of a political thriller." In BLACK NATIONALISM: A Search for an Identity in America, by E. U. Essien-Udom (University of Chicago, $14.95), the Nation of Islam is portrayed as a movement that transcended purely political objectives by offering a sense of unity and purpose to poor blacks. Previously out of print, this 1962 book is "an excellent standard treatment of black nationalist belief," Michael Eric Dyson said in these pages in 1992.
 
THE GOOD HUSBAND
By Gail Godwin. Ballantine, $12.
 If behind every successful woman there is a man, he is probably like Francis Lake, who has supported his wife, Magda Danvers, in her scholarly efforts and must now see her through terminal cancer. In this novel Magda's demise and her marriage have a powerful impact on another couple grappling with tragedy. "Ms. Godwin has a remarkable capacity for the subtle presentation of real insight," Sara Maitland wrote here last year.
 
TALKING FROM 9 to 5. Women and Men in the Workplace: Language, Sex and Power
By Deborah Tannen. Avon, $12.50.
 A linguist analyzes speech patterns, showing that verbally assertive women do not reap the same rewards as verbally assertive men. This is "a book that everyone who has ever apologized needlessly, snapped at a subordinate or withered from lack of praise should surely read," Derek Bickerton said in these pages in 1994.
 
IN THE TIME OF THE BUTTERFLIES
By Julia Alvarez. Plume, $11.95.
This novel re-creates the lives of the deceased Mirabal sisters, three women murdered in 1960 by underlings of the Dominican dictator Rafael Leonidas Trujillo. Another character is Dede, the surviving sister, and it is in her portrait "that we best understand the depths of Ms. Alvarez's despair and the authenticity of her effort," Roberto Gonzalez Echevarria wrote here last year.
 
SEX IN AMERICA: A Definitive Survey
By Robert T. Michael, John H. Gagnon, Edward O. Laumann and Gina Kolata. Warner, $12.99.
 This report is based on the most comprehensive study of sexual practices in the United States since Kinsey's. Interviewing 3,432 people in 1992, the National Opinion Research Center gathered data showing that we are much more monogamous and much less sexually active than is generally supposed. Written by sociologists (Mr. Gagnon and Mr. Laumann), an economist (Mr. Michael) and a reporter for The New York Times (Ms. Kolata), this book offers "a rich supply of examples to lend those conclusions flesh and bones," Paul Robinson said in the Book Review in 1994. Also reissued is SEXING THE MILLENNIUM: Women and the Sexual Revolution, by Linda Grant (Grove, $12), in which the author argues that the 1960's idea of eroticism was mostly men's; only in the future can we hope for sex devoid of sexism. Our reviewer was again Mr. Robinson, who observed last year, "Pleasure needs as many friends as it can get." LAUREL GRAEBER

SECTION: Section 5; Page 8; Column 1; Travel Desk 

LENGTH: 2787 words

HEADLINE: A Southern Escape

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE; JAMES BROOKE, Denver bureau chief of The Times, was Brazil bureau chief until July.

 BODY:
SAO PAULO, the largest city in the Southern Hemisphere, has become a powerful magnet for Americans, drawing business visitors to Brazil's economic center and tourists to Brazil's air hub. But after more than a week in this dreary, industrial metropolis, visitors traditionally have escaped to Rio de Janeiro, one hour north by air.
Now increasing numbers of Paulistas and foreigners are flying one hour south instead -- for a quiet stay in Florianopolis, the island capital of Santa Catarina State. 
 Virtually unknown to American tourists and barely mentioned in their guidebooks, Santa Catarina now rivals Rio as a destination for foreign tourists. During the last Southern Hemisphere summer, it drew 115,000 foreign visitors, roughly as many as Rio. With tidy towns, crime-free beaches, pleasant driving, five centuries of European settlement and a friendly population of Italian and German descendants, Santa Catarina is the gateway to Brazil's European corner.
Ask a sandy-haired native about Amazon deforestation, and his eyes will glaze over. Local people are more interested in talking about their new computer research parks.
Without samba or flash, the sedate charm of the region has won a wide following. Typically during Southern Hemisphere summers (from December through March), as many as 1 percent of neighboring Argentina's 35 million people migrated to Santa Catarina's 300 miles of beaches.
With no breaking news to draw us to Santa Catarina during five years in Brazil, my wife, Elizabeth, and I set aside a week in April 1994 to explore Brazil's little Europe, first by taxi, then by rented car. Addicts of the off-season, we discovered that southern Brazil's best weather, best prices and best beach conditions are in April and May, and again in September through November.
Florianopolis is positively suburban in the most agreeable sense. One of Brazil's smallest state capitals, this city of only 250,000 is split between the mainland and Santa Catarina Island. Two bridges, a graceful steel suspension span for pedestrians and cyclists and a reinforced concrete one for cars, link the "continente" with the island, the main tourist area. Stretching over 174 square miles, the island is slightly larger than Barbados. Not cold enough to stop palm trees from growing in city parks, the crisp subtropical climate clears the air and adds a luminosity not found in Brazil's humid tropics closer to the Equator.
Boasting the best natural harbor between Rio and Buenos Aires, Santa Catarina still shows signs of the 18th-century power struggle between Spain and Portugal. To defend their prize, the Portuguese started to populate the island with fishing families from the Azores in the 1720's. At the same time, colonial envoys built four forts to protect the island's two sheltered bays. But the defenses didn't work as planned. In 1777, a Spanish armada invaded and temporarily occupied the island.
TWO centuries later, rural parts of Santa Catarina island still maintain an Azorean air -- in red-tiled cottages, women sew white cotton lacework to sell to tourists while the men set out in high-prowed Portuguese boats, netting the day's catch for island restaurants.
In high season, beaches and forts echo again with Spanish, this time from the peaceful invasion of Argentine tourists. Brazil and Argentina are now bound together in a common market. Offering linguistic relief to Americans mystified by the soft, slurring sounds of Portuguese, southern Brazil is the only part of the country where travel agents, hotel receptionists and car-rental clerks often speak Spanish. In the interior of this state, older people are more likely to speak German.
Two planes fly on Saturday from Buenos Aires to Florianopolis, five on Sunday and one on weekdays. The island now has about 65 hotels and inns, largely clustered a half-hour's taxi ride from the airport on the northern end, where the ocean is the calmest. We stayed at the Costao do Santinho, a recently built resort hotel that discreetly dominates a quiet bay surrounded with green vegetation. Less expensive and separated from a beach by a cobblestone street is the island's pioneering resort hotel, Cabanas da Praia Mole.
With 42 beaches to explore on the island, some visitors may never leave the sand. But to visit island forts or remote villages populated by descendants of Azoreans, tour companies offer trips on "schooners," motor-powered coastal sloops that retain masts and booms largely as decoration. The best preserved of the forts, Santa Cruz on Anhatomirim Island at the mouth of the harbor, is now an ecological research station. On foot, we explored around the city's shaded, bustling main square -- a 19th-century palace that is now a state history museum, a puppet fair under a banyan tree and a handicrafts market in a restored, dockside customs house. A world away from Rio's wary tourism, elderly Argentine retirees casually carried cameras, taking snapshots without fear of thieves. The young, middle-class druggies sprawled on the cathedral steps didn't seem to disturb anyone.
For dinner, a local journalist and his wife took us to Capitao e Narbal, an informal seafood haunt hidden away on a side street of Lagoa da Conceicao, a village in the middle of the island. A chilled white wine from southern Brazil accompanied mussels with cream, a fresh seafood salad and a shrimp stew.
The next morning we rented a car to explore the countryside. With one of the world's highest traffic fatality rates, Brazil is generally a driver's nightmare: horses and pedestrians emerging from long grass to cross roads, trucks crawling along at night with their lights out, apparently to save the headlights.
But not in tidy Santa Catarina, the state that every two years smugly announces its election returns hours -- if not days -- before Brazil's 25 other states. With the exception of a dangerously crowded federal highway that runs from Florianopolis to Blumenau, driving in rural Santa Catarina and the neighboring state of Rio Grande do Sul was a pleasure, comparable to driving in Ireland.
After two hours of jousting with trucks and buses on that highway, going north from Florianopolis, we turned inland, following a river valley that looked like a miniature Rhine Valley. If Florianopolis seems faintly European in an unaffected way, Blumenau, with its oompah bands, half-timbered 1980's Bavarian architecture and waitresses in dirndls, is the capital of Brazil's ersatz Europe.
In a country with a populace largely of African-Latin stock, Blumenau has turned its Teutonic roots into a national selling point. When floods wiped out the city center 10 years ago, the mayor hit upon the idea of giving five-year real estate tax exemptions to businesses that rebuilt in the Bavarian style. To further jump-start the economy, a two-week Oktoberfest was started. Now it draws nearly a million people, making it one of the world's largest Oktoberfests after Munich's. Now, the town is trying to draw fewer, but more-monied beer drinkers.
"We are changing our advertising strategy to get more class A people," Adolfo Ern Filho, Blumenau's Oktoberfest organizer, bellowed over a German band belting out polka tunes at a beer hall restaurant, the Moinho do Vale. With a bottle of local Liebfraumilch on the table, dishes included kassler, eisbein, wieners and sauerkraut.
 Back in our Brazilian-made Volkswagen Gol, we returned to Florianopolis and then drove 75 miles south, down a quieter stretch of the federal highway, to Laguna.
A quiet resort town, Laguna offered two beaches with gentle surf, the hilltop Laguna Tourist hotel designed in 1960's modern, and lines of fishermen throwing lead-weighted nets to catch mullet, which are driven into an inlet by helpful dolphins every day. There are also a monument and a museum honoring a young local woman, Anita Ribeiro da Silva, who caught the eye of a passing revolutionary, Giuseppe Garibaldi. After practicing revolution in southern Brazil with mixed results, Anita and Giuseppe Garibaldi set sail for Europe where they helped forge modern Italy.
ANOTHER monument in town marks Laguna's place in 15th-century history. On June 7, 1494, the kings of Spain and Portugal agreed to split the world in half, with Spain taking the part 370 leagues west of the Cape Verde Islands and Portugal taking the part east of the line. Since Europe had yet to learn of the existence of Brazil, the Spaniards thought that they were giving up Africa and a lot of salt water. Soon they discovered that they had signed away a healthy slice of South America -- from the mouth of the Amazon to Laguna.
To celebrate the 500th anniversary of what is known as the Tordesillas Line, Laguna's mayor and local dignitaries gathered in June, 1994, at the intersection where a cement globe marks the line's southern terminus.
We then embarked west, on one of Brazil's prettiest drives -- a new highway that snakes its way up the mountains of Rio do Rastro. The road approaching the mountains crossed an undulating countryside of green hills, wooden cottages with parabolic antennas, cows in pastures studded with Brazilian pines and the occasional lean spire of a Lutheran church. After a police checkpoint, the road climbed more and more steeply, eventually forcing our valiant Gol to labor along in first gear, barely breaking 10 miles an hour. Frequent road turnouts allow engines to cool and drivers to appreciate the unfolding valley view.
 At the top, sweaters went on and the valley below disappeared into a boiling cauldron of cold mist. After a short drive across a table plain, we stopped at the first steakhouse, Churrascaria Cascata. Southern Brazil is cattle country -- the northernmost outpost of the gaucho culture of Argentina and Uruguay -- and the fare of the land is beef, usually served hot off the coals. From the steakhouse, a smooth, lightly traveled ribbon of road led over the mesa plain to Sao Joaquim. At 4,460 feet, Sao Joaquim is Brazil's highest town. But across this tropical land, it is better known as Brazil's coldest town. In the depths of winter -- July and August -- temperatures drop to the 40's. But when thermometers start plunging below 32 degrees, national television networks cover the big event: snow.
We rolled through Sao Joaquim without stopping, trying to cross the Rio Grande do Sul state line before nightfall. Dinnertime found us in the town of Garibaldi, seated at a table appropriately set with a red-and-green checkered tablecloth, and tasting the first of several local wines. While the reds tend to be fruity, Brazil's more expensive whites can be dry if adequately chilled.
Asked how many member families of the Aurora grape growing cooperative are of Italian origin, Jose A. Alberici Jr., the president, answered "99.5 percent." Long an in-house affair, Brazilian wines have improved in quality in recent years. In 1993, Marcus James, an Aurora brand, was the fastest growing brand of wine imported to the United States, surpassing several Italian labels. Aurora offers daily tours of its winery in Bento Goncalves. The calendar is studded with municipal grape and wine festivals.
After touring two wineries, Aurora and Forestier, we drove east to Gramado, another ethnic enclave, this time German. It is a place of clean-swept streets, a thriving chocolate industry and hydrangea shrubs everywhere. A highland retreat for the affluent of Porto Alegre, the state capital 80 miles away, the town's boutiques sell sweaters and hotels offer heated pools.
From our hotel, Laje de Pedra, a Brazilian version of a 1960's alpine family resort, a sweeping view extended over a pine-forested valley, broken occasionally by basalt outcroppings. Five miles away at Caracol Park in Canela, in a tableau that seemed lifted from a 19th-century naturalist painting, we gazed at a river that ran through a pine-cloaked gorge, then fell 420 feet into a rock basin. In the evening, we repaired to St. Hubertus, a traditional restaurant in Gramado's Black Lake district. With antlers over the mantelpiece, a crackling fire in the hearth, and a fondue bubbling under candlight on the table, it was a fitting close to an exploration of Brazil's little Europe.
 
Exploring Little Europe and cowboy country
 
Getting There
From Sao Paulo or Rio, Brazil's two largest ports of entry, there are several daily flights to the coastal state capitals of southern Brazil, Florianopolis and Porto Alegre. Before you go, you must get a visa and should consider a Brazil Air Pass. Only available outside Brazil, the pass is often a way to beat Brazil's exorbitant domestic fares.
Among many car rental agencies, Localiza, telephone (031) 800-2121, rents cars in Florianopolis, Blumenau and Gramado. Daily rate for mid-sized car (Escort, Uno Mille, Corsa or Gol) $75; 100 kilometers free, 28 cents a kilometer thereafter.
The dialing code for Brazil is 55; prices are calculated at .88 reals to the dollar.
 
Santa Catarina Island
By the shoulder of a bluff of coastal rainforest, the Costao do Santinho is a new, Mediterranean-style hotel that dominates a private crescent-shaped beach ideal for quiet strolls. 2505 Estrada Dom Joao Becker; telephone (048) 261-1000. Double rooms start at $90.
A veteran standby is Cabanas da Praia Mole, a resort hotel that is separated from the beach by a road. Families can choose from 60 rooms and 18 chalets. 2001 Estrada da Barra da Lagoa; (048) 232-0231. Doubles range from $124 to $140.
Tucked away on a side street of Lagoa da Conceicao, Restaurant Capitao e Narbal offers fresh seafood dinners in a relaxed setting decorated with hanging plants and fish nets. Favored by the residents, it is a way to avoid crowds of tourists. Dinner for two, with wine, costs about $35. Open only during the summer season, from November through April.
 
Blumenau
Blondes in dirndls, a plywood windmill, oompah bands perspiring in the subtropics, and the cavernous beerhall and sausage house at Restaurante Moinho do Vale, 66 Rua Paraguai, give visitors a glimpse of what Latin America would have been like if colonized by Bavarians. Loud, boisterous groups, many from tourist buses, crowd the long tables. Phone (0473) 26-3337. Sausages, beer, potatoes and cabbage for two: $22.
 
Laguna
Built at the time of the Alliance for Progress, the Laguna Tourist Hotel, on Praia do Gi, has retained many of the 1960's Jacqueline Kennedy-style furnishings. Although the beach is a bit of a hike, this hilltop hotel with parklike grounds offers sweeping views of the South Atlantic and of the fishing port of Laguna, once the southernmost limit to the Portuguese empire. (0486) 46-0022. 98 rooms with double at $79.
 
On the Road
When traveling through Brazil's Gaucho land, dining at a churrascaria is a must; ruddy cowboy waiters in baggy pants, boots and handlebar mustaches go from table to table with roast meat on three-foot skewers. After driving into the plateau above Laguna, Churrascaria Cascata, State Highway 438, kilometer 45; (0492) 321-23, offers all you can eat for $8 a person.
 
Rio Grande do Sul
In Garibaldi, the Casacurta is a family-run inn offering a neo-Victorian charm. 510 Rua Luis Rogerio Casacurta; (054) 262-2166. 12 rooms. Doubles $50 to $68.
Green-and-red-checked tablecloths prevail at the Choppin Restaurant on the town's main avenue, at 507 Independencia. A low-key establishment with a good local wine list, the Choppin offers pasta and beef; dinner for two with wine about $25.
 
Gramado
Overlooking a sylvan gorge outside the town of Gramado, Hotel Laje de Pedra offers a resort setting with one of the few heated pools in Brazil. Check the bill carefully. The cashier "mistakenly" tripled mine. Avenida Presidente Kennedy; (054) 282-1530. 250 rooms ranging from $120 to $180.
Downtown, within walking distance of the chocolate shops and sweater boutiques is the Hotel Serrano; the style is rustic alpine with pine walls and fireplaces. 84 rooms, with doubles ranging from $103 to $185.
Down the street from the hotel, a second-floor perch at Piccolo Paradiso allows the visitor to watch the world go by. A "fetucchine Piccolo Paradiso" with ham, mushrooms and green beans, chicken gratin, dessert and drinks for two: $27. 2455 Avenida Borges de Medeiros; (054) 286-1059.
For a romantic finale to a tour of Brazil's Little Europe, dinner could be at Saint Hubertus, a Swiss-style restaurant in Gramado's Black Lake district (Lago Negro). Reservations are a good idea as couples drive up from Porto Alegre, the state capital for a quiet dinner here. Fondue Bourguignon for two with 13 different sauces, $38. 974 Rua da Carriere; (054) 286-1273.

SECTION: Section 5; Page 4; Column 5; Travel Desk 

LENGTH: 1213 words

HEADLINE: PRACTICAL TRAVELER;
The Rising Cost Of Taking a Trip

BYLINE: By BETSY WADE 

 BODY:
PEOPLE taking their vacations now will probably find that things cost more than they planned when they drafted their budget last spring, although rising prices at the filling station have apparently peaked.
Gasoline and diesel-fuel prices in June were 8 percent above those in June 1994, according to the Federal Consumer Price Index; but by July, these prices were only 3.1 percent above the year before. According to Patrick C. Jackman of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, which prepares the index, filling-station prices follow by a few months the movement of crude-oil prices, and these have been declining. 
 The snapshot showing rising travel costs comes from an index prepared by the Travel Industry Association of America using a selection of the bases in the Government index. The overall travel price index for June, the most recent, showed an increase of 4.3 percent over June 1994, while the Consumer Price Index rose only 3 percent in the same period. The fuel price bulked large in the June travel cost rise; the association gives it greater weight in compiling the index because 80 percent of United States travelers go by automobile.
Fares for air travelers on this index also took a big jump in June, rising 4.8 percent from the May level, putting them 9.9 percent above June 1994, and air fares are continuing to rise, according to the Air Transport Association. Amtrak fares on short trips in the East have risen, too.
Hotel prices are also up. The Travel Industry Association reported that lodging prices between June 1994 and June 1995 rose 3.8 percent against the 3 percent cost-of-living rise. Prices of hotel rooms are at a record level, with the average at $65 a night, according to Smith Travel Research in Hendersonville, Tenn.
And while car-rental costs are not included in the index, the rental companies increased their fees by $5 a day across the board at the end of July, after failing to stick with an effort to return to mileage charges. Cruises, another travel component not in the industry index, are apparently an exception to the trend, with discounts widespread.
 
What the Figures Mean
 The increases have different causes, although emergence from a recession plays a role in all. Most analysts of the industry respond defensively when asked for reasons, saying that many prices had been flat for a long time. Amtrak is under pressure from Congress to stop losing money. The airlines are looking back at months of red ink. Hotel prices from 1986 to 1993 lagged behind the rise in the cost of living. But none of this history lessens the impact on travelers when prices start to pull ahead again.
Like all cost indexes, those on travel cannot be mixed and matched. The Travel Industry Association does not use discounted prices for air fares or hotel rooms, because its source, the Government index, does not. This means that the hotel costs reflected in these statistics are the advertised rates, not what people actually pay. Similarly, according to Bill Evans, the director of economic research for the association, the air fares are "usually" full coach fares, which are normally paid only by business travelers sent out of town at the last minute.
One company that analyzes travel costs, Topaz Enterprises in Portland, Ore., believes this is an out-of-date benchmark. "Nobody pays sticker price," said Elliott Troutman, president of Topaz. Like the Air Transport Association, Topaz deals with what is paid, rather than with the asking price. Mr. Troutman said, however, that his company's figures showed a 10 percent increase between June 1994 and June 1995 in the prices paid for air travel -- a figure not significantly different from the Travel Industry Association's 9.9 percent.
David A. Swierenga, the economist for the Air Transport Association, said the airlines' "yield" -- the price per passenger per mile -- reversed direction in April 1995, with an increase of .5 percent over April 1994; before that, it showed drops every month since the start of 1994. Travel Industry Association figures did not put air travel out of the minus column until May. Air Transport Association figures for June showed an increase of 2.2 percent over June 1994, and for July, an increase of 4.4 percent over the year before.
 
The Lodging Factor
 Lodging costs are a big component of the travel price index. According to Mark Lomano, executive vice president of Smith Travel Research, which specializes in this area, prices are rising because hotel building has slowed and occupancy rates have been increasing, meaning that consumers are now encountering sold-out nights. This has shifted the balance temporarily in the direction of the seller, he said.
Smith's figures show the average price paid for a hotel room in June at $65.41, as against $63.67 in June 1994, an increase of 4.4 percent. The travel association's figures for the advertised prices also showed the June 1994 price at $63 but put the June 1995 price at $68. The margin between the $68 advertised price and the $65 price actually paid shows the consumer's opportunities for bargaining, or at least for asking, "Is that the best price you have?"
Mr. Lomano said hotel rates had been rising for 18 months, most steeply in the last six or seven months. He said he expected the higher level to continue next year. "Then, in two or three years," he added, "more room supply will be built and the balance will shift again."
Mr. Troutman saw a similar picture in air fares. He said the reduction of capacity, through such steps as American Airlines' abandonment in June of its hub at RaleighDurham and all lines' ending of scheduled service to such cities as Trenton and Salem, Ore., and reduction of flights to other places, as well as the demise of several start-up airlines, was enabling lines to raise prices. "But if it becomes too lucrative," he said, "it will attract competitors and someone will figure out how to take advantage of the situation."
 
Excursion-Fare Cutback
 The most complex change is in Amtrak's short-haul fare structure. In May, the railroad abandoned round-trip excursion fares between New York and Washington and went to one-way fares only. It also extended the blackout period for the cheapest tickets. A year ago, the blackout time was Friday from noon to 7 P.M. Since May, the blackout period has been 11 A.M. to 11 P.M. on both Friday and Sunday.
Chuck Blitzer, media spokesman for the Northeast corridor, provided the following simple example: In August 1994, a round-trip New York-Washington ticket on a non-Metroliner train would have cost $92, and this would have been usable for any trip except one leaving between noon and 7 P.M. on Friday. This August, the cheapest unreserved round trip, made on two one-way tickets, would cost $102, an increase of nearly 11 percent, and it would be subject to the new blackout periods. A one-way ticket usable in the Sunday blackout would cost $67 unreserved and $73 reserved; a one-way ticket usable in either blackout would cost $75 unreserved and $83 reserved.
The one-way Metroliner price was $96 for August 1994, Mr. Blitzer said, and is $103 this year. A sharper picture: In 1994, a Metroliner round trip on a weekend was $118; this year it's $170.

HEADLINE: Appraising the Role of the Appraiser

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES 

 BODY:
APPRAISERS, whether independent or hired by a bank or other lender, are somewhat remote figures compared to the real estate agents, lenders and lawyers involved in home sales or home equity loans. But virtually every loan applicant will have to rely on an appraisal to set a value on the property against which the loan is to be made.
Despite a fleeting one-time appearance, the appraiser's function is central to the lender's decision to grant the loan, deny it or reduce it. Until recently the appraiser was unregulated and the borrower had little recourse from a lender's decision based on the appraisal. 
 A succession of changes in Federal law, coupled with the explosion of computer technology in the mortgage industry, have markedly altered the way that appraisals are done, and many in the real-estate business expect the changes to continue, and even accelerate.
"The appraisal profession will change even more over the next five years," said Kenneth Kerin, senior vice president of the National Association of Realtors in Chicago. "Realtors, insurance companies and accounting firms are dropping the appraisal side of their businesses because more data in computer models is doing a lot of the work to determine property value, and appraisers are continuing to drop out, not wanting to meet the cost and inconvenience of complying with licensing requirements."
Borrowers who own or are buying low- and mid-priced homes may be surprised to find that the worth of the property is judged simply by a "drive-by" appraisal, or a broker's opinion reached by surfing the multiple listings for similar homes in the area. Higher-priced homes, however, are required under the law to be fully appraised by a licensed practitioner.
That discrepancy has been the focus of appraisers' dissatisfaction with alterations in the new Federal law. In 1991 a home loan of $15,000 required a full appraisal, but since then the minimum has risen periodically to $50,000, $100,000, and, in 1994, to $250,000. Consequently the norm for homes below the $250,000 threshold is a drive-by or a broker's opinion, neither of which requires a licensed appraiser.
The intent was benign enough. Banking officials proposed the raises in the threshold of prices requiring appraisals as a means of keeping costs down for lender and borrower alike, and speeding up the mortgage process with less time-consuming appraisal procedures.
Appraisers, cut out of a substantial source of income, are understandably dismayed, but they say that their concern is more than self-interest. "What the law protects is the jumbo loan," said Matthew Smith, a partner at Smith & Salerno, a Mineola appraisal firm, referring to larger loans in general. "People at that economic level are educated consumers. They are going to have a full appraisal anyway. It's the hard-working blue-collar families making the biggest investment of their lives that are at risk of being denied mortgages or home equity loans because of inadequate appraisals."
Dominick S. Pompeo, head of Diversified Valuation Group, a real estate appraisal and consulting firm in Manhattan and Brooklyn, and chairman of the New York State Appraisal Board, estimates that "the law virtually exempts 95 percent of all residential properties from appraisal, and 84 percent of commercial real estate." The floor for fully appraised commercial property loans is $1 million.
Others in the real-estate business, while less sympathetic to the effects that the changes are having on appraisers themselves, raise other cautions. "I've been hearing a lot of whining from appraisers," said Gurdon Buck, a lawyer who specializes in real estate issues at the Hartford firm of Robinson & Cole. "When the appraisers got licensed they thought they would be in fat city, but Federal licensing standards are so high that they had to do a lot more work." The extra work necessary, Mr. Buck said, meant that appraisers started "charging rates that went through the roof."
"With the end of the high-rolling days of refinancing, when appraisers were flooded with business, and now the National Association of Realtors generating huge data bases of houses to draw from, and the banks playing fast and loose in a very competitive market for first mortgages and home equity loans, the independent appraiser is becoming a dinosaur," Mr. Buck continued. "Banks are using their in-house employes on straight salaries to do windshield appraisals that cost nothing."
While such appraisals may be skewed to meet the bank's wish to make a loan of a certain amount, Mr. Buck contended, they will not backfire unless the new owner defaults and the house is foreclosed on, or a few years down the road the new owner cannot sell because the house was overpriced and a sale may not cover the outstanding mortgage.
Until 1989 anyone could set up shop as an appraiser by having business cards printed. But during the S&L debacle of the 80's, the loss of $500 billion of publicly insured money on inflated prices of real estate brought the country and the government up short. In the Congressional hearings that followed, "as much as 50 percent of all losses were attributed to faulty or fraudulent appraisals," said Mr. Pompeo.
In attempting to avoid similar catastrophes in the future, Congress passed the Financial Institutions, Reform, Recovery and Enforcement Act, known as FIRREA, in 1989, setting standards for the appraisal industry for the first time since appraising began in the 1920's.
As a result appraisers are required to obtain state licenses or certifications based on the completion of 75 to 165 hours of course work in real estate evaluation, real estate law, environmental law, tax policy, disabilities law, and other subjects. Each state is required to create a mechanism for handling appraisal complaints, backed by the power to revoke an appraiser's license.
Since the law went into effect in 1991 there has been a sharp drop in the number of appraisers nationwide. Approximately 85,000 are registered with the appraisal subcommittee of the Federal Financial Institutions Examination Council in Washington. While there was no way of counting heads before licensing, estimates by appraisers of the total number in the 80's ran up to 200,000.
MANY factors apart from the new regulations contributed to the decline, including the depressed housing market, the demise or merging of banks that employed appraisers, and the growth of electronic data sources that are replacing the experience and familiarity with the market that were appraisers' stock in trade. On the plus side for consumers, however, home buyers are paying less and sometimes nothing for simplified appraisals based on drive-bys or broker's opinions.
Typical of appraisers who have dropped out of the mainstream is Leonard Dahl, Citibank's chief Brooklyn appraiser for 13 years. A casualty of reorganization, he operates as an individual appraiser from the basement of his home. "Every year the business gets less and less because of cost-cutting by banks," he said.
In order to augment his income he works part time in a real estate office, where mortgage lenders frequently submit a $50 broker's opinion form to be filled out. "If the bank wants a drive-by evaluation, that's an extra $100," he said. "An on-site appraisal by a licensed appraiser, containing complete, up-to-date interior and exterior information is $275."
The less time-consuming -- and less expensive -- methods have their critics. David Bunton, executive vice president of the Appraisal Foundation, a federally authorized appraisal standards agency in Washington, is apprehensive that "lending practices are getting risky again. Lenders are highly competitive and they are less and less interested in making sure that the collateral covers the loan. The cost of a good appraisal is not enough to quibble over."
Richard Sorensen, president of the Appraisal Institute in Chicago, a 131-chapter organization with chapters in every state, said he embraces the new technology, "but only insofar as it helps members do a better job." "We are apprehensive," he says, "of the integrity of the data base, and the potential misuse of it. Data bases are more for tract-type subdivisions and condo units. Try to run something like a computerized application in Lake Forest [a luxurious Chicago suburb] or any suburb where there are no two homes alike, and it won't work."
While loan applicants who believe they have been treated unfairly can now complain to the state appraisal board or other designated agency, they may not be aware of that option and can wind up fighting it out with the lender, as Thomas Dambakly, a Brooklyn homeowner, did last April.
He had applied for a $10,000 home equity loan at Roosevelt Savings Bank and was turned down. "The bank," he said, "told me that the house was worth only $200,000." He had paid $243,000 for the single-family, 4-bedroom home in 1992. When he asked how that figure was reached he was told that it was based on comparable houses in the neighborhood, "only the comparables turned out to be two-family houses almost 10 blocks away," he said. "I'm in the Madison section, but the bank evaluated houses in Marine Park, an adjacent working-class neighborhood with smaller homes." No drive-by was done.
The bank offered to do an appraisal for $150, but Mr. Dambakly would not pay to have them "correct their own mistake," he said. The bank then accommodated him with a free, drive-by evaluation and eventually approved a $7,500 loan, based on the $180,000 mortgage he is carrying and the bank's loan to value ratio -- the loan amount divided by the appraised value or purchase price -- of 70 percent.
Officers of the bank would not comment on his complaint, but Walter Mullins, a senior vice president, said: "Real estate loans are our bread and butter. On loans of $7,500 to $10,000, using a house as collateral, we try to keep the cost down for the consumer by arriving at an evaluation through comparables in the multiple listings."
A borrower who is unhappy with the result, he explained, is offered a full appraisal at $250, and the loan will be granted if the appraisal comes in at a high enough number.
Changes affecting appraisals are emerging from another source. Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac -- the Federal National Mortgage Association and the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, two quasi-public corporations -- which purchase about a third of the mortgages sold to the secondary market and sometimes resold to pools of investors, have designed programs to streamline the appraisal process at the point of loan origination while keeping it as accurate and fair as possible.
IN January of this year Freddie Mac introduced a service called the Loan Prospector. Using a nationwide data base from such credit repositories as TRW and Equifax, it has created a computer model for determining credit-worthiness of the borrower, and it can make an assessment of properties anywhere in its vast range of markets, providing detailed comparables.
"We also do drive-bys and complete inspections as needed," said Peter Maselli, a Freddie Mac vice president. "One of our objectives was to make the lending process fairer, more fact-based than traditional underwriting. Using a data base as opposed to human judgment can avoid influences by other forces, such as discrimination against minority individuals and red-lining."
Neal McGarity, spokesman for the agency, said, "A lender using our service can offer the Loan Prospector option to the borrower, priced at or below the prevailing rate and containing the complete packet of information," but the bank has no obligation to inform the customer about the program, nor can Freddie Mac do so, since it has no part in the customer-lender transaction. "You have to ask," said Mr. McGarity. So far few have.
Fannie Mae, Freddie Mac's closest competitor in the secondary market, has a similar program called the Mornet-Plus Network. Last April it unveiled what it calls the Desk Top Originator and the Desk Top Underwriter, offering borrowers wide latitude in mortgage products at competitive prices and with appropriate appraisals, but it must also be accessed by the consumer through the lender.
Efforts are underway in many states to improve and tighten standards allowed by FIRREA. Connecticut has just passed a mandatory licensing law for all appraisers. Paul Pescatello, a lawyer at Shipman & Goodwin in Hartford and a lobbyist for the Connecticut Chapter of the Appraisal Institute, said, "This doesn't mean that a $75,000 home equity loan has to have a full appraisal, but the document must be signed by a licensed appraiser." The threat of license revocation is perceived as a strong motivation for fairness and accuracy.
"Mandatory licensing of all appraisers has been passed in 20 states," said Mr. Pompeo, "and is under consideration in 15 more, including New York."
But the prospects in New York and New Jersey are murky. In the last session of the Legislature the New York State Assembly voted for a mandatory licensing bill and reduction of the threshold to $75,000 for residences and $250,000 for commercial buildings. The Senate failed to vote.
"The banks were concerned about additional cost to the consumer," said John Conway, counsel for Senator Dean G. Skelo, Republican from Rockville Centre, L.I., who introduced the bill. It will come up again in both houses when the Legislature convenes in October, but Frank Sanzillo, an appraisers' lobbyist, sees little chance of passage "because the Secretary of State opposes it," he said.
"The Department of State did not feel that another layer of bureaucracy was the solution, when we are working to downsize government," said Marjorie Eilertson, department spokeswoman. "It's not that we've killed the bill -- we are instructing the licensing department to meet to explore solutions."
New Jersey is in a similar situation, with a proposed bill for mandatory licensing of appraisers not only for mortgages but for properties tied up in divorce or tax litigation that are currently exempt. "It passed the Assembly and sits in the Commerce Committee of the Senate," said Carmen Mistichelli, member of the New Jersey Appraisal Board.
Kevin Earl, former executive director of the New Jersey Board of Real Estate Appraisers, said "the Governor is not in favor of additional licensing, and pressure against it comes from the banking industry and lobbyists who are far more powerful and organized than the appraisal industry. Appraisers are widely diverse and have many professional societies that don't speak with one voice."
IN spite of the cost of full-time staff members, some of the larger banks find it useful to retain in-house appraisal staffs. People's Bank, headquartered in Bridgeport, has 21 staff appraisers and 20 independents on call. Writing about 10,000 mortgages a year, People's is one of the largest lenders in Connecticut.
"We are fully automated," said Linda Stetso, chief appraiser. "We target each appraiser to specific towns, so they are very knowledgeable about their area." The bank pays for the required education, and supplies laptop computers for access to multiple listings, and imaging cameras that transmit pictures electronically. "These are prohibitive expenses for an independent appraiser," said Ms. Stetso.
The cost of an average $250 appraisal multiplied by tens of thousands has many banks and mortgage bankers now relying on less-expensive independent appraisers, or on companies that handle appraisals shipped to them in bulk by lenders who get a good rate on volume.
U.S. Property Appraisals in Pittsburgh, founded eight years ago, is one of about a dozen companies around the country that do bulk appraisals. "We get bundles of up to 2,000 appraisals," said John Foehrenbach, executive vice president. "We can do them in-house or farm them out to local appraisers. Drive-bys cost $50; full appraisals can go up to $315, depending on what the client orders."
Most of the 4,000 lenders that the company deals with, he said, "are demanding ever-lower fees and faster turnarounds." He says that their customers are shopping around, applying to as many as five lenders at one time. "Whichever lender gets the answer first at the lowest cost, gets the loan," he said.
In fact, Robert Bartos, former president of the Appraisal Institute's Connecticut chapter, said he believed that "the industry will be obsolete in five years."
"There is," he said, "a tremendous underdemand for our services."
