HEADLINE: Sea Gulls, Scourge of the Coastal Runways

BYLINE: By BILL RYAN 

 BODY:
IT'S "High Noon" at mid-morning at Groton-New London Airport. Onto the runway strides James Cowley, lean, erect, mustache flowing, shotgun cradled. He stares at the enemy, a small flock of sea gulls enjoying the sun reflecting off the macadam. The gulls stare back at him, fearless, unmoving. James Cowley raises the shotgun.
A shell bursts in the air above the gulls, with a flash of light, a big bang and then a series of smaller bangs. The gulls take to the air, flying as a unit down a short distance of runway, then settling back to resume doing what they do best: Staring at James Cowley. 
"Sometimes they don't move at all," said Officer Cowley. "After a while, they seem to like the noise. They look forward to it."
Thus starts another interesting day at the state airport that juts into Long Island Sound at Groton -- 410 acres bounded by water on three sides, two by Long Island Sound, the other by the Poquonnock River.
It is a very scenic place. It is also a very funny place in the sense of funny as a bit strange: a state-owned airport that also seems to be somewhat of a nature preserve, where airplanes and air birds co-exist in a delicate relationship overseen not only by the State Department of Transportation, which owns the airport, but also by other governmental agencies that are interested in what is going on there, animal-wise and bird-wise.
"We work with both the U.S. Department of Agriculture's Animal Damage Control Division and the Connecticut Department of Environmental Protection's Wildlife Division," said Airport Manager Gary S. Schmid, who has been in charge of the airport for less than a year but was very familiar with it long before that. Two decades ago, he was a pilot for Pilgrim Airlines, a commuter line that operated out of Groton-New London. Early on, he learned of the airport's reputation as a haven for animals and birds, many of which dropped in for lunch and then just stayed on.
The greenery around the airport has harbored fox, deer, coyotes, snowy owls, hawks, turkey vultures, great blue herons, osprey, Canada geese and, of course, sea gulls. For the past few years, it has not officially been spring at the airport until George and Gracie, a pair of ospreys, arrived to set up housekeeping. The advent of fall is heralded by their departure, sometimes with new little members of their family, to winter headquarters in South America.
The osprey family used to nest near the river but several years ago decided to change location, according to Justine Francese, the airport manager's secretary. The new homesite they picked was on the glideslope antenna, an electronic device that tells pilots their altitude. They piled on the branches for a nest, and the antenna shorted out. Each morning, the airport's maintenance crew would remove the branches. George and Gracie eventually got the picture, constructed a new nest off the runway area and have been living there peacefully since.
Most of the birds that make their homes at the airport, however, are not known individually by name but are called many names, all unprintable. These are the sea gulls and the Canada geese, birds that do not enjoy the best of images, particularly at an airport. Canada geese have been described as defecating machines and twice a year they visit the airport (which is on the Atlantic Flyway) during the migrating seasons. What they leave must be cleaned off runways lest planes, incoming and outgoing, slide all over the place.
In addition, 75 to 100 Canada geese are permanent guests at the airport, living there year-round and enjoying it. "There were no predators here and they had plenty of food and water," said Mr. Schmid.
But that has changed somewhat recently, he added. Several months ago, workers at the airport started to notice a coyote wandering around the grassy areas or trotting across a runway, joined later by Mrs. Coyote and eventually three pups. The geese population, particularly young geese, seemed to diminish somewhat. This circumstance, representing an alteration of the balance of nature, has not dismayed the humans at the airport. Fewer geese means less trouble.
Several years ago, a group of them crossing a runway got in the way of a commercial plane that was taking off. A dozen of the big birds were killed and the flight was aborted until repairs could be made. Since then workers at the airport have spent a lot of time shooing geese off the runways by any means possible: firing shotgun blanks at them, herding them by motor vehicle, yelling at them through bullhorns, or even over the public address system.
But if the geese are a big problem, the sea gulls and the oyster shells are a bigger problem. Gulls drop oysters on the hard runways, breaking them open, then scoop up the meat.They leave the jagged shells, threatening to blow out plane tires.
Richard E. Pealer, the former airport manager, traces the oyster-shell menace to Hurricane Gloria, which ripped into the Connecticut shore in September of 1985. The storm brought oyster beds in the Poquonnock River closer to the surface, Mr. Pealer theorized. That allowed gulls to snatch them up at low tide. In any case, since 1985 no human at the airport has needed a tide table. Low tide is when the gulls bombard the runways with oyster shells.
For years after Gloria, Mr. Pealer conducted a spirited and imaginative campaign against the gulls. Armed with a permit from the United States Fish and Wildlife Service, he fired blanks at the birds and, when he felt the situation was becoming desperate, real shells.
He thought of getting a falconer to hunt the gulls but had no idea where to find a falconer. He also considered painting the outline of gulls along the sides of the runways in the belief that the real gulls would not drop shells near them because they do not like sharing meals. He dropped that idea because the painted gulls would be a distraction to pilots.
Finally, Mr. Pealer learned of a company in Minnesota that makes gull decoys for hunting and decoration and ordered a dozen of them, to place along the runways in the hope that the decoys would discourage the real gulls from using the same area. The gulls were not fooled.
When Mr. Pealer, a man with a good sense of humor, retired last year, it was with the knowledge that at best he had reached a standoff with the birds.
The standoff continues. Each morning, the maintenance crew goes out to sweep up oyster shells with a big snow broom, returning as many times as necessary during the day to remove new shells as they are dropped. Gulls and geese and all sorts of other wildlife are herded away with trucks, sirens, flashing lights, blank shells, yells -- anything to make them know they are in an off-limits area. "The other day, we were out there 10 times chasing the birds," said Officer Cowley.
Now Mr. Schmid, a native of Ohio who came to know southeastern Connecticut when he served aboard the atomic submarine Nautilus, has inherited the airport and its problems. It is a task he says he relishes. "This is where I started in aviation and it's a beautiful place," he said. "I love it here."
The airport has become less busy, however, than when he was piloting planes. In the mid-1980's, more than 40 daily commercial flights were recorded out of Groton-New London. Now the figure is down to five -- four to Philadelphia, one to Baltimore. Most of the business today is with private and corporate aircraft. And parking is free because a private contractor selected by the state to run the lot couldn't make money on it and departed.
But the outlook for the old airport, dating to the biplane age, is suddenly bright again, Mr. Schmid said. The reason is the economic jolt the region is experiencing in jobs from the massively successful Mashantucket Pequot casino, the anticipation of another casino to be opened by the Mohegan tribe, and the possibility of one or more theme parks and other spinoffs of the gambling dollar.
"I think this region has a future as a tourist destination area and I think this airport can be a tourist shuttle from Bradley Airport," Mr. Schmid said.
The old airport administration building, which looks like the set for a 1930's movie, is going to get a facelift starting in October, he said, including such marvelous advances as air-conditioning and telephones with buttons instead of rotary dials. He is all for that.
But he also wants to retain the charm of the airport, a place where private pilots can drop in by air, and other visitors by the winding road off Route 1, and spend some time enjoying a good meal at the terminal restaurant while savoring the views of Long Island Sound and the Poquonnock River and, of course, the birds. They may be problems at times, those birds, but they do bring a certain elan to the place.

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: Landmarks Group Has $1.5 Million for Facade Work;
Conservancy Seeks To Lend in Queens

 BODY:
People in Queens don't apply for the New York Landmarks Conservancy's preservation loans -- and nobody knows why.
Out of 63 low-interest loans granted by the Conservancy since the late 1980's, 23 have gone to residents of Manhattan, 35 to homeowners in Brooklyn, 2 to applicants in Staten Island and 3 to people in the Bronx. None have gone to residents of Queens. 
 So the Conservancy, which has $1.5 million to give out citywide, is targeting Queens: Ridgewood, Hunters Point, Jackson Heights, Richmond Hill, Steinway, Old Astoria, Kew Gardens and Sunnyside Gardens. If you don't live there, but have an older, architecturally interesting house, call the Conservancy anyway, said Peg Breen, the group's president. "We'll take a look at the house and run it by the S.H.P.O.," the State Historic Preservation Office, which determines eligibility for the National Register, she said. "All we need is for them to say: 'Yes, it looks like it's eligible.' "
One Brooklyn house that is benefiting from the program is at 135 St. Felix Street in the Brooklyn Academy of Music Historic District.
The owners, Lucille Smith and Charles Smith Jr., have received a $35,000 loan and are completing exterior renovations.
Interest rates on the loans vary, but seldom exceed 5 percent. "We want to make it do-able to fix your porch, fix your brownstone or rebuild your foundation," Ms. Breen said. "There are so many great houses in Queens that can be brought back."

HEADLINE: CHATTER;
Are Fares and Tolls Fair?

 BODY:
New York officials want to raise the tolls at Hudson River crossings and the fare on PATH trains, saying New Jerseyans aren't paying their fair share. Do you agree?
 
What About the Taxes We Pay to New York? 
 One infrequently mentioned item in this debacle is taxes. Because I work in New York City, my wife's income is used in figuring our New York State and City taxes, even though she doesn't earn a penny in New York State or New York City.
 The thought, therefore, of another toll increase is even more upsetting to me and everyone else in this situation. How much more are we to be bled?
JOEL D. REISER
West Caldwell
 
Ignoring All the Help New Jerseyans Provide
 As usual, politicians are assuming that the fares will increase, more money will be collected, and nothing else will change. This is the quintessential static analysis.
New York politicians, especially, ignore the millions of dollars in taxes that New Jersey commuters provide.
Also conveniently ignored is the boost to the local economy. All New York governors and New York City mayors have always stated that they want to keep the Wall Street district viable, but they never have a problem with making it harder for New Jersey residents to contribute to that viability.
Every time the border war escalates, the free flow of people and capital is inhibited. Why would anyone want to voluntarily work or play in New York City when, notwithstanding the rhetoric, all they really want is our money?
EDWARD J. ZOHN
Scotch Plains
 
The Tolls May Go Up, But the Service Doesn't
 It is no wonder that people are fleeing New York City. The increased fares and tolls in the past have not contributed to an increase in service, or even maintenance. New Jersey residents are weary of highway robbery.
ROBERTA MEEHAN
Allentown

HEADLINE: EARNING IT;
Job Advice for 2005: Don't Be a Farmer, Play One on TV

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

 BODY:
THE next decade looks good for travel agents, private detectives and subway operators. But don't even think about becoming a butcher, watchmaker or ship fitter.
So says the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics, which periodically borrows a standard commercial computer model of the economy, massages the numbers a bit and then grinds out predictions of where the jobs will be. The 25 fastest-growing job categories to the year 2005, along with the 25 fastest-shrinking ones, are displayed here for your edification. 
 As a soothsayer, the bureau is distinctly fallible: too much, after all, turns on imponderables like the rate of military spending and the Federal Reserve's ability to keep the economy out of recession. Still, Uncle Sam's educated guesses offer some striking insights into the ways business is trying to squeeze more value from fewer dollars paid to labor.
As might be expected, virtually every unskilled or semiskilled job linked to manufacturing is a loser. Manufacturing output will continue to grow, said Ronald Kutscher, associate commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics. But productivity is rising more rapidly than demand, undermining employment in several categories, from tire makers to printers to a catch-all called "packing and filling machine operators."
By the same token, jobs most vulnerable to imports -- those requiring a lot of semiskilled labor to add value -- will likely be a drag on the market. It wasn't much fun being an American shoe or apparel worker in competition with Asian and Latin workers over the last decade, and it will probably be even less fun in the next.
But other predicted changes catch subtler trends. The number of child care workers, over all, is expected to rise by more than 60 percent by the year 2005, as more mothers with young children go back to work sooner.
The number of legal child care workers in private households, however, is expected to decline, as servants become an ever-less-affordable luxury. This seemingly paradoxical trend is mirrored in other personal services: private cooks and maids are apparently an endangered species, as demand shifts to restaurant cooks, bakers, manicurists, bellhops and laundry and dry-cleaning workers.
Technology and changing tastes produce a host of similar double plays. The number of farmers will continue to decline as agricultural productivity grows relentlessly, while the number of nursery-farm workers will increase with the demand for garden plants and specialized farm crops. The entertainment industry is booming, opening jobs for producers, directors, actors and amusement park attendants. Meanwhile, film projectionists are succumbing to the automation of multiplex theaters.
The aging of the population -- more specifically, the explosive growth in the number of Americans over the age of 80 -- is driving demand for home care aides, as well as the demand for most categories of health care workers. But the pattern of job growth will be powerfully influenced by efforts to contain medical costs: physical therapists, dental hygienists, medical secretaries, registered nurses, psychologists -- in short, anyone who can reduce the work load on high-priced physicians -- will be in demand.
What works for health care apparently works for the other expensive service that Americans cannot seem to do without but do not wish to pay for: legal representation. Legal secretaries and paralegals (lawyers' assistants) are both in the Top 25 job categories, but lawyers are conspicuously absent.
Perhaps most striking is the shuffle of jobs in industries dependent on electronics.
Hundreds of thousands of jobs will disappear in telecommunications and office work, as microprocessors and radio transmitters replace humans in directory assistance, switchboard operations, switching equipment maintenance, telephone and cable television wiring, bill posting, word processing and data entry.
Bank tellers might be on this list, as the efficiency-driven merger of the Chase and Chemical banks last week suggests. They probably escape the bottom 25 only because the shift toward automated teller machines has already decimated their ranks. On the other hand, lots of new jobs will be created to aid in computer design and repair, software innovation and computerized page layout for magazines and newspapers.
A caveat for those who would interpret the list as a guide to the best jobs: while rapid growth in openings means it will be relatively easy to find work in the top 25, many of these jobs will be anything but nifty.
After all, one reason so many are expected to be employed in service jobs like restaurant and home care is that the going wage rates will be low. Those with the talent, ambition and training will still be better off fighting for the prizes in the highly paid professions.

HEADLINE: 500,000 Clients, No Branches

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL 

DATELINE: LEEDS, England

 BODY:
FOR Catholics, it's Lourdes. For bankers these days, it's Leeds.
Representatives of banks from around the world are making the pilgrimage to this industrial city in the north of England for a glimpse of what might be their stagnant industry's equivalent of a miraculous cure. 
 Here, in the shadow of a nuclear power plant, they find a sprawling hangar of a building that houses First Direct, a bank with half a million customers and not a single branch. Not only is First Direct the world's leading telephone-only bank; it is the fastest-growing bank in Britain. In just five years, it has signed up 2 percent of Britain's notoriously set-in-their-ways banking subjects, who call its rows of bankers 24 hours a day, seven days a week, to pay bills, buy stock and arrange mortgages.
"Statistically, in Britain, people are more likely to change their wife than change their bank," said Peter Simpson, First Direct's commercial director. Yet with a combination of savvy marketing and distinctively better service than the average branch has to offer, he explained, "we're opening up 10,000 new accounts a month; that's like two or three new branches."
Now, the First Direct formula for winning affluent, and profitable, customers without the considerable cost of opening and operating new branches is being copied by banks around the world. Even in the United States, where banks are talking about offering services through the Internet, the relatively low-tech telephone -- combined with existing automated teller machine networks to supply cash -- appears to be the best way to lure customers into branchless banking.
Indeed, when Chase Manhattan and Chemical announced their $10 billion merger last week, their executives said they had no intention of using their new bulk to gobble up still more banks with still more branches. Even a huge regional bank like First Union of Charlotte, N.C., which recently bought First Fidelity of Newark for $5.4 billion, would need half a dozen more megadeals of that size to assemble a coast-to-coast network of branches. And, with the industry losing ground to competitors like mutual fund companies, bankers increasingly say those deals may never pay off.
"BRANCHES are becoming less and less significant in selling financial products," said Walter Shipley, Chemical's chief executive. "Not having branches could be an advantage as we leapfrog the physical delivery system."
Just two months ago, with First Direct as its model, Chase introduced a separate banking entity called Chase Direct. Chemical, meanwhile, has been testing a similar operation, called Chem Direct, with some customers who already choose to bank only by phone. After the merger, Mr. Shipley said, the combined bank will offer telephone banking services to its 25 million mortgage and credit card customers around the country.
By that time, two years from now, Chase will have a lot of competition in telephone banking. First Chicago has even taken the name First Direct, much to the chagrin of its namesake in Leeds, for a nationwide telephone banking service.
Several other banks, including First Union, the PNC Bank Corporation and Wachovia, have national aspirations, and many others are creating telephone-only banking services, modeled on First Direct, in their regions. Nonbanking companies like American Express are also starting direct-banking units to get into that business cheaply.
Of course, banks have been expanding the service they offer by telephone over the last decade. Many banks now offer information by touch-tone, and sometimes from live operators, 24 hours a day. Now, the banks say, these services have proven so popular that they are being forced to expand them to make sure that anything that can be done in a branch, short of getting cash or making a deposit, can be handled over the phone.
For consumers who are already used to buying everything from sweaters to sofa beds from mail-order catalogues, the ability to do all of their banking over the telephone may well be a welcome convenience, especially if the banks pass on some of their operational savings in the form of lower fees and higher savings rates.
But for those customers who are unwilling or afraid to trust their money to someone on the other end of the line, the rise of these telephone banks, and the branch closings sure to accompany it, are hardly causes for celebration.
For example, Huntington Bankshares of Columbus, Ohio, has doubled the number of full-service branches it plans to close by the end of next year, from 15 to 30, because of the success of Huntington Direct, one of the first American telephone banks. Ultimately, bank officials say they will be able to close at least half of Huntington's branches.
In New York, the news of the Chase-Chemical merger was greeted with concern by consumer advocates, who said the closing of branches would be another economic blow to some of the city's poorest neighborhoods.
BACK here in Leeds, though, First Direct is an effort to bridge that technology-personal service gap. What's most unusual about First Direct is not that it can transfer money or even open new accounts for people over the telephone. It's that it uses sophisticated technology to create a more personal relationships with its customers, and thus satisfy their needs and sell them more products.
On the average day in Leeds, a location chosen mainly for its low cost, 24,000 calls come into First Direct's two facilities, handled at peak times by 150 bankers. The larger and more recent building is a service-age factory floor in which the telephone bankers, computer programmers and even the chief executive, Kevin Newman, all work together under an arched silver roof.
On the walls are what appear to be sports stadium scoreboards, constantly flashing the number of customers on hold and how long they have been waiting. Posters show how many new credit cards and other products have been sold that month.
"Hello this is First Direct. How can I help?" Tim Grice, a telephone banker sitting in a pastel purple carrel says chipperly into his headset.
"I'd like the balance in my account," says a woman on the line.
After taking her account number and security password, Mr. Grice gives her the information and then arranges to pay 310.77 (about $460) to her credit card account at National Westminster Bank. Meanwhile, his computer screen is displaying all sorts of personal information about the customer. "No Adverse Risk" flashes at the top, indicating that the bank would be glad to loan her money.
Also displayed is the fact that she is a 30-year-old single renter with a job as a project manager, along with a list of all the bank's prior contacts with her.
"HAVE you read the information on the First Direct Visa we sent you?" Mr. Grice asks. "Our card has no fee and a lower interest rate than the card you are probably carrying." Mr. Grice knows that the NatWest account, whose bill the customer just paid, charges 23.5 percent a year, compared to First Direct's 22 percent, but British privacy rules prevent him from using information from her transaction to attempt a sale.
The customer says she will consider the card.
"I sent her a prepared application for the Visa today," Mr. Grice explains after the call. "Then next time we speak to her, we will follow up."
First Direct's computer allows it to create a virtual relationship with its customers, even though they may never speak to the same banker twice. The bankers try to make small talk with customers, but the virtual relationship aims to have substance as well as style.
Instead of randomly mailing out offers for products, such as car loans and mortgages, the bank asks customers to say when they are going to move, buy a car and so on, so it can send them information when they need it.
FIRST DIRECT was created in 1989 as a separate banking division by Midland Bank, Britain's third largest, which was facing declining market share and the depressing fact that a majority of its 2,000 branches were unprofitable.
From the beginning, First Direct tried to break out of the pack with disruptive advertising. For its start-up, the bank actually interrupted an Audi commercial on television (with the car company's permission) for a message that purported to be from the year 2010.
With this and other marketing gambits, the bank has been able to create a brand that appeals to the young affluent professionals who were spawned by the Thatcherite boom. The average First Direct customer is a 35-year-old professional man in a professional job. Nearly half of them live in the London area, compared to one-third of the British population.
A typical customer is Kevin Mochrie, who began banking with First Direct when he was working the night shift at a newspaper in Birmingham.
"Sometimes the only time I could pay my bills was 11 o'clock Sunday night," said Mr. Mochrie, now deputy editor of the Evening Advertiser in Swindon, west of London. "I really began to appreciate them when I moved and I could keep banking without changing anything."
Predictably, these tony customers are more profitable than those of most banks. The average balance is 10 times higher at First Direct than at Midland, while the overall costs are 61 percent less. Overall, First Direct makes money on 60 percent of its customers, compared to 40 percent at the average British bank.
First Direct turned a profit at the end of 1993, but it won't pay back Midland's start-up investment until the end of the decade. By that time, if current trends continue, First Direct could well have more than a million customers, 4 percent of the British market. If it does, the corporate market share of Midland, now a unit of the huge HSBC Banking Group, would approach 20 percent, nearly the level of the country's two largest banks, National Westminster and Barclays.
Of course, those two banks, and many smaller ones, have begun to react to First Direct and are developing telephone banking services of their own. Indeed, some insurance companies and even Richard Branson's Virgin empire are also getting into direct banking in Britain.
Will this work in the United States?
A lot of bankers think the time is right, despite several factors that make such an offering more difficult. For one, people may be shy of doing business with a bank that has no branches for hundreds of miles, even if they never intend to go into a branch.
Midland's name and its nationwide presence certainly reassured First Direct customers that they could use a branch if they needed one. Yet only two percent of First Direct customers actually saw a teller last year, mainly to withdraw more cash than the daily limit at automated teller machines.
IN Britain, however, people have less reason to deposit checks than they do in the United States, because the British electronic funds transfer system is more developed.
"I don't pretend that getting checking account customers won't be the hardest sell until I have a way to take deposits," said James Grant, a senior vice president of First Chicago in charged of its copycat First Direct. Yet he said the bank was encouraged to go ahead with the project in part because it has 27,000 customers who have moved away from Illinois who, without any special offers, still use their First Chicago checking accounts. And in the meantime, the bank is also offering products such as home equity loans and certificates of deposit that don't require as much use of branches.
Some American bankers are betting that by the time they get their telephone banking services up and running, similar electronic funds transfer facilities will develop. And others are figuring that they will have to open a handful of toehold branches in major cities, just as Fidelity Investments and Charles Schwab do. And to lure customers to take the plunge into telephone services, bankers are working on offering direct banking services to members of various trade groups, clubs and frequent flier programs, gambits that have worked well selling credit cards.
Most of the banks that are active with telephone banking are also working to offer their services through personal computer programs or over the Internet. They figure that many customers would rather see information on their screens rather than just hearing it over the phone. But so far these on-line banking offerings have hardly attracted any customers.
"Cyberspace starts with the plain old simple telephone," Said Mr. Randle of Huntington. "And the customer is already there."

HEADLINE: EARNING IT;
Peering Into the Murky Jobs Crystal Ball for 2015

BYLINE: By TRIP GABRIEL 

 BODY:
WHAT should today's toddlers be thinking of doing when they are unable to drag out graduate school any longer and must enter the work force, say around 2015?
Although the Government predicts hot jobs 10 years into the future, there is little solid information on trends beyond 2005. There is, however, plenty of informed speculation by demographers and futurists. 
 Over all, they say, the jobs picture 15 to 20 years out will be shaped by the evolution of technology (and all manner of attempts to fend off its intrusions), along with two big population trends: the retirement of the baby boomers, who begin turning 65 in 2010, and the entry into the work force of the baby boom echo generation, Americans born since a sharp upturn in births in the 1980's.
The boomers' retirement will no doubt accelerate the demand during the next decade for more home care aides and other health workers. In addition, construction workers in the Sun Belt will prosper, predicted Jon Sargent, an economist for the Bureau of Labor Statistics, along with makers of every sort of elderly-friendly device, from big-button telephones to ergonomic wheelchairs.
Information technology is a growth field as far into the next century as nearly anyone can see. The explosion of the Internet may mean that anyone will be able to sell goods and services without the money for a retail store. By 2010 or 2015, computer literacy will be no more remarkable than "telephone literacy" today; nearly every skilled job will require it.
But the problem with anticipating specific job growth in computers is that technology reshapes itself as unpredictably as a hill of silicon.
For example, computer programmers are a hot category to 2005, the Government said. But in the next 10 to 20 years, predicted Paul Saffo, a computer industry analyst at the Institute for the Future, programming will become automated and programmers as outmoded as John Henry and his hammer and chisel.
"The real trick is staying skills relevant," he said. "If you bet on artificial intelligence in 1980, which was then a hot field, you either retrained or you're in another industry."
Future technologies that could become big include biotechnology, which some say is already overdue for greatness, and nanotechnology, the technique of building microscopic machines one molecule at a time.
Even as technology increasingly pervades peoples' lives, some prognosticators see the return of traditional artisanship as an antidote. "Baking bread will become a growth area," said Irma Zandl, a professional trend spotter, who also sees opportunities in high-quality coffee and specialty foods. "When you buy a freshly made coffee as opposed to, say, a soda, in a sense you're getting some of the soul of another human being," she said.
Watts Wacker, a futurist at Yankelovich Partners, a public opinion research firm, said the increasing demand for security guards in the next decade would only become greater. The ultimate corporate perk may be to live in a gated company town where one's employer provides private education, policing and all other services. He thinks there will also be personal-privacy consultants to work as gatekeepers of the vast computerized data about one's life, edit the barrage of incoming information and insure that individuals, in a world where most are self-employed, are paid.
Mr. Wacker also sees a boom in jobs related to environmental cleanup. "Forty percent of the world will live in polluted water," he said.
By 2025 or 2030, he sees current workplace trends in outsourcing, telecommuting and job hopping reaching their logical ends. People will work in four or five fields during a career, and they will join a company knowing that in five years it will be out of business. "You'll see a whole renaissance of the Jeffersonian approach to life," he said. "People will actually be engineers and historians and agrarians."
Well, maybe. In looking to the future, it may be wise to look back at the prognosticating of an earlier age. In 1976, a magazine enthusiastically called The Future! included an imaginary Help Wanted section from the year 2000. There were job openings for an offshore life style consultant, a genetic engineer and an exobiologist -- desperately needed to study alien life forms.
The lesson is that even over a quarter-century when the economy and society went through remarkable shifts, job categories didn't really change all that much.

LENGTH: 746 words

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
In 401(k)'s, It's Great To Be Young And Bold

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
YOUNG laborers are no slackers in the savings department, but they still have trouble taking a long view when investing their newfound money.
At age 29, Jennifer Shine-Hayward of Norfolk, Mass., has socked away $30,000 in the 401(k) retirement plan at Xerox, where she is an account executive. But when she reviewed her account statement earlier this year, it gave her a jolt. Ms. Shine-Hayward found that her investment gain for 1994 was only $150, or about half of a percent. "I would have earned more in a savings account or a money market fund," she said. 
 Alarmed, she sought help from her sister, Judy Shine, 38, a certified financial planner with Financially Speaking in Denver. The problem, said big sister, was not the tiny return, but the way progress was measured.
"Your time frame is not 1994," Ms. Shine recalled saying. "It is 30 years, and you cannot judge performance on one-year returns."
Never has that lesson been more apparent than this year. Anyone who looked at disappointing returns last year and said, " 'Stocks went down, I should get out,' " Ms. Shine noted, "would have missed out entirely on this year's run-up in the market."
A knee-jerk reaction to a year of poor performance can be particularly devastating for people in their 20's, who by all accounts will have to shoulder most of the financial burden for themselves in retirement. Stocks tend to be the most volatile of assets, meaning short-term losses are quite possible, but over the years they have been the only type of investment to outpace inflation and taxes significantly.
Young people seem to have gotten the message about the importance of saving for old age. In a survey conducted this year by Roper Starch Worldwide for Kemper Financial Services, 61 percent of respondents in their 20's said they or their spouses had started saving for retirement, disputing the common notion that the young generation is irresponsible.
More so than older workers, the 20's crowd is investing retirement money in stocks, too, but not as much as Ms. Shine and other financial advisers would like. The average balance in 401(k) accounts is $5,836 for people in their 20's, according to a recent study by Watson Wyatt Worldwide, a benefits consulting firm. About 41 percent of that money is in domestic and foreign stocks, not including their own company's stock, compared with just 28 percent of all the money in 401(k) retirement plans. Most of the money in these plans belongs to people nearing retirement -- the average account for people 61 and older was $179,955 in the survey -- who tend toward more conservative investments as retirement nears.
Despite their progress, the youngest workers will probably come up short in retirement unless they take drastic steps. Watson Wyatt found that nearly 25 percent of people in their 20's have 80 percent or more of their 401(k) money in fixed-income funds, including bond funds and investment contracts that produce a fixed return, a return far lower than stocks historically.
 "Younger workers are still much too conservative with their retirement savings investments," said Sylvester Schieber, research director at Watson Wyatt. They should put most, and perhaps all, of their retirement money in stocks, he said.
A year ago, Ms. Shine-Hayward had her 401(k) money in a balanced mutual fund, which invests in a combination of stocks and bonds and cash. After much counseling from her sister, she put 90 percent of her money in the stock market, with a mix of blue-chip, growth and international mutual funds. That investment strategy could lead to a leisurely retirement if Ms. Shine-Hayward, who is expecting her first child in a few weeks, keeps putting away the maximum amount, just over $9,000 this year, in her 401(k) plan.
Making the switch to more aggressive investments was not easy, though. Ms. Shine said it took more than two weeks of long-distance conversations to convince her sister that the problem with her investment strategy was its conservatism, not its paltry return last year, when stocks and bonds were both weak performers. One reason her sister ultimately agreed to be more aggressive with her 401(k) money, the financial adviser said, was that several of their relatives are having a tough time in retirement.
"Jennifer asked me, 'How can you work all those years and have to struggle?' " Ms. Shine said. Saving aggressively and investing wisely, she said, will keep that from happening to you.

HEADLINE: FUNDS WATCH;
Autumn Agonies: Hello September

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
Will fall bring the fall?
The stock market's meteoric rise has slowed, with August becoming the first month of 1995 to show a drop in the Dow Jones industrial average. But indexes of smaller stocks were up nicely and have now risen for nine months. 
 Still, an eight-month string for the Dow is not bad. The last time we had a similar run, it ended with a small drop in June 1961. (For history buffs, the market was then almost six months from its peak, which saw a further rise of 7 percent. Then came a sharp correction, which lopped 27 percent off the Dow within another six months.)
Today's market looks more than a little speculative, dominated as it is by hot initial public offerings and by surging technology stocks, although some new issues have cooled and Microsoft has now gone more than six weeks without hitting a new high, the longest such stretch since January. Money continues to pour into the riskiest mutual funds, which respond by investing the cash as fast as they can. The market boom is probably safe so long as that public enthusiasm continues, and it is not clear what will end it. It is clear that a lot of investors could not care less about things like low dividend yields or high price-to-book-value ratios.
But there are certain patterns in stock market behavior that may be worth noting. Edward M. Saunders Jr., writing in the American Economic Review a couple of years ago, documented that the market does much better on sunny days in New York than on days when it rains or is heavily overcast. He speculated that people feel better, and buy more, when it's a nice day.
One implication of that, perhaps, is that a lot of rain can cause prices to be unreasonably depressed, providing a buying opportunity, while a string of sunny days might have the opposite effect. Last month was the driest August ever in New York.
Other patterns that recur are that Mondays tend to be worse for stocks than other days, and Septembers tend to be the worst months. Jeremy Siegel, a professor at the Wharton School at the University of Pennsylvania, offers a guess that those patterns, too, are related to investor psychology. On Mondays, he says, people are depressed about having to go back to work and having to pay the bills they ran up over the weekend. In September, people come back from August vacations feeling the same way, only more so.
In any case, the numbers are striking. Stock prices, of course, tend to go up more often than they go down. Since the end of 1914, when the Dow was redone, there have been 968 months, with the Dow up in 58 percent of them. But only 40 percent of the Septembers have shown increases. Every other month was up at least half the time. On average, the Dow falls almost 1 percent in September, much more than in any other month. And it has been getting worse. Over the last quarter century, September has seen 20 declines, for an average loss of 1.5 percent.
Through August, the Dow was up 20.2 percent, on its way to a great year. Since 1960, there have been only seven instances when the index rose at least 15 percent in the first seven months of the year -- in 1961, 1975, 1983, 1986, 1987, 1989 and 1991. Of those, only once, in 1983, did the Dow rise in September. That was when the market was nearing the beginning of a correction.
On the other hand, the Dow started this September with a big gain on Friday.
Have a nice month.

HEADLINE: SPENDING IT;
For Business, the Stakes Are High

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

 BODY:
WHILE the individual income tax is the target of the reformers, business taxes are sure to be included in any radical make-over.
In fact, the three most prominent plans all try to overcome one of the principal objections to the income tax: that it imposes a punishing double tax on investment by taxing profits and dividends once through the corporate profits tax and again through the personal income tax. 
 But while the plans have been advertised as a way to lighten the tax burden on business across the board, in fact the impact of the different plans on different businesses could vary tremendously. That's why, even though any new tax system at best is probably years away, hundreds of high-priced lobbyists are already lining up to influence the outcome. The stakes are so high that the nature of the overhaul could govern which businesses prosper and which suffer.
While there is little research on what would happen if a national sales tax replaces the income tax, analysts at Price Waterhouse found that two other major proposals would have drastically different effects on different industries. They are the flat tax offered by the House majority leader, Dick Armey of Texas, and the U.S.A. tax proposed by Senators Pete Domenici, Republican of New Mexico, and Sam Nunn, Democrat of Georgia.
Compared with the corporate taxes paid in 1992, "we found that the services sector would be a large loser under both the flat tax and the U.S.A. tax, while the transportation, communications and utilities sectors would be a major winner under both tax proposals," said Shevetank Shah, a researcher at Price Waterhouse. "By contrast, the manufacturing sector wins under the U.S.A. tax but loses under the flat tax, while the trade sector loses under the U.S.A. tax and wins under the flat tax."
Here is a brief look at the business side of the three high-profile alternatives to the income tax.
 
The Flat Tax
 The flat tax breaks income into two pieces: wages would be taxed from individuals, just as they are now; earnings on invested capital would be taxed exclusively from businesses. To limit taxable income to just the portion that is consumed, business would be permitted to deduct the full cost of investments in the year they are made.
That makes the flat tax on business simple to compute. Gone are capital depreciation schedules, investment tax credits and the like. Businesses would be taxed on total revenues less expenditures for goods and services, labor, equipment and land. Interest would not be deductible from taxable revenues because it is part of the return to invested capital.
The Armey plan would save businesses time and effort but would not necessarily reduce their taxes. Indeed, otherwise healthy businesses that carry heavy debts -- airlines, for example -- may find themselves in deep financial trouble because they could no longer deduct interest from taxable income. By the same token, businesses that own large amounts of relatively new equipment when the flat tax takes effect would lose the right to deduct depreciation still in the pipeline from future tax liability.
"Mr. Armey understands the problem," said his spokesman, Doug Koopman. "We still have to work this out."
But working it out will not be easy. While interest rates should fall as corporate borrowing shrinks and eases the burden on some debt-ridden companies, others may be pressed into bankruptcy to reorganize their finances. The transition for depreciation would be equally problematic. If it is not fully "grandfathered," companies that had invested heavily in new equipment before the tax overhaul would, in effect, be punished for improving productivity.
But if lawmakers attempt to overcome this problem by permitting companies to carry over their current depreciation until it expires, the tax rate needed to collect the same revenue as today's system would have to be considerably higher than Mr. Armey is advertising.
To be fair to companies that invested in good faith under the current system and still allow the tax authorities to meet the revenue target would require a four percentage point increase in the 17 percent rate originally proposed, Roger Brinner, the executive director of DRI/McGraw-Hill, estimated.
"Transition," concluded Bill Gale, an economist at the Brookings Institution in Washington, "is the Achilles heel of radical tax reform."
 
The National Sales Tax
 Replacing the income tax with a point-of-sale national tax would seemingly be the simplest of all possible reforms. Under the retail sales levy sketched by Stephen Moore, an economist at the Cato Institute, business-to-business sales would be exempt; only goods and services for final consumption would be taxed -- at an 18 percent rate. The tax would be rebated on exports, much the way European countries rebate their "value-added" taxes, in a bid to help make American producers more competitive overseas. And the collection could be turned over to the states, nearly all of which already have sales taxes.
But many of the same transition problems as with the flat tax would arise, and no one can predict what the impact of adding such a hefty extra tab to every purchase would do to America's consumption-driven economy. Even Mr. Moore, while insisting that the enforcement problems would be "no worse than the problems of collecting corporate income taxes," acknowledges that a combination of Federal, state and local sales tax that might easily exceed 30 percent could present strong incentives to cheat.
And then there is the question of whether the sales tax would actually deliver on its promises.
One limit is conceptual. Rebates of taxes would not help exporters as a group, argued Paul Krugman, an economist at Stanford University, because the dollar would probably rise in value enough to cancel out much of the competitive advantage conferred by the tax break. The equation would be altered only if private savings increase substantially, allowing the export of economic resources that had previously been used for domestic consumption.
Another limit is political. An economically neutral sales tax would need to cover such goods and services as food, medical care, advertising and rent that today go largely untaxed. The legislative process could make mincemeat of the best-laid plans of economic theorists.
"The real test of tax reform," said Mr. Gale of Brookings, "is not what goes into the political meat grinder but what comes out."
A third stricture is economic. The retail sales tax, like other consumption taxes, is supposed to increase savings. But Eric Engen, an economist at the Federal Reserve Board, estimates that a pure consumption tax would increase savings by only 10 percent, far less than its boosters hope to achieve.
 
The U.S.A. Tax
 The Unlimited Savings Allowance tax is a hybrid consumption tax whose main selling points are the added incentive to thrift and its attempt to maintain the current modest rich-pay-more progressivity of the tax system. While the tax on individuals is no simpler than the current income tax, the tax on business is straightforward.
Businesses would pay an 11 percent European-style "value-added" tax collected at each stage of production. Wages and salaries would not be deductible expenses, nor would interest paid on borrowed capital. Like a national sales tax, the value-added tax would be rebated on exports.
Unlike any of the other proposals, the U.S.A. business tax would permit a dollar-for-dollar tax credit for Social Security and Medicare levies as part of a broader effort to integrate the payroll tax into a single system. That would remove one significant disincentive to hire workers, particularly lower wage workers.
One strength of the U.S.A. tax is that it pays attention to the problems of moving from one system to another. For instance, the U.S.A. tax grandfathers depreciation of investments made before the new system goes into effect.
And unlike the flat tax and the national sales tax, the U.S.A. tax attempts to avoid widening the gap between the rich and everyone else in American society. Overall, Mr. Gale said, "the U.S.A. tax is at least as progressive as the current income tax."
 PETER PASSELL

HEADLINE: SPENDING IT: OFF THE SHELF;
Searching for the Union Label In the Ideas of Workplace Books

BYLINE: By BARBARA PRESLEY NOBLE 

 BODY:
YOU know you've either sold out or crashed through the envelope of middle age when you plan to spend Labor Day fixing posole for a crowd of country-house guests. Forget planting yourself in front of the stereo to listen over and over, in the manner of a "Louie, Louie" marathon, to Pete Seeger singing "Union Maid" ("There once was a union maid, who never was afraid, of goons and ginks and the company finks and the deputy sheriffs who made the raid . . .") and "Talking Union" ("Take it easy boys, but take it"), occasionally throwing in the Marianne Faithfull cover of John Lennon's "Working Class Hero."
There are signs of life at the A.F.L.-C.I.O. There are unions attracting new members, especially in service industries that organized labor has traditionally ignored. There are young people drawn to careers as organizers. But even an optimist would be strained to say the movement is as robust as the lyrics to "Talking Union" or "Union Maid." 
 For more evidence, check the business book lists of publishers. Labor, per se, barely exists except at stalwarts like New York-based Basic Books, where Steven Fraser, author of a biography of the union leader Sidney Hillman, is an editor, and specialty academic houses like the ILR Press, the publishing arm of the School of Industrial and Labor Relations at Cornell University.
To see the light of print, a book about working conditions must fall under the rubric of "work," not labor. But so-called workplace books are more likely to offer ways to come to terms with the brave new employment arena than to challenge the status quo.
Among the current crop is solace for employees who have survived the latest management fads ("Our Emperors Have No Clothes," Alan Weiss). There is also guidance for breaking patterns that can affect work relationships ("Your Boss Is Not Your Mother," by Brian DesRoches); a plan to help crack the whip over the heads of workers ("The Invisible Assembly Line: Boosting White-Collar Productivity," by Daniel Stamp), and advice for the new, zero-mobility job market ("Beat the Odds: Career Buoyancy Tactics for Today's Turbulent Job Market," by Martin Yate).
One of the hottest new categories is counsel on how to keep yourself and others from going "postal" on the job ("Anger at Work" by Hendrie Weisinger and "Problem People at Work" by Marilyn Wheeler).
There is also an apocalyptic genre, which predicts huge structural change in the organization of work, and ranges from the quickly readable ("The End of Work" by Jeremy Rifkin) to the thoughtful and highly readable ("The Jobless Future," by William DiFazio and Stanley Aronowitz). The books in this genre give no comfort to anyone who likes to have a grip on the future. What we don't see are militant titles like "The Scales Fell From My Eyes: How the Middle Class Broke the Bonds of False Consciousness and Embraced Unionism."
Well, no matter. In bad times, it's best to hunker down to the basics, a course that may be followed painlessly with two new atlases of the American economy. "The New Field Guide to the U.S. Economy" (New Press, $12.95), by Nancy Folbre and the gang at the Center for Popular Economics, takes a broad, left-of-center view of the numbers necessary to understand the current state of the American economy. Ms. Folbre and crew include charts on the concentration of wealth, corporate political donations and the gap between worker pay and chief executive compensation, along with more familiar data on the flattening of wages, the decline of health care coverage and the declining participation of males in the labor force. The authors work hard not to sound too passionate, but the numbers speak for themselves.
In "The New Illustrated Guide to the American Economy" (AEI Press, $14.95), Herbert Stein and Murray Foss of the right-of-center Enterprise Institute offer a more traditional vision of the economy. Though the numbers aren't strictly comparable with those of Ms. Folbre's guide, the two books do not conflict in the details. As might be expected from the right brain of the party that has dominated American politics since 1980, the tone of the Stein-Foss book is more measured, less urgent.
The two books even agree at times in interpretation: both regard employee health care benefits as a government subsidy for some citizens at the expense of others.
These are possibly not the sort of books that most people will want to plunge into on the long last weekend of summer. We plan to curl up with something with a little more zing, a little more a la recherche du temps perdu: Edmund Wilson's "To the Finland Station." O.K., so maybe the revolution didn't work out, but at least we'll know what is to be done until the posole is ready.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: RED HOOK;
Is B.I.D. Plan One Too Many?

BYLINE: By MICHAEL COOPER 

 BODY:
Wally Shapiro, who has run a Red Hook warehouse for 41 years, supports a plan to create a business improvement district that would levy fees on businesses to pay for private security, sanitation and marketing. "The B.I.D. would give us services the city is supposed to supply, but doesn't have money to adequately provide," he said as he walked past the stacks of carpets, tungsten and potpourri he stores.
Damian Lubrano, who has watched the staff of his Barge Autobody shop on Coffey Street dwindle to 6 from 22, questioned what he would get for his money. "We have a good Sanitation Department and a good Police Department and they have always worked with us," said Mr. Lubrano, who was born and raised in Red Hook. "What business owner wants a new tax?" 
 The plan for a Red Hook Business Improvement District has exposed tensions between businesses and residents over how to share their isolated peninsula on the far side of the Gowanus Expressway.
It is not the only plan in the works for Red Hook. Noting that the neighborhood's population fell to 11,000 from 21,000 since 1950 as it lost waterfront jobs and industries, Community Board 6 released a broad urban renewal plan last year calling for new housing, a new high school, a waterfront museum and other economic development.
While the two plans are not mutually exclusive, disputes have arisen between businesses and residents over the sites of truck routes, new housing and the new high school. The City Planning Commission, which received the urban renewal plan enthusiastically this year, delayed its vote to give businesses a chance to weigh in on the proposals.
"I think a lot of people would like the businesses to go away and leave them with a nice waterfront community without trucks, without workmen sitting outside eating lunch," said Bette Stoltz, the executive director of the South Brooklyn Development Corporation, a business group that created the B.I.D. proposal with a grant from the state's Urban Development Corporation. "They would rather have an espresso place than a ball-bearing manufacturer."
Unlike many of the city's 33 business improvement districts, the one in Red Hook would focus on industrial businesses like manufacturers, warehouses, bakeries and distributors. A main retail strip, along Van Brunt Street, would be excluded. Ms. Stoltz said that stores there were reluctant to join the district and that many would have trouble paying the fee.
Supporters of both plans have held several meetings this summer to try to resolve their differences. "In a general sense, the plan and the B.I.D. are complementary documents," said Craig Hammerman, the district manager for Community Board 6. "They seek to accomplish the same goal: a stronger community, one that would be less impacted by a national recession." M.C.
 
BUDGET
A B.I.D.'s Bottom Line
 
The proposed Business Improvement District for Red Hook would include approximately 230 industrial businesses. Each would be assessed dues based on the size and value of its properties. This is what the dues would go toward:
Security $68,250 (increase private security patrol to 84 hours/week from 44)
Administration $52,100 (salary for 3 part-time staff members to run district and write grant proposals)
Sanitation and Maintenance $37,500 (clean illegally dumped trash, remove graffiti)
Marketing and Promotion $35,400 (banners, landscaped public spaces and brochures)
Contingency $16,750 (miscellaneous expenses and to cover members behind in their dues)
Total $210,000
(Source: South Brooklyn Local Development Corp.)

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MIDTOWN;
The Next Wave In Mega-Retail: The Global Deli

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT

 BODY:
Sooner or later, it was bound to happen.
First came the invasion by the big suburban-style retailers like Home Depot, Toys 'R' Us, Pathmark, Bradlees, Staples, Herman's, Crate and Barrel, Tops, Sports Authority and Bed, Bath and Beyond. 
 Now comes the ultimate New York response. The mega-deli.
It runs a full city block -- enter on 34th Street and exit on 33d, if you wish. To tickle the taste buds of a gorgeous mosaic, its menu has a global stretch from pizza to fried plantains to sushi.
Formally known as Penn Plaza Deli and Restaurant, it opened in May in a vacant bank office on the east side of Eighth Avenue, opposite Penn Station and the main post office.
Unlike its claustrophobic ancestors with cramped aisles and cluttered shelves, the mega-deli has 6,000 square feet spacious aisles, multiple serving stations, wood and tile decor, piped-in music and large television sets. A blocklong counter with stools and adjacent tables seat 100.
"The variety is incredible, from Mongolian barbecue to whatever speciality you want," said David Morrison, who works nearby in publishing and comes for lunch.
Open 24 hours a day, Penn Plaza Deli has 50 workers and was two years in the planning, said Suk Hun Chung, its president. The site was picked for the nearby office buildings, 34th Street retail corridor and hub of commuter rail, subway and bus lines. Most customers are local workers, travelers and shoppers. Mr. Chung hopes for a boost when Kmart opens a store down the block on 34th.
The owners expanded on their experience at other delis to create the new format, said Chung Hoon Shin, the manager. He described the concept: "Have the best food and the biggest place. We have everything so you don't have to go to a lot of different places."
About the only customer they don't cater to is the indecisive diner, for whom the mega-deli would be tormenting. A ham and cheese sandwich or Japanese udon noodles? Maybe the Cajun grilled chicken, the smoked shrimp and crab salad, the rotisserie chicken or the ribs? There are separate stands for sushi, the charcoal grill, the big Mongolian cooking drum and the pastries, among other choices.Prices are moderate: $1.50 for a slice of pizza and daily lunch specials for $4 and $5.
The owners say business has been slow to build. But a sampling of customers gave positive reviews. "I love it," said Frank Jenkins of White Plains, who works in the insurance business. "I get off the train every morning and have breakfast here."
Larry Krizan, an economic development consultant from Albany waiting for an Amtrak train, wandered in for a snack.. "It's like everything in New York," he said. "It's big and busy and has lots of interesting choices." BRUCE LAMBERT

GRAPHIC: Photo: "We have everything," says Chung Hoon Shin, manager of the Penn Plaza Deli. (Ruby Washington/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: NEW YORKERS & CO.;
Of Industrial Things Past

BYLINE: By SARAH JAY 

 BODY:
BEFORE the coffee bars had spread to Bedford Avenue, before the artists had assembled their lofts and the musicians their recording studios, even before the Poles had founded their restaurants and the Italians their groceries -- before all that, there was industry in Williamsburg: metal spinners and bottling factories, food distributors and trucking companies.
Now, entire blocks of that industrial village stand barren and silent. Time stands still as a stone. 
 It is a stark and lonely landscape of broken images. A smokeless smokestack rising into the sky like a monument to itself. A fence dividing nothing from nothing. A steel girder protruding from a second floor window, testament to the pre-elevator era when hoisting was accomplished with ropes and pulleys and muscles. Two steps descending to a plot of shattered earth, with a pair of Corinthian columns supporting sooty air, a modern-day Roman ruin.
These are relics of an age when the whine and whir of factories filled the streets. And while commerce is far from dead, it has slowed considerably since its heyday in the 1950's. From 1969 to 1991, overall industrial employment fell by nearly two-thirds. Between 1989 and 1991, East Williamsburg alone suffered the loss of two-fifths of its trucking and warehouse jobs, two-thirds of car repair jobs and almost a quarter of its metal fabrication plant jobs.
It didn't help that most industrial buildings in Williamsburg were two-or-more stories high at a time when most businesses were seeking one-level, horizontally arranged structures. Or that manufacturers and distributors who like to be near interstate highways felt that the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway, one of the oldest access highways in the country, was not up to the task. "Difficulty negotiating the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway is a disincentive to locating industrial businesses in Brooklyn," said Eric Kober, a city planning official.
There are hints of a slight revival, he said, as solid waste companies consider setting up plants. Already, down by the once-open waterfront, a recycling warehouse now looms.
And the landscape continues to change. An abandoned gas station anchored to a triangular island disappears one day, nothing left but its gutted signpost. No one seems to have noticed or cared.

HEADLINE: Companies Merge; Families Break Up

BYLINE: By Lester C. Thurow; Lester C. Thurow is a professor of economics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

 BODY:
No country without a revolution or a military defeat and subsequent occupation has ever experienced such a sharp a shift in the distribution of earnings as America has in the last generation. At no other time have median wages of American men fallen for more than two decades. Never before have a majority of American workers suffered real wage reductions while the per capita domestic product was advancing.
 So on Labor Day this year, as with a lot of Labor Days, most laborers don't have a lot to celebrate. The median real wage for full-time male workers has fallen from $34,048 in 1973 to $30,407 in 1993. 
 Wages of white men are falling slightly faster than those of black men, and the young have been clobbered: wages are down 25 percent for men 25 to 34 years of age. Median wages for women didn't start to fall until 1989, but are now falling for every group except college-educated women. The pace of decline seems to have doubled in 1994 and early 1995.
 The tide rose (the real per capita gross domestic product went up 29 percent between 1973 and 1993), but 80 percent of the boats sank. Among men, the top 20 percent of the labor force has been winning all of the country's wage increases for more than two decades.
 Adding to the frustrations, the old remedy for lower wages -- more education -- no longer works. True, wages of males with only a high-school education are falling faster than the pay of those with college degrees. But investing in a college education doesn't get one off the down escalator and onto an up escalator -- it merely slows one's descent.
 No one knows exactly how much of the decline can be traced to any particular cause, but we do know the set of causes that has been responsible.
 New production and distribution technologies require a much better-educated work force. If decisions are to be pushed down the corporate hierarchy, those at lower levels have to have skills and competency beyond what was required in the past.
 With our global economy, where anything can be made anywhere and sold everywhere, the supply of cheap, often well-educated labor in the third world is having a big effect on first-world wages. One month's wages for a Seattle software engineer gets the same company an equally good engineer in Bangalor, India, for a year. Ten million immigrants entered the United States during the last decade, competing for jobs and lowering wages.
 American companies are moving production overseas, using new technology to replace workers, engaging in mega-mergers such as this week's Chase-Chemical deal, and otherwise downsizing. Each year more than a half-million good jobs are eliminated by the nation's most prestigious companies. More new jobs are being generated in the service sector, but they come with lower wages and fewer fringe benefits.
 With the death of Communism and, later, market socialism as economic alternatives, capitalists have been able to employ more ruthless approaches to getting maximum profits without worrying about political pressure. "Survival of the fittest" capitalism is on the march.
 What economists call "efficiency wages" (a company paying higher salaries than the minimum it needs to pay, so that it gets a skilled, cooperative, loyal work force) are disappearing to be replaced by a different form of motivation -- the fear of losing one's job.
 Falling real wages have put the traditional American family into play, as the one-earner middle-class family becomes extinct. With children needing ever-more-costly educations for ever-longer periods of time, the cost of supporting a family is rising sharply just as earnings plunge.
 Thirty-two percent of all men between 25 and 34 years of age earn less than the amount necessary to keep a family of four above the poverty line. Mothers have to work longer hours if the family is to have its old standard of living.
 Children exist but no one takes care of them. Parents are spending 40 percent less time with their children than they did 30 years ago. More than two million children under the age of 13 have no adult supervision either before or after school. Paying for day care would use up all or most of a mother's wages.
 In the agricultural era, children had real economic value at a very early age, especially during planting and harvesting time. Parents knew that their children were their only pension system. For both parents and children the family was the social welfare net. One supported the family, and left it only reluctantly, since it was difficult to survive without it.
 Using the language of capitalism in today's economy, children have shifted from being "profit centers" to being "cost centers." To support them, parents have to be willing to make large economic sacrifices. Men have a strong economic incentive to bail out of family responsibilities since when they do so their real standard of living rises 73 percent -- although that of the family left behind falls 42 percent.
 Whether it is fathering a family without being willing to be a father, whether it is divorce and being unwilling to pay alimony or child support, or whether it is being an immigrant from the third world and after a time failing to send payments to the family back home, men all around the world are opting out. (The Japanese seems to be the only exception.)
 If mothers were willing to bail out, they too could have a higher standard of living. Often children would have a higher standard of living in foster care.
 People support the family less because it is now much less necessary to their personal economic survival. People do not work as a family. Often they seldom see each other, given conflicting work and education schedules. Students who use college loans owe their parents less. Living thousands of miles apart, families lose track of one another. The family is no longer the social welfare system when one is disabled, old or sick, and it will not resume these duties even if the state were to withdraw.
 The traditional family is being destroyed not by misguided social welfare programs coming from Washington (although there are some Government initiatives that have undermined family structure) but by a modern economic system that is not congruent with "family values."
 Beside falling real wages, America's other economic problems pale into insignificance. The remedies lie in major public and private investments in research and development and in creating skilled workers to insure that tomorrow's high-wage, brain-power industries generate much of their employment in the United States.
 Yet if one looks at the weak policy proposals of both Democrats and Republicans, "it is a tale, told by an idiot, full of sound and fury, signifying nothing."

HEADLINE: Word for Word / Military School;
Going Back to College To Study War Some More

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
AS thousands of students across the country get ready to return to school this week, thousands of the military's best and brightest are setting aside their fighter jets and battle tanks and hitting the books too. They're going to war college.
 The services run well-known undergraduate schools, like West Point, which provide about 15 percent of their newly minted officers. But the Pentagon also operates postgraduate schools for officers from eager young captains to battle-hardened colonels. 
 A soldier's performance in battle or in command is still crucial for winning promotions. But ever since Gen. Colin L. Powell, as Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, put more emphasis on interservice war planning and operations, one of the hottest tickets for up-and-coming admirals and generals is at one of these military graduate schools.
 What are they learning? The following is a sampling from current course catalogues. ERIC SCHMITT
 
 
National War College, Washington, D.C.
 
Command Decision: Civilian Leadership in War -- Explores the nature of the personal relationships established between modern political leaders and their military lieutenants and the effect these relationships have had on the use of military power. Beginning with the American Civil War, students examine several such relationships to include (among others): Abraham Lincoln and U. S. Grant, Winston Churchill and Alan Brooke, and George Bush and Colin Powell.
 
Human Behavior in War and Combat -- Exposes students to some of the historically based literature on what motivates, for better or worse, human beings in war. Course materials and seminar discussions focus on the face of war and battle from the strategic to the tactical level to give an appreciation of the difficulty of both waging war and motivating individuals in combat.
 
 
Marine Corps Command and Staff College, Quantico, Va.
 
Civil War Week -- This course examines the national and military strategies of the North and South, and explores the strategic objectives of both belligerents. The focus is on leadership and command, while examining how operational and tactical commanders attempted to achieve their objectives. Highlighting the week are staff visits to Chancellorsville and Gettysburg.
 
Operations Other Than War -- The most likely form of military force commitment over the next decade. The course focuses upon the operational categories of operations other than war: insurgency/counterinsurgency, terrorism, peace missions and peacetime contingency operations.
 
 
Air War College, Montgomery, Ala.
 
Command and Conscience -- In a prudent and practical manner, this course will examine a variety of topics of immediate professional concern to the commander. How does today's commander, for example, resolve the tension inherent in the occasional clash of command responsibility and ethical imperative? To whom or to what does the leader owe the highest loyalty? To his superior? To the Constitution? To his religious/philosophical judgments? Which has priority, mission or men? If integrity is, as it must be, the heart of the officer corps, it must first be examined before it can be assimilated. This course inquires into the nature of military integrity.
 
United States-Russian Relations in the Post-Cold War Era -- The United States and Russia have come full circle from hostile superpower rivals and adversaries to professed "partners" and even "friends." Several issues of contention still remain: NATO expansion, Russian activity in neighboring Soviet successor states, crisis in the former Yugoslavia, the Middle East and North Korea. It is still uncertain whether Russia will continue on a course of democratization, privatization and a pro-Western tradition. The course will examine the evolution of the United States-Russian relations focusing on traditional security issues, including arms control, proliferation and regional conflict, as well as a range of other areas presenting new opportunities and challenges in the post-Cold War era (economics and investment, space).
 
 
Army War College, Carlisle Barracks, Pa.
 
Creative Thinking -- This course is designed to provide a greater understanding of creative thinking and the creative process. The course will consist of a series of progressively more challenging projects designed to demonstrate and exercise various aspects of, and barriers to, problem-solving.
 
Political Violence & Terrorism: The Democratic Response -- This course analyzes how various societies respond to the diversity of challenges posed to democratic values, procedures and institutions by political violence and terrorism.
 
Computers for Colonels -- This course will expose students to current MS-DOS desktop computer instruction and provide general instruction in computer fundamentals. The student will become comfortable with computer hardware and will be exposed to practical exercises in modifications to secondary storage, expansion card installation and configuration of peripheral devices.
 
The American Way of War -- The course will treat America's wars and warriors from Bunker Hill to Desert Storm. Emphasis will be on how Americans have fought their wars, but the following will not be ignored: how and why the resort to war was adopted, the raising of forces and reactions to the effects of war.
 
 
Naval War College, Newport, R.I.
 
Ocean Laws and Policy for the Operational Commander -- This course focuses on the legal and policy environment in which the naval commander must operate at sea. It is designed to enable the student to better understand the legal and policy foundations upon which operational orders emanating from the National Command Authorities are premised. The navigation and overflight articles of the 1982 United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea, including those pertaining to innocent passage in the territorial sea and transit passage in international straits and archipelagic sea lanes, will be examined.
 
Faith and Force: Religion, War and Peace -- Religious beliefs affect our attitudes toward the world and our actions during times of crisis. This course focuses on the three great monotheistic religions of the Western world: Judaism, Islam and Christianity, as their teachings bear on such issues as war and peace, church and state, land and power.
 
Financial Planning for the Military Executive -- The senior military executive is often called upon to counsel subordinates on personal financial problems. Additionally, the senior executive must efficiently plan his own financial affairs as the demands of the job normally allow little time for personal business. The senior officer, however, rarely has the background or experience to accomplish these tasks. This survey course will cover the basic elements of financial planning for use by the individual and in counseling others.
