SECTION: Section 4; Page 3; Column 1; Week in Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1334 words

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Their Eyes on Labor's Shrinking Prize

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
LABOR is back in Labor Day. Two Irish-Americans, both balding and born in the Bronx, both veteran colleagues of New York's labor wars, are out on the hustings, leafletting and glad-handing, and this weekend, they're all over the airwaves.
 John J. Sweeney, 61, and Thomas R. Donahue, 67, are dueling for the presidency of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., and they are making quite a spectacle for an institution that normally abhors disclosure of internal dissent. Since its formation 40 years ago, its presidents always ran unopposed and were elected by acclamation. 
 "What we have for the first time in my professional lifetime of 25 years," said Richard W. Hurd, director of labor studies at Cornell University, "is a real open debate about the role of unions. It means that the defenders of the status quo no longer control the labor movement."

 
 
Loyal Lieutenant
 Not that unions wanted this. The last president brought it on, inadvertently. Lane Kirkland, 73 years old and president for 16 years, had intended to run for another two years. But Mr. Kirkland had become a symbol and, to his detractors, an agent, of labor's decline. Presidents of 11 of the federation's 80 member unions, including the richest and biggest, urged Mr. Donahue, Mr. Kirkland's loyal lieutenant throughout the 16 years as secretary-treasurer, to take him on.
 When Mr. Donahue demurred, the mutineers promised another challenger, and Mr. Kirkland gave up, retiring in August. Mr. Donahue was elected to fill out the last months of Mr. Kirkland's term and jumped into the campaign for the Oct. 26 election.
 But by then the mutineers had massed behind Mr. Sweeney, whose big Service Employees International Union is one of few that have managed to prosper and grow throughout the labor movement's decline.
 Both combatants say they hope the campaign might stir interest in the artifact that in the era of Samuel Gompers, Walter Reuther and John L. Lewis was known as Big Labor.
 After decades of withering decline that unions blamed on Republican lawmakers and anti-union businesses, the unions are allowing that they brought a lot of their misery upon themselves.
 Many need look no farther than their own members, like those in Decatur, Ill., America's most strike-bound city. The auto workers are striking the Caterpillar plant, the rubber workers are striking the Bridgestone-Firestone tire plant, and the paper workers have been locked out of the A.E. Staley corn sweetener plant. Many have been out for more than two years.
 Many of labor's hardest-won rights -- to reclaim a job after a strike, to a 40-hour, five-day week, to company-paid health benefits, even to a living wage -- are in jeopardy there. And management victories there would surely reinforce management everywhere. But strikers complain that members of nonstriking unions are crossing picket lines to help management keep managing.
 They complain, too, that they're running out of money. David Watts, leader of the Staley workers, whose union is among the poorest, says each worker is collecting only $60 a week in strike benefits. He says they lost their health benefits days after the lockout began.
 "We need maximum help right now," Mr. Watts says. "I am disgruntled by the bureaucracy of the A.F.L.-C.I.O."
 Unions these days fight just to hold onto what they've got. The great workplace gains of the last 100 years have been under assault since the 1960's, and with a vengeance since the start of the 1980's. "If you're not making dust," said Ron Carey, the former Long Island UPS driver who is president of the Teamsters, "You're eating it."
 In other times like these, unions made dust. Industry is swimming in profits. In a new report, the pro-union Economic Policy Institute says that corporate profits last year were the highest in 25 years and are looking even fatter this year. But the institute reports that the median wage of men has fallen one percent a year for the last six, and that women's wages have begun to slip, too.
 So where do the profits go? The institute says more and more are going to industry's stockholders. Stephen Roach, an economist at Morgan Stanley in New York, says that a lot are going into investment in industry to make it more efficient, and that wage increases should soon follow. Business Week magazine says more are going to management. It says company chief executives now earn 53 times as much as a factory worker. In 1980 they earned 42 times as much.
 To make matters worse, according to a study by Claudia Goldin, an economist at Harvard, the gap between the best paid workers and the worst, which unions helped close, "has come full circle to what it was more than a half century ago."
 Since unions haven't been able to stop those trends, workers wonder, why join them? And they don't.
 About a quarter of all workers in the private sector belonged to unions in the 1950's. Today 11 percent belong, or no more, proportionately, than in the 1930's. When public employees, who have had growing union membership, are counted in, the total rises only to 15.5 percent of the nation's work force.

 
 
Merger Fever
 And while total union membership has registered some recent small gains -- amounting to about 3 percent over the last two years -- these have not kept pace with the growth in employment.
 It took a while, but these changes have begun to haunt the House of Labor. Proud old unions are seeking strength in a wave of mergers. Among them, the Steelworkers agreed this summer to take over the Rubberworkers and then agreed to join the Auto Workers and Machinists to form a two-million-member goliath. The Ladies' Garment Workers and the Amalgamated Clothing and Textile Workers have just joined forces, and the Communications Workers are taking over the Newspaper Guild.
 But in themselves, mergers will have little effect on the operation of the federation and its 35-member, policy-making executive council, which takes positions on issues before Congress. It has been on the losing side of nearly every political battle, like its campaigns to stop the North American Free Trade Agreement and to forbid industry to fire workers who strike.
 Republican ascendancy is one reason, but another is that Labor, for the first time in its history, has no face. Unlike his immediate predecessor, George Meany, whose ferocious image became etched onto television screens as firmly as Mickey Mantle's, Mr. Kirkland distrusted the media. In periodic polls, the most recent in July, the union-funded Labor Research Association in New York found that 95 to 97 percent of the public could not name the person whose position made him the No. 1 spokesman for the nation's wage earners.
New voices that might ask uncomfortable questions within the council are rare because the union presidents tend to hold office until death or retirement. The federation's newspaper rarely reports bad news about a union, like corruption or the loss of a strike, or it scratches for silver lining in bad news, like the annual Government reports on membership figures.

 
 
Who's to Recruit?
 But in the last couple of years, a few presidents had begun to ask about the decline of member unions. One reason is that as industrial companies shrink, there's no one for the one-industry unions to recruit, and they dedicate their resources to protecting the jobs and pensions of their veteran workers.
 This campaign, however, has forced the labor movement to acknowledge a failure to tap the sole obvious source of new strength -- new members.
 "My brothers and sisters," Mr. Sweeney said in a speech before the race began, "the problem with the labor movement is that we are irrelevant to the vast majority of unorganized workers in the country."
 In the campaign, both he and Mr. Donahue are promising huge, ten-fold increases in spending to train organizers to recruit those workers. So no matter who wins, the election no one wanted is already bearing fruit.

HEADLINE: The Nation;
You're Fired! (But Your Stock Is Way Up)

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
NOTHING succeeds like unemployment, at least when it comes to stock prices.
 Chemical Bank and Chase Manhattan Bank got together last week and decided that they would slash employment by 12,000 people, leaving them with 63,000 employees. 
 That news, of 16 percent fewer workers, sent the value of the two bank stocks up 11 percent. Put those figures on a graph, draw a line, and the implication is obvious: Each canned worker increases the combined market value of the two banks' shares by about $216,000. If the banks got rid of all their workers, their share prices would go up another 53 percent.
 That is absurd, of course. Somebody has to be around to put cash in the ATM machines. And, besides, there were plenty of other reasons for Wall Street to love the Chemical-Chase deal, not least among them the expectation -- denied by the banks -- that the increased market power would enable the bank to charge higher fees for some services.
 Still, firing workers remains popular among investors. Wall Street is quite happy to believe that almost any big company can make more money by firing people.
 Times Mirror stock, for example, is up 69 percent since Mark Willes was hired away from General Mills to become president and chief executive of the media company, while the overall stock market, as measured by the Standard & Poor's 500, is up just 10 percent. Mr. Willes' principal contribution since then has been close down one money-losing newspaper -- New York Newsday -- and to cut back employment at other newspapers.
 All this seems reasonable, to some extent. Wall Street loves higher profits, and they can come in one of two ways. It's nice if a company can manage to sell more of whatever it makes, or sell it for higher prices. But almost every company is constantly trying to do that, and it is not easy for a chief executive to order an increase in revenues. It is a lot easier to command a reduction in costs, by slashing the payroll.
 It even works in high technology companies. Stratus Computer said last week that it will get rid of 500 workers, or 18 percent of its workforce. The stock of Stratus, which makes computers that are supposed to never crash, rose 9 percent.
 One might think that if too many companies do that, it would be bad for the overall economy, and thus for the stock market. After all, all those fired people are consumers, and they probably are going to buy less if their incomes vanish. But the economy has created enough jobs to offset that effect, at least until now.
 In fact, the overall stock market seems to do best when economic growth is far from robust. Last year, 1994, was the market's worst year since 1990, but it was the economy's best year, as measured by job growth, since 1984. Growth is much slower this year, and stocks are up a lot more. As it happens, 1984 was also a poor year for the stock market, even as it was a great year for jobs and economic growth.
 "There is competition for capital between the real economy and the financial economy," says David Shulman, the chief equity strategist at Salomon Brothers. The real economy includes everything from new machinery and new manufacturing plants to new homes, but it does not include the financial markets. So when the real economy slows down -- when people aren't shelling out money to buy things -- the money thus freed up can slosh over into the financial economy, driving up prices for stocks and bonds.
 This is not really a new phenomenon. In the 1920's, to recall one painful example, economic growth had slowed, and parts of the country had run into economic problems, long before the stock market peaked in 1929. Some people figured there was no need to build a new plant when you could get rich a lot faster by simply speculating in stocks.
 There is, of course, a fine line there. Investors do not want a recession, let alone a depression, and if it was widely believed that one was coming, the stock market probably would suffer.
 But slow growth, with the expectation of faster growth someday, seems to be just what Wall Street wants. So for now, at least, there is no quicker way to get your stock price up than to announce plans to fire a lot of workers.

HEADLINE: Retailers Say the Special Olympics Was a Bust

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: NEW HAVEN, Sept. 2

 BODY:
For weeks, Chris Papanikolau prepared his Athenian Diner for the Special Olympics, one of the biggest events ever to take place in this city. Organizers predicted that the games would bring Connecticut hundreds of thousands of visitors and millions of dollars in spending, and Mr. Papanikolau expected business to boom. He increased staff and bought a month's worth of food.
But as the swarms of athletes, coaches, volunteers and spectators descended on the city for nine days in July, Mr. Papanikolau watched busloads of people speed by his restaurant without stopping. Business plummeted by one third. 
 Mr. Papanikolau and other retailers argue that the Special Olympics was an economic bust. Instead of attracting business, they say, it frightened customers away.
"They scared people with the advertising about traffic," Mr. Papanikolau said. "A lot of people took off. And then they were running buses which were picking people up and driving them straight to the games. People could never get out of the bus to spend money in the city."
Arthur R. Henick, the games' spokesman, said that "unsubstantiated fears" of traffic problems might have frightened spectators away.
When asked about the economic impact on the city, he said, "We always said that it would be a statewide impact."
New Haven, one of America's poorest cities, spent three years preparing to organize the games, the largest athletic event in the world in 1995. Local businesses donated between $5 million and $6 million to the event, which brought 7,000 mentally retarded athletes from 143 nations to compete in New Haven and six other communities. Banners festooned the city, and about 62,000 volunteers turned out.
Mr. Papanikolau's complaints are reflected in a survey by a city business newspaper, Business New Haven. The publication did a random poll of 82 retail businesses near sites where events were held and reported that 57 percent of respondents experienced a decline in business during the games. Fewer than 13 percent reported any substantial increase.
New Haven's Mayor, John DeStefano Jr., blamed a "fax-induced hysteria" for the low turnout, but said the rumor mill had inflated some retailers' expectations well beyond reason.

HEADLINE: Clinton Sees Lessons in the Postwar Era

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: HONOLULU, Sept. 2

 BODY:
Fifty years after Japan formally surrendered to Gen. Douglas MacArthur on the deck of the battleship Missouri, President Clinton today urged Americans to regain the sense of national purpose that propelled the United States into its postwar period of economic expansion and world leadership.
On the second day of ceremonies marking the end of World War II, Mr. Clinton heralded the valor of the Americans who fought in what he called the "most destructive conflict in all human history." But he also touched on the ways that the war and the helping hand the nation extended to returning veterans changed the social and economic fabric of the country. 
 "In order to succeed, we must remain true to the spirit of that brilliant time," the President said in an address at the National Cemetery of the Pacific, where small American flags marked the graves of more than 33,000 servicemen and servicewomen.
"A time when our people cared for each other and sacrificed for others," he continued, "when our nation stood united in purpose and mighty in spirit as never before. A time when Americans forged the strength of their diversity into a community for victory and progress."
Mr. Clinton recalled how the G.I. Bill of Rights gave returning veterans previously unimagined access to post-secondary education and allowed them to buy their first homes. He spoke of how 16 million women kept the nation's assembly lines working in the war and how afterward the United States "would begin to integrate this extraordinary force into the economy and into our nation's military."
And he remembered the black Americans who had fought for their country in segregated units until, slowly after the war, the country recognized that "if people of different races could serve as brothers abroad in uniform, they could surely live as neighbors at home."
"You understood that you could together make the world a better place, and that you could not permit America again to withdraw from the world," Mr. Clinton said to the thousands of elderly veterans who had come to Hawaii to remember the war in a weekend of pageantry and commemoration.
Mr. Clinton's remarks were solemn and nonpolitical. But they laid the groundwork for a theme that he is expected to flesh out in California on Monday and Tuesday and throughout the fall's budget battles with the Republican Congress: a call for the country not to abandon programs like education and training that lend support to Americans as the G.I. Bill once did.
Mr. Clinton, the first President since World War II not to have served in the military, paid tribute to the five Presidents before him who served in the Pacific. He noted in particular President John F. Kennedy, who served on an ill-fated PT-109, and President George Bush, who was shot down as a pilot.
After he spoke, Mr. Clinton, visibly moved, laid a wreath at the cemetery accompanied by two veterans of World War II's Pacific campaign: 82-year-old Robert Allen, who was a prisoner of war in Manila, and 72-year-old Alfred Los Banos, who lost his legs during the Korean War and came to the President's side in a wheelchair.
The three remained together as the war dead were honored with a 21-gun salute, a rendition of taps and a fly-over. "There's so many people that I went to war with," Mr. Los Banos said afterward, "and as taps play, it's something that I look back on and I'm thankful to them for giving us this day. So when taps play, I always cry."
Later Mr. Clinton visited PearlHarbor, where 3,600 American servicemen were killed or wounded in the Japanese attack on Dec. 7, 1941. He visited the U.S.S. Carl Vinson and the U.S.S. Arizona Memorial.
Mr. Clinton did not serve in Vietnam, a war he opposed. And his relationship with the military has often been strained by his lack of service and by his move early in his Administration to allow homosexuals to serve in the armed forces. But his reception from veterans and active-duty personnel this weekend has been warm.
Today the President lingered at the National Cemetery long after the ceremonies had ended, shaking hands with elderly veterans, hugging one, signing an autograph for another. And on Friday, after reviewing troops at Wheeler Army Airfield, Mr. Clinton mingled with about 500 of the men and women who had marched, even posing for pictures wearing a camouflage fatigue hat. At several points the troops broke out in cheers. Someone even shouted, "Four more years."

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Clinton and two veterans, Robert Allen, left, and Alfred Los Banos, yesterday in Honolulu during ceremonies marking the end of World War II. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: A Powerful Fund-Raiser Who Also Oversees State Contracts

BYLINE: By JOE SEXTON and DOUGLAS FRANTZ 

 BODY:
Charles A. Gargano is hardly a household name to the average New Yorker. But to state business leaders who gave millions of dollars in political contributions to elect George E. Pataki Governor last fall and to many of those same business people now seeking multimillion-dollar contracts from the Pataki administration, Charles A. Gargano is a crucial name to know.
Mr. Gargano is the colorful, sometimes controversial, immensely successful chief fund-raiser who collected $14.5 million to finance Mr. Pataki's upset victory last fall and who continues to be chairman of $1,000-a-plate Republican fund-raising events. 
 Mr. Gargano is also the Commissioner of the State Department of Economic Development, a job he has held since February that gives him enormous leeway in handing out millions of dollars worth of contracts to businesses across New York.
At times these last seven months, it has been hard to know which Charles Gargano was sitting at the table -- the one asking state business leaders for money or the one giving them the taxpayers' money.
Mr. Gargano is not accused of violating any laws. But his dual roles raise ethical questions that even the Governor has acknowledged in recent weeks that his administration must handle more carefully.
A case in point is an intimate dinner that the Governor and Mr. Gargano attended on June 23 at the home of a construction company president in Lloyd Harbor on the prosperous North Shore of Long Island.
Officials of the company, A-J Contracting, make no bones about it: they have no state contracts, but they would be interested in landing some state business. And six days after that dinner, the company president, Jerome A. Gannon; his wife; the company's chairman, Charles Uribe, and Mr. Uribe's two daughters sent checks to Mr. Pataki's personal campaign fund totaling $100,000.
Then there is the case of the Pyramid Companies, a developer that had been trying unsuccessfully for 10 years to build a $250 million shopping center in Rockland County. In March, after a personal appeal from the Governor, a company executive made a $25,000 contribution to the Republican State Committee. Two months later, Mr. Gargano made phone calls to two state agencies and suddenly, the delays disappeared. A month after Mr. Gargano's helpful calls, the developer contributed $3,000 to Mr. Pataki.
For Mr. Pataki's young administration, where to draw the line on using officials to collect campaign money has been a nagging problem.
Last month, the Governor had to acknowledge that a mistake had been made when a member of the State Racing and Wagering Board and the chairman of New York Power Authority served as chairmen for a fund-raising day at Saratoga Race Course that collected contributions from people who do business with those offices. Mr. Pataki said it would not happen again.
In an interview, Mr. Gargano, who made his fortune in the private sector as a construction company executive, said he would follow Mr. Pataki's new edict and avoid serving on formal fund-raising committees in the future. But he defended his right to keep raising money for the Governor and others in an unofficial way.
"It is preposterous to suggest that I should relinquish all my rights as an American citizen to participate in the democratic system," he said. "As long as I know in my heart and my head that I'm fine about what I'm doing, that's fine with me."
In the Pyramid case, he said, he was unaware of the contribution and defended his intervention as a legitimate attempt to eliminate "bureaucratic red tape." As for the A-J Contracting dinner at Mr. Gannon's home, he sees no problem. "For me, there is no conflict," he said. "I was invited as a guest, and I went to the dinner, and that was it. Plain and simple. I've known Jerry Gannon for many years. He's a member of my country club."
Mr. Pataki also sees nothing improper in Mr. Gargano's activities. "No man in his position has been asked to step aside from activities that are proper, including attending fund-raising parties," said Mr. Pataki's spokeswoman, Zenia Mucha.
 
Ethical Mine Field Over Fund Raising
 In many ways, Mr. Gargano personifies the ethical mine field confronting government officials who are involved in fund-raising. Those concerns were raised seven months ago at his confirmation hearing for the posts of Economic Development Commissioner and chairman of the Urban Development Corporation. The agencies provide assistance to businesses in a variety of forms, like contracts for training workers and loans and grants for expansion. Democrats expressed fear that Mr. Gargano might turn his $163 million budget into a political "slush fund."
If Mr. Gargano were a Federal official, he would not be permitted to do what he does, but state administrators are not prohibited from raising campaign funds. Mr. Gargano's activities have veered into the gray area where the interests of governing overlap with the realities of political finance.
Since taking his state posts, he has attended numerous parties similar to the A-J dinner as well as taken a more public role on occasion. In April, he was honorary chairman of a fund-raising dinner kicking off the Republican Presidential campaign of Senator Bob Dole of Kansas. On June 1, he was honorary chairman of a $1,000-a-plate dinner at the Sheraton New York for the Republican State Committee. Both events were attended by people who could benefit by decisions made by Mr. Gargano.
Mr. Gargano, 60, describes himself as a Brooklyn boy who made good through hard work and innovation in the unglamorous world of heavy construction. Trained as an engineer, he spent most of his career at J. D. Posillico Inc., helping the company become a dominant construction company on Long Island.
But his rise to prominence has not been without brushes with scandal. In 1981, the Suffolk County District Attorney filed a $270 million civil racketeering suit accusing Posillico and five other companies of bid rigging on a $1 billion sewer project. Mr. Gargano's actions were not called into question. The company eventually settled by paying $315,000 without admitting wrongdoing.
Mr. Gargano emerged unscathed and went on to a career in government and political fund-raising.
When asked the key to Mr. Gargano's legendary success in raising money, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, his political patron, said: "People like him. He likes people. Charlie is a very warm person. And very effective." This success has fueled Mr. Gargano's aspirations. He has said privately he would like to be Commerce Secretary if Mr. Dole becomes President.
 
Under the Influence Of Senator D'Amato
 Mr. Gargano's government career began in 1981, when he was appointed a deputy administrator in the Federal Department of Transportation. It was in Washington that he came under the patronage of Mr. D'Amato, who had just been elected to the Senate.
When Mr. Gargano left the post in 1983, Mr. D'Amato helped him become New York director of the campaign to re-elect President Reagan. In 1986, Mr. Gargano helped raise a then-record in campaign funds for Mr. D'Amato's re-election. And in 1988, he was appointed Ambassador to Trinidad and Tobago.
Mr. Gargano is proud of his diplomatic stint and still likes to be called Mr. Ambassador. But two people who served with him in the State Department said he seemed to spend about half his time on Long Island, an assertion Mr. Gargano denies.
What is undisputed is that he was not in Trinidad at the critical moment of his tenure. On July 27, 1990, when rebels seized the Prime Minister and killed more than 20 people in a coup attempt, Mr. Gargano was on Long Island. He said he had just started a vacation and returned to Trinidad immediately. The two officials, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said that the Embassy did not know where to locate Mr. Gargano initially and that he was summoned to Washington and criticized when discovered at home.
Even while Ambassador, Mr. Gargano raised funds for a political committee with ties to Mr. D'Amato, according to state election records. Political fund-raising by Ambassadors, which is now barred, was then permitted on a limited basis.
After resigning as Ambassador in 1991, Mr. Gargano described himself as semiretired and resumed fund-raising for Senator D'Amato. Last year, when Mr. D'Amato threw his support to Mr. Pataki in the Governor's race, Mr. Gargano became the Republican candidate's finance chief, part of a contingent of D'Amato loyalists who helped defeat Gov. Mario M. Cuomo.
After the election, Mr. Pataki appointed Mr. Gargano to his state economic posts, despite Democratic complaints that his past as a fund-raiser would lead to conflicts with his state job. Those complaints seemed to come true when Mr. Gargano intervened for Pyramid.
For almost 10 years, the Syracuse-based developer had fought objections from local and state officials over its plans to build a huge mall near two landfills in West Nyack. There were environmental and traffic concerns.
In March, Pyramid's senior partner, Robert J. Congel, received a phone call from Mr. Pataki, soliciting contributions to pay for advertisements supporting his budget proposals in the General Assembly. Mr. Congel sent a check for $25,000 to the Republican State Committee.
Ms. Mucha, the Governor's spokeswoman, acknowledged that Mr. Pataki sought the money, but she said he never discussed Mr. Congel's project.
On May 2, Mr. Congel visited Mr. Gargano to discuss delays on the shopping center. Before the developer left his office, Mr. Gargano had telephoned John Daly, Commissioner of the State Transportation Department, and officials at the State Department of Environmental Conservation on his behalf. By May 17, the obstacles had disappeared, and Pyramid broke ground by June.
Mr. Congel said the $25,000 contribution and Mr. Gargano's intervention were "purely coincidental."
For his part, Mr. Gargano said: "This wasn't directly for Pyramid or Congel. This was for economic development. I was on the other side and was frustrated so many times with state, county and other agencies holding up projects and costing the business person a tremendous amount of money for no good reason except lazy bureaucrats using regulations."
Officials at the other state agencies said that Mr. Gargano had urged them to act quickly but that Pyramid received no special treatment.
"The danger here is that the 'for sale' sign is being distributed in New York Government," said State Senator Richard A. Dollinger, a Rochester Democrat.
 
Major Shareholder In Casino Operator
 Mr. Gargano has a mixed record as a businessman. He traded blocks of stock daily that often exceeded $250,000 while an Ambassador and said he wound up losing money. Some of his many real estate deals have been winners, but court records contain judgments against Mr. Gargano and various partners in other transactions.
One investment that raises questions about the intersection of his business interests with his state job is Mr. Gargano's position as a major stockholder and director of the Alpha Hospitality Corporation, a small New York City company that operates a riverboat casino on the Mississippi Gulf Coast.
Alpha -- whose revenue and stock price have plummeted in recent months -- has been trying to negotiate a deal with the St. Regis Mohawks to open a casino on their reservation upstate. Three tribal leaders say that, when the tribe resisted, company representatives suggested that Mr. Gargano could help the Mohawks in a land dispute with the state.
"They were throwing around Charles Gargano's name," said John Loran, the head chief until June and an opponent of the Alpha proposal.
Stanley S. Tollman, Alpha's chairman, said Mr. Gargano's name may have come up in talks, but he denied using it and said he had not sought Mr. Gargano's help.
With the General Assembly approving the first step toward legalized gambling in New York, Mr. Gargano's stock and seat on the Alpha board pose potential new conflicts. He said selling the stock, for which he paid nearly $1 million, would make him lose half his investment. But he said he had asked his lawyers to draw up papers so he could resign from the board.
"Not that I am concerned about having a conflict, personally," Mr. Gargano said. "It's just so it doesn't give the appearance of one."

HEADLINE: Sacred to Russians, Not to U.S. Budget Cutters

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: KHUZHIR, Russia

 BODY:
Arching out of the vivid, azure blue of Lake Baikal, where it laps up against Olkhon Island, is one of Buddhism's holiest sites, the Shaman Rock. It is revered by the native Buryat people, and the Dalai Lama has also prayed here.
In the Soviet period, when most native traditions and religion itself were considered anti-state activities, the authorities built a dock directly under the Shaman Rock, where ships unloaded supplies and diesel oil for this small town of 1,500 and picked up the garbage. 
 Filthy, unsightly and sacrilegious, the dock has now been dismantled and the sacred beach, on this sacred lake, is being cleared of oil and rubbish. There is a project to beautify the walk to the rock for tourists, and to let them share in the terasun ceremony, involving a healthy gulp of the slightly psychedelic fermented sheep's whey. The whey also seems to go well with the local fish, a sort of salmon trout called omul.
The town is getting a simple system of wind and solar power that will give the residents more electricity than they have ever had before, and make regional plans to run an electric cable through the lake and a surrounding national park unnecessary.
The townspeople are preparing a zoning plan; moving the single gasoline station from the shore, where it pollutes protected waters; extending a log-built cultural museum; restoring native flora and fauna to the island and growing vegetables better suited to the climate.
All this is being done with the aid of the American taxpayer, through the United States Agency for International Development, in a project to promote sustainable and environmentally sound economic progress. The money involved on Olkhon, with its seven sub-projects, is less than $150,000 a year over four years.
But if Congress goes ahead with suggested cuts in foreign aid, it is projects like these, on Baikal, that are most likely to disappear.
Olkhon is the largest of 12 pilot projects in the Baikal region designed and run by the nonprofit Ecologically Sustainable Development Inc., or E.S.D., under a four-year, $3 million contract with the Agency for International Development that began in 1993. The larger effort is to create a sensible plan for resource and land management all around Lake Baikal, the world's largest lake by volume and source of about 20 percent of the earth's fresh water. The lake harbors more than 1,800 unique species of plant and animal life that have developed in its 25-million-year history.
Russians consider Lake Baikal the clear, clean heart of the world, an environmental treasure. But it is at risk from uncontrolled development in a period of weak government, official corruption and wild capitalism.
Working with local people and three regional Russian authorities, a task of great political delicacy, the E.S.D. project is seeking to preserve one of the world's wonders while trying to better the lives of the people here. The plan is to provide new ideas and training in activities that earn income and produce tax revenue, and then get out of the way. Ideally, these pilot projects will be copied elsewhere with local resources, directed by those Russians now working for and with E.S.D.
The group's other projects include developing "ecotourism," to allow visitors to experience Baikal without harming it, reclaiming polluted land, and restarting reindeer herding in mountainous areas, the indigenous form of animal husbandry. The Soviets made this impossible by their artificial demands for meat and milk quotas, which required herds of cows that had to live in the already overburdened valleys.
These efforts are an important sign of American interest in provincial Russia -- outside the rampant corruption and glitz of Moscow -- where the country's future is being formed. Even provincial government leaders grudgingly acknowledge the usefulness of the projects.
To George D. Davis, a forester and former executive director of the Wilderness Society who runs Ecologically Sustainable Development, the possibility that Congress will cut financing for the program is a stupid tragedy.
Mr. Davis, 52, developed a similar program in his native Adirondacks region in New York State and won a five-year MacArthur Foundation Fellowship in 1989 for his work. That allowed him to establish Ecologically Sustainable Development and feed his family.
After considerable publicity for wasting aid money in the first years of America's effort to assist Russia, the Agency for International Development has tried to do better lately at spending its smaller budget -- $250 million in fiscal year 1995.
But Mr. Davis has been told by agency administrators that prospective cuts -- the House wants to limit agency aid in Russia to $195 million -- will kill his kind of program, while big construction projects with huge overhead and little local training continue, because the cost of administering small projects is almost the same as that for large ones.
"We could produce bigger and more expensive projects," Mr. Davis said with annoyance. "But those are the ones that locals can't duplicate, because they can't afford it."
The American Ambassador to Russia, Thomas R. Pickering, who came to see the projects here, thinks that Congress will cut 20 to 30 percent from last year's aid totals. "We'll fight to keep every cent," he told somber E.S.D. workers.
Washington had planned to phase out most aid to Russia by 1998 in any case, Mr. Pickering said, "so if it phases out sooner, we can adjust." Still, he said, environmental aid should be part of a "base program" of aid to Russia even after 1998, and "Baikal is the epitome of Russia's environmental concerns."
Ecologically Sustainable Development employs just 11 full-time workers based in Elizabethtown, N.Y., has about 30 part-time employees and calls on 100 expert volunteers, but more to the point, it has 229 Russian employees, mostly part-time. The Americans pay Russian salaries the first year, but the contribution declines to a third over the four years of the grant, forcing local projects to become self-sustaining or die.
Along Baikal, the main environmental issues are air and water pollution from Soviet-built factories, like two big paper and pulp plants that pour 8.8 million cubic feet of waste water a day into the lake, and the rise in the level of the lake of a yard since the 1960's, largely due to a dam for a power plant. The extra water is the rough equivalent of 15 trillion two-liter bottles of Coca-Cola and has changed the lake in ways still little understood. The combination threatens Baikal, which has a 380-year recycling period, compared with about 10 years, for instance, in the Great Lakes.
Already, the number of omul in the lake is dropping, and not from overfishing, so that the one factory on Olkhon Island, a fish cannery that employs 200 people, mostly processes imported herring rather than omul.
The director of the factory, Vladimir Vinsak, 39, criticized Mr. Davis for not concentrating his efforts on fish. "Projects for energy and tourism are fine, but this island lives on fish," Mr. Vinsak said. "It's like the tail without the head. I'd like the program to begin with water and water resources."
Still, he said, the United States Government and Mr. Davis are helping where the Russian and regional governments had done little but talk. "It's right for the American side, but unpleasant for the Russian side," Mr. Vinsak said. "We're afraid only that the Government could stop any aid from foreign governments."
At Bolshoye Goloustnoye, a small, dying town of some 700 people, unemployment is about 70 percent, said Lyudmila Sagayeva, the Ecologically Sustainable Development director there. The village was founded 300 years ago to exploit the timbered hills, but the establishment of a national park in 1987 stopped logging and nearly killed the town.
Half the rough wooden buildings are empty; there has been a lot of vandalism and "a loss of hope," Mrs. Sagayeva said. The idea is to encourage employment in ecotourism, based on the lake, the older landmarks of the town and the surrounding forest.
Ecologically Sustainable Development has employed residents to reclaim the town's beach, which was used for many years as a log storage area. Others work with park rangers, some of them American volunteers, to build "interpretive" walking trails in the forest, with guides to its flora and fauna. A collapsing, austere wooden church from the last century is being restored, and the schoolhouse is now lighted with solar energy. Mrs. Sagayeva believes that the projects have restored a small measure of hope to the town.
"What pleases me most is the degree to which the Russians on the ground are running things," Mr. Davis said. "Not all 12 projects will go forward and spawn 800 others, but at least some will go on without any government assistance."
Sergei Shapkhayev, director of the Buryat/Baikal land-use program and head of the Buryat Republic's small Green Party, fears for Baikal generally. In the next century, he said, Baikal will be pressed hard by Russia's need for development and revenue, especially from unexploited forests and waters, and by its new, market-era chaos and corruption. Still, he said, the programs here can "try to soften the damage done to Lake Baikal and lay the foundation for better protection in the future."
With the free market, there are more competing companies and more lavish corruption. With privatization, there is by definition less Government control over land, which can now be bought and sold.
The influx of new people "with a totally different attitude toward nature" has diluted the ethnic balance of the lake's indigenous peoples, who "over the centuries have worked out ethical standards toward the land, and who are more conservative in their technologies," Mr. Shapkhayev said.
As an indication of these problems, a local boat owner spoke privately of a company he had formed with employees of the Interior Ministry and the Federal Security Service, the domestic side of the former K.G.B., to buy lakefront land for a resort. The owner, perhaps boasting, said money was little problem, given the income from sales of diverted oil and timber, but he was looking for a Western partner.
Told of this conversation, Mr. Davis sighed. "This kind of work has such incredible peaks and valleys, sometimes twice a day," he said. "But there's so much need out there, and frankly, the cost is so low."

HEADLINE: Audit Agency For Mexico Is Proposed

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Sept. 2

 BODY:
Promising to scale back his own authority and confront rampant Government corruption, President Ernesto Zedillo says he will support the creation of an independent agency to oversee public spending.
In his first state of the nation address, Mr. Zedillo said on Friday that he would soon propose a constitutional amendment to establish a comptroller's office under the legislature with an autonomous professional staff and wide powers to audit the federal Government. 
 "It would be a decisive step in the fight against impunity and corruption," he said. "We will be able to make great strides toward giving new life to the checks and balances among the branches of government."
Mr. Zedillo offered few details of the plan, and no explanation about what would become of the federal ministry that now audits the Government, largely in secret. But in a speech that otherwise generated little enthusiasm even among his supporters, the initiative was for the most part well received.
Answering critics who say he has done little to fulfill his promises to strengthen law enforcement, Mr. Zedillo outlined a new public security system that would coordinate the efforts of federal, state and local police forces. He also said he would propose organized crime legislation to use against drug traffickers.
Law enforcement officials have long complained that Mexican laws are inadequate in prosecuting the increasingly sophisticated mafias that transship most of South America's cocaine into the United States. In only a handful of cases have major drug traffickers been given long-term prison sentences, and even then, several have been able to maintain their criminal organizations while imprisoned.
After nine months in office and more than eight months of an economic crisis that has shattered his campaign promises of a new prosperity, Mr. Zedillo vowed again that the worst of Mexicans' suffering was behind them.
Many economists remain skeptical. But Mr. Zedillo promised that even though the economy had shrunk 5.8 percent in the first half of this year, it would begin to grow modestly in the coming months.
Government spending for the year is projected to be 10 percent less than in 1994, he said. But three-fourths of that money is to be disbursed in the second half of the year.
Along with increasing stability in the financial markets, a drop in interest rates and the sale of some Government assets, Mr. Zedillo said, the surge in spending should make for a noticeable recovery this year.
As much as its substance, his address was noted for its style.
In the past, the annual presidential report before the Congress was a spectacle of executive power. After speeches that droned on for hours and were sifted endlessly for clues to the leader's thinking, the President rode through the streets of Mexico City in an open car, showering in confetti distributed by his aides. Then he spent hours in what was called the hand-kissing: a greeting for hundreds of bureaucrats, diplomats and politicians.
Mr. Zedillo, who stands in most public opinion polls as the least popular new leader in Mexican memory, did not ask anyone to kiss his hand. He rode to Congress in a bus, and his aides considered it a victory that opposition legislators did not try to shout him down from the floor.
The text of the President's remarks was scrutinized as ever. The term he used most frequently, newspapers reported this morning, was "crisis."

LENGTH: 732 words

HEADLINE: The Sad State of the Parties

 BODY:
Thomas Kean's decision not to run for the New Jersey Senate seat being vacated by Bill Bradley is at once sad and instructive. It is sad because he was a useful Republican Governor and in all likelihood would have been a useful senator. It is instructive for what it reveals about Washington, about the disheveled condition of our two major political parties and about the ferment affecting American politics in general.
 Mr. Kean's reasons for not seeking membership in the Senate broadly parallel Mr. Bradley's reasons for leaving it. Mr. Bradley said he was "disgusted with the politics of both parties" and their inability to find common ground. Mr. Kean, rather more passionately, said that Washington in general and Congress in particular had become uncivil, "mean-spirited" and relentlessly inhospitable to moderate voices like his own. 
 He did not single out his own party for special blame. But it was clear from the context of his remarks that the city he wants no part of is a city over which Bill and Hillary Clinton preside in theory and the Republicans preside in fact. These are people, he said, "who don't want my views down there" and who would quickly find ways to "marginalize" him with minor committee assignments.
 This is not without irony. Mr. Kean was a party star of the 1980's. He was much admired even among conservative Reaganites who did not always share his views, and he was chosen to deliver the keynote address at the Republican convention that nominated George Bush in 1988. But by the next convention in 1992, a gathering dominated by the likes of Pat Buchanan, he had become a forlorn figure, trying without success to persuade the platform writers to include a few compassionate words in their plank on abortion. The right wing marginalized him then and there.
 Mr. Kean's decision signals unrest in the Republican Party in much the same way that Mr. Bradley's decision reaffirms the decay of the Democratic Party. The Democrats' problems have been widely chronicled. Three House Democrats and one Senate Democrat have already defected to the Republicans this year and more departures are anticipated. Bill Clinton has not greatly altered Washington's cozy culture or transformed his party. Even so, the President still has a reasonable chance for re-election, especially if Republican primary voters and convention delegates indulge their taste for candidates with the meanest vocabularies and narrowest positions.
 Despite its numerical strength, the G.O.P.'s Congressional wing does not seem particularly content, perhaps because of intramural strife over who ought to be President. Right-wing partisans are sore because Newt Gingrich and Bob Dole did not deliver on term limits and a balanced budget amendment. Silenced or disaffected moderates like Mr. Kean, meanwhile, are aghast at Mr. Gingrich's wholesale rejection of the Federal Government's historic obligation to provide relief for the poor and remedies for the shortcomings of the marketplace.
 In short, neither party can count on that vast, testy body of middle-class voters who tend to decide elections and who, right now, are worried about their economic prospects, cynical about sound-bite politics and frustrated with the ineffectiveness of government. They are madder at the Democrats than the Republicans, but their disgust is generalized enough to feed continual yearnings for a third party. That is why Ross Perot is still around, why Lowell Weicker thinks about the White House, why pundits (and Colin Powell's book publicists) keep touting a Powell candidacy.
 Kenneth Duberstein, Ronald Reagan's chief of staff, put the matter this way in an interview with a Times reporter: "People are clicking off politicians. In '92 they clicked off George Bush. In '94 they said they were clicking off Bill Clinton and the Democrats. The next channel we may turn to is an independent channel."
 Political parties, of course, are capable of astonishing change. Both parties have endured cycles of disintegration and resurrection. Perhaps the Republicans will find some way to include their Tom Keans. Perhaps the Democrats can build a strong new house. But there is no evidence that either is really trying. All we are hearing -- as Congress and the President return to work -- is that clicking sound, the sound of people channel-surfing through the political landscape.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
The View From Taipei

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

DATELINE: TAIPEI, Taiwan

 BODY:
The crisis simmering today between Taiwan and mainland China has replaced Korea as the powder keg voted most-likely-to-explode by Asian leaders. The man holding the fuse is Lee Teng-hui, President of Taiwan, father of Taiwan's democratic reform movement and the only person in the world whose receipt of an alumni award plaque from Cornell University almost triggered a war across the Straits of Taiwan.
 President Lee invited me over for an interview Friday in his office in downtown Taipei. The conversation left me both reassured and disquieted. It was reassuring because Mr. Lee is an unlikely fuse. A sober, owlish man, who weighed his words carefully, he evinced a strong grasp of the red lines that constrict Taiwan's behavior -- red lines he is certainly trying to push out but won't likely breach. It was disquieting, though, because, as he made clear, this is a plastic moment in relations between China and Taiwan, a time when new pressures are bending old constraints to the breaking point. The potential for miscalculation by Beijing or Taipei is enormous. 
 With that in mind, Mr. Lee, speaking in Mandarin, made two overarching points: First, he is not seeking internationally recognized independence for Taiwan -- a move that could easily spark a war. He is, though, seeking a higher profile for Taiwan on the world stage -- one that would be commensurate with its economic clout and freewheeling democracy but would still fall short of formal independence. Second, he signaled a strong desire to step back from the brink and resume the quiet dialogue that had been going on between Beijing and Taipei since 1987, but was broken off by Beijing in the wake of Mr. Lee's June visit to Cornell.
 Asked what his long-term goal was, Mr. Lee said: "It has always been and remains unification with the mainland. But unification must be achieved only when we can guarantee democracy, freedom and prosperity for all the peoples of a unified China. I have never talked about independence or permanent separation for Taiwan."
 The President suggested that in seeking a higher profile for Taiwan in international forums he was only acting on his people's natural desire for recognition of their remarkable achievements on this once-barren island, which is now one of the richest countries in the world. Thumping the coffee table, he fumed: "This is a democratic country. I have to do what people want me to do. This is a different world now. People cannot live in isolation. Any leader here must give some expression to the dignity of the country. We don't think this impairs our future goal of reunification."
 What would he tell President Clinton if he got the chance?
 "I would tell him I welcome the resumption of normal relations between the U.S. and Beijing, but no one should be allowed to manipulate this rapprochement against us. It is important not to make a strategic error and treat Taiwan as a province of [Communist China]. The U.S. still has the responsibility and the obligation to protect Taiwan based on the spirit of the Taiwan Relations Act."
 But the Taiwanese President went out of his way to extend an olive branch to China's President, Jiang Zemin, suggesting that their two countries settle their differences quietly, without the U.S.
 "You can see that they have criticized me so violently and I have not said a word," said Mr. Lee, speaking of Beijing's virulent propaganda attacks on him, which have only made him more popular at home. "I can assure you that we are going to deal with this problem with patience, reason and calm, not emotion. We are opening the door and waiting for them to come back to the table."
 Mr. Lee expressed his hope for a summit between himself and Mr. Jiang, and he seemed to hint that he might be flexible on the venue. Until now Taiwan has insisted on an international setting, while Beijing wants it in China.
 "Perhaps after the power shifting is sorted out in Beijing and the elections are over in Taiwan [in March] we could all consider the possibility of a meeting again," said Mr. Lee. "Jiang Zemin's position is very delicate right now, and so we need to wait for a quiet moment when things might be less sensitive."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL: NOTEBOOK;
Selig's Job Title Could Change Because of Brewers' Problems

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
Cal Ripken won't be the only baseball figure to surpass a milestone this week. On Tuesday, the day Ripken ties Lou Gehrig's consecutive-game record, Bud Selig will surpass the tenure his predecessor, Fay Vincent, held as commissioner.
Selig is technically acting commissioner, but there's nothing make-believe about his $1.25 million salary, the highest ever paid a commissioner. 
 Vincent, who was elected commissioner after Bart Giamatti died, served 1,091 days, resigning under fire Sept. 7, 1992. Two days later, Selig was elected chairman of Major League Baseball's executive council, meaning he was the man in charge.
Despite some complaints within baseball and in Congress that an owner can't also be the commissioner, Selig has retained the position with firm backing from a vast majority of owners who like his consensus style of running the game (his critics would replace the first 'n' in running with an 'i').
A new commissioner, Selig and his fellow owners have decided, will not be named until they have a new labor agreement with the players. By the time that goal is reached, Selig, who has resisted overtures that he take the job on a permanent basis, may be in position to take it on permanently.
The reason is the sad economic state of his team, the Milwaukee Brewers. They are in serious trouble and will be in worse trouble if the Wisconsin Legislature rejects a plan for a new stadium that is the lifeline to the Brewers' future in Milwaukee.
The Legislature is scheduled to vote on the plan in two weeks. The proposed method of raising funds for the stadium is to increase by a tenth of a cent the sales tax in two counties that would benefit most from a new stadium -- Milwaukee and neighboring Waukesha.
Passage of the controversial plan already was questionable, but Gov. Tommy Thompson, in his zeal to boost the project, might have made chances of adoption worse. Touring the state last Wednesday on a motorcycle, the governor urged listeners at one stop, "All the taxes come from Waukesha and Milwaukee. Stick it to 'em."
His subsequent apologies did not undo the damage. Now it remains to be seen what the Legislature will do.
If the stadium plan fails, Selig will be faced with the very real prospect of taking or selling the Brewers elsewhere, a move the lifetime Milwaukee resident has not wanted to confront. His fellow shareholders have supported Selig's resolve to remain in Milwaukee, but even they may have to succumb to reality.
Selig, at 61 the youngest of the shareholders, owns 25 percent of the club. The rest of the ownership has been described as consisting mainly of people close to or past retirement age.
Lori Uihlein, in her early 70's and the widow of the former president of the Joseph Schlitz Brewing Company, owns 18 percent. Charles Krause, 63, who has a consulting company, owns 20 percent. The Stearns family trust holds 15 percent. Everett Smith, 85, a financial backer of Selig, has an 8.5 percent share. The remaining 14.5 percent is divided among a few other people.
Selig won't talk about the possibility of moving or selling the Brewers. He always has believed in franchise stability, and some owners might cast a dubious eye on his desire to move his team, considering his longtime stance. But he would have strong arguments in support of a transfer: no prospect of a new stadium or increased revenues and the financial losses of recent years.
If that day comes, Selig could relinquish his ownership and his $450,000 salary as president and chief executive officer of the Brewers -- reduced voluntarily from $700,000 -- and remove the "acting" from his other title. His new employers would probably even give him another raise.
 
Members of the Board
 The third anniversary of Fay Vincent's ouster and Bud Selig's succession comes at a time when a major business transaction could bring Vincent back to baseball. He is a member of the board of directors of Time Warner Inc., which is in the process of negotiating the purchase of Turner Broadcasting, which owns the Atlanta Braves.
Turner, who would become vice chairman of Time Warner in the deal, and Vincent would be fellow board members. When Vincent became an embattled commissioner in 1992, Turner assured Vincent that he would support him. When the Braves voted, though, they voted against him.
One theory was that Stan Kasten, the Braves' president, and William Bartholomay, the board chairman, decided on their own to join the oust-Vincent forces. Turner, by that time, had stopped attending owners meetings.
Asked the other day about the vote, Kasten said, "That's not something I care to discuss."
As for the potential change in ownership of the Braves, Selig said: "It's too early to even think about that. I've talked to the Braves people quite a bit, but I don't have a comment because I haven't thought it through."
 
An Open-Checkbook Policy
 Perhaps he just doesn't want to detract from the event that will occur in Baltimore this week, but Peter Angelos, the Orioles' owner, is remarkably low-key about his team's underachieving season. He said "no changes are contemplated" at this moment but added, "That doesn't necessarily mean that won't change at the conclusion of the season."
The prevailing belief in Baltimore is that Angelos will make changes in the front office, replacing General Manager Roland Hemond and his assistant, Frank Robinson. He might have presaged the moves when he talked about "the inadequacies of the bullpen."
"They weren't expected," the owner said, "since the resources for bringing the bullpen up to a higher level were there but not utilized because it was thought the pitchers were there."
Translated, that means money was available to go out and get the best bullpen help available, but the front-office people didn't think such drastic steps would be necessary.
"We had an open checkbook policy; we were looking to win," Angelos said, speaking candidly of his willingness to spend, then explaining: "We have tremendous fan support. The kind of support we're getting, I feel obligated to produce a winner for the fans and I'm prepared to do whatever is necessary to win."
 
Distraction and Disharmony
 As if baseball hadn't done a poor enough job of making fans forget the labor war, some clubs have resurrected replacement baseball. An idea most general managers and managers abhorred when the owners created it last winter, it has cropped up periodically during the season when a club has summoned a replacement player from the minor leagues.
But the practice has reached a new plateau in recent weeks, first when the Houston Astros called up pitcher Craig McMurtry on Aug. 13 and then when the Los Angeles Dodgers promoted Mike Busch last Tuesday.
Some people believe the unwelcomed presence of McMurtry, who during his real career spent a week short of seven years in the majors, helped lead to the Astros' disastrous 11-game losing streak that began Aug. 17. Astros management doesn't believe it, but they'll never know for sure.
The Dodgers' players reacted in a most negative way when Busch arrived. The most startling aspect of the development was the reaction of Dodgers fans. They lustily cheered Busch and repeatedly booed Brett Butler, who served as the players' spokesman in their rejection of a player they called a scab. The Dodgers lost the first two games they played with Busch in their dugout.
"I have no reason to believe that games are won or lost because of the presence of a scab on the team," Gene Orza, the union's associate general counsel, said. "That isn't the issue. That's just a convenient way of avoiding dealing with the merits of the situation."
And the merits are?
"All the people in Los Angeles can simultaneously stand up and cheer for a person," Orza said. "It doesn't make it right. It's not right to step over the backs of strikers to get a job."
Seventeen replacement players have spent time on 11 major league rosters this season. Kansas City and Milwaukee each have used four and nine other teams one each.
The Dodgers' use of Busch indicates a change of philosophy from the team unity the late Walter O'Malley practiced when he owned the club. After four players went against the large majority of Dodgers and voted against a strike authorization in spring training of 1972, O'Malley asked Marvin Miller who they were. Miller declined to say, but O'Malley subsequently learned their identities elsewhere and got rid of all four players.

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS;
Jennifer Manner And Eric Glasgow

 BODY:
Jennifer A. Manner, an associate at the Washington law firm of Akin, Gump, Strauss, Hauer & Feld, and Dr. Eric Glasgow, a National Research Council Fellow at the National Institutes of Health in Bethesda, Md., were married on Wednesday at the Ram's Head Inn on Shelter Island, L.I. Rabbi David Greenberg performed the ceremony.
Ms. Manner, 30, is keeping her name. She graduated from the State University at Albany and received her law degree from New York Law School and a master's degree in international and comparative law from Georgetown University. The bride is a daughter of Joyce and Dr. Maurice Manner of Larchmont, N.Y. Ms. Manner's father is a professor emeritus of business and economics at Marymount College in Tarrytown, N.Y. Her mother retired as a teacher of business education at St. Barnabas High School in the Bronx. 
 Dr. Glasgow, 37, is a molecular geneticist. He graduated from California State University at Northridge and received a Ph.D. in molecular biology from the State University at Stony Brook, L.I. He is a son of Lyle and Myrna Glasgow of West Lake Village, Calif. His father retired as the section chief of reactor operations and development at the Rockwell Corporation, the aerospace company in Canoga Park, Calif.

HEADLINE: U.S. Embargo on Cuba Slows Pace of Reform;
Business Loses Big

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Richard Nuccio, the White House special adviser on Cuba, is dead wrong in stating (front page, Aug. 27) that American businesses are not losing out with respect to investment opportunities in Cuba, as the rest of the world opens its doors to trade and investment with the island nation. 
 Cuba is busy settling its debts and differences with all of Latin America, and has just been admitted to the newly formed Association of Caribbean States, some 15 countries including Haiti, the nations of Central America, Mexico, Colombia and Venezuela that are committed to democratic principles, human rights and expansion of regional trade.
 Anyone visiting Cuba can't fail to notice vastly increased foreign investment in many parts of the economy. Life is still very rough for the average Cuban, but Cuba has definitely hit bottom economically and is moving forward.
 Although committed to Socialist principles, the Cuban Government is ready to do business.
 It is especially noteworthy that Israel, the only country in the world to support the United States embargo, is developing in Cuba what will be the world's largest citrus growing project.
 
THOMAS R. MILLER
Director, Association for Free Trade With Cuba
Oakland, Calif., Aug. 27, 1995

HEADLINE: U.S. Embargo on Cuba Slows Pace of Reform

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 In your Aug. 27 front-page article on United States companies pressing President Clinton to lift the Cuba embargo, Richard Nuccio, the White House special adviser on Cuba, says the embargo is the only pressure that drives Cuba toward economic or political reform. Nothing could be further from the truth: the embargo inhibits economic and political reform. 
 Why haven't the Cuban people risen up against Fidel Castro and demanded political change? Any other government that had overseen such a disastrous collapse of its economy as has occurred in Cuba over the past five years would have been overthrown -- no matter how tight its security system. Cubans have not risen up against Mr. Castro because they are nationalists -- their ire against attempts by the United States Government to dictate Cuba's fate is greater than their unhappiness with their own Government.
 The embargo unites Cubans behind Fidel Castro. And the new legislation proposed by Senator Jesse Helms and Representative Dan Burton to tighten the embargo further merely gives another boost to Mr. Castro's popularity.
 As for economic reforms, they are taking place despite -- not because of -- the embargo. After the collapse of the Soviet bloc, Cuba was forced to open its economy to foreign investment. Instead of encouraging this process, the United States Government tried to thwart it by tightening the embargo in 1992 to include American subsidiaries overseas. Now the Helms-Burton legislation would further punish other countries that trade with Cuba.
 Aside from violating international law and being repudiated by all our allies, the bill defies all logic. You can't cut Cuba off from the world market and then turn around and condemn it for not opening up its economy.
 The Clinton Administration and Congress should be ashamed of their policy on Cuba. It certainly makes no sense for United States business. But more important, it harms the Cuban people by denying them even life-sustaining food and medicine simply because we don't like their Government. While appeals for lifting the embargo on humanitarian grounds have unfortunately fallen on deaf ears, it is to be hoped that appeals by United States businesses will prove more fruitful.
 
MEDEA BENJAMIN
Director, Global Exchange
San Francisco, Aug. 27, 1995

HEADLINE: MEETING OF WOMEN SAYS SURVEILLANCE BY CHINA MUST END

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON 

DATELINE: HUAIROU, China, Sept. 2

 BODY:
With the United Nations Fourth World Conference on Women about to open, leaders of the parallel forum here delivered an ultimatum to their Chinese hosts today, warning that if security forces did not cease their intense surveillance of participants within 24 hours, they could close the forum down.
With nearly 30,000 women from around the world gathered here for a bonanza of networking and workshops, the demand by leaders of the Non-Governmental Organizations Forum on Women intensified a sense of crisis among United Nations and other officials that their long-planned conference could be ruined by unruly hosts. 
 Outrage over pervasive surveillance -- for a fourth day participants complained that they were aggressively filmed, followed and harassed -- came to a boil at a news conference where members of the forum's leadership committee issued their ultimatum.
"If they do not comply, we will go back to our constituencies and ask: Do you want to cancel, do you want to boycott, do you want to riot, or what?" said Salamo Fuliavi, a member of the committee. "If they say 'let's go home,' that's what it means."
Late tonight, the officer in charge of security here denied that the police had followed or conducted surveillance of any participant.
But concern over the often brazenly pushy behavior by security agents was echoed by senior members of the United States delegation to the United Nations conference, including Timothy Wirth, Undersecretary of State for Global Affairs, who said he thought the integrity of the meeting was being threatened.
"If they continue this, they are going to find themselves making the conference extremely difficult," Mr. Wirth said of the Chinese organizers. "They are meeting a lot of frustration and concern from people on how they are handling this."
With Hillary Rodham Clinton scheduled to arrive in Beijing early Tuesday, Mr. Wirth and other members of the United States delegation seemed eager to defuse the crisis. Mrs. Clinton is honorary chairwoman of the American delegation to the United Nations conference, which opens on Monday and runs through Sept. 15.
In Hawaii, Calvin Mitchell, a spokesman for the National Security Council, said White House officials are "obviously following the events carefully" and added, "At this point I am unaware of any change in her schedule."
Mrs. Clinton, who is leaving from Hawaii on Sunday, plans to address the United Nations conference in Beijing on Tuesday, then speak before the forum here later in the day on women's need for better health care, political rights and economic opportunity.
Until today, organizers of the forum, which is to continue until Friday, had tried to play down the practical difficulties they have encountered. Their public turnaround and ultimatum was a remarkable shift toward a head-on confrontation with their Chinese hosts.
Many participants at outdoor workshops held under white canvas tents on the 100-acre site said security agents routinely approached the meetings with video cameras and focused closely on their faces and note pads.
Surveillance was particularly heavy at a workshop this morning where exiled Tibetan women argued with Chinese-sponsored participants from the region over human rights and environmental conditions in Tibet. Other participants said that nearly every workshop they attended was under surveillance and that some meetings at hotels had been disrupted.
"We saw that there was a pattern of surveillance, both here at the workshops and in the hotels," said Irene Santiago, executive director of the forum. "We did not want the whole security apparatus there."
The authorities have sharply cut back transportation to and from the site of the forum in Huairou, which is about 35 miles from Beijing. And today they banned all taxis from the main United Nations conference site at the Asian Games Village in Beijing, a decision one security officer said was an effort to protect delegates from unreliable taxi drivers.
In Huairou, security officers have confiscated videotapes and printed material from workshops, and stopped translations of some speeches that touched on human rights.
Ms. Santiago said these actions clearly violated an agreement signed earlier this year between United Nations and Chinese organizers that specified, among other things, that there be no security presence on the forum site.
But it was not clear what action the leadership committee would take. With many participants no doubt reluctant to abandon the forum, and others exasperated by the behavior of the Chinese agents, Ms. Santiago was careful to say no decision would be made before noon on Sunday, when the committee's 19 members are scheduled to meet.
With a forum so deeply focused on free speech and free movement taking place in a country where political activity is so tightly controlled by Communist Party authorities, such a confrontation was perhaps inevitable.
"The Chinese have to understand that the idea of a U.N. conference is the free flow of ideas," said Melinda Kimble, Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for international organizations.
Yet Chinese leaders are unused to allowing any kind of unscripted political gathering, concerned that open discussion might include direct criticism of Communist Party rule, a point of sensitivity that often seems to verge on paranoia.
The officer in charge of security here, Zhang Kemian, insisted that he had mobilized "a certain number of police officers" to guard against criminals but, in an apparent concession, he said he had reduced the number "now that security has been initially insured."
Mr. Zhang also asked for patience.
"Although Chinese police have accumulated experience in providing security services for large international sports and cultural events, it is the first time for them to cover an event as large as the current one," Mr. Zhang said, according to a report from the New China News Agency.
"It takes time for the police to adapt to the circumstances and improve their mode of work so as better to meet the requirements of large international conferences."
Most participants at the forum seemed eager to concentrate on the issues facing the conference, like violence against women, and expressed frustration with the distraction caused by the security agents.
"It's really ridiculous," said Marilyn Golden, of the Disabled Rights Education and Defense Fund in San Francisco. "But now that we've started to complain about access for the disabled, they've been increasing surveillance on us, too, coming up and taking pictures at our meetings."
Dorothy Q. Thomas, director of the women's rights project for Human Rights Watch, a New York-based group, said a man who appeared to be a security agent leaned over her shoulder to film her notes at a workshop on human rights.
"We want to speak openly with Chinese women about conditions they encounter in this country," said Ms. Thomas. "But in an atmosphere like this, these women are terrified to come forward, and this is happening under the umbrella of the United Nations at a conference on the advancement of women's rights."
Repeating a charge that many other women voiced, Ms. Thomas said conditions at Huairou were the worst she had experienced at any of the many conferences she has attended.
"That the United Nations has allowed this to occur is appalling," she said.
Mr. Wirth, the Undersecretary of State, also laid responsibility for persuading the Chinese to cooperate squarely at the feet of Boutros Boutros-Ghali, the United Nations Secretary General, whose staff announced that he would not attend the conference because he has the flu.
"It's very important that we have the U.N. at the highest level weighing in very heavily," said Mr. Wirth. "It's something that Boutros-Ghali must do with the Chinese."
Mr. Wirth said he had met with Mr. Boutros-Ghali's representative, Ismat Kittani, who said flaws in the agreement over logistics signed between the United Nations and the Chinese had caused the troubles. Efforts to reach Mr. Kittani were unsuccessful.
Mr. Wirth added that he had canceled plans to accompany Mrs. Clinton to Mongolia later in the week because of the likelihood that the conference would require constant, high-level attention.
Many of the men filming and harassing participants wore participants' passes. Ms. Santiago, the forum's executive director, said there was no way to tell how many of the 5,000 registered participants in the forum from China were actually working as security agents.
Another 23,500 participants from overseas have registered for the forum, and about 4,000 journalists are also attending.
Throughout the forum, women expressed frustration with the Chinese hosts.
"As you can see, they are really against human rights," said Afaf Mahfouz, a representative from the Congo. "We want to protect human rights."

CORRECTION-DATE: September 4, 1995, Monday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about the international gathering of women's groups in China misstated in some copies where Calvin Mitchell, a spokesman for the National Security Council, commented on the gathering. Mr. Mitchell was in Hawaii, not Washington.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 2; Money and Business/Financial Desk
