HEADLINE: SPENDING IT;
The Tax Code Heads Into the Operating Room

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

 BODY:
FLAT tax, consumption tax, value-added tax, national sales tax, unlimited savings allowance tax: The jargon is largely new, but the underlying politics are familiar. Many Americans loathe the personal income tax, and influential lawmakers are beating the bushes for a winning replacement.
While President Clinton has yet to offer his own ideas on what may well be a central issue in the 1996 campaign, just about every other important politician in Washington is backing one of the several tax overhaul plans floating around today. 
 These plans, Republican and Democratic alike, share a political imperative: They seek to soothe taxpayer anger by promising to make the tax code both simpler and fairer. But while the leading Democratic plan, sponsored by the House minority leader, Dick Gephardt, would retain the familiar income tax while seeking to simplify it, the three main Republican proposals would go much further, either eliminating the income tax altogether or utterly changing the way the Government collects money from its citizens. And as with most everything in Congress these days, it is the Republicans who are driving the debate.
Though their plans are quite different, they share a central premise: No longer would Americans be taxed on all that they earn -- from work, savings or investments. Instead, they would be taxed only on what they spend, which tends to place a proportionally greater burden on those least able to pay. Each plan's champion predicts lower interest rates and an economic windfall from encouraging Americans to invest more for the future and allowing them to keep more of the extra dollars they could earn by working harder and smarter.
The most visible of the new tax plans -- and the one with the greatest political momentum behind it -- is the flat tax, proposed by Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the House majority leader. The Government would tax salaries and benefits at a single low rate and eliminate all remaining itemized deductions, from mortgage interest to state and local taxes. Interest, dividends and capital gains would be tax free for individuals. After allowing for a generous personal exemption for each taxpayer, Mr. Armey contends that he could replace the current system with a single 20 percent rate, falling to 17 percent after two years. Others argue that the flat rate would have to be higher, at least 21 percent, and perhaps more.
A competing plan offered by Representative William Archer of Texas, the chairman of the tax-writing House Ways and Means Committee and advocated by Senator Richard Lugar, the Indiana Republican who is also a presidential candidate, would replace the income tax completely with a national sales tax, which would probably have to add about 18 percent to the price of all goods and services to collect as much revenue as the current system.
Two Senate barons, Pete Domenici, the New Mexico Republican, and the Georgia Democrat Sam Nunn, are offering yet another alternative. The plan, known as the U.S.A. Tax, would keep the familiar progressively higher step-by-step income tax rates and retain popular deductions for mortgage interest and charitable contributions. But it would provide an unlimited exemption for all savings and add a new limited deduction for outlays on education.
This week, Senator Bob Dole, the leading Republican candidate for President, is expected to join the debate by endorsing the concept of a flat tax, although it is unclear whether he will support any specific plan.
"The general approach now is, 'Don't bother me with the details -- we'll worry about that later,' " explained Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey, a Democrat who was a principal architect of the major 1986 rewrite of the tax code that sharply lowered rates and eliminated many preferences for special interest groups.
The Republicans' proposals, to be sure, would address the public's continuing call for a still-simpler tax system that would eliminate many economic distortions caused by special tax advantages. And that alone should save tens, perhaps hundreds, of billions of dollars now wasted on recordkeeping, accountants and misdirected investments. Just as clearly, though, the plans would dramatically shuffle wealth and privilege in ways certain to delight some and infuriate others.
And those shifts raise troubling questions that many advocates of a thorough tax overhaul skate over lightly:
* Is it possible to reconcile the effort to boost growth and investment -- which inevitably would provide greater direct benefits to those affluent enough to save substantial sums -- with the public demand for fair treatment?
* Would eliminating the deductions for mortgage interest and property taxes -- currently worth more than a $80 billion a year to homeowners -- send the economy reeling into a recession? By one widely circulated estimate, that move alone would wipe out as much as $1.7 trillion in home equity by depressing real estate values on average by 15 percent.
* What would be the impact on consumer spending -- which accounts for more than three-fifths of overall economic activity -- of shifting to a tax system designed to promote savings at the expense of current consumption?
* How would charities, state and local governments, and a host of other entities that have come to depend on tax incentives respond to the loss of those provisions?
* And what would investors do once they could sell their stocks without worrying about capital gains and tax-free municipal bonds would no longer enjoy any tax advantage over Treasury bonds?
None of these questions is easy to answer. Even after decades of experience, there is no consensus among experts about the impact of the current tax system. And that makes sorting out the claims and counter claims of the various proposals all that much harder.
"If you don't know where you've been," says Joel Slemrod, director of the office of policy research at the University of Michigan, "it's hard to figure where you're going."
What follows is a rundown on the three most prominent alternatives to the income tax, each of which has friends in Washington and admirers among economists. None of the proposals is likely to be enacted without substantial modification and nothing is likely to happen until after next year's Presidential election.
 
Flat Tax
 Narrowly defined, this is simply a tax with a single bracket. But since the approach was outlined more than a decade ago by Robert Hall and Alvin Rabushka, economists at the Hoover Institution in Palo Alto, Calif., it has come to mean much more.
Under the plan sponsored by Mr. Armey, all taxes on labor income would be collected from individuals and all taxes on investment income would be paid by businesses. To many economists, the clean division of taxes between individuals and businesses is one of the plan's great virtues. To those who worry more about broad issues of tax equity, though, it is one of its greatest flaws.
The personal income tax would be transformed into a wage tax with absolutely no deductions. Mr. Armey proposed a 17 percent rate, although it questionable whether that would generate as much revenue as he claims. Roger Brinner, the executive director of DRI/McGraw Hill, an economic forecasting group, estimates that a 21 percent rate would be needed to replace the revenues from the current system. The Treasury says the rate might at least temporarily have to be as high as 24 percent.
Not all wages would be taxed. The latest version of the Armey plan calls for a generous untaxed "family allowance," so that a family of four would have to earn at least $31,400 in 1996 to owe any tax at all.
Taxpayers would not keep track of mortgage interest, state and local taxes, charity, medical expenditures or retirement accounts because the deductions would be eliminated. "Hundreds of thousands of pages of tax law, rules, guidelines, and decisions could be ripped up and thrown away," states Raymond Keating, chief economist of the Small Business Survival Foundation.
This would be no small feat. Mr. Slemrod estimates that it now costs 10 cents to collect a dollar through the income tax, a waste of tens of billions of dollars in taxpayers' time and outlays for enforcement.
But any such wholesale elimination of tax deductions would generate powerful political opposition. Costly medical expenses that are uninsured would no longer be deductible. Wealthy philanthropists would no longer see their generosity rewarded. And local politicians would scream about the elimination of the deduction for state and local taxes, which would only add insult to injury to the loss they would suffer from no longer enjoying a tax-free borrowing advantage over Federal Government bonds.
Most important in political terms, the flat tax would almost inevitably cut the value of existing houses, so that its effects would spread far beyond the 30 million homeowners who currently claim the mortgage deduction. DRI/McGraw-Hill, which did research commissioned by the National Association of Realtors, estimated that average home values would drop 12 to 15 percent, even assuming that mortgage interest rates decline by 2 percentage points due to the broader economic effects of the tax change. The plunge would be much steeper if interest rates do not fall as much as predicted.
Advocates of the flat tax maintain that is an exaggeration. And Mr. Armey contends that the long run economic gains from his plan should outweigh any initial decline. "The American dream is not just about owning a home," Mr. Armey said. "It's about getting your kids out of it."
But getting that point across to a vast homeowning middle class woul not be easy.
That's one reason Senator Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania, another Republican Presidential campaigner, has proposed to retain at least a partial deduction for mortgages (only the interest on the first $100,000 would be deductible) and allow for charitable contributions up to $2,500. But those tokens may do little to defuse opposition from real estate agents and charities, while at least partially undermining the appealing simplicity at the heart of Mr. Armey's plan.
 
National Sales Tax
 All Americans understand that a trip to the store usually requires a tithe to the state at the checkout counter. Senator Lugar, as a key element of his Presidential campaign, hopes to exploit that familiarity by dropping the income tax in favor of a national sales tax. And although he has yet to put a formal plan on the table, Senator Lugar has a powerful ally in Mr. Archer, whose committee must originate all tax legislation and who says "the time has come to tear the income tax out by its roots."
The closest thing to a fleshed-out plan comes from Stephen Moore, an economist at the libertarian Cato Institute. He proposes an 18 percent tax on retail sales of all goods and services. To avoid double taxation, purchases by businesses would be exempt -- much as they are today in the states.
To Mr. Moore, the biggest appeal of such an approach is that it would seem to put a stake through the heart of the government agency most Americans cannot escape: the I.R.S. The politics of tax reform is "driven by the civil liberties issue," he said. "Americans want Government out of their lives."
The I.R.S. would be abolished; states would be compensated for collecting the Federal sales tax on top of their own. To help compensate for the fact that sales taxes represent a disproportionate burden on the poor, every American would get an annual $900 check -- equivalent to an exemption for $5,000 of personal expenditures.
The impact of such a sales tax on all consumer goods and services would be almost identical to that of an integrated wage and business flat tax. And all consumption choices -- everything from purchases of food to the services of divorce lawyers -- would be treated identically.
A sales tax would shift the tax burden from the rich to the middle class, since affluent people save a much larger portion of their earnings. But Lawrence Kotlikoff, an economist at Boston University, explains that, at least initially, a new tax on consumption would constitute a big, one-time hit on accumulated wealth.
An easy way to think of it, he suggests, is in terms of purchasing power. An 18 percent sales tax would raise the prices of all final goods and services by 18 percent, and thus reduce the value of accumulated savings when they are spent by 18 percent.
One big catch to any universal sales tax is the practical problem of collecting the money. Imagine a department store selling sweaters for $20, plus 18 percent Federal tax plus 10 percent state and local tax. Then imagine the street peddler outside selling the same sweater without the 28 percent tax. "There is no way you can run a sales tax at that level without draconian enforcement," predicts Mr. Slemrod.
He suggests the obvious fix: a "value added tax" that collects revenue from every transaction in the purchasing chain from seed corn to corn flakes. But the V.A.T., while universally adopted in Europe and relied upon by nearly every advanced industrial state outside the United States, has never enjoyed political support here.
Other pitfalls could doom the sales tax or its value-added variant. It would be difficult to extend sales taxes to traditionally exempt areas such as rent, groceries and medical care. And the sales tax could be pecked to death with small exceptions: Would Congress be willing to tax kidney dialysis machines or Salvation Army uniforms?
 
U.S.A. Tax
 The simplicity and straightforward appeal of the flat tax and the sales tax, if not all their consequences, are obvious. Not so the Unlimited Savings Allowance or U.S.A. tax, a combination of a deductions-loaded personal income tax and a value-added tax collected by business.
But unlike the other radical alternatives to the income tax, it is a full blown legislative proposal, not a gleam in the eye of policy intellectuals. "The U.S.A. Tax is the only tax reform plan that is close to a living, breathing tax code," said Arthur Hall, a senior economist with the Tax Foundation, a conservative research group in Washington.
The U.S.A. tax starts with the familiar personal income tax. Wage and investment income, plus proceeds from insurance and annuities, are taxed at progressive rates ranging from 19 percent to 40 percent.
But the blow is softened by a fat standard exemption and host of new preferences. Not only would the deductions for mortgage interest and charity continue, it would also allow taxpayers to deduct net annual additions to savings accounts, mutual funds and the like. Education expenses could be partially deducted. And once tax liability is figured, taxpayers would get to take a credit equal to their share of the payroll tax for Social Security and Medicare. This effectively lowers the maximum tax rate on wages to 32 percent.
The U.S.A. Tax, while seeking to accomplish the same goal of encouraging thrift and long-term investment, lacks the simplicity of the previous two approaches. Rather than striving for neutrality among expenditures and income classes, it adds a new a preference for education and it taxes the incomes of people earning $500,000 at far higher rates than those earning $50,000. It would require taxpayers to continue to struggle with questions of defining personal income and verifying deductions.
But the U.S.A. tax plan does address an issue untouched by others by effectively eliminating the payroll tax, which many economists believe is a significant deterrent to employing unskilled workers. And it deals directly with the formidable problems of changing from one tax system to another that the other proposals ignore.
But where the flat tax appears to have grassroots appeal and the sales tax offers a direct assault on the I.R.S., the U.S.A. tax, argues Mr. Hall, is an "inside the Beltway" effort that does not enjoy much popular support outside Washington. While it would slaughter few sacred cows, it is also not likely to generate much passion among the tens of millions of Americans who see themselves as victims of the tax code.
 
 
 
Meanwhile, Business as Usual
FOR all the talk on Capitol Hill about simplifying taxes, Congress has done it again: passed a law that adds yet another line to Form 1040.
Drafts of the 1995 tax forms show a Line 53 in the "other taxes" section. It covers an obligation even the Internal Revenue Service acknowledges you'll probably ignore -- unless you're a politician or a prospect for the Cabinet.
After all those unpleasant surprises about the nannies and maids of public figures, including Gov. Pete Wilson of California and two of President Clinton's nominees for Attorney General, come next April there will be yet another schedule (H for household employment taxes) to be filled out, as well as six pages of instructions to study.
Individuals who employ a nanny, maid, gardener or other household servant and pay them more than $1,000 during 1995 are supposed to report any Federal income taxes withheld, as well as Social Security and Federal unemployment taxes, and pay those taxes when filing income tax returns.
These taxes are not deductible by the employer because they are for personal services, as opposed to a business expense. Half of the Social Security tax, and all of the Federal Unemployment Tax Act payments, come solely out of the employer's pocket.
The new law does not require individuals to withhold Federal income tax payments. Only if "your household's employee asks you to withhold Federal income tax and you agree" are Federal income taxes to be withheld and then paid by next April 15, according to the instructions.
This latest bit of "tax reform" replaces a rarely enforced law which required individuals to report payments of more than $50 made to servants in a 90-day period. The new law requires only annual filing when payments exceed $1,000 for the year.
"Basically the I.R.S. has swapped a form for reporting wages paid to household workers for a line on the 1040 and a new Form H that goes with your 1040," said Peter Berkery, Washington editor for the Research Institute of America, a tax news service.
Arthur Hall, senior economist at the Tax Foundation in Washington, said the added paperwork "is just indicative of the complexity of the tax law. As things get more and more complex there are more lines, more forms, more instructions. It's really not the fault of the I.R.S., but of the law."
The Tax Foundation estimates that Americans spend $200 billion a year filling out returns and otherwise complying with tax laws. DAVID CAY JOHNSTON

CORRECTION-DATE: September 10, 1995, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, a front-page table last Sunday with an article about proposed changes in the Federal tax code referred incorrectly to one proposal. The abbreviation in "U.S.A. Individual Income Tax" stands for unlimited savings allowance, not universal savings account.
A table with the continuation of the article, comparing potential effects of the proposals on the tax bills of several hypothetical taxpayers rendered some data incorrectly. Under the current income tax, the standard or itemized deduction for the family with no children and an adjusted gross income of $100,000 is $19,000, not $15,000. Under the flat-tax proposal, the total tax for the families with adjusted gross incomes of $50,000 and $300,000 would be $3,395 and $31,923, respectively, not $2,885 and $27,135.

$8,276 -- Under the current system, this family falls into the 28 percent tax bracket. They receive a sizable deduction of $30,000 for mortgage interest and property taxes, along with other itemized deductions, which substantially reduces their tax liability.
 
$16,368 -- This family falls in the same 28 percent tax bracket. But because their home is paid for, and they have no children, their deductions and personal exemptions are smaller, which leaves them with much more taxable income.
 
FLAT TAX
Would eliminate all itemized deductions and tax all wages and benefits at a flat rate, calculated here at 20 percent.
 
$12,070 -- By eliminating all itemized deductions, particularly the deduction for interest on home loans, the flat tax would greatly increase the taxes on his family.
 
$10,960 -- This family fares very well under the flat tax because they have few deductions to lose and their income from investments and savings would no longer be taxed on the personal level.
 
U.S.A. INDIVIDUAL INCOME TAX
Would keep many features of the current system but would exempt all savings and some educational expenses.
 
$8,992 -- Compared to the current system, the so-called universal savings account tax would only modestly increase the tax burden for this family.
 
$22,112 -- This family suffers the most under this proposal. The top tax rate is higher, and because they have few deductions, they end up paying much more.
 
NATIONAL SALES TAX
Would abolish the personal income tax and replace it with an 18 percent sales tax on nearly all goods and services.
 
$7,806 -- Because this family still spends a lot on its home, the tax on its other spending leaves it slightly better off.
 
$12,972 -- This family also does better under a national sales tax than under the current system. Its tax liability is still higher than that of the first family, but its tax burden is reduced more than theirs, too.

PUB-DATE: September 3, 1995

SECTION: Section 6; Page 28; Column 1; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 5085 words

HEADLINE: Campaign '96

BYLINE: By Richard L. Berke; Richard L. Berke is the national political correspondent of The New York Times.

 BODY:
It's labor day weekend, when people tradition-ally just begin to grasp that a Presidential campaign is in the offing. But like it or not, the 1996 contest has been in full motion for months, and is about to burst into public consciousness.
 It may well be the longest, if not the most interminable, campaign anyone can remember, studded with pivotal events months before the customary snowy start in Iowa and New Hampshire. While the road to the White House always has dramatic twists, there will be even more this time around, thanks to tremendous changes in the primary schedule, a fitful electorate, a roster of sharp-tongued (if uninspiring) Republicans and the shadowboxing among independents. And don't forget the biggest question of all: Can the self-proclaimed Comeback Kid do it again? 
 Maybe events will unfold as forecast by those know-it-all prognosticators. Maybe Senator Bob Dole will glide to the G.O.P. nomination. Maybe President Clinton will not face a primary challenger. Maybe the Powells, the Perots and the Bradleys will chicken out.
 But Presidential campaigns never follow the script.
 "Every campaign is a door, and you don't know what's behind it when you kick it down," says James Carville, the Clinton strategist. "People are just going to find out how tough it is to run for President. And '96 is going to be the toughest of them all."
 To make it through, get to know C-Span, stop by the candidates' Internet Web sites and consider this early guide to an unusually long campaign season.
 
1995
Sept. 4
LABOR DAY
On this lazy weekend four years ago, Clinton had not yet declared his candidacy, voters were months away from even asking, "Ross who?" and President George Bush was tanned and relaxed on the 29th and final day of his vacation in Kennebunkport, Me. (Clinton is not repeating the mistake of leaving for too long; in August, he scheduled 17 days off.)
But these are fast times in Presidential politics, and the '96 race has been under way for months (years for the overeager, like Phil Gramm and Lamar Alexander). So, for the Republican hopefuls -- enticed by a weak incumbent, their party's staggering successes last year, the earlier primary dates and, to be sure, their own oversize egos -- this weekend is not so much
a kickoff as one more chance to squeeze hands at picnics in hamlets like Laconia, N.H., and Oskaloosa, Iowa, while straining to look natural in something other than a blue suit.
Although the contenders at the starting gate are not the most exciting bunch, they cannot be dubbed the "Seven Dwarfs," as were the Democratic hopefuls in 1988. For one thing, there are nine of them, give or take. Maybe the "Little Leaguers" would be more appropriate.
Here they come, in alphabetical order:
Lamar Alexander, former Governor of Tennessee. Perhaps best known for taking long walks in a red lumberjack shirt. Hopes there's a sudden yearning for a politician from outside Washington. Never mind that he worked in the Nixon White House, or was Bush's Secretary of Education. His biggest challenge, besides moving beyond the margin of error in the polls, is to convince G.O.P. voters that he's no moderate and can dish out red meat as lavishly as the others.
Patrick J. Buchanan, conservative talking head. No longer dismissed as a spoiler and has had a more successful summer than his opponents. But even a few extra percentage points doesn't mean much when you're 40 points behind Dole.
Senator Bob Dole of Kansas. The only candidate most Republican voters have heard of. His strategy: Say or do anything to preserve his lead all the way to the convention in San Diego. As he told prominent Republicans this summer, "I'm willing to be another Ronald Reagan if that's what you want."
Representative Bob Dornan of California. Enlivened early campaign events with his rabid far-right pitch. But don't count on him to last much longer. He says he may bow out by the end of October and seek re-election because Gingrich needs him in the House. "Newt comes up to me and says, 'Don't do that to me,' " Dornan recalls. (Translation: He'll get to the White House in his dreams.)
Senator Phil Gramm of Texas. Impresses everyone with his fund-raising and organizational prowess and his ability to stick to his message of fiscal conservatism. Despite an impressive showing at the Iowa straw poll in August, he still needs to prove he didn't peak 18 months too soon. Even he raises the obvious: Is he too unappealing to be President?
Alan Keyes. Best orator of the bunch. He is not viewed as a serious contender, probably not even by himself. A former State Department official, this African-American may be satisfied to come out of the early going with improved ratings for his radio program.
Senator Richard Lugar of Indiana. His Howdy Doody mien is a yawner. Just ask the audience at Perot's United We Stand America conference in Dallas last month, where he devoted his speech to the important yet unriveting threat of the international proliferation of plutonium. Best shot is if country finds itself in a war and he can show off his foreign policy acumen. Or maybe his un-politician-like style will draw votes. The Paul Tsongas of 1996?
Senator Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania. Most Republicans still scratch their heads over his notion that a pro-choice foe of the Christian Coalition can win. "Arlen, in a Republican primary, would come in some distance behind Hillary Clinton," says Representative Henry Hyde of Illinois, a leading abortion opponent.
Gov. Pete Wilson of California. Big problem: No one can figure out which state he would win before California. Bigger problem: He even lags behind Dole in California polls. But after all, this is Pete Wilson, Governor of the most populous state, the man Richard Nixon predicted would win the nomination. But then again, Nixon, hedging his bets, told Dole he would win.
 
Sept. 6
AN EXPANDING FIELD?
Malcolm S. Forbes Jr. -- he prefers the more proletarian "Steve" -- announces about now whether he will run in Republican primaries. Forbes, who is the head of his family's publishing empire, fancies himself a "pro-growth, pro-opportunity" Republican who wants a flat tax.
 He's articulate and well read -- and looking for a niche in the Republican Party as a thinking man's Perot. Forbes's biggest asset is not his knowledge of issues and surely not his lackluster speaking style but, well, his assets. Like Perot, Forbes can plow millions into the contest. The company's 727, called the Capitalist Tool, is at his disposal. Forbes's greatest contribution may be that he gives the Jack Kemp supply-side gold-standard crowd a horse to root for.
While Forbes weighed his decision, a poor man's millionaire, Morry Taylor of Grosse Pointe, Mich., declared. He, too, wants to buy his way into the primaries. Taylor, C.E.O. of Titan Wheel International Inc., which makes wheels and tires, tells voters that if they love Perot, they'll love him.
There's one more G.O.P. contender, Arthur Fletcher, a member of the United States Commission on Civil Rights. He doesn't have deep pockets, but he thinks someone needs to counter the other candidates' efforts to scrap affirmative action. Thus far, Fletcher -- the other African-American in the race -- has gone largely unnoticed.
 
Sept. 8
CHRISTIAN COALITION ROAD TO VICTORY CONFERENCE
Once again, Republican candidates will try to top one another in the "holier than the other choices" department as they display their pro-school-prayer, pro-family bona fides. Don't expect disagreement over issues at this event. The Goldwater-Rockefeller-style rancor is a thing of the past. Instead, the competition will be over who can pronounce the conservative dogmas most quickly -- and most convincingly.
This Washington event will have its share of political blood sport. Dole may try to impress upon the audience that his nomination is inevitable. Will the self-described happily married Lugar elaborate on his criticism of Dole, Gramm and Wilson for their divorces? See if Alexander tries to clarify his less-than-fervent opposition to abortion, or if Gramm attacks Hollywood (his investment two decades ago in the dubious film project "Beauty Queens" notwithstanding).
This might be the time for a contender to make a splash by pledging to pick an anti-abortion running mate, though at the risk of being pegged a panderer. Also look to see if Pat Robertson or Ralph Reed, who have not endorsed anyone, hint about their favorite.
 
Sept. 15
BOOK PRIMARY
Colin L. Powell's memoir, "My American Journey," may already be on sale. A book tour has never before served as the prelude for a White House run, but a race of some sort is already on between Powell and Gingrich. The central question is whether Powell's book will outsell Gingrich's "To Renew America," which catapulted to the top of The New York Times's best-seller list in July. "I'm glad it's coming out weeks after mine," Gingrich says.
The book tours explain why Gingrich and Powell have flirted so long about running for President. They get free publicity and can gauge interest in their candidacies -- not to mention sell a few books.
Watch Powell's carefully orchestrated public relations offensive, and see if he discloses any opinions. Word has it that despite his admiration of Reagan, Powell reveals in his book that he voted for J.F.K. and L.B.J. So will he let Barbara Walters in on whether he's a Democrat or a Republican?
People close to Powell say he wants to be President, and make history as the first black President. If he runs, it will most likely be as an independent. He's confident, they say, of reaching the 19 percent Perot threshold, but is not sure how much beyond that he could get.
Adding to the uncertainty, Powell, as a career military officer, is accustomed to structure; Presidential campaigns, particularly independent ones, are plan-as-you-go affairs. Besides, Powell knows that if he runs, he'll never be as popular as he is now.
Yet the media-assisted groundswell builds. "I'm not promoting his candidacy," says Tom Brokaw, the NBC anchorman. "But to have somebody come out of the military ranks -- that would certainly stir the blood." Now that Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey is toying with an independent bid, some in the press have concocted an even more stirring scenario: a Powell-Bradley "dream ticket."
(Or, how about Bradley-Powell?)
To that end, Bradley is jumping into the book derby. The yet-to-be-titled volume on his last two decades is due out in January.
Even Dan Quayle (who's playfully threatening to pop back into the race) is toiling on a new book about -- what else? -- values. And Perot is already hawking his latest, "Intensive Care: We Must Save Medicare and Medicaid Now."
The more the press ruminates over these aspiring author-politicos -- and their orchestrated indecisions over running -- the better for Dole. The distractions make it less likely that any of Dole's G.O.P. challengers will get noticed.
Who, for example, is eagerly anticipating, or has even heard of, "We Know What to Do," Lamar Alexander's book about his travels across America, which also appears in bookstores this month?
 
Sept. 17
ANNUAL HARKIN STEAK FRY
Forget the steak. See if Clinton gets seared. This big Democratic event on the Warren County fairgrounds in Indianola, Iowa, sponsored by Senator Tom Harkin, is the place to be to pick up rumblings of a challenge to the President. If there are bumper stickers that proclaim "Bradley '96," look out. And note the number of cars plastered with Clinton's name. (Of course, don't use that as the sole gauge of early enthusiasm for his re-election. Stickers may be a better sign of the quality of Clinton's advance work than anything else.) Clinton himself will be in Des Moines in October for the annual Jefferson-Jackson Day Dinner.
 
Oct. 4
POPE ARRIVES IN UNITED STATES
Expect Clinton to meet with him, and G.O.P. hopefuls to insert themselves into a photo op. But candidates should anticipate tense moments. Pope John Paul II is not one to resist pressing his tough line against abortion at a time when Republicans are trying to play down the intraparty angst on the matter. No one is more outspoken on abortion than the Pope. Except for Buchanan, Dornan and Keyes.
 
Oct. 15
PUTTING THE CARDS ON THE TABLE
Candidates' third-quarter finance reports are due at the Federal Election Commission. See who is close to collecting the magic $20 million that some candidates boasted was necessary to wage a full-fledged primary campaign.
And just as important, who has already frittered away millions on large staffs and television time.
"It's a lot like poker," says Dave Carney, a New Hampshire strategist for Dole. "Now it's time to show your hands. It will be clearer who's bluffing and who's not."
Easy for him to say. As the front-runner and majority leader, Dole is a magnet for access-hungry Republicans. Likewise, cash is the least of Gramm's problems.
The biggest tests are for Wilson, who needs to prove his vaunted fund-raising skills at the Presidential level, and for Alexander, who must show the payoff for luring fat-cat Bush and Reagan fund-raisers.
Any camp that has not pulled in at least $15 million by now fails the expectations game.
But candidates with smaller reserves, like Specter, Lugar and Buchanan, are out to prove that the $20 million figure is all hype -- and was part of Gramm's early ploy to scare the Quayles and the Cheneys and the Kemps out of the race. These candidates believe that for the first time in modern Republican politics a cash-deficient campaign can win the nomination.
On the Democratic side, those curious about Jesse Jackson's White House intentions should check to see if he's paid off the remaining $150,000 debt from his 1988 campaign.
 
Nov. 7
OFF-YEAR ELECTION
The municipal elections will be enlivened by City Vote, a nonpartisan straw poll in which voters in more than 20 cities -- including Boston, Tucson, Newark and Spokane -- will be asked their preference for President. The most obvious beneficiary of this unofficial national urban primary is Jesse Jackson, who has made a career of campaigning in urban America. Don't believe the spin about the outcome of this month's Governors races in Louisiana, Kentucky and Mississippi as portending the outcome next November. These races have little significance beyond their borders.
 
Nov. 13
D.L.C.'S ANNUAL CONFERENCE
Watch, on this day at least, for Clinton to embrace the Democratic Leadership Council's agenda for welfare and economic reforms, insisting that he never abandoned the moderate group that helped kick off his last campaign. But will Al From, the group's chief agitator, give up on Clinton once and for all, discouraged by his cozying up to the party's liberal wing?
 
Nov. 15
DAY OF RECKONING?
The Government could hit the debt ceiling and run out of cash. Republicans will dare Clinton to go along with their huge spending cuts in benefit programs like Medicare and welfare or to use his rarely unsheathed veto pen -- thereby potentially shutting down the entire Government. This could be the showdown of the year in Congress. But no one knows which side wins. Clinton could reveal some spine by standing up to Republicans and thwarting the extremists, or he could be blamed for another outbreak of gridlock.
While the budgetary brinkmanship offers an intermission from the G.O.P. nominating derby, these battles could spill into the Presidential sweepstakes. Depending on the outcome, the Republicans might look harsh -- or heroic -- for making good on their promises to slash the budget. Yet if they fail to pass a budget that moves toward balance, they risk looking like weasels on their prime campaign promise.
The jockeying will also be played out within the G.O.P., where Dole and Gramm are vying to get more credit for delivering to conservatives. The early line is that Dole, as majority leader, can point to more concrete accomplishments. But Gramm, unburdened by having to wheedle and compromise, scores for staking the purest conservative positions.
 
Nov. 18
'PRESIDENCY III' STRAW POLL
Tom Slade, Florida Republican chairman, calls his party's straw poll in Orlando "the single most important event in American politics this year." Hyperbole aside, it should carry more weight than most of the dozens of straw polls being conducted. Some candidates have hired people to make blind calls to pack the event. Florida is taking on newfound importance because it is the most delegate-rich state in which no candidate has an obvious edge. Winning could give a candidate the perception that he's catching on. Larry King, not about to cede his position from 1992 as television's grand political pooh-bah of the candidate Q. and A., has all the contenders on an expanded version of his show the eve of the straw poll.
 
REPUBLICAN GOVERNORS MEET
The star of the Republican Governors Association meeting in Nashua, N.H., won't be any of the Presidential candidates but Gov. Stephen Merrill. For months, the contenders have been courting him for an endorsement, and unless he has already thrown his support to someone, the meeting here will allow him to savor the national spotlight.
Merrill's backing is critical because he is popular and has a seasoned organization in the state. He could make a big splash by endorsing this weekend. But he may want to get a better read on who's likely to win before he makes a move. Expect him to pick anyone but Gramm: Merrill is still steamed over the Texan's antics to win support in Arizona and Delaware, even as those states were threatening New Hampshire's cherished spot as the first primary state.
Alexander, in particular, hopes for a surprise endorsement to get him some attention. But Dole may be a safer choice. "I'm not trying to be coy, but I'm going to be with a conservative," Merrill says coyly. "And with a conservative who can win." So much for narrowing the possibilities. Keep your eyes open for back-room deals. Vice President Merrill?
 
Nov. 19
ONE MORE CHANCE
Missed out on the Merrill endorsement? There's still The Manchester Union Leader. Best bet is that the right-wing paper will endorse Buchanan, whose columns it published for years, and who got the nod in 1992. But Gramm has a fighting chance.
 
Dec. 15
DO-OR-DIE DEADLINE
Last chance for contenders to pony up $1,000 and sign a declaration of candidacy to get their names on New Hampshire's primary ballot.
In a rerun of the "waiting for Mario" scene four years ago, expect hopeful Republicans to wait, perhaps in vain, for Powell or Gingrich or their ideal candidate to enter the race. And Clinton will find out once and for all if Jackson, or another prominent Democrat, will compete in the primaries.
There are more potential surprises on the G.O.P. side. If Dole's lead in the polls has eroded by now because of fumbles or if people grow tired of him -- and his opponents aren't gaining steam -- leading Republicans (and the Limbaughs of the world) are likely to press for Gingrich. "There's not a lot of excitement out there," grouses Bill Bennett, the values maven and a former Secretary of Education. "We're in a revolutionary period in Congress, but we do not have a revolutionary in the race."
Just the entry line Gingrich wants to hear. Now that the deadline is upon him, can Gingrich resist the temptation and remain Speaker, the job he always wanted? Talk-radio hosts on both sides are panting for a Newt run. "I can have fun with Bob Dole," says Jim Hightower, a Democrat and Texas Agriculture Commissioner turned radio jock. "But Newt is manna from heaven."
Fat chance, Jim. Gingrich is well aware of the polls showing that even many G.O.P. primary voters (including his own wife) think he should stay put. His backers advance a more alluring scenario: that Gingrich is secretly hoping Clinton will be re-elected so he can stay King of the Hill and King of the Republicans, and position himself for the open White House contest in 2000.
But the Newt Presidential tease is not likely to end if he doesn't run. Count on him to float the prospect that if there's a brokered convention, in which the nominee is chosen in negotiations in San Diego, he will be available.
 
Dec. 19
WHO'S IN CHARGE?
Even if Clinton has announced his campaign team, see if he can stick with it. If Dick Morris, Clinton's consultant-of-the-moment, is still hot, others in the White House will be troubled, but it will be a sign of stability. Clinton should know better than to dally; Bush thought he didn't need to rev up his re-election effort until late in the game, and, well, it never really revved up.
But no matter who the faces are, something of a re-election strategy should have emerged by now. Count on Clinton to present himself as the only bulwark against Republican extremism. One reason Clinton has to demonize Republicans is that he does not dare run on some of the issues that were central to his campaign in 1992. Forget health care. And national service. And the notion that Government can do more to help you.
As Clinton struggles to find his message, look to see how the White House, the re-elect campaign and the Democratic National Committee vie for Clinton's attention. But as they compete over campaign strategy, they may be trumped by Hillary.
 
Dec. 23
WILD CARD!
In American politics, it is always necessary to expect the unexpected. Some real-life events inevitably intrude on every candidate's painstakingly plotted calendar. Be prepared for a bimbo eruption, a heart attack, a surprise withdrawal or more trouble with Bosnia, China or Iraq. And don't forget the long-awaited special counsel's Whitewater report. Will there be an unanticipated smoking gun (or maybe just a slightly warm gun with a smudged fingerprint)? If that doesn't make waves, there's always next month's publication of James Stewart's "Blood Sport," an examination of Whitewater.
Republicans will no doubt try to use the three W's against Clinton -- Whitewater, Waco and Women.
But Gary Hart advises his fellow Democrat not to look back: "He would be the first person to say: 'I'm not Winston Churchill. I'm Bill Clinton, and this is who I am. I am not being measured against God. I'll do the best I can and maybe that's better than Bob Dole.' "
Still, the Republicans are itching to get nasty. Alex Castellanos, Gramm's media adviser, is only half-kidding in saying that Clinton is "going to try to expand his lead on female voters, one woman at a time."
 
Dec. 24
CHRISTMAS EVE
If grumpy lawmakers are still being serenaded with Christmas carols in the corridors of the Capitol, it means they are still unable to resolve thorny issues like the budget and Medicare. In that case, Dole risks being blamed for presiding over a do-nothing Senate -- even while his rivals were free to prowl the hamlets of New Hampshire, extolling the need to change the way Washington works. Meanwhile, Clinton remains by the Rose Garden, unmuddied by the discord up the street.
 
Dec. 29
AD WARS
The first contest, the Iowa caucuses, is tentatively set for 45 days from now, and campaigns are now entitled to cheaper television advertising rates. With the rate change, the ad wars enter a more intense phase. Most campaigns are likely to stay on the air from now until the voting in Iowa.
As much as the experts talk about shorter attention spans and a restless electorate, don't count on that being reflected in the ads. Television ads are expected to drone on longer and have more beef. Ad campaigns will start earlier, with some mimicking Perot's successful 30-minute infomercials.
For the first time, Presidential campaigns will do battle in cyberspace. Watch for direct-mail solicitations to decline. Instead, campaigns are targeting donors and spreading their messages on their home pages. "We've had over 70,000 visits to our Internet site," says Mike Murphy, Alexander's chief strategist. "That's as big as some caucuses."
 
1996
Jan. 1
NEW YEAR'S DAY
The real world doesn't tune in to Presidential politics until the snow hits New Hampshire -- and sometimes not even then. Now, in the dead of winter, if you don't pay attention, you could miss the primaries. That's because the '96 nominating sweepstakes might be compared to a shotgun wedding or, as Rich Bond, a Dole adviser, less delicately puts it, "a Presidential quickie."
The point is: Expectations have been building for months, even years. But because so many states have moved up their primary dates, in an effort to make themselves more vital to the process, the whole enterprise could end up being a five-week blur of commercials, debates and meet-and-greets. Thus, what seems like the longest campaign may feature the shortest primary season.
There's no time for candidates to make mistakes (or, for that matter, to capitalize on the mistakes of others). No more time for campaign managers to stage phony focus groups to prove to the restless candidate that, yes, there is a groundswell for his candidacy. And no time to raise money; that's why everyone scrambled to stockpile as much as possible last year.
Since so many states are holding primaries in rapid succession, many on the same day, the campaign will be nationalized far earlier than ever before. With candidates having little time to stump in each state, let alone delve into local issues, don't expect major tussles like the past ones over the Seabrook nuclear plant in New Hampshire. Compounding the swift pace is that in delegate-dense states like Texas, New York and California, Republicans have winner-take-all primaries -- the victor reaps all the delegate spoils.
If the front-runner doesn't stumble, he could knock off his rivals fast. Just the same, if a dark horse takes off, he could be unstoppable. Gary Hart, for one, might have used his 1984 victory in New Hampshire against Walter Mondale to catapult himself to the Democratic nomination.
"Suppose Lamar Alexander wins New Hampshire," says Bill Schneider, a political analyst. "All of a sudden, he's on the national stage. The press hasn't examined him with care. There's no time for the voters to find out who he is. But he could sweep the primaries. Suddenly, he's nominated, and the Republicans don't know who he is."
They would find out but quick. There's nothing like a new face to get the press, and the Democrats, to pounce. They'll seize on everyone from the candidate's second-grade teacher to his date at the prom.
 
Jan. 13
IOWA DEBATES
The Des Moines Register holds one of the first major debates, or, more accurately, tear-down-the-front-runner sessions. If Dole is still ahead in the polls, his rivals will struggle for the No. 2 spot -- ridiculing him as a faux conservative and a compromiser too crotchety to be President. But it's hard for his opponents to set themselves apart because they are pronouncing essentially the same positions: cutting taxes, reducing Government and emphasizing family values. That may leave them little else other than personal attacks.
Dole has history on his side. Unlike the fratricide-prone Democrats, Republican primary voters are far more disciplined in coalescing around their front-runner. In every election since Eisenhower, the Republican nomination has been captured by an established party figure who had run before, had been nominated for President or Vice President or had served in one of those offices.
The trouble usually arises when the party is split between its heart and mind, when G.O.P. voters really want a particular candidate but end up throwing their allegiance behind another contender they think has a better chance of winning. Consider 1976: Many Republicans said their heart told them Reagan but their head told them Ford. And in 1992 in New Hampshire, many Republicans identified more with Buchanan even though they knew he did not have a shot against Bush. In both of those races, the fractured Republicans went on to defeat in November.
The challenge for Dole, then, is to head off a hearts-and-minds split and not let anyone else outflank him. It's a tricky situation because the nominee will ultimately have to attract swing voters who are more moderate.
But Dole's opponents predicate their campaigns on the belief that either Dole will falter or they will somehow capture the imaginations, and votes, of Republicans. "We refer to that as the Wile E. Coyote school of politics," says Nelson Warfield, Dole's spokesman. "They think that Dole's going to stumble and slip. But like the Road Runner, he keeps foiling them."
Rival camps spin all sorts of scenarios as to how Dole could collapse. His famed temper might rear itself again. Or his age could slow him down. Or voters might reject him for pandering to the right. The press, to be sure, will encourage a spirited competition. Gramm, for one, cites the news media's thirst for melodrama. "Let's face it," Gramm says, staring down a reporter. "You're going to help create this race. And in the end, this is going to be a nail biter. And if you want to look very clever, you ought to start saying, 'My political instinct tells me that Gramm, through sheer hard work and lots of good grass-roots activism, is going to win this race.' "
Indeed, Peter Jennings, the ABC anchorman, says his biggest fear is "the boredom factor" of a Dole-Clinton match-up. "The notion of doing Bob Dole again," he says,
"is very challenging to a political report." But don't count on the press to look to Gramm. Jennings, for one, dreams of a Powell, plus maybe a Perot, to liven up his broadcast. "I'd be delighted," he says. "We'd cover the hell out of it."
 
Jan. 18
NATIONAL ISSUES CONVENTION
To find out what people really want from their elected officials, a representative sampling of 600 voters nationwide will gather at the University of Texas at Austin to question Presidential candidates in programs televised by the Public Broadcasting Service.
More important than eliciting answers from candidates, over four days these forums may put a face on the American voter of '96. The question can be boiled down to one of restlessness. Are voters as dissatisfied and dispirited with Clinton as the '94 election seemed to suggest? Or are they disappointed with what the Republicans have wrought, and willing to keep Clinton? Or are they still searching for another savior, an independent perhaps?

LENGTH: 457 words

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MIDTOWN;
The Next Wave In Mega-Retail: The Global Deli

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT

 BODY:
Sooner or later, it was bound to happen.
First came the invasion by the big suburban-style retailers like Home Depot, Toys 'R' Us, Pathmark, Bradlees, Staples, Herman's, Crate and Barrel, Tops, Sports Authority and Bed, Bath and Beyond. 
 Now comes the ultimate New York response. The mega-deli.
It runs a full city block -- enter on 34th Street and exit on 33d, if you wish. To tickle the taste buds of a gorgeous mosaic, its menu has a global stretch from pizza to fried plantains to sushi.
Formally known as Penn Plaza Deli and Restaurant, it opened in May in a vacant bank office on the east side of Eighth Avenue, opposite Penn Station and the main post office.
Unlike its claustrophobic ancestors with cramped aisles and cluttered shelves, the mega-deli has 6,000 square feet spacious aisles, multiple serving stations, wood and tile decor, piped-in music and large television sets. A blocklong counter with stools and adjacent tables seat 100.
"The variety is incredible, from Mongolian barbecue to whatever speciality you want," said David Morrison, who works nearby in publishing and comes for lunch.
Open 24 hours a day, Penn Plaza Deli has 50 workers and was two years in the planning, said Suk Hun Chung, its president. The site was picked for the nearby office buildings, 34th Street retail corridor and hub of commuter rail, subway and bus lines. Most customers are local workers, travelers and shoppers. Mr. Chung hopes for a boost when Kmart opens a store down the block on 34th.
The owners expanded on their experience at other delis to create the new format, said Chung Hoon Shin, the manager. He described the concept: "Have the best food and the biggest place. We have everything so you don't have to go to a lot of different places."
About the only customer they don't cater to is the indecisive diner, for whom the mega-deli would be tormenting. A ham and cheese sandwich or Japanese udon noodles? Maybe the Cajun grilled chicken, the smoked shrimp and crab salad, the rotisserie chicken or the ribs? There are separate stands for sushi, the charcoal grill, the big Mongolian cooking drum and the pastries, among other choices.Prices are moderate: $1.50 for a slice of pizza and daily lunch specials for $4 and $5.
The owners say business has been slow to build. But a sampling of customers gave positive reviews. "I love it," said Frank Jenkins of White Plains, who works in the insurance business. "I get off the train every morning and have breakfast here."
Larry Krizan, an economic development consultant from Albany waiting for an Amtrak train, wandered in for a snack.. "It's like everything in New York," he said. "It's big and busy and has lots of interesting choices." BRUCE LAMBERT

GRAPHIC: Photo: "We have everything," says Chung Hoon Shin, manager of the Penn Plaza Deli. (Ruby Washington/The New York Times)

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: September 3, 1995

SECTION: Section 7; Page 20; Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 973 words

HEADLINE: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks

BYLINE: By LAUREL GRAEBER

 BODY:
WHO WILL RUN THE FROG HOSPITAL? By Lorrie Moore. Warner, $11.99. 
A woman coming to the end of her 30's and possibly the end of her marriage looks back on the bond she and her best friend shared when they were both 15. Her story is "a sad, witty, disillusioned fairy tale," Caryn James said here last year, and Ms. Moore's "richest work yet."
 
DAISY BATES IN THE DESERT By Julia Blackburn. Vintage Departures, $12.
 She was difficult and determined, an almost compulsive liar and a wandering soul who finally found peace only in the bleakest regions of Australia. Daisy Bates, an Irish self-taught anthropologist who lived among the aborigines from 1913 to 1934, was not an easy person to capture, but Julia Blackburn has given her substance by searching for herself among the fragments of her subject's life. She "has given us both a fascinating exercise in biography and a rare, intimate glimpse into the biographer's imagination," Linda Simon wrote in the Book Review in 1994. Vintage Departures has also reissued the account of a woman's more recent journey into the heart of Australia. TRACKS, by Robyn Davidson ($12), chronicles the author's traversal of 1,700 miles of her native country's outback, which she made in 1977, in the company of four camels and a dog. In 1981 Sarah Ferrell, writing in The New York Times, called Ms. Davidson "a lively stylist" whose "analyses of her states of mind . . . are both convincing and engrossing." Australia is just as powerful a presence in the work of Rodney Hall, whose YANDILLI TRILOGY (Noonday/Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $16) takes place during the country's colonial era. "The Second Bridegroom," the first novel in the collection, is narrated by one of the slave laborers who tamed Australia's wilderness, a young British convict. In 1991 our reviewer, Judith Grossman, praised "the prodigal energy and ebullience of Mr. Hall's writing." In "The Grisly Wife" the storyteller is Catherine Byrne, an English missionary who came to Australia with her husband, an illiterate bootmaker and self-styled prophet. Hers is "a rich, wild" tale by "a thrillingly smart and juicy writer," Beverly Lowry said here in 1993. "Captivity Captive," based on a real turn-of-the-century murder case, features another tormented narrator, an octogenarian who was one of 10 abused children. His story is "harrowing and beautiful. . . . A book that makes demands on the reader's soul," Joyce Reiser Kornblatt said in the Book Review in 1988.
THE SHADOW OF THE PANTHER: Huey Newton and the Price of Black Power in America By Hugh Pearson. Addison-Wesley, $14.
 In this study the bold leader of the Black Panther movement emerges as a brilliant strategist and a ruthless killer. The author analyzes the party's terrorist tactics and the role sympathetic whites played in its fame. Last year our reviewer, Bob Blauner, called the writing of the book "a courageous act," in which Mr. Pearson sometimes achieves "the excitement of a political thriller." In BLACK NATIONALISM: A Search for an Identity in America, by E. U. Essien-Udom (University of Chicago, $14.95), the Nation of Islam is portrayed as a movement that transcended purely political objectives by offering a sense of unity and purpose to poor blacks. Previously out of print, this 1962 book is "an excellent standard treatment of black nationalist belief," Michael Eric Dyson said in these pages in 1992.
 
THE GOOD HUSBAND By Gail Godwin. Ballantine, $12.
 If behind every successful woman there is a man, he is probably like Francis Lake, who has supported his wife, Magda Danvers, in her scholarly efforts and must now see her through terminal cancer. In this novel Magda's demise and her marriage have a powerful impact on another couple grappling with tragedy. "Ms. Godwin has a remarkable capacity for the subtle presentation of real insight," Sara Maitland wrote here last year.
TALKING FROM 9 to 5. Women and Men in the Workplace: Language, Sex and Power By Deborah Tannen. Avon, $12.50.
 A linguist analyzes speech patterns, showing that verbally assertive women do not reap the same rewards as verbally assertive men. This is "a book that everyone who has ever apologized needlessly, snapped at a subordinate or withered from lack of praise should surely read," Derek Bickerton said in these pages in 1994.
 
IN THE TIME OF THE BUTTERFLIES By Julia Alvarez. Plume, $11.95.
 This novel re-creates the lives of the deceased Mirabal sisters, three women murdered in 1960 by underlings of the Dominican dictator Rafael Leonidas Trujillo. Another character is Dede, the surviving sister, and it is in her portrait "that we best understand the depths of Ms. Alvarez's despair and the authenticity of her effort," Roberto Gonzalez Echevarria wrote here last year.
SEX IN AMERICA: A Definitive Survey By Robert T. Michael, John H. Gagnon, Edward O. Laumann and Gina Kolata. Warner, $12.99.
 This report is based on the most comprehensive study of sexual practices in the United States since Kinsey's. Interviewing 3,432 people in 1992, the National Opinion Research Center gathered data showing that we are much more monogamous and much less sexually active than is generally supposed. Written by sociologists (Mr. Gagnon and Mr. Laumann), an economist (Mr. Michael) and a reporter for The New York Times (Ms. Kolata), this book offers "a rich supply of examples to lend those conclusions flesh and bones," Paul Robinson said in the Book Review in 1994. Also reissued is SEXING THE MILLENNIUM: Women and the Sexual Revolution, by Linda Grant (Grove, $12), in which the author argues that the 1960's idea of eroticism was mostly men's; only in the future can we hope for sex devoid of sexism. Our reviewer was again Mr. Robinson, who observed last year, "Pleasure needs as many friends as it can get." LAUREL GRAEBER

HEADLINE: THEATER;
Words' Power, Not Special Effects

BYLINE: By ALVIN KLEIN 

 BODY:
IT isn't every American summer stock production that luxuriates in rehearsing -- for three weeks, mind you -- on a London stage, the very same stage where the play at hand has been running for years.
But then nothing about "The Woman in Black," which opens a two-week run at the Westport Country Playhouse tomorrow, is going the stock way of summer theater. A spooky English thriller, a genre that's all but vanished from the American theater experience, the adaptation by Stephen Malatratt of a novel by Susan Hill, began its seventh year in June at the Fortune Theater in the West End. Before moving to the Fortune, the play ran more than six months in three other London playhouses. 
 Though the Westport engagement is the professional American premiere of a London hit that has built a considerable reputation as a tourist attraction, it is not the first attempt to import the play. Indeed, this is the 15th try for an American showing of "The Woman in Black." So it has been recorded in the diaries of the director, Robin Herford, who commissioned the play in the first place and has since staged touring companies in the English provinces as well as productions in Japan, Australia and Spain.
Those attempts involved big-time plans for Chicago and for New York. One came close. A 1993 Broadway production was in place, theater (the Music Box), cast (F. Murray Abraham and Robert Westenberg) and all. But $400,000 of the production's $1.5 million budget was not forthcoming three days before rehearsals were to begin.
Will "The Woman in Black" travel to New York this time around when production costs could exceed the numbers of two years ago? Mr. Herford and the Westport's stars, Roy Dotrice and Maxwell Caulfield, envision Off Broadway. (The Fortune has 450 seats.)
And "The Woman in Black" is essentially a small-scale two-character exercise in the power of theater to suggest, to transform and -- old hat as this may seem -- to tell a story through words rather than technological effects and exploding sets.
"We ask the audience to commit their imagination and emotion and they create the atmosphere, of an island reachable by a causeway that can only be approached at low tide," Mr. Herford said. "The audience prepares the stage with that setting, for all we actually have is a very bare space with remnants -- an old skip, an armchair, a clothes rack and a Brentwood chair. The rest is storytelling." (Skip is the British word for hamper.)
The background of that story involves a solicitor, Arthur Kipps, who was sent to a community on the Yorkshire coast in the dead of winter in order to attend the funeral of a client -- one mysterious and dreaded Mrs. Drablow who died at the age of 87.
Kipps was supposed to bring rationality to what Mr. Herford described as "an extremely complicated, creepy, frightening, odd, supernatural turn of events, filled with evasions and ghosts." All that happened 25 years ago.
In the play the solicitor is so obsessed with the eerie tale that he engages a young actor (Mr. Caulfield) to help him exorcise it. The actor reworks the story into a two-character play. The actor, played by Mr. Caulfield, takes the part of Kipps as a younger man, and Kipps himself, played by Mr. Dotrice, takes on six other roles.
Mr. Herford, Mr. Dotrice and Mr. Caulfield flew in from London last Sunday for an additional week of rehearsals. All assumed a "don't ask, we won't tell" position about the identity of the woman in black.
Is this, after all, more than a two-character play? "The atmospheric sound effects -- that's the third character," Mr. Caulfield answered cheekily. "And 110 light cues," Mr. Dotrice interjected.
But who is the woman in black? "That remains to be seen," Mr. Caulfield said. "The piece calls for actors to call on their art form -- and to fire the audience's imagination."
If any actor can weave the combined spell of stage art, artifice and illusion, it's Mr. Dotrice, once a member of the Royal Shakespeare Company. Among an array of roles, from classical to contemporary, Mr. Dotrice has proved to be a master of the transformation, having played Churchill, Lincoln, Chekhov and, most memorably, John Aubrey, in his one-man show, "Brief Lives."
"This piece is about theater," Mr. Dotrice said. "Kipps learns to be an actor by playing six parts." Both Mr. Caulfield and Mr. Dotrice have "designs" -- Mr. Caulfield's word -- on a New York run. "The play has a fantastic track record on the other side of the pond," Mr. Caulfield said. "And there's a bus load coming -- I think on the 11th -- I hope producers will be on it," Mr. Dotrice added.
Wary of the irrational economics of theater on and off Broadway and quite able to reel off the English hits that hadn't a ghost of a chance in New York, James B. McKenzie, the Westport Playhouse's veteran executive producer who sends out road companies the year round, said: "Sure, everybody's coming to Westport -- the Nederlanders, the Shuberts -- but New York is not my goal in life. "Everything's tougher there -- it's less fun, less rewarding. Of course if it works in New York, it's worth more on the road. Yet I'm open to deals from anyone with ideas and money -- from New York or from Timbuktu."

HEADLINE: ON THE TOWNS: FILM;
Offbeat and Arty in the Land of the Multiplex

BYLINE: By ALVIN KLEIN 

 BODY:
FOR state-of-the-art brutality, follow the crowd to "Mortal Kombat." All the shootouts you can stand? Try queuing up for "Desperado." Look at other films high on the current box-office charts ("Dangerous Minds," "Waterworld," "Lord of Illusions"), and there's not an art-house title on the list.
To the moviegoing masses, the term "art-house fare" may sound like trade talk or conjure visions of the snob who goes to the cinema, not the movies. In New York City, showplaces for these offbeat films flourish, unintimidated by the multiplex (and some in multiplexity themselves). And if Albert Gabriel Nigrin, the director and curator of the New Jersey Film Festival, has his way, the state won't remain far behind as a serious center for non-mainstream films. 
 The festival, with screenings at several locations in New Brunswick, opens on Thursday with Martine Dugowson's "Mina Tannenbaum," the story of a 25-year friendship between two Jewish women in Paris. More than 60 films dating from 1927 to 1995, including 20 New Jersey premieres, are to be screened before the festival ends on Dec. 2. (Information and schedule: 908-932-8482.)
New Jersey has pockets of small alternative theaters -- among them the Lost Picture Show in Union, the Brook in Bound Brook and the Montgomery Cinemas in Rocky Hill -- with occasional short-lived connoisseur's series like Projected Images, in Hoboken, which opens Tuesday and runs through Nov. 15. But Mr. Nigrin's festival, which includes spring and summer series, represents the first sustained effort at year-round art-film programming in the state.
His expansive mission to perpetuate film as an art form has been evolving since 1983, when he was a graduate student in French literature at Rutgers University. "As a scholar and as a film buff, I always wanted to see films I could not see during the nascent stages of the video mall," he said. So, investing "$300 of my own money," he presented six films by the likes of Fritz Lang and Jean Renoir in a 250-seat hall at Rutgers.
"It was a slow growth, but always open to the public," Mr. Nigrin recalled. Series by series, the budget increased, from $1,000 to $3,000 to $5,000 to $8,000. In 1987, the university's media department became the first sponsor. By 1991, the idea of a festival -- "of seeing films with other people, as a gathering, as a community" -- was bandied about. By 1993, the series became a festival. with some films being shown at the State Theater in New Brunswick (capacity: 1,800). Mr. Nigrin says the restored Art Deco theater recalls the grandeur of movie palaces of old, "where you can lose yourself in the space."
In addition to running the festival, sponsored by the Rutgers Film Co-op and the New Jersey Media Arts Center, Mr. Nigrin, 37, is a lecturer in film at Rutgers. His programs include not just screenings, but also dialogues with film makers and workshops on legal and business aspects of motion picture production, distribution and other offshoots.
This fall's festival includes several theme series. One is titled "Thicker Than Blood: The Family Binds." No "Life With Father" here, but rather such unsettling family portraits as Terry Zwigoff's "Crumb," the much-praised documentary about the obsessions and dysfunctions of the clan and colleagues of the iconoclastic comic-strip artist Robert Crumb. "My Family: Mi Familia" tells the story of a Mexican family in Los Angeles from the 1920's to the 80's, directed by Mira Nair. Other series include "After the Fall: Films of the Post-Glasnost Era" and "Women's Works III."
The up-to-the-minute (Wayne Wang's "Smoke") coexists with old, established forms like film noir, from American ("The Naked Edge," from 1961, with Gary Cooper in his last performance) to Chinese ("The Day the Sun Turned Cold"). Classics encompass the silent (Lillian Gish in "The Wind," Buster Keaton in "College") and the raucously comic (the Marx Brothers). Homages to directors encompass Satyajit Ray, Luis Bunuel and John Sayles, with a nod to the young, independent spirits of Hal Hartley and Todd Haynes.
The art film, then, is "the one that doesn't make it to a multiplex of 10 or more theaters," Mr. Nigrin answered. "While most people go to mainstream movies to escape their existences, they go to an art-house film to probe it, to explore the plight of the species. The reason is existential, not escape. And someone wanted to make the film because of what it says, instead of what it will earn."
How to explain a night of Ed Wood films? It's Halloween, of course. The evening is to include a costume contest and an appearance by Dolores Fuller, an actress in such staples of the Wood canon as "Jail Bait," which is to be shown with "Bride of the Monster" and "Plan 9 From Outer Space" in a triple bill of "three of the worst films ever made."
"We debated long and hard about that, but these were the drive-in movies," Mr. Nigrin explained. "How do they play vis-a-vis today's films? What accounts for the Ed Wood cult? This is part of the historical context: the progression of early junk to present vanguard.
"Remember, the festival is not too intellectual, not too arty. We are here to celebrate film."
To Mr. Nigrin, it's above all a celebration of passion. "That is the bottom line, not the bank account. The risk is now out of the motion picture business. It is talked about as an industry, based on the safe bet, and a lot of people just don't agree. We champion films using intelligence and economy, so you can see Maximilian Schell and Vanessa Redgrave in 'Little Odessa.' Baby boomers will demand more than a reiteration of the same formula, the same trappings.
"Films can be more. Films can be art. And New Brunswick has become the mecca for filmgoers in New Jersey, a true cinematheque where you'll never see the Flintstones. Or the Brady Bunch."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Above, the cast of "My Family: Mi Familia," to be screened in New Brunswick on Saturday as part of the "Thicker Than Blood" series presented by the New Jersey Film Festival. Left, Albert Gabriel Nigrin, the festival's director and curator. (New Line Cinema)

HEADLINE: At Midyear, Office Market Holds Its Own

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER

 BODY:
STEADY, but less spectacular than activity in 1994, is how commercial real estate brokers in Westchester assess leasing activity at midyear.
"No question, there has been an upkick in the market judging from the steady absorption of empty space," said Carl Austin, head of the 25-year-old brokerage company of Austin Corporate Properties in White Plains. Yet, on the minus side of the ledger, Mr. Austin warns that more corporate downsizing is still possible. 
 "Major corporations such as I.B.M. and Nynex are in the final throes of slimming down," he said, "and that will produce an upheaval in the market. This may be the last round of corporate downsizing, but like the hurricane, we will feel the ripples from it."
Nynex, which occupies several large buildings, will move some of its Westchester work force to New York City. And while International Business Machines has rebounded financially, there is no assurance that the company has finished downsizing in Westchester, said William V. Cuddy Jr., senior vice president of Rostenberg-Doern, a major independent brokerage concern in Purchase specializing in corporate real estate, in a midyear report issued by his company.
"Nevertheless there are positive signs that the recovery is on track," Mr. Cuddy said. "The office market held its own during the first half of 1995, with the vacancy rate countywide at 22.1 percent, which was essentially unchanged from the vacancy rate at the end of 1994."
During the first six months of the year, companies moving into Westchester or expanding their presence in the county included Abitibi Price, the Canada-based forest-products company, from Manhattan to Purchase, Heineken U.S.A. from Manhattan to 50 Main Street in downtown White Plains, Arthur J. Gallagher from downtown White Plains to Westchester Avenue and Paxar Corporation, one of the largest lease transactions in Westchester this year, moved to Corporate Park Drive in White Plains.
Paxar, a maker of merchandise labels and bar code tags primarily for the apparel and textile industries, is moving its corporate headquarters from Pearl River to 29,538 square feet of leased space, which is the entire third floor, at 105 Corporate Park Drive in White Plains, in a building owned by Eastridge Properties. "Paxar's move reaffirms Westchester's reputation as a prestige corporate headquarters location and shows that high-end corporate space continues to lease first," said John P. Hannigan of Rostenberg-Doern, who represented Paxar in the transaction.
In speaking of the move, Victor Hershaft, Paxar's president and chief operating officer, said:
"Our new headquarters provides us with an excellent access to major highways in Manhattan as well to the Westchester County Airport. We're looking forward to joining the Westchester business community."
At the Tarrytown Corporate Center, a 1.2-million-square-foot office complex on White Plains Road in Tarrytown, more than 150,000 square feet of new leases, expansions and renewals have been signed, said Jon L. Halpern, president and chief executive officer of Halpern Enterprises, the owner and manager the center.
"The level of leasing activity continues to outpace the rest of the Westchester office market at the Corporate Center," Mr. Halpern said. "Our occupancy rate is currently more than 95 percent."
Companies signing leases at the Tarrytown Corporate Center deal in financial services, insurance, fashion, marketing, consumer products, medical technology, computer software and electronics, Mr. Halpern said. The largest individual lease was signed by Citibank, for the renewal of 34,950 square feet of space for its telemarketing and retail training operation at the building at 580 White Plains Road. Philips Electronics North America also renewed its lease for 15,540 square feet in the same building.
The Liberty Mutual Insurance Company moved from Manhattan and Scarsdale into 21,489 square feet of space at 560 White Plains Road in the Tarrytown Conference Center. In addition, AIG Claim Service signed a lease last month for 24,128 square feet of office space at 660 White Plains Road, also in the Tarrytown center, in a joint venture of Halpern Enterprises and the Robert Martin Company of Elmsford.
Three important corporate moves that were announced in 1994 began to take shape during the first half this year. Mastercard International began moving its corporate headquarters from Manhattan to Purchase, and the Ciba Corporation broke ground for an office-laboratory in the Tarrytown Corporate Center in what is the only new construction activity in Westchester undertaken in the last four years. Ciba is moving its United States headquarters from Ardsley to Tarrytown.
The move by Ciba, Mr. Halpern said, has helped generate a great deal of interest in the Tarrytown office complex. "Ciba's given the center a major boost toward establishing the Tarrytown Corporate Center as a prime headquarters location in Westchester," he said.
Construction has also begun on the re-adaptation of the 23-year-old building at 104 Corporate Park Drive in White Plains, which will serve as headquarters for Malcolm Pirnie, an environmental engineering company. The owner of the building is the Principal Mutual Life Insurance Company of Des Moines.
"I think it is inspirational to see how committed Principal Mutual is to Westchester," Mr. Cuddy said. "Principal owns nine office buildings in the county and what they are doing with them makes great economic sense."
As a precursor to new construction, Mr. Cuddy pointed out, the challenge is to recycle vacant inventory for new use. "For instance," he said, "buildings such as Corporate Park Drive, which were built in 1972, are tried and true in good locations.
"They were successful in their first long life and they will be again; 104 Corporate Park Drive is being gutted completely, stripped to the core, and will be entirely reconstructed for Malcolm Pirnie's use."
Such re-adaptations, Mr. Cuddy said, are a trend in the industry. "Re-adaptations will continue until the next cycle of new construction activity begins," he said. "Today's effort is to control cost, and the efficient re-use of existing inventories -- not speculative building -- is what people are doing."
And just recently, the Crosswest Office Center, a 133,000-square-foot building in White Plains, became fully leased, said Patrick Colwell of CB Commercial Real Estate Group, the leasing agent for the property. State Farm Insurance, Mr. Colwell said, signed a lease for an additional 2,910 square feet, completing the leasing program at Crosswest and increasing State Farm's presence in the building by almost 70 percent.
The vacant space that came on the market as a result of overbuilding in the 80's, Mr. Austin said, is finally being absorbed. "It was a shock when the go-go years ended," he said. "However, what is heartening is that Westchester is still perceived by the general market as offering good value to tenants in well-priced, quality buildings."
Most of the large blocks of space are gone, Mr. Austin continued, and "the heart of the market, which is the midsize market for 15,000 square feet of space to 50,000 square feet of space, has rebounded."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Workers at 104 Corporate Park Drive in White Plains. The office market has been steady. (Chris Maynard for The New York Times)
