NEW JERSEY
 
THE ADVERSARIES: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman versus the Communications Workers of America, representing 34,000 of the 65,000 unionized state workers.
 
THE ISSUES: The Governor wants to turn some state functions over to private contractors and wants union members to pay for part of their helath care if they do not join a managed-care plan.
 
THE STATE OF PLAY: Governor Whitman shifted 23 Division of Motor Vehicles offices to private hands, costing 334 ybuib hibs, She is still negotiating a new contract with the Communications Workers, which rejected settlements accepted by two smaller unions.
 
Besides the restrictions on health benefits, those new contracts provide for a two-year wage freeze and a flat cash bonus of about $1,000 per worker for each of the third and fourth years.
 
THE ADVERSARIES: The New Jersey Turnpike Authority versus the union that represents 1,500 toll collectors and maintenance workers.
 
THE ISSUES: Job security is the latest issue to stall negotiations for a new contract. Management wants to eliminate a contract provision that allows layoffs only as a result of an act of God.
 
THE STATE OF PLAY: The union offered to settle immediately or agree to a fact-finder's recommendation; management said no.
 
CONNECTICUT
 
THE ADVERSARIES: Gov. John G. Rowland versus 10 of the state's 30 unions covering 21,000 of 52,000 state workers.
 
THE ISSUES: Governor Rowland called for the State Senate to reject 10 arbitrated awards granting pay increases to state employees. Mr. Rowland said the state could not afford them, and they would make tax cuts impossible.
 
THE STATE OF PLAY: The State Senate overturned 9 of the 10 pay increases and sent them back for renegotiation. The State Police Union abandoned requests for retroactive pay increases for 1994 and 1995 in return for 3 percent raises in 1996 and 1997, no increase in 1998 and a 2 percent increase in 1999. The other contracts are in negotiation.
 
NEW YORK STATE
 
THE ADVERSARIES: Gov. George E. Pataki versus a variety of state employee unions in the state work force of 200,000.
 
THE ISSUES: The unions have been wary about what will happen to them if he pushes ahead with his vow to trim government.
 
THE STATE OF PLAY: Mr. Pataki settled contracts with 6 of 13 major bargaining units in his first 90 days in office. All salaries frozen for the current fiscal year, while promising raises and bonuses in future years.
There wree few major changes in benefits. The state budget includes about 3,000 layoffs, and cuts 4,700 more jobs through attrition and early retirement. With a $2.7 billion deficit expected next year, state workers are girding for the worst.
 
NEW YORK CITY
 
THE ADVERSARIES: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani versus unions representing 200,000 municipal workers.
 
THE ISSUES: The Mayor had made labor concessions a major element of his campaign to restructure city government. But he has, in fact, been quite pragmatic at the negotiating table.
 
THE STATE OF PLAY: When talks with the city's 83 municipal unions ended earlier this year, all matched the pattern set by former Mayor David N. Dinkins, with wage and benefit increases of 8.25 percent over 39 months and no concessions. Only the sanitation contract had any explicit agreements on productivity. The Mayor dropped a proposal that union members pay part of their health insurance, instead accepting a package of $600 million in savings from the unions, largely through renegotiating health costs. The city's work force has been cut by 16,000, primarily by paying workers to leave voluntarily, without resorting to the layoffs he had threatened.
 
THE ADVERSARIES: Mayor Giuliani versus 6,000 unionized school bus drivers.
 
THE ISSUES: The Mayor initiallyu pushed for competitive bidding on school busing. The union threatened towalk off the job if it lost provisions that guarantee its members jobs regardless of which companies hold the busing contracts.
 
THE STATE OF PLAY: The union agreed to forgo a pay increase this year and to delay pension, health and welfare payments. The bus companies agreed to take less money and, for the first time, to accept advertising on their buses, with all revenue going to the schools. The city gave in on a job guarantees.

HEADLINE: Link of Interest Rates to Budget Cuts Opposed

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: JACKSON HOLE, Wyo., Sept. 3

 BODY:
Politicians in Washington may hope that the Federal Reserve will quickly reduce short-term interest rates to reward efforts to balance the Federal budget. But the consensus among economists at the Fed's annual conference here this weekend was that such a move was neither likely nor wise.
 While top economists from around the world agreed that economic output in many countries would be slightly larger if the countries reduced their budget deficits, they argued that central banks should be slow to react to political promises of multiyear deficit-reduction programs. They said central banks should reduce interest rates only as budget deficits actually drop significantly. 
 Prof. John B. Taylor of Stanford University contended that if a country pursues the sort of seven-year budget-balancing effort now planned by Congressional Republicans, then the central bank should reduce short-term interest rates by no more than one-seventh of one percent each year for seven years, with each reduction dependent on a further drop in the deficit.
"These changes in monetary policy may appear remarkably small, and they would be nearly invisible compared to the typical fluctuations in interest rates during such a long transition period," he said in a paper presented at the conference, which was sponsored by the Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City.
Two professors, Laurence Ball of Johns Hopkins University and N. Gregory Mankiw of Harvard University, suggested that an even smaller reduction in interest rates might be warranted in the United States.
While Federal Reserve officials did not discuss their interest rate policies here, Alan Greenspan, the central bank's chairman, emphasized in his opening speech that deficit-reduction efforts in Western industrial democracies would have to be sustained to be effective.
"In assessing future risks, we must stress that today's actions and commitments are only the first step to fiscal reform that must be consolidated by future legislators," Mr. Greenspan said. "Indeed, the will and means to follow through are at least as important as the initial commitment to deficit reduction."
The seven-year Republican plan to balance the budget as well as the nine-year plan offered by President Clinton both require annual votes by Congress on whether to make progressively deeper cuts in spending. So the broad prescriptions of economists here would be for little reduction, if any, in interest rates this autumn in response to actions by the President or Congress.
Mr. Greenspan said that Mr. Taylor's paper "provides interesting insights into how monetary policy might adjust to a period of sustained fiscal consolidation." But the Fed chairman did not elaborate.
Interest rates might fall anyway if the Fed decides that it needs to stimulate the slowly growing American economy.
Historically, the argument among economists has been that a smaller deficit might brake short-term economic growth while accelerating long-term growth by insuring that more money is spent on productive private-sector investments. So a central bank might temporarily reduce interest rates to help the economy out of a temporary slowdown.
But Mr. Taylor argued that it was a mistake for a central bank to risk its credibility by lowering interest rates in response to deficit-reduction promises by politicians that might never be fulfilled.
The deficit-reduction efforts that have provoked such vigorous debate in Washington this year are tiny by the standards discussed by economists and foreign officials here this weekend. Finance Minister Goran Persson of Sweden won considerable admiration here when he described a shrinking of his country's budget deficit this year by an amount equal to 3.5 percent of the nation's economic output. By contrast, the Congressional Budget Office had estimated that the Republican budget targets adopted by Congress this summer would, if fully instituted, reduce the American budget deficit by $19 billion during the fiscal year that begins on Oct. 1, or a quarter of 1 percent of American economic output.
With the reduction, the American budget deficit would equal 2.3 percent of economic output, compared with 10 percent recently in Sweden.
Mr. Greenspan did allude to one possible effect of a lower budget deficit that might lead to reduced interest rates at some point. He said lower budget deficits tend to strengthen a country's currency, because international investors would perceive the country's economic prospects as improving and would want to buy stocks and bonds there.
Mr. Greenspan did not elaborate, but a stronger dollar in the United States would give the Federal Reserve more latitude to reduce interest rates. When the dollar is falling, high interest rates are needed to give investors a reason to keep their money here.
But several economists took issue with Mr. Greenspan's assessment of the link between a currency and a budget deficit. Martin Feldstein, a chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers under President Ronald Reagan, noted that smaller deficits mean a government is borrowing less money. With less competition from government, borrowers would be able to pay lower interest rates, and lower interest rates in financial markets would mean less demand for the currency.

HEADLINE: Factories in New York City Prosper in Niches

BYLINE: By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ 

 BODY:
New Yorkers often look at neighborhoods like Long Island City, Queens, and see only vacant warehouses and factories, idle piers and other fading remnants of the city's industrial past.
Few realize that a new plant on 38th Avenue produces fresh pita each day for the city's Greek diners and restaurants. Nor do they know that thousands of custom-made mannequins are churned out at a factory on 43d Avenue each year, just a few blocks from a company that assembles plastic teeth and jaws used to train dental students across the city. 
 "Most people tend to think that manufacturing is a thing of the past in the city," said Thomas P. Knierim, executive director of the Long Island City Business Development Corporation. "It's really incredible to see the wealth of products that are being produced here every day."
New York will never regain the industrial might it had just a generation ago when vast sugar refineries, breweries and paper mills dominated the streetscape of its industrial neighborhoods. But around the city -- particularly in Long Island City but also in neighborhoods like Red Hook, Brooklyn, and Flushing, Queens -- thousands of smaller plants and factories have survived and even prospered in a trend that may offer modest hope for the city's long-struggling manufacturing industries.
Experts say that many small manufacturers, new and old, have carved out niches within industries that feed the distinct and rapidly changing appetites of New Yorkers. Kronos Gyros Products Inc. provides pita for the city's Greek enclaves, Goldsmith Mannequins shapes customized mannequins for the garment industry, and Columbia Dentoform assembles fake teeth and jaws for dental students to sharpen their skills at schools like New York University.
From July 1994 to July 1995, the number of manufacturing jobs in New York rose modestly to 280,400, reversing a 19-year decline in the July figures, according to the State Department of Labor. The numbers come a year after a New York University study that said the 40-year exit of such jobs had finally come to a halt, in a shift that the study suggested was propelled by the emergence of specialized companies.
"It might be premature to speak of a complete turnaround," said Thomas Corban, a statistician with the Labor Department. "But it looks like manufacturing in New York City is holding its own."
While a number of businesses have profited from low-interest loans and other incentives provided through the city, many experts say manufacturing has been propelled by smart entrepreneurs willing to explore new markets. "It's a lot of intrepid manufacturers," said Richard Werber, the director of marketing for the Industrial Technology Assistance Corporation, a nonprofit group that helps companies obtain grants and other assistance.
Many of the businesses have been aided by other forces as well, including technological advances that make it possible to manufacture an assortment of products on smaller and smaller scales. And a lot of what New York's manufacturers make is still rather ordinary: scaffolding, sheet metal, staples, newspapers and magazines, belts, dresses, earrings and necklaces.
But a number of companies have prospered by tapping rapidly evolving markets that cater to the city's immigrants, artists, fashion designers and restaurateurs, among others. Every day, these companies produce quiches, Indian spices, French bread and fried vegetable chips, as well as theater costumes, mannequins, customized picture frames, false teeth, dyed ostrich feathers and CD-ROM's.
"New York's great advantage in manufacturing is product innovation," said Mitchell L. Moss, the director of the Urban Research Center at New York University. He wrote the study describing the city's shifting industrial base, which was financed by the State Urban Development Corporation and the Sloan Foundation.
"There's a constant search for the new products in New York because we have such an enormous market with very sophisticated tastes," Professor Moss added.
Nowhere is the changing face of manufacturing more evident than in Long Island City, the sprawling industrial heartland of New York, where nearly 50,000 workers arrive each morning to make things.
No single company can boast dominance in this scruffy neighborhood of cobblestone streets, squat warehouses and aging docks. Rather, it is the smaller companies that form Long Island City's industrial backbone, employing an average of 25 workers in factory spaces that are usually no more than 50,000 square feet.
Gone are the days when a manufacturing titan like the Silvercup Bakery churned out truckloads of bread at its plant on Queens Bridge Plaza. But Long Island City has Demetri Astin. He makes pita, and his story typifies the experience of today's New York industrialist.
An immigrant from Athens, Mr. Astin began his business, Kronos Gyros Products, about 14 years ago in a small factory with the modest aim of selling pita to New York's Greek diners and restaurants. But in a city with a constant craving for new tastes, the bread's popularity quickly spread beyond the Greek community.
"It took off," said Mr. Astin, who built a block-long plant on 38th Avenue a few years ago to keep up with the orders from his 2,000 customers.
"It's the same thing that happened with Goya," he added, referring to the company that made its name selling food to Hispanic customers. "Everyone uses their product now, not only the Hispanics."
These small businesses must contend with high taxes, crime and all the other problems that come with running a business in the city, and many owners say they have considered moving out of New York. But they have stayed largely because they feel they must be close to their New York customers. No fax machine or modem connection can match having the client right there in the plant as critical decisions are being made.
Just ask Mark Goldsmith, whose company, Goldsmith Mannequins, each year makes 8,000 of the figures that inhabit department store windows and aisles all over the city.
It's important for him to have the designers of stores like Bloomingdale's and Saks Fifth Avenue nearby to help his staff decide whether, say, the skin tone and eye color of a line of mannequins are just right.
He recalled how designers from Giorgio Armani made frequent trips to the plant on 43d Avenue a few weeks ago as his sculptors and painters worked on 150 custom-tailored mannequins for the fashion-design firm.
The Armani designers would often bring along a few outfits, drape them on the working models and then offer one suggestion after another. "Those people must have been in here 20 times making changes," Mr. Goldsmith said.
But such are the burdens of dealing in a niche market. "We're like the people who make the Polynesian umbrellas that go in drinks," he said. "You don't think about it, but some factory somewhere is whipping those things out."
The same can be said about the production of fake teeth. It's a market that has been cornered by a small company called Columbia Dentoform, whose major clients include New York University and Columbia University.
Every week, the company gets special orders from professors of dentistry requesting new kinds of practice models to train their students: mouths that need root canals, bridgework, braces and the like. Company technicians even visit the schools to help install new models in classrooms.
"You get to know teeth after doing this for a few years," said Carlos Munoz, who molds about 2,800 molars, incisors and other teeth each day at the company's plant on 41st Avenue.
Many factory owners say New York offers another important asset to companies producing custom-tailored goods: a pool of experienced graphic artists, metalworkers, designers, sculptors, painters and other laborers with specialized skills.
New York's immigrant enclaves, for instance, are so chock-full of seasoned tailors that the Eaves & Brooks Costume Company has been placing want ads in the city's foreign-language papers for years.
"We're getting first-class cutters and tailors," said Guy Geoly, the vice president of the company, which makes costumes for Broadway shows, movie companies, circuses and ice shows at its plant on 41st Avenue near the foot of the Queensboro Bridge. These days, the tailors arrive with Russian accents.
"Where else are you going to get workers like this?" Mr. Geoly wondered. "Down South?"

HEADLINE: Black Businesses on the Internet: A Market That Was 'Invisible Until Now'

BYLINE: By STEPHEN C. MILLER 

 BODY:
William Jordan Jr., an electrical engineer, and his brother, Rodney, a software designer, wanted to test their concept of "the uncut black experience" -- blacks marketing to blacks and controlling the experience.
And what better way to do that than to use the Internet's World Wide Web? It offers small black businesses an inexpensive way to market goods and services to a vast audience of blacks and others. An estimated 10 million to 30 million people worldwide use the Internet. 
 With these advantages, a growing number of black entrepreneurs are counting on the Internet to help small businesses.
The Jordans are co-owners of the New Perspective Technologies Company, which markets Internet services to minority businesses and has offices in Norfolk, Va., and Washington. And now the company also operates Melanet, a name derived from "melanin," a brown or black pigment that colors the skin, hair or eyes. The 20 Melanet clients include a specialist book publisher and a funeral home. The Jordans say Melanet turned a profit three months after it was set up.
William Jordan says the low cost of Web pages makes the Internet more attractive and less risky to small businesses than to large corporations. "A large company might invest $1 million in putting up a Web site and will expect to get back $3 million," he explained. "A small firm might invest $500 for a presence on the Web and be happy with a return of $1,000."
Internet users are a sought-after market niche: they are well educated and likely to spend money for products on the Net. Forrester Research, a marketing research company in Cambridge, Mass., said revenue from sales of goods and services through interactive retail totaled $240 million last year and is expected to total $6.9 billion by the year 2000.
Many businesses that sell to black Internet users believe that the market is a multimillion-dollar niche. In a 1993 study, the Census Bureau said that 19 percent of the 22.8 million homes with computers were occupied by blacks.
The first company on Melanet was United Brothers and United Sisters Communications Systems Inc., a book publisher in Hampton, Va., that specializes in African and African-American themes. H. Khalif Khalifah, the chief executive, said that by using the service he was discovering "black professionals who have been invisible until now."
The Internet is also helping Mr. Khalifah build a global mailing list of potential customers. He culls the names from a list of Web-site visitors who fill out an electronic form for a free copy of "The Black Book Guide." The newsletter reports on the publishing and marketing of books with African and African-American themes.
It costs Mr. Khalifah only about $100 a month to maintain his Web page. "We've gotten inquiries from as far away as Holland and Japan," Mr. Khalifah said, "and these are people we would not have gotten before we were on the Internet."
Michael Tuyo, co-founder of Object Oriented Information Systems, or O2IS, a software and Internet consulting company in Cambridge, Mass., is equally sanguine about cybermarketing. O2IS operates Afrinet Central, a Web site offering minority business information.
Mr. Tuyo's company is an Internet provider, helping other companies connect directly to the Net. Most companies rent space on the systems of Internet providers and then sell advertising space.
Net Noir Inc., a media company based in San Francisco, started offering its Afrocentric Net Noir Online service on America Online on June 19.
Tony Brown, the host of "Tony Brown's Journal," the PBS public-affairs show, plans to provide Internet service later this summer with "Tony Brown on Line."
Mr. Brown says he is spending more than $1 million to set up his service in a fiercely competitive arena that is dominated by Internet powerhouses: Netcom, P.S.I. and the older commercial on-line services like Compuserve, Prodigy and America Online. He says the service can foster economic self-reliance in the black community, because technology can bring people together not only for commerce but also to come up with creative solutions to social problems.
Mr. Tuyo, too, has a social agenda. "I would like to see blacks become producers instead of consumers; it's time we provided the services," he said.
Not everyone believes cybermarketing is the best use of the Internet. "The Web should be used as an informational device," said Craig Settles, president of Successful Marketing Strategists, in Berkeley, Calif., one of the few companies dealing with cyberspace marketing strategies. "It's going to take time for people to become comfortable with shopping on line."

HEADLINE: Economics Sinks In At Gay Publications

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP 

 BODY:
Debuts, departures and diversification are transforming the segment of the publishing industry devoted to gay and lesbian concerns, as the companies search for new ways to survive economically.
Because magazines and books play a crucial role in linking otherwise disparate homosexual communities, publishers have often put political and editorial missions ahead of financial strategies. As a result, many have gone under. 
 "The most radical thing we could do is put out a publication that actually supports itself," said Michael Goff, president and editor in chief of Out Publishing Inc. of Manhattan, whose flagship is Out magazine.
In its slick brassiness, Out is a far cry from the furtively published newsletters of the 1950's, but it is heir to the tradition of serving readers who find little of their own lives reflected in the general press.
"The gay and lesbian press not only reported on the community, it helped to create it," wrote Urvashi Vaid, in "Virtual Equality," her new book on the lesbian and gay political and cultural movement.
Perhaps the best-known publication is The Advocate, which began in 1967 as mimeographed sheet. Today, it is a glossy magazine that shares news racks with scores of other publications. The Mulryan/Nash advertising agency in New York tracks 128 newspapers and magazines aimed at gay men and lesbians, with a combined circulation estimated at 2.9 million.
But the publishing graveyard is also quite full. Troy Masters knows that well, having been the advertising director of Outweek, which closed in 1991, and the publisher of the weekly QW, which shut down in 1992.
That is why he began New York City's newest lesbian and gay newspaper, LGNY, without so much as an office. "We did the publication entirely electronically," he said. "All of us had modems hooked up and we worked from home."
LGNY, a tabloid sheet that costs $1.25, has published twice monthly since April. About 9,000 copies are being sold, said Mr. Masters, who is the publisher. And the staff has moved into an office, at 225 Lafayette Street. Mr. Masters would not discuss revenue, but said some issues had made money. Most advertisers are local merchants.
LGNY has a home page on the Internet (http://gravity.fly.net/ lgny), with articles, listings, a directory and a calendar of events. Out magazine jumped on line in June (http://www.out.com/) and soon plans to offer news, listings and guides from at least 15 publications across the country and in Canada, including The Washington Blade and Homo Xtra in New York.
This summer, Out began producing HRCF Quarterly for the Human Rights Campaign Fund, a national lesbian and gay political group. The company even lent its name to "Out Classics," a compact disk with works by gay composers.
"Any gay publications that have been successful have other areas of business," said Sarah Pettit, the editor of Out, which is three years old and claims a circulation of 100,000.
Until recently, The Advocate was on such shaky financial footing that it depended for survival on revenue from companion publications -- Advocate Classifieds, Advocate Men and Freshmen -- which contain sexually explicit material.
Now that has begun to change, thanks in part to the growing number of mainstream advertisements in The Advocate, which guarantees a minimum of 75,000 readers.
"It's finally turning a profit after 28 years," said Jeff Yarbrough, editor in chief of The Advocate and editorial director of the parent company, Liberation Publications Inc., based in Los Angeles. "We feel we're ready for the challenge of taking on new media enterprises."
The biggest step in this direction was the acquisition four months ago of Alyson Publications Inc., a Boston publishing house. The terms of the sale were not disclosed.
While Alyson is best known for the children's books "Heather Has Two Mommies" by Leslea Newman and "Daddy's Roommate" by Michael Willhoite, it has published books by and about gay black men, bisexuals, deaf people and teen-agers, as well as lesbian erotica and political histories -- about 250 titles in all. Sasha Alyson founded the house in 1980.
Mr. Yarbrough said the annual list of 20 titles would be more than doubled by 1997. The new editor in chief and associate publisher is Helen Eisenbach, a novelist and playwright who was executive editor of QW and a senior editor at NAL/Dutton. The first new hardcover title will be "Gays on the Right," edited by Richard L. Tafel.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Troy Masters, the publisher of LGNY, New York City's newest lesbian and gay newspaper, in his Manhattan office. (Jim Estrin/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Soul-Searching on Labor Day

 BODY:
For at least two decades, it has been a ritual of Labor Day in America to point out the decline and fall of organized labor. The political downward spiral of unions is underscored this year by a Republican Congress vowing to undo job safety regulations and other hard-won achievements of workers. But Labor Day of 1995 also arrives with a rare opportunity for labor's renewal. The beginning in earnest of the 1996 Presidential election campaign comes just as labor's own leadership is engaging in an unusual bout of soul-searching.
Criticism of organized labor's past lethargy and parochialism is echoing through the fierce battle for the presidency of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., which got under way after the retirement last month of the venerable but stolid Lane Kirkland. Reflecting the times of his long tenure, Mr. Kirkland often seemed more interested in cold war politics abroad than the erosion of union strength at home. Now his handpicked successor, Thomas Donahue, may well be swept from office by a vigorous challenge from an insurgent, John Sweeney. 
 Mr. Sweeney comes out of the service worker sector, a place that is more ethnically diverse and, more importantly, is growing in strength. But both he and Mr. Donahue are talking about the need for a younger leadership and greater efforts to organize workers. At a time of rising anxiety among American workers over job security and standards of living, union leaders argue -- not surprisingly -- that the solution to these problems is more unions.
The A.F.L-C.I.O.'s favorite statistic, for example, shows that living standards have declined at almost the same rate as the percentage of the American work force that is unionized. What this statistic ignores, though, is that unionized workers themselves have had to make wage and benefit concessions to avoid layoffs as company after company has downsized. Clearly the underlying problems cannot be addressed by organizing alone.
The 1996 Presidential election, which will intensify after this weekend's traditional political events, ought to be a forum on how technology and overseas competition are throwing Americans out of work and suppressing wages -- and on the best response to turn that decline around. So far, however, the Republican candidates are relying on the tired litany of blaming everything on taxes and government regulations. Some are doing even worse, stirring up trouble by telling workers that their problems will be solved if only the nation scraps affirmative action, beats up on the children of illegal immigrants or -- in the case of Patrick Buchanan -- walks away from free trade.
There is little doubt that the labor movement will line up with the Democrats once again, despite many workers' disappointment with Bill Clinton. Unions fought the White House on Nafta and lost. They fought shoulder to shoulder with the White House on health care and lost. But the President is right to repeat again and again that the only response to international competition and technological change is to invest in a trained and educated work force.
Labor Day is a good time to recognize that workers and companies must undertake together the task of finding solutions to the problems afflicting the work force. In their scramble to improve profits and productivity, businesses must take some responsibility for providing a climate of prosperity and security for their workers as well as shareholders, perhaps by helping to train and educate their employees to compete. On the political side, organized labor can play a constructive role in the coming campaign if it moves beyond its usual tactic of bartering for legislative tidbits and forces a debate on economic and social issues that a lot of the candidates would be happy to ignore.

HEADLINE: Helpful Corporate Pressure on Cuba

 BODY:
Frustrated as they watch foreign companies making deals with Cuba, American business executives have increased pressure on the Clinton Administration to end the American economic embargo. That is a healthy sign. Corporate pressure was a key element in the recent change in policy toward Vietnam.
Cuba does not loom large as a market for the United States. But for some businesses it could represent significant opportunities, and it is galling for these companies' executives to watch helplessly while corporations from Japan, Canada, Europe and other Latin American nations take advantage of Cuba's new openness. 
 American telecommunications companies have had to stand by while Grupo Domos, a Mexican corporation, recently signed a huge deal to overhaul Cuba's telephone system. Louisiana rice growers would love to recapture what was once their biggest export market. Otis Elevator fears that Japanese manufacturers will move in to replace Otis equipment installed throughout Havana before Fidel Castro took power.
Executives confronting Assistant Secretary of State Alexander Watson at a recent State Department briefing, however, received the worn, formulaic response: "This Administration will maintain the embargo until major democratic change takes place in Cuba."
The business people at the meeting were not mollified. They pointed out to Mr. Watson the inconsistency in Washington's stance towards other Communist countries, notably China and Vietnam, where trade has gone forward despite the presence of authoritarian governments. As Mr. Watson noted at the meeting, however, Cuba is a special case.
The primary reason is the influence of the Cuban exile community. The Cuban American National Foundation, which has worked tirelessly for the overthrow of Mr. Castro, contributes heavily to Congressional campaigns and sways a large bloc of voters in Florida. Few politicians, including Presidents, have chosen to tangle with so powerful a lobby.
But the unity of the exile community is beginning to crack. Its leaders' messianic insistence on deposing Mr. Castro has begun to alienate a younger generation and more recent arrivals from Cuba. In June, Eloy Gutierrez Menoyo, a man with impeccable anti-Castro credentials -- he spent 22 years in a Cuban jail -- visited Havana and spent three hours talking with Mr. Castro. Mr. Gutierrez represents a new, moderate faction in the Cuban diaspora, a faction recognizing that many Cubans still support Mr. Castro.
Cuba has kept its commitments to the United States on immigration. With the end of the cold war, it poses no security threat to the United States. Yet the sanctions on Havana are tighter than those imposed on Iraq. Legislation now before Congress -- which President Clinton has sensibly threatened to veto -- would tighten sanctions even further.
The legislation has clearly alarmed many business people. Some of its provisions would threaten their subsidiaries in other countries that already do business with Cuba. If the executives are serious about changing Cuba policy, they need to help the Administration find the courage to take on the conservative exile lobby, and make their wishes known to Congress. They are on the right track.

HEADLINE: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;
Finally Reckoning With Rock History

BYLINE: By JON PARELES 

DATELINE: CLEVELAND, Sept. 3

 BODY:
Chuck Berry had the first word and the last at the Concert for the Rock-and-Roll Hall of Fame and Museum on Saturday night, nearly seven hours of rock oldies and tributes performed for the 60,000 people at Cleveland Stadium and those watching the live HBO telecast. At 2:15 A.M. Sunday, with Bruce Springsteen at his side, he sang, "It's got a backbeat, you can't lose it/Any old way you choose it." He was a living symbol of rock's heritage being honored and preserved; so is the Hall of Fame.
The concert, of songs by Hall of Fame members, was a show of rock unity. Pioneers from the 1950's (Little Richard, Johnny Cash, Jerry Lee Lewis) and figures from the 1960's and 70's (James Brown, Robbie Robertson of the Band, the Kinks, Booker T and the MG's, Martha and the Vandellas, the Allman Brothers Band, George Clinton, Sam Moore of Sam and Dave, Jackson Browne) shared the bill, and sometimes the stage, with current hit makers (Melissa Etheridge, John Mellencamp, Jon Bon Jovi, Natalie Merchant, Slash) who played old songs. 
 There were glorious moments: Al Green singing Sam Cooke's "Change Is Gonna Come" and trying to top Aretha Franklin in a duet; John Fogerty belting his Creedence Clearwater Revival songs; Bob Dylan and Bruce Springsteen trading verses on "Forever Young"; Soul Asylum backing both Lou Reed in "Sweet Jane" and Iggy Pop in "Back Door Man." And there were embarrassing ones: Sheryl Crow singing Rolling Stones songs (by imitating Bonnie Raitt); Jackson Browne trying Bob Marley's "Redemption Song"; the Gin Blossoms attempting the Beatles' vocal harmonies in "Wait." For iconoclasm's sake, Chrissie Hynde, from Akron, led the Pretenders in "My City Was Gone," a song denouncing urban renewal in Ohio -- the kind of program that led to the construction of the $92 million Hall of Fame. But at the concert, music that has been the battle cry in generational warfare became, for the occasion, a link between eras.
The concert proved that "you can't lose it"; the museum decides how to choose it. The Hall of Fame, which requires careers dating back at least 25 years for inclusion, is only one exhibit in the larger museum, which presents rock artifacts and information from the pre-rock era to the present. At the summit is the Hall of Fame, a dark, quiet rotunda with illuminated signatures and a tone that hovers between reverential and funereal. But the remainder of the museum is a clamorous, eye-popping display that brings together artifacts and ephemera with films, video and multimedia computer data bases. Despite gaps and quirks, its inaugural installation is a promising start.
The museum has a message: that rock-and-roll is a liberating force, and that the ideas and emotions it reveals may be troublesome but must be reckoned with. Visitors are guided initially toward a film, "Mystery Train," that celebrates rock-and-roll as both a grand synthesis of American music -- blues, country, gospel, work songs, jazz -- and the antidote to 1950's suburban blandness. In another room, banks of video screens on opposite walls zoom through history, with Presidents and news events on one side, contemporaneous rock on the other. A 185-seat upstairs theater, which will double as a lecture hall, presents a 20-minute film, "Rock Is," that shows both exhilaration and self-destructive excesses, including drug use.
Evocative objects and documents are everywhere. Naturally, there are plenty of well-strummed guitars and flashy stage costumes, most of them contoured to extremely skinny bodies. The museum exhibits Buddy Holly's high school diploma, parts of Otis Redding's crashed airplane, U2's record-company rejection letters, a receipt for $5,000 from Col. Tom Parker to Sam Phillips for exclusive rights to Elvis Presley's career, and detailed notes from Aretha Franklin on how an album should be remixed.
Jim Morrison's mother provided material from his elementary-school years, including a block-lettered page reading "I Love You, Mother" -- which takes on resonance in the light of his Oedipal recitation in "The End" -- and report cards indicating his need for "a firm hand in the classroom." John Lennon's report card shows that one teacher considered him "hopeless," while a homemade magazine he drew as a child shows that his wry, sardonic humor was formed early. Handwritten lyrics from Jimi Hendrix, Mr. Berry, Mr. Springsteen, Neil Young, Paul Simon and the Ramones, among others, are reminders that rock is the work of people who scribble things down and fiddle with rough drafts.
Like most museums, the Hall of Fame is most self-assured when dealing with the distant past, where there is some historical consensus. On entering, visitors can read about important pre-rock performers from Hank Williams to the Platters to Ma Rainey. Touch-screen computer terminals link rock musicians to two influences each, with capsule biographies and audio and video clips; the Doors, for instance, hook up to Howlin' Wolf's blues and Kurt Weill's cabaret songs. But with rock's explosive growth, and its constant splintering, there's no single narrative for the museum to follow after the 1950's. "This isn't the complete story of rock-and-roll," said Jim Henke, the chief curator, "and I'm not trying to pretend it is."
From about 1960 onward, the museum goes channel surfing through rock history. This is very much a video-era museum. Its film clips are quick-cut montages, impressionistic rather than narrative; for more linear information gathering, visitors can use computer terminals to read biographies and hear songs.
Rock is an audible medium and a performance medium; like African masks, it is best appreciated while in motion. As a result, some of the hall's best material is intangible: a virtual museum of songs, images, voices. One extraordinary exhibit is a room holding old radios, headphones and computer terminals that allow visitors to hear disk jockeys (arranged by decade, region and city) from the 1930's to the 1990's, including, of course, Alan Freed in Cleveland.
There's a wall of blues, rhythm-and-blues and gospel memorabilia across from exhibits devoted to seven city styles: Memphis rockabilly, New Orleans rhythm-and-blues, San Francisco psychedelia, Motown soul, New York and London punk, Seattle grunge, New York hip-hop (which gets extremely sketchy treatment) and Jamaican reggae. The British Invasion and other scenes may get their chance later.
There's an exhibit on obsessive fans, including a sunburst of one collector's hundreds of autographed drumsticks; there's a display of one-hit wonders, explaining how they reached their brief moment of popularity. There are displays from the archives of Sun Records and Atlantic Records. (Although Atlantic's chairman, Ahmet Ertegun, started the nonprofit foundation that runs the museum, his label deserves its place in the museum for its role in rhythm-and-blues and rock.)
And there are wall cases and floor displays devoted to individuals or groups, including the Who, Elvis Presley, the Allman Brothers, Madonna and Michael Jackson (where the identifying label reads, "Collection of Michael Jackson, King of Pop," presumably a condition of the loan). For some reason, the Everly Brothers have two spaces.
The museum's larger exhibits raise questions of emphasis and omission. Its displays depend on its collection; its collection comes from gifts and loans, since its organizers did not want it to become a player in the memorabilia market. And its center of gravity is in 1960's and 70's rock bands led primarily by white singers and songwriters, the kind of music rock critics find easiest to discuss. "In the end, rock-and-roll comes down to the song," one wall label reads, a position that might be argued by fans of dance rhythms or people who just love the noise.
The emphasis is probably a combination of curatorial decisions and the contents of the collections. Because costumes and stage props are simply larger and more flamboyant than other materials, performers who have provided them have an edge. The Rolling Stones, who provided a historical survey of Jagger costumes, are extolled as rock's greatest touring band; the Grateful Dead, who were on the road constantly, turn up only in the San Francisco exhibit and in a memorial row of Jerry Garcia photographs. But the Dead were never as theatrical as the Stones.
There's a big floor display for Z. Z. Top's fuzzy drums and car-shaped bass guitar. Yet Bob Dylan, a far more important figure who has apparently not donated anything, is represented only by a few wall posters, and Van Morrison, another Hall of Fame member, appears entirely absent. All he does, however, is sing.
Because theatricality makes for eye-catching exhibits, the museum overemphasizes rock's connection with fashion. The designer Stephen Sprouse, who is the curator of the costume displays, is drawn to glitter and androgyny. A large exhibit that shows David Bowie and Iggy Pop as deities of a polysexual rock menagerie, includes costumes from such obscure groups as the Dopes and Psychotica.
But while the museum has plenty of sequins and spiked hair, it underestimates rock's T-shirted hordes, whose rebellious machismo led them to thrash-metal bands and gangster rap, the two styles that currently annoy teen-agers' parents and bear the brunt of anti-rock agitation. Neither has much presence in the museum, although earlier rebellions are celebrated.
Because it concentrates on songwriting by individual performers, the museum misses some other possibilities as well. It could examine rock's rhythmic evolution, which would make a fine display of dancing from twist to techno to mosh (glimpsed in the "Rock Is" film) while tracing the beat. It could, perhaps from its existing archives, cast an eye on music-business practices, including the art of the contract. It could look at evolving instrument and recording technology, from 12-string guitars to computers. It could dissect a song as an electronic collage as well as an artistic statement.
Still, the Rock-and-Roll Hall of Fame and Museum has to start somewhere, and it succeeds in its main goal: to capture rock's energy and silliness as well as its serious social impact. Now that what Mick Jagger once called "the phantom temple of rock" has been built and organized, it can easily add a few new riffs.

HEADLINE: Why Should We Adjust to Job Market Reality?;
Women's 76 Percent

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Danielle Crittenden in "Yes, Motherhood Lowers Pay" (Op-Ed, Aug. 22) misunderstands both economics and biology in her effort to defend the inequality of working women as a product of genetic wiring. 
 Ms. Crittenden is mistaken to think that her $800 in income "contributed" to the gender gap in wages where women earn only 76 percent of men. The 76 percent figure applies only to full-time employees; if unemployed and underemployed women like her were added in, the gender gap would increase dramatically.
Nor is it true that women who don't have children have achieved equality; this particular subset of women who sacrifice family for a career still face the cumulative effects of discrimination down the road.
There is no biological imperative for women to be paid less than men. It is true that women who have children will probably suffer economically for a variety of reasons: Because child care in America is inadequate (although I know of no studies proving its "unhealthiness," as Ms. Crittenden claims), and because men are paid more than women, it is sometimes financially rational for women to stay home and raise children.
But these are issues to take up with Congress, not Nature. There is nothing in my genetic code that makes me care less about a child than a woman does. The difference is in cultural conditioning and economic opportunities.
Ms. Crittenden fails to see that discriminating against mothers is only a subset of discrimination against women. What we need are not more excuses for inequality, but a change in society's expectations of paternal responsibilities and a change in the routine discrimination women face, so that we can make sure motherhood is not incompatible with equal participation in the work force.
 
JOHN K. WILSON
Chicago, Aug. 25, 1995

HEADLINE: Why Should We Adjust to Job Market Reality?;
Raise World Wages

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "Leaky Boats on the Rising Tide" (Op-Ed, Aug. 29), Steven Rattner seems to be speaking to difficulties faced by a small percentage of young professionals, rather than average workers. 
 The trend of falling wages for the overwhelming majority of Americans will defy any job-training scheme. It does not stem from a "mismatch between the skills of the work force and the jobs that are available," as Mr. Rattner suggests, but from the huge surplus of labor in the world market. As long as labor is available worldwide at bargain-basement rates, most Americans can count on a combination of wage declines and job losses.
Policy prescriptions by European governments to keep wages from falling have worked, but at the cost of increased unemployment, a cure that is arguably worse than the disease, especially in the United States, where our social safety net has more holes. Any idea to keep wages from falling further in the United States will have to include an international component that raises wages in the developing world.
 
DOOLEY ADCROFT
New York, Aug. 30, 1995

HEADLINE: Don't Let New York's Maritime Business Die

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your Aug. 30 news article on questions about the maritime industry's future in New York City raises an important issue for Brooklyn and for the city. It is time for a reassessment of the mission of the Port Authority. However, to suggest that the city would be "better off if it let some or all of its commercial shipping business just die" is misguided, shortsighted and unwise, particularly with regard to Brooklyn's waterfront. 
 Brooklyn was at one time the national leader in maritime commerce and trade. Unfortunately, much of its working waterfront has been made obsolete. This condition is the result of a failure to respond to changes in shipping technology and the perpetual delay in providing direct rail freight access and a permanent rail freight float operation across New York Harbor to Brooklyn. However, a unified effort on the part of the Federal, state and city governments can reverse this condition and result in an expansion of the maritime industry.
One example of what a concerted effort can produce was demonstrated over the past year as Brooklyn's only major shipping terminal, the Red Hook Containerport, experienced an almost 100 percent increase in volume of cargo passing through the facility.
However, except for the Red Hook Containerport, the state, the city and the Port Authority have done little, if anything, over the past 15 years to maintain, develop or expand the infrastructure and the facilities necessary to restore maritime commerce and trade to Brooklyn.
Specifically, the 65th Street Rail Park in Bay Ridge must be completed. Reconstruction must be done on the Second Avenue Rail Line in Sunset Park.
These projects are critical for the cost-effective transfer of goods from the Brooklyn waterfront to the rest of the country. In addition, major improvements are needed at the South Brooklyn Marine Terminal in Sunset Park in order for that facility to meet its full potential.
With Brooklyn's natural deep-water facilities, and the completion of these infrastructure projects, Brooklyn can once again regain its status as the premier maritime center for the region.
Public agencies like the Port Authority and the New York City Economic Development Corporation must work with the maritime industry, labor and elected officials to develop a strategy for improving rail and highway connections as well as the construction of modern shipping facilities. These agencies should also undertake an aggressive marketing campaign to attract maritime commerce and trade back to Brooklyn and New York City.
The recent report on the role of the Port Authority, prepared by the New York City Department of City Planning, points out that the Port Authority has failed to provide adequate rail and freight access to the east side of the Hudson River. Moreover, the report says the Port Authority has used most of its resources to promote marine activities and infrastructure projects on the New Jersey side of the river, to the detriment of Brooklyn and New York City.
I have long had concerns about the direction the Port Authority should take in Brooklyn and the rest of the region. There is a tremendous need for a truly open dialogue among the Governors of New York and New Jersey, as well as the mayors, county executives and borough presidents within the New York-New Jersey Port District, in order to discuss the appropriate mission and role of the Port Authority.
I look forward to participating in that dialogue.
 
HOWARD GOLDEN
President, Borough of Brooklyn
Brooklyn, Aug. 30, 1995

HEADLINE: Hoffa Opens Drive For Father's Post

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Sept. 4

 BODY:
James P. Hoffa formally announced today that he was running for the post his father once held: president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.
"I run because I see a great union on the edge of financial collapse while an incumbent administration spends us into bankruptcy," Mr. Hoffa, a 54-year-old labor lawyer and executive assistant to the president of the Michigan teamsters' joint council, said before the start of Detroit's Labor Day parade. A crowd of several thousand interrupted with chants of "Hoffa, Hoffa, Hoffa." 
 Mr. Hoffa's father, James R. Hoffa, disappeared in Detroit in 1975 while trying to run again for the presidency of the teamsters. He had led the union in the late 1950's and early 60's before being convicted of mail fraud and jury tampering and being sent to prison in 1967. His 13-year prison sentence was commuted by President Richard M. Nixon in 1971.
The younger Mr. Hoffa wants to unseat Ron Carey as head of the 1.4-million-member teamsters union in 1996. It is only the second time the union's rank and file has selected a president. The first elected president was Mr. Carey, who ran in 1991 on a platform promising reform.

HEADLINE: PRESIDENT REBUTS SOME G.O.P. THEMES ON ECONOMIC WOES

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: MONTEREY, Calif., Sept. 4

 BODY:
Directly challenging some of the Presidential campaign themes of California's Republican Governor, President Clinton today told a cheering crowd here that immigration, affirmative action and welfare were not responsible for the economic distress of the middle class.
In a day that strongly resembled a Labor Day campaign kickoff, in a state crucial to his re-election hopes, Mr. Clinton said the answers to stagnant wages lay instead with a higher minimum wage and more education and training programs for workers, two initiatives the White House has advocated against Republican opposition. And he reminded his listeners to remember their roots. 
 "We should never, ever permit ourselves to get into a position where we forget that almost everybody here came from somewhere else and that America is a set of ideas and values and convictions that makes us strong," the President said to cries of support from more than 10,000 people.
Mr. Clinton came to California, a state that has lagged much of the nation in economic recovery, to dedicate a new state university at Monterey Bay. The university is at the former site of Fort Ord, an Army post that was closed in 1994.
The President did not mention the state's Governor, Pete Wilson, by name. But he stepped squarely onto the turf of Mr. Wilson, who has based much of his campaign for the 1996 Republican Presidential nomination on a crackdown on illegal immigration and an end to racial preference programs, as well as budget cutting and tough laws against career criminals.
Mr. Clinton noted that despite a thriving economy the median wage had dropped by 1 percent over the past 30 months. "In the next year or so, all of you are going to have to decide what you think the answer to this wage problem is," he said. "There are people who will tell you that the answer, the real reason middle class wages are stagnant, is that welfare people are taking all your money away or that we have too many immigrants, or that affirmative action is destroying opportunities for the middle class."
Mr. Clinton conceded that the country had too many illegal immigrants, that an overhaul of welfare was needed and that some affirmative action programs had to be changed. But, he said, "that's not the real reason for the middle class economic anxieties."
In a jab at Mr. Wilson, he said: "We've done what we could to close the borders and send people back. But you know what? This is a nation of immigrants. Most of us do not have ancestors who were born here."
Freshly sunburned and appearing rested after three weeks of vacation, Mr. Clinton also looked toward the confrontation looming with the Republican-dominated Congress over the budget. Advocating his own plan to balance the budget over 10 years, he said, "The decisions made in the next 60 to 90 days will determine what kind of country we're going to be in the 21st century."
Mr. Clinton carried California in 1992 with 46 percent of the vote, and he has marked its significance to his re-election chances by returning here 19 times since he became President. Yet another visit is planned in two weeks for fund-raising events in Los Angeles and San Francisco.
Mr. Clinton spoke of a Japanese-American veteran with whom he had played golf in Hawaii, where he had gone over the weekend to commemorate the 50th anniversary of the end of World War II. The man, the President said, had fought for America although he had been placed in an internment camp and two of his brothers were in uniform in Japan. One of the atomic bombs dropped in Japan damaged the man's former home and his mother and youngest brother subsequently died of radiation poisoning.
"There's not another country in the world that could tell that story," the President said. "Why? Because people all over the world wanted to be part of what is America. And we should never forget that."
On affirmative action, the President said he opposed quotas and reverse discrimination. "But I am for making a conscious effort to bring the American people together," he added.
Despite his strong defense of immigrants today, Mr. Clinton has called for a crackdown on illegal immigration at the border. And he has endorsed a recommendation of a commission on immigration reform, headed by former Representative Barbara Jordan of Texas, that legal immigration into the United States be sharply reduced.
In an interview with The San Jose Mercury News given on his way to California, he said, "You can make a good case for a modest reduction of the quota on legal immigration."
Mr. Wilson was out of the state today, in Washington to hold fund-raisers and make speeches on the topic of welfare. The state's Democratic Lieutenant Governor, Gray Davis, attended the Monterey dedication as acting governor.
Asked later why the President had not criticized Mr. Wilson by name, the White House spokesman, Michael D. McCurry, said, "It's still 1995." But the day had 1996 written all over it.
Mr. Clinton's decision to visit Monterey Bay, for example, highlighted the Federal Government's role in helping to convert some of California's many shuttered military bases to profitable new uses. When Fort Ord was shut in September 1994, nearly 17,000 jobs were lost, creating a local unemployment rate of 20 percent. The new college is part of a government-private sector plan to build back the local economy.
Later in the day, at a more partisan Labor Day picnic in Alameda County, the President announced the award of a $3.4 million Federal grant to a consortium seeking to build electric cars at the former Alameda Naval Air Station on San Francisco Bay.
And in Monterey he sought, candidate-style, to cast himself as a political outsider allied with the common folk rather than the occupant for nearly three years of the most powerful post in the nation.
"You couldn't run a family, a business, a university, a church, a civic organization; you couldn't run anything in this country the way people try to run politics in Washington, where talking is more important than doing," he said, drawing laughter and applause.
On Tuesday, the President plans to teach a history class at the Abraham Lincoln Middle School in Selma, Calif., before flying back to Washington.

HEADLINE: Stocks Down Again in Japan After Strong Gains in Europe

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
In Japan, stocks were lower in morning trading today after a sharp decline yesterday.
Earlier, stock markets in Europe ended with solid gains for the most part yesterday as many fund managers returned from summer vacations. 
 Financial markets were closed in the United States and Canada for Labor Day holidays. The absence of American participants dampened trading in many Asian and European markets, traders said.
In Tokyo, stocks tumbled before recovering in late morning trading today. At the midday recess, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 163.14 points, or nine-tenths of 1 percent, at 17,585.38.
Yesterday, the Nikkei fell 372.21 points, or 2.05 percent, dragged down by a selloff in the stocks of small companies that had recently led the market.
The morning decline today came as the dollar continued to strengthen against the Japanese yen. At midday, the dollar was trading at 98.16 yen, up from 97.43, its late quote in New York on Friday.
"The dollar is stronger, and speculative stocks are performing better," said Masayoshi Yano, general manager of equities at Nikko Securities in Tokyo. "But this week selling by corporations has increased."
In European currency trading yesterday, the dollar remained steady against the German mark.
"I think we could remain in this consolidative market for a few more weeks," said Stuart Frost, a currency market analyst with Natwest Markets in London. "The angle of the dollar's recent rise has been a steep one, and a lot of people bought at the top."
European stock markets were buoyed yesterday by Wall Street's strong gain on Friday, when the Dow Jones industrial average rose 36.98 points.
In London, stocks climbed back toward their record high set two weeks ago, but trading volume was thin. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange index of 100 leading issues closed up 13.3 points, or about four-tenths of 1 percent, at 3,522.7.
Trading volumes were also thin on the German and French markets.
The 30-share DAX index in Frankfurt closed up 17.24 points, or eight-tenths of 1 percent, at 2,250.33, and then rose to 2,263.08 in after-hours trading.
"Small orders hit a thin market and they managed to pull the entire market higher," one German broker said. "It is not as if a buying wave or frenzy had broken out."
Stocks in France were carried higher by a technical bounce that took the CAC-40 index back just above the psychologically important 1,900 level. The CAC-40 closed up 18.83 points, or 1 percent, at 1,900.52.

HEADLINE: Cooler Economy in Hawaii Makes a Paradise Look a Lot Like Other Cities

BYLINE: By ASHLEY DUNN 

DATELINE: HONOLULU, Sept. 1

 BODY:
Randy Schoch, one of the best-known restaurateurs in Hawaii, first came to the islands 18 years ago to surf the wild waves of Oahu's North Shore, but stayed to ride the tide of Hawaiian prosperity that turned him into a millionaire by the time he was 32.
He had worked his way up from being a busboy in Honolulu to co-owner of Nick's Fishmarket, a celebrity hangout in the heart of Waikiki, and the fashionable Black Orchid restaurant. With his new-found wealth, he built a $1.8 million palace in paradise, at the top of Hawaii Loa Ridge, with a view that stretched from Koko Head to the cane fields of Ewa. 
 Today, after four years of recession, he is leaving the islands to take a job on the mainland. Through the depths of the recession, he watched as the number of tourists dwindled and the real estate market crashed to the sea floor. To keep afloat, he sold his BMW, the Black Orchid and his home in the mountains.
"I chased the market all the way down," said Mr. Schoch, who sold his home, taking a loss of $500,000. "Here I was driving a $60,000 BMW with a $1.8 million house, and I couldn't afford a refrigerator. I had to bring ice home from the restaurant so we could have milk for the kids."
Hawaii has an image as a paradise of balmy trade winds, where mangoes grow like weeds and bikinis dot the beaches while the rest of the country is shivering in thermal underwear. But for many residents who came for the good life, Hawaii has become paradise lost.
"Hawaii's time was in the 80's," said Wayne Hyna, a general contractor who has returned to being a carpenter since work began to dry up. "It's the greatest weather in the world, but you can't live off the weather."
After a decade of booming growth, the Hawaiian economy has stagnated -- a victim of dwindling tourism, shrinking investment and fading industries, like sugar cane.
Although not so severe as the economic downturns suffered in California and Texas, the recession here, which began in 1991, is the longest since Hawaii became a state, in 1959. Tourists still pack the streets in trendy Waikiki, but the unemployment rate has doubled in six years, to 5.3 percent, as have the number of bankruptcies.
Tourism has dropped for the first time in decades, going from a high of nearly 7 million visitors a year in 1990 to 6.5 million last year. The state's $629 million surplus six years ago has dwindled, even after $144 million in emergency budget cuts, to about $50 million.
The state has eliminated 600 jobs and is considering a $1 charge for checking out a best seller from a public library. Honolulu recently began charging tourists $5 to snorkel in the coral mazes at Hanauma Bay.
While Hawaii has begun a comeback this year, some residents say the sheen of paradise has been scuffed for good. It is a different Hawaii -- a place of humbled optimism and growing social ills that in some ways have made it indistinguishable from the mainland.
"We're sort of going through a midlife crisis," said Paul Brewbaker, chief economist for the Bank of Hawaii. "It was really a cool and mellow place when I was growing up here. But now it's just become like a lot of other places."
The mystique about Hawaii has always exceeded reality. Even two decades ago, many people found Hawaii to be a place of backbreaking work in the cane fields; many lived in company shacks, tucked far away from the high-rise hotels that were beginning to sprout across the islands. Work in the cities could be scarce, rents sky high and the cost of living among the highest in the nation.
Mr. Schoch, 38, remembered that when he first came to Honolulu in 1977, it was already a tough town.
"I mean, I couldn't even get a busboy job in this restaurant," he said as he sat in the dark art nouveau interior of Nick's Fishmarket on Kalakaua Avenue.
Mr. Schoch had grown up in Southern California, surfing at places like Huntington Beach. So when it came time for an adventure, it was natural to pick Hawaii.
"It was very exotic, and it had waves," he said.
Eventually, he got the busboy job, and in three years, he became the manager of Nick's, which led to becoming a partner. With his earnings, Mr. Schoch joined the thousands of people on the islands who rode a booming real estate wave fueled by Japanese investment.
Prices were rising so fast, he said, that he once bought a condominium for $700,000 and sold it a few months later for $875,000.
His biggest real estate investment was his $1.8 million, 5,500-square-foot house on Hawaii Loa Ridge. But just as construction was starting in 1991, the high-end real estate market was beginning to crash. Real estate investment by the Japanese plunged from a high of $2.3 billion in 1991 to $633 million the next year, according to state figures.
It took Mr. Schoch two years to sell his house.
In the past year, Mr. Schoch's restaurant business has recovered, he has bought a cheaper house in a nice neighborhood, and he has become a partner in another Honolulu restaurant. But he has still decided to take a job this month as an executive with Ruth's Chris Steak House in Scottsdale, Ariz.
"I have two successful businesses, I own my own home, but when I look at the future, I just don't see much of a future here," Mr. Schoch said. But he added that he would hold on to his Hawaii restaurants.
At its worst, in 1991, the Hawaiian economy shrank just four-tenths of 1 percent. But Mr. Brewbaker, of the Bank of Hawaii, pointed out that even that small decline had been a shock because of the decade that preceded it, when the economy kept growing above the national rate.
Still, Hawaii's troubles are relative. Although the unemployment rate and number of bankruptcies have doubled, those numbers are below the national average. Unlike other hard-hit states, Hawaii still has a budget surplus, even though it is much smaller.
"The problem is that this place is accustomed to growth," Mr. Brewbaker said. "It's a whole new era."
Mr. Brewbaker said Hawaii was changing fundamentally. Big industries like agriculture and the military are beginning to fade. And tourism, which now accounts for almost 30 percent of the economy, is not the booming industry it was, although it is beginning to improve as more visitors come from Asia.
The changes of the 1990's have turned parts of Honolulu into a tropical version of any other American city. Residents grumble about muggings in Ala Moana Park and homeless people on the beaches. Traffic on the Kamehameha Highway rivals that on the Santa Monica Freeway, and residents talk of a rat race. Honolulu, packed with minimalls and cheap apartment buildings, even looks a lot like Los Angeles.
A grim sign of the change is that for the young, life is harsher than it was for their parents.
For the last four years, 28-year-old Lisa Tanaka has worked three jobs to get ahead. Monday through Friday, she is at First Hawaiian Bank, working as a business development officer. On Wednesdays and Thursdays, she leaves the bank at 5 P.M. and heads to the Itoguruma restaurant in Waikiki to work as a waitress until midnight. On Sundays, she puts in a whole day at Sekiya's Restaurant & Delicatessen.
"It's worth it because I can get a little cash on the side," Ms. Tanaka said. "But I am tired."
With her three jobs, Ms. Tanaka brings in about $40,000 a year. Her fiance, Chad Kamibayashi, makes another $40,000. They have saved enough to buy a $233,000 two-bedroom condominium in Honolulu.
The recession has pushed some residents, particularly native Hawaiians, to the edge of the economy.
Michael Spencer worked for years as a disk jockey, but he has been making his living lately by selling a sticky sweet taro delicacy known as kulolo by the side of the road. He said many of his friends had already left the islands for greener pastures.
"Like everyone else, we're struggling to stay here," Mr. Spencer said. "It's outrageous here: $4.50 for a gallon of milk, $5 for a box of cornflakes, $1.50 for a gallon of gas."
Others who came to Hawaii in search of paradise have now turned their eyes farther west.
Mr. Hyna, who came to Hawaii in 1974 after serving in the Vietnam War, said it had become too hard and frustrating to live in paradise.
He said he would always love some things about Hawaii: the mountains and beaches, the weather and the friendliness. But he also said he had grown tired of the struggle.
After a vacation in New Zealand, he and his wife have sometimes thought about moving there in search of a new life.
"It's a laid-back place," he said. "There's no rat race, and the beauty of the place is just spectacular. It's absolutely gorgeous. It's paradise."
