HEADLINE: Trucks' Popularity Undermining Gains In U.S. Fuel Savings

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Sept. 4

 BODY:
Americans who might sneer at driving a gas-guzzling Cadillac are tickled to be seen in a Jeep, Range Rover or Chevy Suburban. But the enormous popularity of these light trucks is reversing the nation's impressive gains in fuel efficiency.
Because the Government sets a much looser standard for trucks -- including sport utility vehicles, mini-vans and pickups -- they use far more fuel than cars. Light trucks get only 20 miles to a gallon of gasoline, on average, while cars get 28, according to the Department of Transportation. 
 And with trucks now accounting for 4 of 10 new passenger vehicles sold, the boom is dirtying the air and making the United States more dependent on oil.
As a result, the Clinton Administration is weighing the first significant increase in years in the mileage standard for trucks. Any new standard would take effect by April, for trucks that reach the showrooms in late 1997.
Yet an increase is by no means guaranteed. The Big Three auto companies -- General Motors, Ford and Chrysler -- are scrambling to thwart it, and they have found a powerful ally in the House of Representatives, which recently voted to block the Government from taking such action.
The auto makers argue that Americans like their trucks sturdy and powerful, and that it would be too expensive to make engines for such vehicles burn less fuel. Further, the Big Three auto makers say, any stiffening in the regulations would hand a chunk of the light-truck market, which they dominate, to Japanese companies, which make more efficient truck engines.
"It scares us," said Michael J. Stanton, a lobbyist for the American Automobile Manufacturers Association.
 But energy-conservation groups and other critics say the auto companies have not even tried to improve the fuel efficiency of trucks. And, they point out, most Americans who drive light trucks do not use them for the kinds of activities that require Herculean shock absorbers and towing strength, even if they like to pretend they do. After all, the United States has not suddenly realized Jefferson's dream and become a nation of farmers; nor has it become a nation of off-road adventurers.
Instead, the auto companies' own research shows, it has become a nation of overprepared commuters, as millions of Americans use the rugged vehicles only to drive to work and haul youngsters and groceries.
 
Trucks Are to Blame As Fuel Rating Slips
 The impact of the growing popularity of light trucks has been striking. With cars and light trucks counted together, average fuel economy increased steadily among new vehicles from the 1979 model year until 1987, when it was 26.2 miles a gallon. Since then, as truck sales have surged, overall fuel economy has declined, to 24.8 miles a gallon in the 1995 model year, according to a Government estimate.
"Because of trucks, we've lost fuel efficiency in the fleet," said Robert E. Larson, associate director at the Environmental Protection Agency's National Vehicle and Fuel Emissions Laboratory in Ann Arbor, Mich. "At the same time, everybody thinks we're getting better."
Because of improvements like front-wheel drive and lighter-weight materials, passenger cars are much more fuel efficient than they were in 1975 (although there are more cars traveling more miles). By contrast, light trucks in total are burning twice as much fuel as they were 20 years ago. And the United States is more dependent on foreign oil than it was then.
"It's utterly outrageous," said Daniel F. Becker, director of the global warming and energy program at the Sierra Club. Because of the lower standard for trucks, he said, "we have more pollution, more oil consumption and a higher trade deficit in oil."
Light trucks have sold so well because buyers, tempted by the auto makers and little concerned about the cost of gasoline, are substituting them for passenger cars. "The Montero. A Luxury Car Not Designed for the Idle Rich," reads an advertisement for a Mitsubishi sport utility vehicle. An ad for the Chrysler Town & Country mini-van crows, "It Has Leather in Places Luxury Cars Don't Even Have Places."
As trucks have crossed over, fancy rugs have replaced rubber floor mats; coffee-mug holders, compact disk players and outlets for telephones and computers have proliferated in once-spartan cockpits; neon yellows, pinks and greens have washed over traditional duller tones; once-jouncy rides have mellowed.
In a sure sign that Alan Alda has replaced Tom Joad in the driver's seat, Ford announced last month that the new model of its Ranger pickup will have not only a passenger-side air bag but also a switch to turn it off when the passenger is a child in a rear-facing child seat.
Niceties like cruise control, adjustable lumbar support, a tilt steering wheel and an in-dash three-disk CD player helped persuade Scott Domingue of Patterson, La., to trade in his Honda Accord for a Toyota 4Runner sport utility vehicle.
Those amenities, he said, more than made up for what he called the vehicle's only deficiency. "The mileage is horrible," he said -- averaging about 18 miles to the gallon. "I drive 100 miles a day and burn about two and a half tanks a week."
 
Double Standards On Mileage Ratings
 The domestication of light trucks has prompted more than a few people to wonder why the Government maintains separate fuel economy standards for them. "A Ford Taurus station wagon and a Ford Windstar mini-van with different fuel economy norms?" the trade weekly Automotive News editorialized last week. "Ridiculous!"
Mileage requirements are not the Government's only double standard on fuel economy. The so-called gas-guzzler tax, which is applied to cars with combined mileage ratings below 22.5 miles a gallon, does not affect light trucks at all.
Yet in another crucial area, safety, the Government now treats light trucks the same as cars.
At the heart of the fuel efficiency debate is the so-called "corporate average fuel economy" program, known as CAFE, which has its 20th anniversary this year. Congress created the program in response to the Arab oil embargo in the early 1970's, in hopes of reducing the country's dependence on foreign oil.
Under the program, the fuel economy of passenger vehicles produced by an auto company must meet, on average, certain standards. Congress set the standard for cars at 18 miles a gallon in 1978, mandating that it rise to 27.5 miles a gallon by 1985. While the car standard has not risen, the actual average fuel economy of cars has continued to improve, to 28.2 miles a gallon today.
In 1975, light trucks were a small fraction of the market -- burly, basic workhorses for farmers and contractors. Congress did not bother to set a mileage requirement for them, instead directing the Transportation Secretary to set the level each year.
The standard climbed from 14 miles a gallon in 1980 to 20.5 later in the 1980's, but it has all but stalled since. It is set to reach 20.7 miles a gallon over the next two years.
According to E.P.A. statistics, 20.7 miles a gallon was already the actual average fuel economy of light trucks in 1983. Today it is 20.4 miles a gallon. These numbers, based on laboratory tests, are likely to be higher than real-world results.
Even the longest production car in the United States, the barge-like Cadillac Fleetwood, has an E.P.A. rating of 17 miles a gallon in the city and 25 on the highway. And it has an eight-cylinder engine and rear-wheel drive.
By contrast, General Motors' biggest light truck, the four-wheel-drive Chevrolet Suburban, gets only 13 miles a gallon in the city and 15 on the highway, according to Chevy's estimate. Even the much smaller Chevrolet Blazer sport utility vehicle performs worse than the Cadillac, getting 16 miles a gallon in the city and 21 on the highway -- despite having a six-cylinder engine.
 
Tougher U.S. Rules May Benefit Japanese
 The auto companies say that making trucks more fuel efficient would weaken their appeal. Sure, an owner may use his truck mostly for commuting, said Dick Kinsey, manager of fuel economy planning and compliance at the Ford Motor Company. But, he added, "there is that weekend that he wants to go to the lumberyard and fill it full of plywood."
With gasoline costing less than Coca-Cola, Mr. Kinsey said, customers do not worry about fuel. "Our customers are demanding more performance," he said.
The Big Three say that strengthening the truck mileage standard would benefit the Japanese auto makers, just as they contend that strengthening the car standard did in the late 1970's. Then, the Japanese sold a higher proportion of fuel-efficient small cars, just as they now sell a higher proportion of fuel-efficient compact trucks.
As a result, as the Big Three scrambled to make more small cars in the 1980's, the Japanese were able to introduce larger cars that burned more fuel, while still meeting the Government averages. In the same way, they could now move into the full-size pickup and sport utility market -- as they have already begun to do -- while the need to meet the average could restrain Big Three truck production.
"CAFE is something we're pretty good at," said Bob Thomas, president of the Nissan Motor Corporation U.S.A. "Our four-cylinder and six-cylinder engines are very efficient, so we would have no problem."
Publicly, the Big Three have long favored a steep gasoline tax in place of the fuel economy standards, although their critics have never believed they are sincere.
Critics say the auto companies could raise fuel efficiency at reasonable cost. Many truck engines have "1960's to 70's-vintage technology," said John M. DeCicco, a senior associate at the American Council for an Energy-Efficient Economy. By using turbochargers, multiple valves per cylinder and other available technology, he said, "you can meet the power needs with a smaller engine, and that improves efficiency."
 
House Acts to Bar Increase in Standard
 More than a year ago, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, which runs the fuel economy program, suggested that it would raise the fuel economy standard for trucks, setting rules several years into the future to give the auto companies time to meet them. If they are imposed by next April, such rules would affect light trucks beginning with the 1998 model year.
The auto companies filed comments opposed to increases, and for months they have been nervously awaiting the agency's proposal.
The agency refuses to discuss its plans. But in July, in testimony before Congress, Barry Felrice, the agency's associate administrator for safety performance standards, said, "In light of the rapid growth in fuel consumption by light trucks, we believed that we should see what could reasonably be done to improve light-truck fuel economy in the long run."
Without endorsing the finding, Mr. Felrice noted that a 1992 National Academy of Sciences report projected a "technologically feasible" level of 26 to 28 miles a gallon by 2006.
Now Congress has stepped into the act. As part of the appropriations bill for the Transportation Department, the House of Representatives effectively forbade the traffic safety agency to raise fuel economy standards next year.
"Because the light-truck market now represents over 40 percent of total vehicle sales, and it is a segment which is dominated by domestic manufacturers, this action would be devastating to the nation's economy," Tom DeLay, a Texas Republican and the House majority whip, said in remarks submitted to the Congressional Record about raising the fuel economy standard.
The Senate did not pass the same restriction. It is not clear whether the Clinton Administration will act before a House-Senate conference on the bill this month.

HEADLINE: Dole Aims a Barrage at 'Intellectual Elites'

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr. 

DATELINE: INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 4

 BODY:
Angling anew for the votes of the conservatives who dominate the Republican Presidential nominating process, Senator Bob Dole of Kansas contended today that elitist liberals were trying to undermine American values in the nation's schools and other cultural institutions.
"The keys to our unity are under attack from our Government and from intellectual elites who seem embarrassed by America," said Mr. Dole, the Senate majority leader, whose front-running Presidential campaign has recently lost some momentum. He spoke to the 77th national convention of the American Legion here. 
 Mr. Dole demanded an end to multilingual education, thereby edging himself into the growing immigration debate, which has become a major element in the campaign.
"Insisting that all our citizens are fluent in English is a welcoming act of inclusion, and insist we must," he said. "We need the glue of language to help hold us together. We must stop the practice of multilingual education as a means of instilling ethnic pride or as a therapy for low self-esteem or out of elitist guilt over a culture built on the traditions of the West."
Somewhat in the same vein, Mr. Dole also condemned history courses that heavily emphasize national shortcomings, particularly past treatment of minorities. In particular, he criticized the "sanitized" National History Standards proposed by a Federal study group, saying they "glorify other cultures" and are part of the Government's "war on traditional American values."
"They disparage America and disown the ideas and traditions of the West," he said.
The Senator said affirmative action programs constituted reverse discrimination that "no amount of tinkering" could correct, a political dig at President Clinton's contention that affirmative action needs only minor corrections.
"It was never supposed to be permanent," Mr. Dole said. "We know it has failed. Let's stop dividing Americans by race."
Then, repeating an earlier campaign assertion that won him considerable publicity a few months back, the Senator said the film, music, advertising and television industries too often were guilty of "marketing evil."
"It's not for the good," he said.
The Senator warned that for the nation to "return as a people to the original concept of what it means to be American," it would be necessary to debate subjects that "the arbiters of political correctness" would prefer not to discuss.
"Our diversity," he went on, "requires us to bind ourselves to the American idea in every way we can -- by speaking one language, taking pride in our true history and embracing the traditional American values that have guided us from the beginning."
The several thousand conventioneers in the city auditorium here, many of them, like Mr. Dole, decorated veterans who were wounded in World War II, responded with loud applause.
In his long career on Capitol Hill, Mr. Dole has been mostly a mainstream Republican ideologically, and he has built his career mostly on his ability to lead and legislate. But in recent months, in his third campaign for the Presidency, he has found it politically expedient not to play up his Capitol Hill skills and his moderate conservatism.
Instead, he has inclined hard to the right and the votes of the Republicans who dominate the nominating process, hardening his stand on gun control, finding fault with affirmative action and mass culture moguls and, in today's speech, throwing down still more red meat by taking on "elitist" educators.
The Senator's aides, acknowledging the slippage in his campaign after his poor showing in the Iowa straw poll two weeks ago, aggressively encouraged coverage of the speech here, saying it would deliberately touch only lightly on Labor Day and veteran matters despite the date and audience.
The aides said that come Tuesday in Chicago Mr. Dole would deliver another major speech, expounding on economic policy and offering some new thoughts on the American tax system.
Jauntily sporting a blue American Legion cap as he spoke today, Mr. Dole said the forces of elitism and political correctness had so infiltrated the nation's cultural life with their "shocking campaign" to "hijack and untie the strings of citizenship" that what once was good in the United States had become bad.
"What we see as opportunity, they see as oppression," he said. "Where we see a proud past, they see a legacy of shame. What we hold as moral truth, they call intolerance."
Any and all American institutions are "ripe for infection," he declared, even great museums.
"When the Smithsonian created a display to commemorate the anniversary of Hiroshima," he told his fellow veterans, "the message was that dropping the bomb was an act of American violence against Japanese culture. Veterans groups that complained were dismissed as 'special interests' who couldn't be objective."
He paused, letting that assertion sink in.
"Well," he said, finally resuming, "if you love this country so much you're willing to die for it, maybe you do belong to a 'special interest.' "

HEADLINE: Imported Pasta's Rising U.S. Sales Draw Complaints

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE 

DATELINE: ROME, Sept. 4

 BODY:
Italy's premier pasta makers have decided that America's growing appetite for Italian food is too good to pass up, so with promotional cries of "Eat! Eat!" they are shipping as much pasta as they can spare to the United States.
With pasta consumption in Italy stagnant and discount stores here pushing prices lower, the American strategy has paid off. By last year, shipments of Italian pasta to the United States had nearly doubled in four years, to $119 million, and Americans still aren't full. 
 The American pasta industry, though, has had enough. This spring, three of the largest makers -- the Hershey Foods Corporation, which sells Ronzoni pasta; Borden Inc., which sells the Prince and Creamette brands, and the Gooch Foods division of the Archer Daniels Midland Company, which makes the La Rosa and Martha Gooch lines -- filed a complaint with the Commerce Department and the International Trade Commission against the Italians and several small Turkish pasta makers. The Americans argued that the foreign producers were using government subsidies at home to sell pasta in the United States at prices that were below cost.
American companies, including Borden, have occasionally imported Italian pasta themselves for its quality and low price, but they never reckoned with Americans being seduced by the mystique of Italian brands like De Cecco and La Molisana, or the three-pounds-for-a-dollar lure of Italian-sounding Turkish pasta brands like Luigi Vitelli.
The Commerce Department is expected to decide next month whether to impose tariffs to offset the European advantage. Lawyers for the big American pasta makers say the case represents a test of American trade law in the wake of the 1993 world trade agreement.
The law bars the United States from retaliating against companies that receive certain subsidies from foreign governments, including some intended to promote economic activity in less-developed regions.
Italy's pasta makers argue that subsidies of this kind are among the ones cited by the suit, which will test how stringently the Commerce Department intends to apply the law.
Italy's pasta makers say the complaint is more about the higher costs American pasta makers pay for advertising and for the American wheat they use, rather than about Italian or Turkish subsidies. Any American tariff, they say, will simply mean that American consumers will pay more for pasta.
Canada has already prohibited sale of imported pasta except for direct sales by the foreign manufacturer, effectively wiping out what had been a $20-million-a-year business for Canadian importers who brought in Italian pasta.
All this gives indigestion to Italy's pasta giants, like Barilla S.p.A., Italy's biggest pasta company, with 35 percent of the market.
"Our American prices are 23 percent above the market average," said Lamberto Prati, a spokesman for Barilla in Parma, Italy, which markets its product in America as a premium pasta. "How can that be dumping?"
Barilla has been branching out into other European countries and earlier this year set up an American subsidiary. In the spring, Barilla agreed with the Campbell Soup Company to sell pasta sauce in the United States and, as if to emphasize the importance of the American market, named Edwin L. Artzt, the former chief executive of the Procter & Gamble Company, to its board.
Paul C. Rosenthal, a Washington lawyer who represents the big American pasta makers, is unfazed. "If Barilla does not need to be subsidized," he said, "they should give up the subsidy portion."
The trade suit, he said, sought merely to eliminate unfair trade, so that "every company can have an unlimited share of the market."
For Italians, such a pasta war is not new. In the 1980's, the Reagan Administration imposed a 40 percent tariff on Italian pasta imports after the Commerce Department found that European wheat subsidies gave Italy an unfair advantage.
The European Union refunds to pasta makers the difference between the high price they pay for European wheat and lower world wheat prices. But Italy thought it had solved the problem in 1987, when Washington agreed to accept subsidies on roughly half the pasta imported from Italy. Rising wheat prices further defused the issue by causing the European refund to pasta makers to evaporate.
The Italians argue that the thrust of the latest legal action is aimed not so much at the likes of Barilla, but at the medium-priced brands sold by companies like De Cecco S.p.A. and La Molisana S.p.A., respectively the No. 1 and 2 Italian imports. With wheat prices at nearly $7.50 a bushel, compared with $4 in 1992, the European refund has shrunk to the equivalent of 4 cents a pound of pasta.
The suit by the American producers, said Peter Carolan, the president of La Pace Imports in Mendham, N.J., which sells La Molisana, is a tool to "get the market up" by raising prices for all types of pasta. "It's a subtle way of price-fixing," he said.
According to Mr. Carolan, who heads an industry committee fighting the suit, the American manufacturers are trying to push the price of pasta into the range of 99 cents to $1.09 a pound. The medium-priced imports now usually sell for 59 cents to 79 cents a pound.
Mr. Carolan said that big American pasta makers were being squeezed by competition from cheaper imports and the high prices for American durum wheat and mounting merchandising expenses. Last month, the National Pasta Association, which represents the American manufacturers, complained to the Clinton Administration about the price of American wheat, which is inflated partly by import restrictions on cheaper grain from countries like Canada, a leading supplier to the Italians.
Mr. Rosenthal, the lawyer bringing the complaint against the imported pasta, says the action is aimed, in essence, at what his side regards as unfair trade practices. But he acknowledged that "quite clearly we're hoping there will be price relief as a result; there is no question about that."
Even if Italy's export refund fell to 2 cents a pound of imported pasta, Mr. Rosenthal said, this could have a "significant effect on Italian imports."

HEADLINE: A Small Pasta Importer Takes On Big Competitors

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: HAWTHORNE, N.J., Aug. 31

 BODY:
What three big American pasta makers call unfair trade practices, Claudia Vitelli considers just good business -- and the only way a small company such as hers can get its products on the nation's grocery shelves.
The Vitelli-Elvea Company, which employs about 20 people in modest offices in this northern New Jersey suburb and at a warehouse in Linden, N.J., began importing pasta from a Turkish manufacturer, Maktas, in 1987 and marketing it under the brand name Luigi Vitelli, the great-grandfather of Ms. Vitelli's husband, Bruno. 
 Since then, the privately held company's sales have steadily grown. Ms. Vitelli, who runs Vitelli-Elvea with two partners, declined to disclose the company's earnings but said that for the fiscal year that ended today, it imported about two million cases, or 12,000 tons, of pasta, and had sales of about $12 million.
Now, though, Ms. Vitelli, the product of a Neapolitan family who lives on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, faces legal action brought about by her competitors, the big American pasta manufacturers Hershey Foods, Borden and the Gooch Foods unit of Archer Daniels Midland.
In petitions filed in May with the Commerce Department and the International Trade Commission, the big pasta makers asked for investigations into whether Vitelli-Elvea had benefited from dumping by the Turkish pasta industry or subsidies from the Turkish Government.
Ms. Vitelli says that her bigger rivals are trying to use their economic might to stifle competition from a much smaller company that through a sound idea and the willingness to take a risk, has managed to carve out a niche at the low end of the pasta market.
"They are bullies, and they are against the American spirit," she said. "I am going to fight. I will put every effort -- psychological, physical, financial -- into this."
To Ms. Vitelli, the legal fights are just the latest challenge to her company. One of her first obstacles, she recalled, was winning over retailers who had limited shelf space available and concerns about how quickly their customers would take to pasta made in Turkey. She said she had to give away 22,000 cases just to get her pasta on supermarket shelves.
But she can point to concrete results. At a Shop Rite in Jersey City recently, for example, Luigi Vitelli had nine varieties on the shelves.
Paul C. Rosenthal, a lawyer for the big American pasta makers, said Luigi Vitelli was selling its Turkish pasta for 63 percent less in the United States than the fair-market price in Turkey. His clients seek an offsetting tariff on the imports.
Mr. Rosenthal said it was doubtful that Ms. Vitelli was unaware of any subsidies received by the pasta's manufacturer, Maktas, or unaware that the Turkish company was dumping its pasta exports onto the American market -- that is, taking a loss in the hope of eventually raising prices.
If Maktas is being subsidized, Ms. Vitelli argued, those subsidies would be in accordance with what the world trade agreement permits. As for dumping, Ms. Vitelli said Maktas was aware that a Turkish product, regardless of the quality, could never compete in the American pasta market without offering a significant price advantage.
"The reason why our pasta is inexpensive is that it is made in a country where labor is still extremely cheap," Ms. Vitelli said, adding that workers in the Maktas plant made the equivalent of about $80 a month.
In a separate action, Hershey has sued Vitelli-Elvea in United States District Court in Harrisburg, Pa., contending that the Turkish pasta it sells does not use 100 percent durum semolina, as stated on the Luigi Vitelli package. In June, Judge Sylvia H. Rambo rejected Hershey's request for a preliminary injunction against the pasta's sale; a trial has not yet been scheduled.

GRAPHIC: Photo: To Claudia Vitelli, the big pasta makers seeking tariffs on her company's products just want to cut competition. "They are bullies," she said. (Frank C. Dougherty for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Congress Returning to Face Long List of G.O.P. Promises

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2

 BODY:
The Congress everyone discusses in superlatives -- most sweeping, most radical, most impatient -- returns to town on Tuesday. This time, it faces a job almost beyond words.
With eight months gone and deadlines circling overhead like vultures, the Republican majorities in the House and Senate take up a list of commitments this week as incomplete as it is ambitious. Legislation to overhaul Medicare, marked for passage this fall, has yet to be introduced. Bills to trim Medicaid and disassemble the welfare system have barely moved out of the House. 
 Plans to cut taxes, perhaps by $245 billion over seven years, still exist mainly on paper. Deep cuts in farm subsidies and scores of other politically incendiary programs, from public broadcasting to heating assistance for the poor, face several floor votes before final passage.
Many in this Congress want to achieve them all by year's end, in one fell swoop. Even more daunting, most are vital to achieving the Republicans' ultimate goal: a 1996 budget that takes the first step toward erasing the Federal deficit in seven years.
The great question is whether that goal, the most sweeping, radical and ambitious of all, will also prove the most elusive. No one expects an answer by the time the law supposedly requires it: Oct. 1, the day the new fiscal year begins and the old year's spending authority peters out. Too much remains undone.
"The Republicans bit off more than any Congress has ever bitten off," said Robert Reischauer, the Brookings Institution scholar who most recently ran the Congressional Budget Office. "The battle of the budget really is going to last through most of December -- and in some scenarios, I can see it going into January and February."
By itself, delay is not fatal. This Congress promised a great deal, and by many measures it is slowly delivering: about half of Speaker Newt Gingrich's Contract With America has reached votes in both the House and Senate as promised, although only 2 of its 12 measures have been signed into law.
Both chambers have voted in historic fashion to rewrite the 61-year-old law governing competition in communications, and they are well on the way toward overhauling banking laws that have escaped modernization for decades. Both chambers excised $16.3 billion from the current fiscal year, an unheard-of act.
But the fiscal issues ahead are more difficult. Many, like controlling the cost of Medicare, touch exposed political nerves, and most have no easy answers. Republicans will be under crushing pressure; their majorities are slim, and their hopes for the Presidency and continued control of Congress may rest on the public's judgment of their success.
Nor can they expect help. Democrats recall that they had to pass President Clinton's first deficit-cutting budget in 1993 without a single Republican vote, and suffered for it in the 1994 midterm elections.
For survivors, this is payback time. Democrats on the Senate Finance Committee, for example, are sitting on their hands as the one-vote Republican majority gropes toward consensus on issues like welfare reform and tax policy.
The Senate will leap into its work on Tuesday, taking up a military spending bill and re-opening debate on a stalled version of the welfare bill that the House passed months ago. The House plans to immediately open hearings on Medicare, hoping -- like the Senate -- to produce some cost-cutting plan for consideration by late this month.
Much more remains to be done, and the time to do it is short:
*The House and the Senate have agreed on a final version of only one of the 13 spending bills, totaling about $600 billion, that finance the Federal bureaucracy and the military, and the White House has threatened to veto it. Twelve more spending bills must go to the White House; Mr. Clinton already warns he may veto six of them.
The two sides have until Oct. 1 either to reach accords on all 13 bills or allot money to run them temporarily; after that, any agency lacking a legally approved budget must shut down. Most experts expect many agencies to do just that, at least for a while, until the White House and Congress have made their rhetorical points and begin cutting spending deals.
*The House and Senate must write and pass separate versions of legislation covering the remainder of the budget, mostly tax reduction and major benefit programs like welfare, farm subsidies, Medicaid and Medicare. Most are likely to be hugely controversial, but the spending reductions in them are critical to Republican hopes of achieving a balanced budget by 2002.
Most will later be folded into a single "reconciliation" bill in each chamber, then melded into a final version that will go to the President. He is considered all but certain to veto it, setting the stage for either negotiations or a political standoff that could last into the 1996 election season.
*The Government is expected to reach its debt ceiling -- in effect, its credit limit -- some time in October, and to run out of petty cash by mid-November, when a $22 billion payment on Treasury notes falls due.
Only Congress can raise the debt ceiling, allowing the Government to borrow more money to meet its obligations. Some Republicans may seek to attach reconciliation legislation to the debt ceiling measure, forcing Mr. Clinton to choose between accepting their fiscal dictates on the most sensitive parts of the budget or throwing the entire Government into default.
Other Republicans want the debt ceiling considered by itself, in order to attach other controversial social and fiscal measures to it. Still others hope to avoid a default scenario -- the "train wreck" that has become the capital's hoariest political cliche -- by offering the White House a temporary extension of the debt limit until after the 1996 elections.
Those are the flash points. How and whether they will ignite is an open question. "If anybody can tell you where we're going this fall, they're either a fool or they're lying," one budget expert on the Senate Republican staff said last month.
The motivations of the major powers in this debate are nevertheless obvious to outside experts and the participants themselves.
Congress's Democratic minority, most agree, not only opposes the Republican proposals on their merit, but also has every interest in seeing the new majority break its promise to shrink Government.
As for the Republicans: "Unity is breaking down in both houses, and between the houses, too," Stan Collender, the Federal budget expert for the accounting firm Price Waterhouse, said last month. "But the way it's happening is interesting."
People in Congress are thinking about their re-election for the first time, he said. And so Representative George Nethercutt of Washington, the Republican who deposed Speaker Thomas S. Foley last fall by depicting him as a pork-barrel politician, is becoming an ardent defender of farm subsidies in his agricultural district. And Senator Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico, the Budget Committee chairman and a premier advocate of fiscal balance, labored last month against Republican cuts in Indian programs and in Energy Department projects that play important economic roles in his state.
Significantly, Mr. Gingrich has in recent weeks begun to emphasize that legislating is a two-sided affair, and that few deals as big and contentious as a Federal budget are struck without compromise.
A senior aide among Senate Republicans raised the same prospect in a recent interview, suggesting that the party may find it more prudent to strike a deal when public opposition to difficult spending cuts starts to mount and Mr. Clinton begins to rain vetoes that Republicans are unable to override.
"If we fail to produce a balanced budget, he wins in a big way," the aide said. "So for the political survival of Republicans in Congress, I think we have to produce it, somehow, and he has to veto it. And he will veto it.
"And at that point we can say, 'We had a plan,' and he can say, 'I saved the country,' and the morning after we can say, 'O.K., what can we do now?' " A lot, he said, is possible, including changes in the Republicans' budgets, economic assumptions, spending base lines and even the seven-year target for reaching fiscal balance.
But other Republican spines are stiffening. Representative Gerald B. H. Solomon of New York, an advocate of a balanced budget, said that to Republican freshmen and others in the House, talk of concessions are no more than pipe dreams.
Of speculation that the deadline might be extended, Mr. Solomon said: "I don't think that's possible. We've got to stick it out with a seven-year time line." On the issue of temporarily extending the debt limit, he said: "The President had better understand that this Congress is not going to extend that unless we get some very, very reasonable compromises. You can swear by that. The House will not budge, and I'll be leading the fight."
Mr. Solomon may be right, and Congress and the White House may be in for a long and excruciating battle over control of the Federal purse. But one expert, Kenneth M. Duberstein, a Republican strategist and former White House chief of staff, said last week that the odds for compromise may be better than many believe. For one brief interlude, he said, moving toward a balanced budget is in the political interest of the people whose opinions count most: Government leaders.
Mr. Clinton, he said, desperately needs to shore up his image as a leader, something a budget agreement would accomplish. Mr. Gingrich needs bipartisan success on a big issue like the budget to dispel at last his image as a bomb thrower and backbencher. The Presidential hopes of Senator Bob Dole, the majority leader, rest in part on his ability to get things done, even with Democrats.
"Dole, Gingrich and Clinton, each in his own fashion, need to demonstrate an ability to govern," he said. "I think there's a lining up of the moons here."

GRAPHIC: Chart: "A PRIMER: The Fall Budget Debate"
 
APPROPRIATIONS BILLS
 The House has passed 11 of the 13 spending bills that finance all Government operations except some major benefit programs, like Medicare and Social Security, and interest payments on the national debt. The Senate has passed seven. Both chambers must pass all of them, and then approve 13 House-Senate compromise versions before they can be sent to the President.
 Agencies must cease operations if their spending bills do not become law by Oct. 1, unless Congress and the President agree to finance them temporarily.
 
Through conference and ready for the President: Legislative branch, $2.2 billion
 
Passed by both chambers heading into House-Senate conferences (dollar figures from House bils): Transportation, $38.1 billion; Military construction, $11.2 billion; Energy and Water Development, $18.7 billion; Interior, $12 billion; Treasury, Postal Service and General Government, $23.2 billion.
 
Still before the Senate (dollare figures from House bills): VA-HUD-Independent agencies, $79.4 billion; Commerce, Justice and State, $27.2 billion; Labor, Health and Human Services and Education, $61 billion; Foreign operations, $11.9 billion; Defense, $240 billion; Agriculture, $62.7 billion.
 
BENEFIT PROGRAMS AND OTHER REQUIRED SPENDING
 Major benefit programs like Medicare, Medicade, Social Security and farm subsidies are covered by separate legislation called a reconciliation bill. So are tax cuts. Republicans want to use the bill as a vehicle to restrain the growth of benefit spending and sharply cut taxes; President Clinton maintains that the Republicans are going too far on all fronts, and has threatened a veto.
 Unlike other spending bills, a veto of the reconciliation package would not shut benefit programs down, but instead would allow them to operate at their existing spending levels, which have long been set by other laws.
 Among the biggest measures that are likely to be folded into the recondiliation package:
 
Medicare: Republicans propose to spend about $8 billion less in 1996 than thier budget experts say would be spent under the program's existing guidelines; this is the first down-payment on their plan to slow Medicare spending by $280 billion over the next seven years. But Congress has yet to say how this first cut would be achieved. The White House, by comparison, proposes to reduce spending by about $3.3 billion below its 1996 projections.
 
Welfare: The House passed a bill in March to turn most welfare programs over to the states, giving them a lump sum of Federal money to spend on the poor as they see fit. The Senate debated similar legislation in August but failed to reach agreement. Debate could resume this month, but if the impasse remains, Republican leaders may attach their version to the reconciliation bill.
 
Tax cuts: All sides sharply disagree over how much to cut taxes. The House has approved $350 billion in tax breaks spread over seven years; the Senate wants no more than $170 billion. In June the two chambers split the difference, alloting $245 billion for tax cuts. But neither side regards that as final, and the true size and timing of any breaks will not be settled until at least September, and probably later.
 The White House proposed in June to cut taxes by $105 billion through 2002, about $4 billion of that in 1996.
 If Mr. Clinton rejects the reconciliation bill, as many anticipate, Congress could write a compromise version with White House officials. Or it could attach the bill as an amendment to the one piece of legislation that Mr. Clinton has little choice but to sign: a bill to raise the debt ceiling.
 
THE DEBT CEILING
 Though the Government may seem to run up deficits with abandon, it is authorized by law to carry only so much debt -- about $4.9 trillion, actually. When deficit spending hits that debt ceiling this fall, virtually the entire Government would grind to a halt unless Congress votes to raise the debt limit, thus autorizing the Goverment to sell more Treasury bonds to finance operations. Failure to raise the ceiling could cause the United States to default on its obligations, potentially touching off a global financial crisis.
 The Government will probalbly hit the debt ceiling in October, but it can continue to operate on a cash basis, spending tax revenue as it trickles in, for several weeks. Most experts believe the Treasury would run completely dry in November. (pg. D9)

SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: Sharp Rebound for U.S. Makers of Memory Chips

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR 

 BODY:
Straight out of Boise State University, Steven R. Appleton joined a local memory-chip maker called Micron Technology Inc. in 1983. It soon seemed that he had chosen a dead-end career.
In the mid-1980's, the memory-chip business appeared to be lost forever to Japan. One major American semiconductor company after another, even Intel, the memory-chip pioneer, dropped out of the field, figuring that it would always be a poor business. 
 "Back then," recalled Mr. Appleton, who is now Micron's chairman, "it was just a matter of survival for us. "
The company, based in Boise, Idaho, is doing far more than surviving these days. For its 1995 fiscal year, which ended last week, analysts expect its profit to double, to more than $800 million, on sales of $2.8 billion. And Micron has become a Wall Street favorite, as investors have driven up its stock price fivefold since last fall.
Not bad for a company that was barely profitable as recently as three years ago. Indeed, companies like Micron and Texas Instruments have managed a remarkable American comeback in the market for memory chips. In doing so, they took advantage of a recession in Japan, American trade policy and the boom in personal computers, which more and more have a voracious appetite for memory.
Today, the American memory-chip makers are thriving -- a turnaround that has left experts shaking their heads in surprise and delight.
"In the early 1990's, I had written off memory chips for good as a commodity business," said David B. Yoffie, a Harvard Business School professor and Intel director. "But now it's a very profitable market. It just goes to show that in fast-moving technology businesses, never say never."
Besides Japan's woes and Washington's trade advocacy, the unexpected turn of events is explained by the growth and broadening of the personal computer market -- as the machines increasingly go into homes and people use them to communicate, roam the Internet and play multimedia games.
"We're seeing the personal computer change into something far more than just a machine for crunching numbers and writing reports," said Richard Zwetchkenbaum, an analyst at the International Data Corporation, a research firm. "And all these new uses for the PC mean a greater demand for memory."
The latest new demand for computer memory is coming from Windows 95. Over the next year, millions of people are expected to buy the Microsoft Corporation's husky new operating system, with 11 million lines of code. And the new games, word processors and data base software made to run on Windows 95 are also big programs, brimming with new features and flashy graphics.
With too little memory, a machine runs these fancy new programs at a crawl or crashes altogether. The memory chips, known as D-RAM's (dynamic random access memory), hold the current work on a personal computer for quick access -- as opposed to the computer's hard disk, where software programs are permanently stored.
For many computer users, the decision to buy Windows 95 is soon followed by a realization that they need $200 or more in added memory. Some retailers are selling Windows 95 together with memory upgrades -- typically four megabytes, or four million bytes. (A byte is the amount of memory needed to store one character, like a letter or number.)
Though Microsoft officials say that Windows 95 will run on a personal computer with four megabytes, they recommend eight megabytes. Most computer experts, though, say that 16 megabytes of memory is preferable if one wants to run games, search the Internet and do other things that Windows 95 is intended to make easier. Yet most desktop computers sold as recently as last Christmas came with eight megabytes, and most notebook machines had four megabytes.
"The surge in demand was well under way before, but Windows 95 will force more people to buy more memory," said Daniel Klesken, an analyst with Robertson, Stephens & Company in San Francisco.
Just how quickly the demand for memory is increasing among PC buyers is evident at the Dell Computer Corporation. The direct-mail marketer of computers, based in Austin, Tex., makes its PC's after orders are in hand. Every machine is made to order for each customer, and its customers tend to be somewhat more experienced users than the PC market as a whole.
By the end of last year, the computers sold by Dell had an average of 10 megabytes of memory. Today, the average is 16 megabytes, up from 14 megabytes two months ago. "The demand for memory just keeps creeping up steadily," said Michael Dell, the company's chairman.
To line up supplies of memory chips, Mr. Dell has just returned from a trip to Boise to meet with Micron, which is becoming an increasingly important supplier for Dell, along with Toshiba of Japan and Samsung of South Korea. "Steve Appleton and I have become friends real quickly," Mr. Dell said. "We need him and he needs us."
Theft is often a reliable indicator of demand, and there seems to be a brisk illegal traffic in memory chips. On Aug. 23, for example, the campus police at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology sent a bulletin on the university's electronic-mail system to alert people of the "growing problem" of the "theft of computer memory chips."
The worldwide memory-chip market is expected to grow nearly 60 percent this year, to $37.1 billion, according to Robertson, Stephens. Next year, it estimates, it will expand 35 percent more, to $50 billion.
Steadily rising demand is one reason the memory-chip market is growing so much in dollar terms. Another reason is that the recession in Japan, starting in the early 1990's, forced the Japanese producers to pull back from a strategy of building more capacity to gain market share, with little or no regard for profit.
When the Japanese stopped building new chip factories, the South Koreans stepped in. Still, the let-up in Japan, combined with extremely strong demand, has meant that chip prices have held steady instead of dropping 30 percent annually as they had for years before.
"Prices haven't fallen in four years," said Brian Turner, owner of Chip Merchant, a San Diego retailer. "What I'm selling for $100 now would be selling for $30 if the traditional price declines had continued."
Not surprisingly, memory-chip factories are being built to try to cash in on the suddenly lucrative market. In addition to South Korea and Japan, Taiwan, Malaysia and China are all building plants.
This year, 14 new factories are starting production, increasing supply of D-RAM's by 46 percent, Tom Thornhill of Montgomery Securities in San Francisco estimated.
In 1996, 16 more factories are expected to begin churning out chips. Yet with demand rising 70 percent a year, most analysts predict that memory chips will continue in short supply for the next couple of years.
In Boise, Micron has aggressive plans for growth. Since 1991, the company has doubled production. Next year, it intends to increase its chip-making capacity by 30 percent. Earlier this year, Micron announced that it would build a sprawling $1.3 billion chip factory in Lehi, Utah.
Over the years, Micron did benefit from anti-dumping cases brought by the United States Government against Japan and South Korea, and from the 1986 semiconductor agreement with Japan to give American chip makers greater access to the Japanese market.
But company strategies and economic shifts played a far greater role than Government policy. Micron, for example, has been an innovator in chip design, shrinking the size of its chips and making them easier to package for PC makers.
So when the competitive assault from Japan eased, Micron was positioned to be a winner, helping double the United States' share of the market to more than 20 percent since 1991. "There's no question that the U.S. has made a comeback," Mr. Appleton said. "But we suffered for years from competing against countries instead of companies, and there's still plenty of competition out there."

HEADLINE: Unions Open Drive to Recruit Immigrants

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ 

 BODY:
With a nod to the past and an eye to the future, leaders of labor unions in New York announced an organizing effort among the thousands of new immigrants now working for low wages and no benefits in supermarkets, factories and stores throughout the city.
"This will be an effort that has not been seen in this city since the 1960's, when the taxi drivers and public employees pushed for collective bargaining," said Brian McLaughlin, an Assemblyman from Queens who is also the president of the New York City Central Labor Council, an umbrella group of union locals chartered by the A.F.L.-C.I.O. The council donated $250,000 to begin the campaign, which will first focus on a score of stores in upper Manhattan where it says Hispanic immigrants are paid $250 for 72-hour weeks. 
 "All you have to do is look around New York City and see the diversity of our work force and see the future of the New York City labor movement," he said. "We want to create the same opportunities for today's immigrant and minority laborers that the movement provided to immigrants and minorities 100 years ago."
The drive, which was announced at a breakfast before the city's Labor Day Parade, will provide for some 100 workers to be trained as organizers through the Harry Van Arsdale Jr. Center for Labor Studies at the State University of New York's Empire State College. The first group of people to be trained will work with the United Food and Commercial Workers Union in reaching out to employees of supermarkets and other food stores.
The drive comes at a time when organized labor's primary focus has been defending the rights and benefits of current members, rather than attracting new members. At the same time, thousands of immigrants -- legal and illegal -- have flooded the city, often working in businesses that skirt or flout labor laws.
Mark Perrone, a regional vice president for the food workers' union, said the organizing efforts had already resulted in one large store's increasing wages and benefits for some 250 workers. He said that many of the 3,000 other workers in the stores that are the focus of the campaign were paid in cash, with no taxes or social security withheld from their pay.
Labor Secretary Robert Reich told the audience at the breakfast that the Clinton Administration was intent on protecting workers and also supported an increase in the minimum wage to $5.15 an hour from $4.25.
"Before I started fighting for the rights of labor, I used to be 6 foot 5," joked the diminutive Mr. Reich, whose head barely peeked above the podium. "This administration is going to continue to fight for working people until I completely vanish."
Some of that humor in the face of a tough fight, along with a vision of the multiethnic movement union officials have advocated, was evident along the Fifth Avenue parade route, as thousands of marchers clutching banners and balloons strode cheerfully under sunny skies. Huge trucks crept up the avenue blasting their horns to cheers from small but enthusiastic groups of onlookers. Dancing dragons heralded a contingent of Asian garment workers, while a salsa band rocked the crowd a few blocks away.
Christina Molina, a retired teacher from the Bronx, jumped up and down, clapping and waving to the floats that drifted past to the tune of "We Shall Not Be Moved."
"We wouldn't be able to be out here if it wasn't for all the benefits," she said. "We're just sorry that the labor force is like it is. Employees are easily replaced now. There's no loyalty. The loyalty we grew up with."
Inez Layne, a unionized garment worker, said she was pleased with the reaction from passers-by.
"We want to show them power in this city," she said. "We need to keep everything in America like it used to be."
As is his habit, John Cardinal O'Connor stood outside St. Patrick's Cathedral, beaming and waving to the marchers. He said it was important that people be reminded of the union's role as intermediary.
"Is the corporate structure the important thing or is it the right to negotiate?" he said. "I suggest we have informal, amiable meetings between business leaders and union leaders to see if we can come to an understanding of the importance of both."
In keeping with the spirit of the day, a few hundred garment workers split off from the parade to protest outside a Gap store on Lexington Avenue. They accused the clothing retailer of doing business with latin American contractors who employ children. A statement issued by the company said it had failed to substantiate those allegations, although union officials remained skeptical.
"In the global economy and global village, these companies have a responsibility to have a certain basic standard against child labor," said Jay Mazur, the president of UNITE, the garment workers' union. "Children belong in schools."
Along the parade route, David Eisenstadt helped serenade a police officer to the strains of the reggae song "One Love." A drummer who belongs to Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians, Mr. Eisenstadt smiled when asked if he felt uncomfortable marching through the heart of a neighborhood that was home to countless corporate bosses.
"I think more of them are becoming interested in what happens to the working person," he said. " You need two people to make a living."
Larry Siegel, a banjo player who led the band, launched into "Don't Worry, Be Happy," insisting that he was there to celebrate, not complain.
"We're trying to preserve a living wage and the spirit of the union and not to be taken advantage of," he said. "That's the best we can do in 1995."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Mexican Stocks Rise on Vow by President

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY Sept. 4

 BODY:
Stocks soared to a nine-month high today as investors cheered President Ernesto Zedillo's pledge to increase spending to bolster the economy.
In the first day of trading since the President's state-of-the-nation address on Friday, the leading stock market index jumped 73.05 points, or 2.9 percent, to 2,590.04 -- its biggest one-day gain in two months. The rally occurred as financial markets in the United States were closed for Labor Day, reducing demand from foreign investors. 
 "Investors are expecting that as the President said in his first state-of-the-nation address, the recovery will be a priority in the next few months," said Esteban Rojas, an analyst with Arka Casa de Bolsa S.A.
Construction and cement companies, which stand to benefit from increased spending on public works projects, led the market's rally.
Trading on the stock exchange, although below the daily average for the last three months of 94 million shares, was still substantial, with 77.1 million shares changing hands.
The day's close of the stock market index was the highest since Nov. 30, when it closed at 2,591.34. The index has climbed 79 percent since reaching a 28-month low of 1,447.52 on Feb. 27.
Mexican financial markets were closed on Friday for the President's address.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Japan's Job Market Shocks Collegians

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Sept. 4

 BODY:
While most Americans observed Labor Day by taking the day off, more than 12,000 college students in Japan, who graduate next spring, packed into the giant Tokyo Dome sports stadium today with the anxious hope of landing jobs.
Hundreds lined up before dawn, some having traveled from distant cities by plane or train. Wearing their trademark "recruit suits" -- navy blue suits, white shirts, striped ties and black shoes -- they came for a huge job counseling program organized by the Ministry of Labor. 
 September brings the formal start of Japan's annual job-recruitment season. But after nearly five years of recession and "job shokku," or job shock, those entering the work force face the most forbidding season in years, and many have settled for jobs they would have once dismissed.
"I am looking for a job as a receptionist, a sales clerk -- it doesn't matter," said Takako Nakahara, who flew more than 500 miles from her two-year college in southern Japan for today's program .
"I got an interview with one company, a manufacturer of bathtubs, and I told them I really wanted to be a receptionist," Ms. Nakahara said. "But the prospects for me to get that job are low because many other people wanted it."
High school and college graduates -- especially women -- have borne the brunt of Japan's economic pain. Thanks in large part to the lifetime employment practices of most Japanese companies, the nation's official unemployment rate is only 3.2 percent -- a level Americans would consider a victory over joblessness.
But the reality behind the statistic is more grim, and it was on display today as students moved among the tables of more than 600 companies, including some of the country's largest. Because companies are loath to lay off workers, the primary tool for cutting labor costs has been to avoid hiring.
Even seniors from some of Japan's respected four-year universities were competing for jobs as sales clerks, secretaries, construction workers and entry-level bookkeepers.
With lifetime decisions hanging before them, almost everyone was serious -- even the small number of renegades who wore gray suits instead of blue. Everyone examined the information provided by each company -- its recruitment goals, academic standards, salary ranges and even its holiday schedule -- as if it were a racing form.
Most tried to select a handful of companies for interviews, and they were clear about which jobs were for which gender. Although gender-based discrimination is illegal in Japan and there were no signs saying "women need not apply," the difference in treatment between men and women was noticeable and ubiquitous.
"We are offering 10 positions for men and 5 for women," said Akihisa Hasuo, the personnel chief for Nisshim Fudosan, a small construction company. "For men, it's mainly salespeople and career-track jobs. For women, the jobs are for generally clerical. It doesn't mean women can only do clerical work, of course. Even if you're hired as a clerical person you can move on to other jobs."
If some executives were more discreet, both men and women had no misconceptions about where to look for jobs. Women moved almost exclusively to the tables of companies looking for clerical workers, secretaries and sales clerks. The men signed for interviews at companies offering career prospects in management, engineering, accounting and marketing.
"I am more fit for the clerical track," said Chika Naito, a senior majoring in Japanese literature at Showa Women's College. "I once thought of pursuing the career track, but this year those jobs are so difficult to get."
Ms. Naito said she wrote letters to 200 companies over the last year. So far, however, she has had no luck.
Tomoko Kusano, a senior at Kasei University in Tokyo, has the confident and forthright manner of an aspiring professional. But her efforts to find an entry-level job in accounting have not been encouraging.
"I got an interview at a chemical and construction company, but they had only one job to offer," she said. "They said they wanted both women and men, but they said they only wanted students in law, business or management and I come from the literature department."
Because of her academic weakness, Ms. Kusano doubled her course work during the last six months by going to a vocational school for training in accounting. But she said she had failed the entrance examination -- the first hurdle at many companies for winning an interview.
For many smaller companies, job shokku has allowed them to hire students who would have insisted on joining bigger and seemingly more prestigious companies a few years ago.
"Since the start of the year, we had inquiries from 10,000 students -- we couldn't even deal with it," said Mr. Hasuo of Nissham Fudosan, a company that builds condominiums.
A few women grumbled about the more limited opportunities they were given, but they were discreet. "Many companies claim to employ without regard to gender, but in practice certain numbers of them employ men only," said a woman who insisted on anonymity.
Young men did not have it easy either. That became clear listening to the representative of Sato Construction, who boasted that his company was "No. 1 in steel-reinforced concrete" and had built the Cinderella castle at Tokyo Disneyland.
Though Sato did have a few immediate white-collar openings, the company's representative told the men most of the jobs were at the construction sites.
"Five years after you join the company, you aim at being the team leader at a construction site," he said. "That's like being head of a small company, because you have to think about your costs and profits. After that, you aim at being head of a much bigger construction site, one with perhaps 200 workers. And after another five years, then you aim for an office job."
That sounded good enough for Yosuke Meguro, a senior in business management at Ishinomake Senshu University, a respected four-year college about 150 miles north of Tokyo. "I'm hoping to get a job in the second category, because I would like to have a good feel of construction," he said.
Of course, he added, "before we become team leaders, we will have to do some real physical work."

HEADLINE: Fireworks on Jerusalem's 3,000th Year

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN 

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Sept. 4

 BODY:
To the boisterous accompaniment of fireworks, dancers, laser beams, politics and controversy, the city of Jerusalem today began a 15-month celebration of the 3,000 years since King David wrested the hilltop town from the Jebusites and proclaimed it the capital of the Jewish people.
"United Jerusalem is the heart of the Jewish people and the capital of the state of Israel," Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin declared in opening ceremonies outside the Parliament. Mr. Rabin, who was born in Jerusalem and led the Israeli Army when the Old City was taken in the 1967 war, added: "United Jerusalem is ours! Jerusalem forever!" 
 But while Mr. Rabin also spoke of the 3,000 years as "a message of tolerance between religions and love between peoples," the grand party was boycotted by Palestinian Arabs and Western Europeans and criticized by many Israelis as a one-sided celebration of a city on which many faiths and people have claims. No major foreign government has recognized Jerusalem as Israel's capital, and the Israelis and Palestinians have agreed to negotiate its status in the final round of their negotiations on Arab self-rule.
Palestinian Arabs, who comprise a quarter of Jerusalem's population and who seek East Jerusalem for their capital, refused any part in the "Jerusalem 3000" festival. A statement issued by the Palestinian Authority led by Yasir Arafat asserted that "the Israeli aim of these celebrations is to affirm that the city which was subjected to many forced changes over the past 28 years is a united Israeli city and that the only thing left is for the world to recognize this alleged unification."
Last month the European Union rejected Israel's invitation to sponsor cultural events on the grounds that the festival laid too exclusive an emphasis on Jerusalem as a Jewish and Israeli city.
The United States has made no statement on the festival, but Ambassador Martin Indyk was absent from the opening ceremonies. An embassy spokesman said protocol did not require the Ambassador to attend a cultural event.
The opening ceremonies also came under attack from Israeli members of the Peace Now movement, which champions peace with the Arabs. Leaders of Peace Now asserted that holding one opening-day ceremony on the original site of King David's Jerusalem, now outside the walled Old City, was a provocation to the Arabs, since part of the site is an Arab village called Silwan, where Jewish settlers forcibly seized several Arab houses four years ago with tacit endorsement and support from the Government.
Silwan has remained a source of friction, controversy and lawsuits ever since, and a symbol to the Palestinians of efforts by Israeli nationalists to elbow them out of Jerusalem. Peace Now leaders declared there was no place more appropriate to begin the celebrations than the "City of David," but the movement said the site was also "a powerful symbol that settlers are above the law and the Palestinians beneath it."
The brief opening ceremony at the City of David, which preceded the gala at the Parliament, was held under tight security in a tent next to an archeological excavation. About 300 Israeli dignitaries attended, including Mr. Rabin; Ehud Olmert, the Mayor of Jerusalem, and Teddy Kollek, his longtime predecessor.
Soldiers and policemen were perched on the roofs of nearby Arab homes, but the only evident demonstration was a Palestinian flag floated aloft by balloons.
Despite the controversies, the opening ceremonies gave a foretaste of what is scheduled to be an impressive schedule of events, ranging from concerts by the Berlin State Opera under Daniel Barenboim to a "King David's Feast" next March, at which 500 people will eat from specially made Rosenthal china at a 12-course kosher dinner made by 12 of the world's leading chefs.
Bright banners emblazoned with "3000" have been fluttering for weeks from every street light. At the stroke of 8 P.M., the sky over the Parliament and the Israel Museum exploded in fireworks prepared by Alberto Navarro of Seattle, while laser beams traced the night sky.
Among many other events scheduled during the next months are a night of Psalms on Mount Scopus and a huge parade on Oct. 11 with floats, bands and dancers from around the world. In November, Dutch botanists will plant thousands of bulbs in the Jerusalem Botanical Gardens. The final event will be a concert on Jan. 7, 1997.
Much of the controversy about "Jerusalem 3000" has been laid at the feet of Mayor Olmert, a member of the conservative Likud bloc. The idea for the festival, however, began with Mr. Kollek.
Mr. Kollek's initial idea, according to Yossi Tal-Gan, head of the festival, was "marketing Jerusalem to the wide world for touristic and economic reasons," adding, "He wanted to create a program and thus develop the city as a tourist attraction through Government and private investment."
But once talks opened with the Palestinians in 1993, and a Likud administration won the Mayor's office in 1994, the preparations became increasingly politicized. Once the decision was taken to include Jerusalem's status in the negotiations, any claim to the city by either side became an instant dispute.

Guerrilla Kills Israeli Settler
 JERUSALEM, Tuesday, Sept. 5 (Reuters) -- A Palestinian guerrilla stabbed an Israeli to death and wounded his wife at a Jewish settlement in the occupied West Bank early today, security sources said.
The attacker entered the Michmash settlement, near the Palestinian town of Ramallah, under cover of darkness. He fatally stabbed a settler who had gone outside after hearing a noise and then knifed the settler's wife, the sources said.
There was no immediate claim of responsibility for the attack.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Truck Boom Erodes Gains From Fuel Savings
The boom in mini-vans, pickups and sport utility vehicles has had unwanted side effects: increased air pollution and a greater dependency on oil imports. That's because light trucks are far less fuel efficient than cars, getting an average of 20 miles to a gallon of gasoline, while cars average 28. 
 In response, the Clinton Administration is considering the first significant increase in years in the mileage standard for trucks. Auto makers plan to fight the move, but conservation groups and other critics say the companies have not even tried to improve the fuel efficiency of light trucks. [Page A1.]

The Next Big Trade Dispute: Pasta?
Italy's pasta makers are shipping as much as they can spare to the United States, a strategy paying off with steadily growing sales. But now they face complaints filed by three leading American pasta makers contending that the foreign producers use Government subsidies at home to sell pasta in the United States at prices below cost. [D4.]
 
What big American pasta makers call unfair, Claudia Vitelli considers good business -- and the only way her small importing company can get its products on grocery shelves. [D4.]
 
In Japan, Job Hunt Is Bleak
In Japan, September is the beginning of the annual job-recruitment season, and 12,000 college students packed a stadium in Tokyo yesterday for a job-counseling program. This season, though, may be the most forbidding for applicants in years. After nearly five years of recession, many of those entering the work force are settling for jobs they would have once dismissed. [D2.]
 
Ford to Get a Japanese Loan Japan's Export-Import Bank will lend the Ford Motor Company $153.2 million to develop and market right-hand-drive cars. The bank completed a similar deal with General Motors a week ago. [D2.]
 
Prudential Securities Is Sued
Prudential Securities continues to be plagued by the limited partnerships it sold in the 1980's. Even as the firm saw a $110 million settlement with some investors receive a judge's preliminary approval, other investors sued the firm last week. The latest class-action suit contends that Prudential failed to meet the terms of a settlement reached three years ago involving two partnerships. [D6.]
 
Home Depot on the Upswing
Can Home Depot regain its fast pace of growth? After years of booming success with its warehouse-style home centers, the shares of the company have languished. Home Depot executives say the company has every intention of meeting its previous standards of growth. But analysts, while forecasting strong growth for the company, say it has been too successful to maintain that imposing pace. Market Place. [D6.]
 
Stocks Rise in Europe
Stocks posted strong gains on markets in London, Frankfurt and Paris. But trading on many of the exchanges was thin with American participants absent because of the Labor Day holiday. [D6.]
 
New York Unions Plan Drive
New York City labor leaders plan to start an organizing effort among the thousands of new immigrants now working for low wages and no benefits in supermarkets, factories and stores throughout the city. [B3.]
 
Big Salaries for Charity Work
Top executives of the largest charities and foundations often earn $200,000 a year or more, and their salaries continue to grow even as the pay scales of these groups come under increased scrutiny, according to a survey to be published this week. [A12.]
 
Mysteries of Marketing
What do frogs and ants have to do with beer? Has anyone ever seen a "U.S.A.-shaped pretzel"? Summer is nearly over, so it must be time for another 20 questions about advertising, marketing and the media.
Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D5.]

HEADLINE: Battling Against Big Powerboats

BYLINE: By ROBERT HANLEY 

DATELINE: HOPATCONG, N.J., Sept. 2

 BODY:
Tim Clancy was out fishing on Lake Hopatcong late the other night when his boat was almost run over by two sleek cigarette boats, one 30 feet long, the other 27 feet, he said. Both were cruising slowly. Mr. Clancy is convinced the operators saw him but did not care about his boat and fishing lines.
"As far as I'm concerned, they're both too big for a lake this size," he said. "It gets hairy out on the lake now, to the point of being dangerous." 
 Drayton Mook, 82 and a lifelong summer resident, has a different complaint. Increasingly in recent years, he says, cabin cruisers and outboards anchor in clusters off his handsome home in Byram Cove.
"One day this summer I counted 204 of them -- an all-time record," Mr. Mook said. The occupants swim, sun, socialize and party. But for Mr. Mook, the clusters become an obstacle course whenever he tries to steer his antique mahogany Chris Craft into his boathouse.
As summer draws to a close on Lake Hopatcong, New Jersey's biggest and busiest lake, an anti-boat chorus is strong and steady. All variety of powerboats whiz around the lake on summer weekends, and some residents contend that too many are too big and too powerful for a lake that is eight miles long and full of coves and islands. They complain that the biggest ones generate two- and three-foot waves that constantly pound into -- and eventually damage -- docks and seawalls, erode shorelines and make sailing and canoeing just about impossible.
"I've seen 32-foot boats out there," Marty Kane, president of the Lake Hopatcong Historical Society, said. "You expect to see that at Barnegat Bay or in the Hamptons, not on a small inland lake. There are no regulations on size. You could put the Queen Mary on the lake. We're not saying, 'Bring it back to canoes only.' But if everyone had a 16-footer, there wouldn't be any problems at all."
Few, if any, around the lake seriously promote the idea that boats longer than 16 feet must go. But a campaign is under way to create an agency to regulate boating on the lake and to charge boat owners fees to use it.
Clifford R. Lundin, the Mayor of Hopatcong, one of four communities on the lake, proposed the idea in mid-August at a symposium on the lake's future sponsored by the Lake Hopatcong Yacht Club. The club's members complain that bigger and bigger boats have ruined their tradition of weekend sailing.
Mr. Lundin seeks the creation of a strong, 12-member agency of residents to take charge of managing the lake. He says that 15 different state departments and agencies now have a regulatory say on the lake and that the state's oversight is fragmented, confused and indifferent.
"We're basically ignored by the state," Mayor Lundin said. "Its emphasis is on the Jersey Shore. All the dollars are aimed at the shore."
The board he proposes, the Lake Hopatcong Watershed Management District, would have the power to adopt and enforce boating regulations and to regulate the discharge of waste into the lake and the ground water in the lake's basin. It would also regulate storm-water runoff, businesses and all forms of construction on the shoreline.
The agency would replace a weak, 22-year-old advisory body, the Lake Hopatcong Regional Planning Board, that has no office, telephone or full-time paid staff.
The board's main accomplishment so far has been the annual "harvesting" of about two million pounds of weeds that would otherwise have encouraged the growth of aquatic vegetation, which erodes water quality. But the weeds are still fed by other nutrients in the lake, principally phosphorous, which comes from septic tank runoff and storm water, said Dr. Stephen Souza, the director of aquatic programs for Coastal Environment Services, a consulting firm in Princeton, and the water-quality adviser for the lake planning board.
Residents say another problem is that none of the Lake Hopatcong marinas have pumping stations to drain the portable toilets on cabin cruisers. Although there is no data on such discharge, some residents are convinced that the sewage ends up in the lake because of careless boaters.
Dr. Souza says the data on the lake's health is mixed. "There's been some improvement in the deepest part of the main body of the lake," he said. "But we have seen a decline in water quality in some coves and shallower parts."
Mayor Lundin says little headway will be made against the lake's problems without the creation of the management agency. But it would need approval of the three other towns on the lake and the state.
His proposal is modeled after the Lake George Park Commission, a powerful agency created by New York State in 1987 to protect water quality in Lake George. It has broad powers that include regulating the speed, noise and sanitary facilities of boats on the lake. Money for the commission comes from special registration fees on powerboats above 10 horsepower and sailboats over 18 feet, along with dock fees.
Mayor Lundin said the agency he proposes could employ a similar registration-fee system on Lake Hopatcong.
Some marina operators and boat owners frown on the idea of a management agency. One operator who spoke on condition of anonymity said that Lake Hopatcong can accommodate the boats on it now. The solution to the lake's problems, he said, is increasing the number of state police patrol boats to four from two and requiring that marinas have pumping stations for marine toilets.
"The lake doesn't belong to one person or people with lake-front homes," he said. "It belongs to all the people of New Jersey."
Marvin Haas of Wayne agreed as he docked his 25-foot cabin cruiser, Go For Broke, the other afternoon. "Last time I looked, this was a state lake," he said.
The lake is crowded with boats on many summer weekends, Mr. Haas said. "But we're also contributing to the local economy. We pay a good amount to dock here."

CORRECTION-DATE: September 6, 1995, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
A picture caption yesterday about a dispute over the size and number of powerboats on Lake Hopatcong in New Jersey misattributed a quotation in some editions. As the article reported, it was a marina operator, speaking on condition of anonymity, who said, "The lake doesn't belong to one person or people with lakefront homes"; it was not Marvin Haas, the boat owner shown.
