HEADLINE: 3 Nations to Resume Bargaining On the Naming of New Elements

BYLINE: By MALCOLM W. BROWNE

 BODY:
AN international crisis of sorts involving the United States, Russia and Germany has been temporarily averted, and although some feathers remain badly ruffled, the parties have agreed to return to the peace table. There is now at least a chance that during the next two years they may be able reach an agreement on the disputed naming of a half dozen man-made elements.
 The substances in question, numbers 104 through 109 on the periodic table of chemical elements, were all created during the last two decades using nuclear accelerators. Only a few atoms of each of these elements were generated in any experiment, and all of them decay radioactively within a few seconds of their birth. They are of interest mainly to a small group of nuclear physicists and chemists probing the limits to which assemblages of protons and neutrons -- the nuclei of atoms -- can be pushed. 
The formal naming of these elements has little importance for science, chemists agree, but names have a great bearing on personal and institutional prestige and on the politics of the international nuclear community. In recent years, names have fueled a heated scientific squabble that came to a head late last year. Negotiators meeting in Britain last month hammered out a tentative compromise, but no final agreement is yet in sight.
 The tempest in a teapot began in March 1994, when the discoverers of Element 106 at Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory in Berkeley, Calif, announced that they had named Element 106 seaborgium, in honor of Dr. Glenn T. Seaborg, the former director of the laboratory. Dr. Seaborg, who was awarded the 1951 Nobel Prize in Chemistry, was a creator and co-discoverer of plutonium and nine other man-made elements.
 Element 106 was created and identified at Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory in 1974, and the discoverers of new elements are traditionally granted the right to name them. The name seaborgium, proposed by the Berkeley group, was promptly endorsed by the American Chemical Society, whose officials assumed that the name would be formally accepted by the International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry, the world arbiter of chemical names.
 But the Americans were in for a surprise. On Aug. 31, 1994, an international panel of 20 chemists appointed by the international union's commission on nomenclature met in Hungary and drew up its own list of names. The American Chemical Society was stunned to learn that Dr. Seaborg's name had been expunged; instead of seaborgium, Element 106 was to be called rutherfordium, in honor of Ernest Rutherford, a New Zealand-born pioneer in atomic physics. (In the United States, chemists had already assigned the name rutherfordium to Element 104.)
 Another change by the international commission that infuriated the Berkeley scientists was the international union's decision to name Element 104 dubnium, in honor of the Joint Institute for Nuclear Research in Dubna, Russia. The Berkeley group objected, not only because Americans had long used the name rutherfordium for Element 104, but because some of Dubna's claims to the discovery of new elements were said to be unsupported by adequate experimental evidence.
 The American Chemical Society also has an economic reason for objecting to the international union's slate of names. Names adopted by the American society have already been widely published in scientific journals, reference works and textbooks, and formal changes in American nomenclature would compel publishers to revise them.
 The main reason given by the international commission for striking Dr. Seaborg from the periodic table was that he was still alive. But Dr. Seaborg himself pointed out that both einsteinium and fermium (Elements 99 and 100, honoring Albert Einstein and Enrico Fermi) were named while their namesakes were still alive. The names themselves, however, were classified secret at the time, since the elements were first identified as constituents of the debris of nuclear explosions.
 Albert Ghiorso, the scientist at Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory who designed much of the accelerator equipment used to discover many new elements, called the international group's names "outrageous," and the fight began.
 The quarrel reached the point that last month an ad hoc committee was convened, with representatives from Germany, Russia and the United States, the three nations responsible for creating all the new elements from Element 93 (neptunium) onward. The committee has reached a compromise, its members report, in which Element 106 would remain seaborgium, but Element 104 would become dubnium, and some other changes opposed by the Berkeley group would be adopted.
 Dr. David F. Eaton, a chemist at the Du Pont Company who serves as leader of the American delegation to the international union, said in an interview that his counterparts from Russia and Germany agreed during their recent deliberations to accept the name seaborgium for Element 106 "as a gesture of their high esteem for Dr. Seaborg," and with the hope that compromises could be reached on some other names.
 "I think that I.U.P.A.C.'s ruling that no element could be named after a living person was more a precedent of convenience than a substantive reason," Dr. Eaton said. "It was the Russians and Germans themselves who initiated the compromise meeting the three of us held, and I think they were very accommodating."
 But neither the American Chemical Society nor the Berkeley group is satisfied with the proposed compromise, he said, which in any case carries no formal weight with the international group. The nations of the world are far from agreed on names.
 "During the meetings last month," Dr. Eaton said, "I saw periodic tables published in Britain, the United States, Arabic countries and Russia, and none of them agreed on the names of Elements 101 through 109."
 However, as a result of the deliberations by the United States, Russian and German delegations, the international union's General Assembly, meeting in Guildford, England, announced that its original list of names had been changed from "definitive" to "provisional," a small victory for the Berkeley scientists. The international group also announced that it would entertain comments from interested chemists during the next five months, and these comments will be considered at the next meeting a year from now. A final meeting to resolve the naming is to take place in two years.
 Dr. Kiril I. Zamarayev of Russia, who heads the international group, reported progress in settling the dispute. But chemists familiar with the proceedings said that the battle lines had been changed and perhaps hardened by the new attitude of Germany, which no longer entirely supports the American slate. Late last year, the Germans discovered two new elements (Elements 110 and 111), neither of them yet involved in the nomenclature row. This, said a chemist, presumably entitles the discoverers, headed by Dr. Peter Armbruster at the Society for Heavy Ion Research accelerator laboratory at Darmstadt, to propose names for 110 and 111. By gaining naming rights to two new elements, he said, the Germans no longer feel impelled to support American objections to the international union's renaming of Elements 104 to 109, which include the change of a German name to a French name.
 The international group proposes that Element 105, now commonly called hahnium (for the German Otto Hahn, discoverer of nuclear fission), should be called joliotium, named for Frederic Joliot-Curie of France, a pioneer in nuclear physics.
 Element 108, which the German discoverers provisionally named hassium (for the Latin name of Hesse, a German province), would be renamed hahnium, under the international union's scheme.
 "It all seems like much ado about nothing," a chemist said, "but from a certain perspective, it matters a lot to a few people."

HEADLINE: Stocks Rise On Corporate Profit Outlook

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
A post-holiday rally drove some stock indexes to record highs yesterday, as investors bet that the economy would not slow enough to hamper the growth of corporate profits.
The rally was led by technology stocks, but automotive issues and other cyclical stocks also rose after announcements about strong August sales for General Motors and Chrysler eased concern that past interest-rate increases had stalled the economy and jeopardized this year's stock rally. 
 "Auto sales were pretty strong last month and that's giving some people encouragement," said Graham Tanaka, president of Tanaka Capital Management in New York. "The economy is in decent shape -- not too strong and not too weak."
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 22.54 points, to 4,670.08, its third straight gain and the highest close since Aug. 9. Shares of International Paper, Boeing, G.M. and Alcoa -- companies whose profits swing with economic cycles -- rose the most.
The broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 5.33 points, to a record 569.17, its seventh gain in the last eight sessions and its biggest rally since a jump of 6.11 points on July 12. The index has risen 1.8 percent in the last week. And the technology-laden Nasdaq index rose 19.83 points, to a record 1,039.30, led by Microsoft, Intel, Oracle and Cisco Systems.
Among auto issues, Chrysler jumped 2 1/2, to 57 1/8; G.M. was up 3/4, to 49 1/4, and Ford Motor rose 1 1/8, to 32 3/8. On Friday, G.M. said sales of cars and light trucks rose 7.1 percent and Chrysler posted a 4 percent gain. The S.& P. auto index, which gained just 4.9 percent this year through Aug. 22, has since climbed 11 percent and closed up 7.12 points yesterday, to 244.34.
One of the declining stocks in the Dow industrials was I.B.M., down 1 5/8, to 101 1/8. Jerome B. York resigned as the company's chief financial officer to become vice chairman of Tracinda, the investment firm. The move by Mr. York, who was instrumental in the recent turnaround at I.B.M., ignited speculation that Tracinda would revive its failed bid for Chrysler.
Nearly two stocks rose for every one that fell on the New York Stock Exchange, where about 333 million shares traded hands.
Other indexes also rose to records yesterday, including the Russell 2000 Index of small-capitalization stocks, which climbed 2.14 points, to 308.31, and the Wilshire 5,000 Index, comprising stocks on the New York, American and Nasdaq stock exchanges, up 51.81 points, to 5,674.11.
Paper industry stocks were among the gainers. Sherman Chao, an analyst at Merrill Lynch, said the advance came because investors were growing more confident that the economy would pick up steam later this year and drive demand for paper and the cardboard boxes used to ship goods. Some investors may be betting that the Federal Reserve will cut interest rates later this year, further stimulating the economy.
International Paper rose 2, to 84 1/2, while Weyerhaeuser climbed 1 3/8, to 47 1/2. Georgia-Pacific gained 1 3/4, to 92 1/4, and Champion International surged 2 1/8, to 59 3/8.
Among chemical stocks, the big gainers included Eastman Chemical, up 7/8, to 64 3/4; Rohm & Haas, up 1 5/8, to 61 5/8; and B. F. Goodrich, up 3/8, to 60 1/2.
Technology stocks gained ground because orders for software, computers and semiconductors remain strong, said Steven Goldman, market strategist at Weeden & Company.
Yesterday, an Oracle executive said analysts' earnings estimates for the computer software company were too low. Oracle's shares rose 5, to 44 1/4.
"Techs should re-emerge as leaders of the market, though the gains won't be as homogeneous as the first part of the year," Mr. Goldman said.
Among the biggest technology gainers today were Dell Computer, up 5 1/2, to 80 3/4, and Micron Technology up 5, to 81 3/8. Microsoft gained 5 1/4, to 95, while Hewlett-Packard surged 4 3/4, to 83 1/8, and Intel rose 2 13/16, to 63 11/16. Cisco Systems was up 2 3/4, to 68 1/8.
Airline stocks rose after USAir said it expected to report a pretax profit for the third quarter and full year on stronger-than-anticipated traffic. USAir rose 1 3/4, to 9 3/4. The gains helped lift the Dow Jones transportation average 32.70 points, to a record 1,945.19.

HEADLINE: Cooperate, Dole Tells Clinton, Or Face Brawl With Congress

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr. 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Sept. 5

 BODY:
In one of his sharpest attacks yet on President Clinton, Senator Bob Dole warned today that the fall Congressional session would be a rough-and-tumble affair unless the White House joined with Republicans to balance the budget, cut taxes, eliminate bureaucracy and rework the welfare system.
Mr. Dole, the Senate majority leader and current front-runner among Republican Presidential candidates, said Mr. Clinton could either climb on board the Republican legislative juggernaut or face all-out political warfare. 
 "If the President wants to join us in forging fundamental change in government, we'll welcome him to the conservative revolution," Mr. Dole said in a major speech to the Economic Club of Chicago.
"But he should know," Mr. Dole continued, "that we will never compromise away the mandate the American people gave us last November. This will not be an autumn of compromise. This fall we will win our fight for revolutionary change vote by vote, bill by bill."
In any event, Mr. Dole concluded, come next fall Republicans plan to "change the occupant of the White House."
Mr. Clinton did not immediately respond to the Dole challenge, which included a call for a total overhaul of the Federal tax code, with emphasis on sharply reduced rates, as well as adoption of a constitutional amendment to make enactment of new taxes much more difficult.
In past months, Mr. Clinton has said he would like to work with Republicans on Capitol Hill this fall, as long as their revolution does not cause undue hardship on the needy. Otherwise, he has warned, the Republican-controlled Congress can expect to contend with White House vetoes.
His tough talk notwithstanding, Mr. Dole did suggest one area of compromise today: Medicare. He said the program was too important to the nation's elderly and in too much financial trouble to be the subject of partisan debate.
"Let's agree to take Medicare out of the realm of politics," Mr. Dole proposed. "When Social Security was in trouble back in the early 1980's, both parties agreed the program was too important for playing politics. So we worked together to fix it. Medicare is no less important."
Mr. Dole's speech seemed intended in good part to reinforce the Senator's credentials with conservatives, who control the Republican nominating process and who sometimes see him as too moderate. Out on the campaign trail, Senator Phil Gramm of Texas, at this point Mr. Dole's chief rival for the nomination, has been boasting that he is more conservative than Mr. Dole and therefore deserves the support of the Republican right.
The speech marked the end of Mr. Dole's Labor Day weekend tour through the Midwest, an event-packed swing designed to reinvigorate his campaign, which has been flagging a bit since his poor showing a couple of weeks back in an Iowa straw poll. In Indianapolis on Monday, for example, he grabbed bold headlines and network news coverage with a biting attack on "elitist liberals" and a demand for formal adoption of English as the nation's official language.
Mr. Dole told his Chicago business audience today that the country was on the threshold of a "fabulous future" but that the threshold would never be crossed if Mr. Clinton continued to embrace "the outdated economic mind-set of the 1930's."
"The only barrier preventing America from reaching her full potential is a failure of leadership and a failure of vision, not a failure of our people," the Senator asserted.
He went on to accuse the President of "zero-sum thinking" and said Mr. Clinton was guilty of encouraging "envy and class warfare."
"They always talk about attacking 'the rich' and hitting people they feel got a 'free ride,' " Mr. Dole said, sarcasm in his voice.
Then Mr. Dole laid out his own vision for a prosperous nation.
He proposed a much-simplified revenue system of vastly lower rates in which capital gains levies would be all but eliminated and a family of four earning $30,000 a year or less would pay almost no taxes.
The Senator's details were sketchy. But he said that once rates had been cut, the Internal Revenue Service should be sharply scaled back and the country should adopt a constitutional amendment requiring a three-fifths vote by each house of Congress to raise any new taxes.
"I will fight for a lower, fairer, flatter and simpler tax system," Mr. Dole promised. "Any fair system would not penalize but instead would reward people for working harder, investing wisely and saving more. End the I.R.S. as we know it."

HEADLINE: New York Fiscal Chaos Gives First-Day Jitters to Teachers

BYLINE: By MARIA NEWMAN 

 BODY:
If the opening of New York City schools this week seems more chaotic than usual, consider the case of Karen Bloom, would-be teacher, who woke up yesterday unemployed, by midmorning was hired as a substitute at Public School 124 and by noon had landed a full-time teaching job at P.S. 111.
Yesterday, on the first day 65,000 New York City teachers returned from summer vacation, principals were still making last-minute staffing decisions after an angry summer of budget negotiations ended without resolving basic questions, like how many teachers the city will have, how large classes will be and which teachers will teach where. 
 At 8 A.M., Ms. Bloom, wearing high heels and a flowing dress, went to interview for a substituting job at a private school. At 9 A.M., she arrived at P.S. 124 in Chinatown, which, she thought, had offered her part-time work. Officials there told her that someone had given her the wrong information but that she could have a two-month substitute teaching job anyway. She took it, started cleaning her assigned room and called her fiance to say she would be home late.
He told her that she had a message from another school, P.S. 111 on West 53d Street. They had full-time work if she wanted it.
"So I boogied into a cab and came up here," she said at 2 P.M. yesterday, using a broom borrowed from one of her new colleagues to sweep out her fourth-floor room. "I'm so happy to have a job. Anywhere. Any grade."
Of course, the beginning of a new school year is always filled with chaos and some amount of uncertainty, and not just in New York City. On Long Island, where most schools were reopening yesterday or today, a number of districts face budget problems or looming labor disputes. In New Jersey's largest district, Newark, students will report on Monday to schools that have been taken over by the state. Connecticut, though, is already mostly past the first-day crises -- most schools there opened last week.
But in New York City, the nation's largest school district, the normal confusion has been amplified this year as the central Board of Education and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani have battled over $230 million in budget cuts and taken turns blaming each other for delaying the decisions necessary to open the schools.
Even yesterday, more than 1,200 teachers, most of them unlicensed, still did not have assignments, and the board had not ruled out layoffs, which would require further shuffling of the teaching force during the first few weeks of school. High school students begin school today and junior high and elementary school students begin tomorrow.
"This year, we are facing a tough year because of budget cuts," said Sandra Feldman, the president of the United Federation of Teachers. "I think there is going to be confusion -- there is always confusion. I think there is a bit more than usual, but it's not something that can't be overcome."
It is clear, though, that there will be fewer school secretaries, guidance counselors will be rare commodities and teachers will face more students in a classroom.
"Everyone is doing double duty," said Frieda Homer, the assistant principal at Thomas Jefferson High School in East New York, Brooklyn. "All administrative personnel have picked up obligations that are not part of their job situation."
She said her school lost staff through transfers, retirements, sabbaticals and excessing -- a domino-like provision of the contract in which a newer teacher loses a job at one school to make room for a more senior teacher. The first teacher can then bump a teacher in another school.
In spite of the confusion from the budget changes, teachers at schools throughout the city faced the new year with the same enthusiasm and trepidation that a new school year always inspires.
"I usually can't sleep the night before," said Nina Frankel, a pre-kindergarten teacher who has been teaching for 10 years at Public School 111. "The children line up in the playground at 8 o'clock in their new clothes and their new backpacks. It's very nice to see. It's very emotional."
The scenes of the first day back for teachers at P.S. 111 were not unlike those at any of the city's 1,000 or so schools, officials said. Teachers were moving furniture, putting up bright new trimming around bulletin boards, attending meetings about who would do cafeteria duty and placing new labels on baskets of blocks and other supplies they had bought for their classes during the summer.
Even though yesterday was officially their first day back, many of the teachers -- the principal, Robert Kinzelberg, estimated as many as 40 percent of them -- spent some time at the school last week to prepare their rooms for the new school year.
Millie Velazquez, a kindergarten teacher, was knee-deep in plastic blocks, stuffed red apples and cutouts from school catalogues as she organized her room.
Last week, she had come in to scrub down her room, which she divided into areas for music, science and the library and for what she called "pretend." In another corner was a table with sand that she had bought at Home Depot.
"I really want the first day to be special for them," Ms. Velazquez said of her kindergarten class.
But Ms. Velazquez, like many other teachers without city certification, said that when she came in loaded down with her new materials, she was still not sure whether she would have a job at P.S. 111.
"I guess I still don't know," she said, noting that she could lose her job to a more senior teacher if there are further staff reductions.
As Ms. Bloom, the new teacher, was sweeping out her room, other teachers came by to introduce themselves. Karen Rothstein stopped by to congratulate her for getting hired.
"Congratulations to you, too," Ms. Bloom said. Ms. Rothstein had only been hired a few minutes ago, too. She had been teaching at P.S. 126 but was told yesterday that she would no longer be needed.
"I went down to the district office," she said. "and I told them, 'I'm a great teacher and I have a lot of love to give these children, and I need a teaching job and I'm not leaving here until I get one' -- in a very friendly way, of course."
She was told to go to P.S. 111, where she was hired to teach fifth grade.
Ms. Bloom, who is 25, earned her master's degree in elementary education at Manhattanville College in Purchase, N.Y., and sent her resume to 30 New York City schools.
"This is my first job," she said happily, not even riled by the dead roach she found in her room. "I am beside myself."
Ms. Bloom was asked if she was going to begin teaching without an orientation to the school system, or even to the school.
She stopped sweeping a moment to think about that.
"Maybe they had an orientation this morning," she said. "But I don't know. I was in Chinatown."

GRAPHIC: Photos: An hour after learning she had won her first full-time teaching job at Public School 111, Karen Bloom was sweeping the floor of her new classroom. (Jim Estrin/The New York Times)(pg. B8)

HEADLINE: Death-Rate Rankings Shake New York Cardiac Surgeons

BYLINE: By ELISABETH BUMILLER 

 BODY:
It was happening again, and Dr. Richard Dal Col could hardly believe it. An emergency cardiac patient, yet another "salvage case," was dead, this time before surgery could even begin. Enraged and frightened, Dr. Dal Col stormed from the operating room into the administrator's office of St. Peter's Hospital in Albany.
"We've got to do something!" he recalls shouting in his anger at the system. "They're going to pull my license if this continues." 
 A month later, when the New York State Health Department released its annual report card of cardiac surgery, one of the first of its kind in the nation, St. Peter's had the highest mortality rate of any hospital in the state. A year later, Dr. Dal Col had the worst record of any heart surgeon in the state -- the beginning of a period of anguish and self-doubt that has only eased as he has moved off the bottom of the list.
The year 1993, when the ranking was announced, was far better for Dr. Jeffrey Gold at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, where he enjoys life at the top of the list. Dr. Gold was No. 3 the year Dr. Dal Col was last of the 87 heart surgeons listed by name. In the 1995 report he is No. 1.
"How does it feel to be the Willie Mays of heart surgery?" he was asked by CBS. Last week, a man needing heart surgery called from upstate. "Doctor," he said, "I'm 47 years old, I have two young children, I want to live -- and I want the best."
The story of Dr. Gold and Dr. Dal Col illustrates how the elite world of New York cardiac surgeons has struggled to adjust to a new set of rules aimed at improving care. The changes have led to turmoil within the insular cardiac community, forcing at least 21 low-performing doctors out of heart surgery in New York. At the same time, doctors suspect that some high-risk surgical patients are pressured to go out of state.
In 1991, New York became the first state in the nation to release surgeon-specific death rates for coronary bypass surgery. Pennsylvania is the only other state that does so. New York health officials and many doctors say the system, though imperfect, has dramatically lowered the risks of undergoing a coronary bypass, the most common form of heart surgery. Statistics appear to support their claim: Over a recent four-year period, the mortality rate of bypass surgery in New York -- adjusted for severity of illness -- dropped from 4.17 deaths in 100 patients to 2.45. New York's actual mortality rate for bypass surgery in 1993, the most recent year available -- 2.71 deaths in 100 patients -- is the lowest reported rate in the nation. Only those deaths that occur in the hospital are counted.
Yet the cardiac report card, which is not done for any other medical specialty in New York, remains a subject of intense debate. There is a widespread, if unproven, belief among doctors that some of New York State's 133 heart surgeons are turning away severely ill patients for fear a death will hurt their rankings, even though the system makes adjustments for high-risk patients.
A study by doctors at the Cleveland Clinic, one of the nation's leading cardiac centers, found that in recent years the patients referred to Cleveland from New York were significantly sicker than the clinic's other patients -- and their numbers have increased. "They were exactly the kind of patients anyone would think twice about before operating," Dr. Nowa Omoigui, the main author of the study, said.
"There's a lot of talk that the sickest patients are going out of state," Barbara A. DeBuono, the New York State Health Commissioner, said. "The fact is that a person in cardiac arrest is not going to be flown to Ohio."
Dr. Omoigui points out that severely ill heart patients in western New York may simply more often be referred to Cleveland by doctors concerned about the high cardiac mortality rates reported at upstate hospitals in recent years.
Other criticism of the report centers on what is termed risk-factor inflation. Under the state system, doctors report patients' risk factors -- like age, the pumping capacity of the heart, previous heart attacks -- which are weighed so that doctors who take on severely ill patients are not unfairly penalized. In some cases, the death of a patient with many risk factors will count on a doctor's record as only half a mortality.
In a recent article in The New England Journal of Medicine, two researchers at the New York University Medical Center point out that after the report cards were made public, there were large jumps in reported risk factors in New York -- from 1.8 percent to 52.9 percent for chronic lung disease at one hospital, for example -- and argue that this "spurious" increase accounts for much of the decline in New York's risk-adjusted mortality rate.
State health officials, who have made their report available in libraries and on the Internet, dispute the article, saying that many doctors underreported risk factors in the early years of data collection and that the decline in the mortality rate is real.
Both Dr. Dal Col and Dr. Gold, like most heart surgeons in New York, support the report card, although with reservations. Their stories illustrate both the strengths and weaknesses of the system, and how it has changed heart surgery in New York.
 
Dr. Dal Col
A Perfectionist Hurt by a Ranking
 Dr. Richard Dal Col is a gregarious, impassioned man with none of the self-importance associated with heart surgeons, although his wife, Kathy, describes him as a perfectionist. "I'm a nurse, and he used to remake the bed," she said.
Dr. Dal Col, 39, is doing much better these days. At his low point, he was listed with 13 deaths for 265 coronary bypass operations from 1990 to 1992, giving him an alarming risk-adjusted mortality rate of 7.4 percent. The New York State average at the time was 2.99 percent.
In 245 more recent bypasses in 1994 and 1995 tallied by the state, Dr. Dal Col has had no deaths. "I want to tell the next poor guy at the bottom of the list not to panic," he said.
Dr. Dal Col's problems began soon after he started practicing on his own in 1990. As a young surgeon at Albany Medical Center, where he trained in general surgery and cardiothoracic surgery, Dr. Dal Col says, he was getting many "heroic" emergency cases. "You earn your stripes by taking anything that comes," he said. This did not concern him until 1991, when Newsday successfully sued the state under the Freedom of Information Act for a list of cardiac surgeons and their mortality rates. A year earlier, health officials had for the first time released hospital death rates but resisted disclosing surgeon data.
When Newsday published the doctors' list, Dr. Dal Col had only 68 operations and a record that was among the state's worst. (When the state began releasing the surgeon data on its own the following year, it included only those doctors who had at least 200 cases, saying that fewer than that produced rates that were not statistically significant.) Concerned, the partners in Dr. Dal Col's practice decided he would be in a more "protected" position if he operated at St. Peter's, a community hospital that handled fewer crisis cases.
But by the time Dr. Dal Col got to St. Peter's in 1992, its cardiac program was booming. Records show that almost three-fourths of Dr. Dal Col's cases were emergencies or urgent, and that a distressing number of patients were dying -- usually not in the operating room, but a few days later. Given the high risk of these patients, Dr. Dal Col and St. Peter's should have fared reasonably well when the state reported their adjusted mortality rates. But when the hospital came out on the bottom that year, St. Peter's began working with the state to find out what was wrong.
Mark Chassin, the Health Commissioner at the time, said St. Peter's discovered that a small category of patients, the 1992 emergency bypass cases, had a mortality rate of 26 percent -- one in four were dying. The statewide average mortality for such patients was 7 percent.
Dr. Chassin says that the St. Peter's patients were found to be "appropriate candidates" for surgery but that doctors were moving them too quickly into the operating room. They did not stabilize them as much beforehand as doctors did at other New York hospitals. Nor did they use as often in these patients an intra-aortic balloon pump to increase blood flow through the coronary arteries before surgery.
St. Peter's revamped its care of these patients, and in 1993 had no mortalities among its emergency cases. Records show that Dr. Dal Col's mortality rate improved markedly that year, going from 7.4 percent to not quite 2 percent, even as he was taking the same percentage of high-risk cases.
"It's misleading to look at this as a surgeon's problem," Dr. Chassin said. "It really is a system problem."
Nonetheless, there have been problems with individuals. Of the poor-performing heart surgeons identified by the report in recent years, Dr. Chassin said some had such high mortality rates -- and such a low volume of cases -- that hospitals refused to allow the doctors back in their operating rooms for cardiac surgery, effectively forcing 21 doctors out of the specialty in New York. Dr. Chassin said some may now be practicing out of state.
Dr. Dal Col said the ranking never hurt his livelihood because he was in a large practice in a town where people knew him. "If I had been in New York, I'd be dead in the water," he said. He said he has never faced a malpractice suit after a patient's death.. Of the patients who died, he said, "all of them were people who I honestly feel would have died on anybody." His annual income, paid by his practice, has remained in the low to mid six figures. He and his wife have three children.
Still, the ranking changed his life. His wife remembers watching the local news one night and crying as they called her husband the worst surgeon in the state.
"Emotionally, and in terms of my maturation as a surgeon," Dr. Dal Col said, "this has been devastating."
 
Dr. Gold
Refusing Credit For a Top Rating
 It is 9:45 A.M., New York Hospital. Dr. Jeffrey Gold cut into the right atrium of a 35-year-old woman's heart and within minutes lifted out a plum-sized mass that looked like a cluster of clear fish eggs.
"What do you think of that?" he asked. His relaxed tone masked the fact that this was a life-threatening tumor, a myxoma. Five days earlier, a bit of it had broken off and traveled to the patient's brain, causing a major stroke. The patient, who has a 3-year-old daughter and lives in Westchester County, had no obvious prior symptoms.
The tumor removed, Dr. Gold spent the next half hour cutting out a piece of Gore-Tex fabric and fitting it over the hole the tumor left in the woman's heart, where it will remain.
"There is a craft to surgery," he said, making neat, careful stitches with polyurethane thread and admiring the woman's heart, an otherwise normal purple mass about the size of two fists. "Don't you think it's beautiful? The human body is a marvel."
Dr. Gold, 42, once did needlepoint on pillows to keep in practice for surgery, but they overtook his East Side apartment where he lives with his wife, an ophthalmologist, and two children. "I've been married for 22 years," he said. "That's a record in heart surgery." On weekdays, he leaves for the hospital at 6:30 A.M., returning at 10 P.M. or later. On Saturdays he works until 2 P.M., and on Sunday mornings he does hospital rounds.
Dr. Gold operates on diplomats, the owners of New York's most exclusive French restaurants and high-ranking Russians (although not Boris Yeltsin, as was reported in a gossip column). He makes $500,000 a year as an employee of Cornell Medical College; if he were in private practice he could make at least three times that. He is earnest and bookish and collects antique fountain pens to relax.
"Most cardiac surgeons collect Jaguars," he said.
Dr. Gold's risk-adjusted mortality rate in the current cardiac report is 0.22 percent, and he and New York Hospital, where he did his residency in general surgery, are known for taking very sick patients. "But there is nothing that separates me from the rest of the people on the list," Dr. Gold said, crediting his surgical team and the hospital for his good results.
And even though Dr. Gold is ranked at the top of the report, he has qualms about it. "I'm concerned about the predictability of it," he said. "I certainly would not use it as the sole way of selecting an institution or a surgeon."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Dr. Jeffrey Gold, at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, had the best record of any heart surgeon in the state in 1995. (Fred R. Conrad/The New York Times); Dr. Richard Dal Col was upset by a low ranking in 1993. (Dave Jennings for The New York Times)(pg. B2)

HEADLINE: Colleges Ease Parents' Fears With Orientation Programs

BYLINE: By MIKE ALLEN 

DATELINE: HARRISONBURG, Va., Sept. 3

 BODY:
Parents of freshmen at the University of North Carolina at Wilmington get this advice from an administrator: After the fourth or fifth week of classes, mail your freshman a card that says $50 is enclosed so he or she can have a nice dinner with a friend.
"But don't put in the money," said the administrator, Richard H. Mullendore, associate vice chancellor for student affairs. "You'll hear from your student. Works every time." 
 Dr. Mullendore's advice is part of a two-day orientation the university holds every summer for families of new students. Such programs, rare 10 years ago, have become common as colleges have learned the value of winning over the people who usually pay the bills, and as more high school graduates have begun to put down deposits at several colleges and universities so they can continue shopping around during the summer.
"Students and parents are becoming more demanding," Dr. Mullendore said. "This is part of the consumerism movement in higher education. We have one student who went to four summer orientations before settling on us."
The orientations, which range from casual talks to sleepovers, are usually either free or carry a small charge. The programs, intended to help reduce parents' separation anxiety, try to prepare them for the fall by giving them and their children separate orientation schedules.
In a 1993 survey by the National Orientation Directors Association, 81 percent of the 548 colleges that responded had some kind of parent orientation, most of them started in the last decade. As a result of these programs, a lot of parents in cars with roof racks looked a little less lost as they pulled onto college campuses in recent weeks.
At the University of the Pacific, in Stockton, Calif., parents are treated to a wine tasting and barbecue at a nearby museum. At Bemidji State University in Minnesota, parents get homework -- a long questionnaire to fill out with their children.
Last year, Xavier University, a Jesuit institution with an enrollment of 6,800, began issuing a "Musketeer parent's card" to each family at its summer orientation. The cards, which have an 800 number for the Cincinnati university and spaces for the student's phone number and address, can be used for a 10 percent discount at the campus bookstore.
Adrian A. Schiess, Xavier's director of freshman programs, said the cards were designed to enhance the university's "service and satisfaction component."
One of the more elaborate programs is here in the Shenandoah Valley, at James Madison University, where parents are invited to spend a night in the dormitories. Theater students put on a skit advising parents not to turn their child's room into a den -- at least until after the student's first visit home.
"Dorm rooms haven't changed much in 30 years -- you get a closet, a dresser, a desk and a bed, all in a space the size of my sewing room," said Sheila Day, 50, a home economics teacher from Heuvelton, N.Y., whose son, Geoff, is a freshman at James Madison.
Other topics are new. The parents are told about procedures that may have been irrelevant in their youths, like calling for security escorts, and about issues that were not discussed, like date rape.
At James Madison, the 2,500 freshmen are divided among 11 two-day sessions in June and July. More than 90 percent of the freshmen have a relative attending the program, said Al Menard, the associate vice president for student affairs. Only 60 percent of the parents use the dorm rooms; the rest stay in motels.
The first impression is so important, Dr. Menard said, that parent orientation is considered part of the recruitment process. Students register for classes and can sign up for phones and checking accounts during the orientation.
While the parents take guided campus tours and receive information about courses and campus social life from a university vice president, the new students take placement tests, meet with their advisers and attend a roundtable discussion with upperclassmen.
During the summer session at Otterbein College in Westerville, Ohio, a psychologist coaches parents about coping with separation anxiety. An evening program called "Sex at 7:00? What Are You Teaching My Son/Daughter?" deals with acquaintance rape and introduces the college's peer-counseling program.
When students arrived at the University of Richmond last month, parents of new students were offered two days of meals and meetings, followed by an invitation to attend the university's chapel service on Sunday morning.
"Schools have become more and more aware that parents are a significant constituency," said Patricia C. Harwood, a dean at Richmond. "You don't all of a sudden become someone else because your daughter or son turns 18.
"We've found that both parents and students benefit from talking about the importance of letting go, and from thinking through this transition in the role of the parent to a support person."
Some young people are skeptical about the value of bringing their parents to campus.
Lisa R. Milliken graduated from James Madison in 1989 and was recently back on campus for an alumni field hockey game. "They should give you a kiss and take off," said Miss Milliken, now a 28-year-old high school teacher in Harrisonburg, said of parents. "What are they going to do next? Take them to their jobs? 'Honey, this is where you'll do your accounting work.' "
But for many parents, the orientation is a practical and psychological godsend. Mary Sue Miller, 49, flew to Harrisonburg from Livermore, Calif., rented a van and knew just where to go to help her daughter, Jennifer, move in.
"I'm not even going to come to parents' weekend this fall," Mrs. Miller said. "I've seen it all."
For some parents and students, orientation gave a taste of the homesickness to come. "Some kids hung around their parents," said Pamela S. Parmer, 39, of Lancaster, Pa., whose son, Jason, will be on the James Madison football team this fall. "You could tell it was going to be pretty traumatic."
Andrew Barry, 19, of Arlington, Va., a sophomore at James Madison, worked as a waiter at this summer's orientation, which he called "therapy for parents."
"You've got to get over it sometime, this parent thing," Mr. Barry said.
 
LETTING GO
 
This fall's parent orientation at the University of Tennessee at Knoxville, included these tips compiled by the National Orientation Directors Association, a group of college orientation officials.
 
 --Don't ask your students if they're homesick.
 --Write (even if they don't write back).
 --Ask questions (but not too many).
 --Expect change (but not too much).
 --Don't worry (too much) about manic-depressive phone calls or letters.
 --Visit (but not too often).
 --Do not tell your students that 'these are the best years of their lives.'
 --Trust them.

HEADLINE: At a School, Clinton Campaigns for Education Spending

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: SELMA, Calif., Sept. 5

 BODY:
Seeking to return to Washington on the political offensive, President Clinton stumped today for education spending before a crowd of thousands gathered outside a middle school in California's farm country.
Mr. Clinton's appearance at Abraham Lincoln Middle School was one of many events the White House has planned to rally public support for the President's fiscal priorities as he and the Republican-controlled Congress move into the crucial months of their confrontation on the budget. 
 "Education is not supposed to be a partisan political football, and it should not be when Congress returns tomorrow," Mr. Clinton said today in his campaign-style rally before a crowd of parents, students and teachers. "We ought to stay on the side of education."
One placard pasted on a wall expressed just the political message Mr. Clinton was trying to send: "Clinton = Education."
Mr. Clinton and Republicans in Congress have sharp differences on issues like education spending, Medicare spending and tax cuts, and for two days Mr. Clinton has been trying to drum up support for his priorities in a state that will be crucial for his re-election hopes.
"When Congress comes back from their recess tomorrow," he said, "we will have 90 days of decisions about the budget, 90 days to choose what direction we're going to take."
So far only 1 of the 13 spending bills that finance the Federal Government has passed both houses, and Mr. Clinton has already issued half a dozen veto threats. In addition, Congress still has not shown how it plans to carry out some of its most controversial plans to scale back the costs of programs like Medicare, Medicaid and farm supports.
If the White House and Congress cannot agree on budget priorities and the spending bills, the result could be a partial shutdown of the Government. The effects of such a shutdown could well spill over into the 1996 Presidential race as voters decide whom to blame for stalled legislation in Washington.
In Chicago today, the Senate majority leader, Bob Dole of Kansas, the leading Republican Presidential contender, vowed not to compromise with the President on balancing the budget over seven years and cutting taxes by $245 billion. "We will fight to the end for fundamental conservative change," Mr. Dole said.
Although he did not mention Mr. Dole, Mr. Clinton told the California crowd: "There are some who say that there should be no compromise this autumn. But I say that good people of good will want us to find common ground, want us to find honorable compromise, want us to balance the budget and keep faith with the children of America and their educational needs."
Focusing particularly on education spending, Mr. Clinton plans to meet with chief executives from companies supporting his endangered Goals 2000 program, which provides Federal financing for state, community and school efforts to raise education standards. And next Monday he is planning a trip to Illinois to highlight a Federal education loan program, which Congress is seeking to scale back or eliminate.
Before the rally, Mr. Clinton gave a history lesson to 20 nervous and excited eighth graders who had been chosen by lottery to see the President. Speaking softly, his hands folded in front of him, Mr. Clinton, who was once a law professor, took them in 35 minutes from the Civil War and the battle to abolish slavery through the first and second World Wars and the end of the cold war.
Throughout his informal lesson, he stressed themes that he has repeated across two days in California -- that American success in the global economy will increasingly depend on education and that Americans need to bridge their racial and ethnic differences.
The students' questions for Mr. Clinton were all personal.
Erica Franco, 13, stumped Mr. Clinton when she asked what he planned to do after he left office.
"I don't know," he said. "I haven't thought about it much. Once in a while I think about it, but I haven't -- you know, if I stay healthy and I've been blessed with pretty good health, I hope I can continue to do some things that are useful for my country. I'm not much on just laying around."

Before the rally, Mr. Clinton gave a history lesson to 20 nervous eighth graders who had been picked by lottery to see him. (Jim Wilson/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Streak Alive as Yankees Veto 13th Stadium Plan in a Year

BYLINE: By VIVIAN S. TOY 

 BODY:
The New York Yankees yesterday criticized the city's current proposal to keep the baseball team in the Bronx, increasing pressure on the Giuliani administration to present the team with more specific proposals for a new stadium elsewhere in New York City.
But Yankee officials, who criticized the city plan in a press release, went to great pains to say that while they intended to consider new stadium sites, they were not necessarily rejecting the Bronx or the stadium's current site. 
 "What is before us simply doesn't accomplish the objectives of the city and of the Yankees," said David Sussman, the Yankees' executive vice president and general counsel. "We are asking the city and the Economic Development Corporation to start in earnest, in an expedited way, looking at other sites the city has identified."
An expert hired by the Yankees to assess the city's latest proposal -- the 13th in the last year -- said in July that the planned improvements were inadequate and would not speed the flow of traffic to and from Yankee Stadium. City officials had asked for time to review the expert's report, and the Yankees' public statement yesterday was apparently intended to remind the city that it should respond as soon as possible.
George M. Steinbrenner 3d, the Yankees' principal owner, often cites heavy traffic, poor access to garages and inadequate parking as reasons for his dissatisfaction with Yankee Stadium. Mr. Steinbrenner was traveling to Tampa yesterday and could not be reached for comment, Mr. Sussman said.
"We are sorry that the Yankee organization did not find the administration's plan for a new Yankee Stadium acceptable," said Deputy Mayor John S. Dyson. "We are willing, however, to go back to the table and continue discussions, including exploring alternative sites for the stadium in New York City."
Mr. Sussman said the Yankees issued their statement yesterday in hopes of getting the city to make an acceptable proposal by the end of this year. He said the team must have plans either for renovation of the current stadium or for construction of a new one very soon because the Yankees' current 30-year lease with the city expires in 2002.
"Even if we were able to commence this project by year end, we would be under a very tight schedule," he said. "The time is now to make a determination and to proceed."
Mr. Sussman did not rule out the possibility that the Yankees might move to New Jersey. He said, however, that all questions about a site in New Jersey would have to be answered by Mr. Steinbrenner.
The Yankees have been squabbling with the city for two years about where the Yankees will play after 2002. The team has said it cannot stay where it is unless parking and road access to the stadium are vastly improved.
The city's latest proposal involved building three garages with 6,000 parking spaces next to the stadium and enlarging an existing one. It also proposed building a new bridge across the Harlem River and new ramps from the Major Deegan Expressway and 145th Street Bridge.
Although the additional garage space would provide the parking the Yankees said they required, Mr. Sussman said the team's expert felt the plan did not adequately address problems of getting cars to and from Yankee Stadium quickly.
Also, getting approval and money for the proposed Harlem River Bridge would be extremely difficult, since it would be built solely to take people to a stadium that operates only half the year, Mr. Sussman said.
Separately, the city has met recently with Mets' officials to discuss plans to build a new stadium near the site of Shea Stadium.

HEADLINE: After 7 Weeks, Detroit Newspaper Strike Takes a Violent Turn

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Sept. 5

 BODY:
With bargaining stalled, the seven-week standoff here between two newspapers and their striking unions has erupted into violence, as police battled pickets who were illegally blockading a printing plant late Saturday and again late Monday.
In Monday night's melee, police officers in riot gear fired pepper spray at pickets who pelted them with auto parts and swatted them with their signs. The demonstrators, on strike against The Detroit News and The Detroit Free Press, dispersed about 2 A.M. today, permitting replacement workers to enter and leave the plant. 
 Eight pickets were arrested in the demonstration that began late Saturday and spilled into Sunday, and 23 were arrested Monday night and today. All were charged with unlawful assembly, inciting to riot, disorderly conduct or resisting arrest.
About 2,500 journalists, printers, truck drivers, maintenance workers and others, represented by six different unions, struck the newspapers on July 13. The business operations of the two newspapers are run under a joint venture, and since the strike began they have published a combined edition.
There is no sign of headway in the talks. Negotiators for one of the striking unions, the Newspaper Guild, met today with representatives of The Free Press but reported no progress. The Guild is battling an attempt by management to impose a merit raise system and to limit overtime, while the other unions are fighting over job security, control of the workplace and other issues.
The Free Press said last week that it would start replacing Guild members who did not return to work by today. "Our offer to bring everybody back is not possible anymore," said Heath J. Meriwether, the executive editor of The Free Press.
The 124 Guild members who crossed the picket lines at The Free Press before the ultimatum had been joined by only one other as of today. But he was a significant one: Mitch Albom, a sports columnist who is probably the newspaper's best known and most popular writer.
Mr. Albom began his column about the strike today with one word: "Enough." He wrote that he would remain a member of the Guild and "give much of what I earn to the people still on strike."
But, Mr. Albom said in an interview, "Newspapers are fire stations, they are police stations, and they should not be shut down."
Mr. Albom, who tried to broker an agreement that would return strikers to work during negotiations, said that he thought both sides in the dispute were wrong and that he did not want to be seen as supporting either. "I didn't want to be waved as a flag," he said.
The demonstration late Saturday by about 3,000 strikers and their supporters was planned by the unions. But Monday's more violent disruption was not, the unions said.
"You're dealing with forces that are very hard to control," said John Lippert, a striking Free Press labor reporter. "You've got people who are really on the brink of economic ruin."
The newspapers sought an injunction today to limit the number of pickets.
Monday night and early this morning, about 300 demonstrators tried to block the gates of the plant, in Sterling Heights just north of here. When 50 to 60 police officers, carrying shields, marched forward to clear a path, the pickets pushed them back.
Chief Thomas Derocha of the Sterling Heights Police Department said demonstrators began throwing half-pound pieces of steel used to make automobile steering columns, apparently stolen from a nearby plant.

HEADLINE: Race for Bridgeport Casino Is Down to 2 Big Operators

BYLINE: By JONATHAN RABINOVITZ 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Sept. 5

 BODY:
The competition to develop a casino in Bridgeport narrowed today to two of the nation's most prominent gaming operators -- the Mashantucket Pequot Indians of Ledyard and Las Vegas-based Mirage Resorts Inc. -- as 10 other candidates dropped out, saying the stakes were too high.
In issuing a request for proposals for the casino in July, the state said it would only select a developer who could guarantee the state $610 million over the next three years, a sum many gaming analysts called unrealistic. To weed out less serious candidates, the state required that potential developers submit a $610 million letter of credit with their proposals, which were due today. 
 It is unclear whether either of the proposals will pass muster with the state. The sealed bids will not be opened until Wednesday.
Yet the Pequots' proposal has already raised doubts because it did not include a letter of credit. Instead, G. Michael Brown, the president of the tribe's Foxwoods Resort Casino, said the tribe would guarantee the state revenue by other means. Under a compact with the state, the casino is expected to provide the state more than $150 million this year in exchange for its monopoly on slot machines.
Richard D. Bronson, a director of Mirage Resorts, said his proposal did include the $610 million letter of credit, though it remained to be seen whether Mirage, which recently embarked upon substantial casino development projects in Atlantic City and Las Vegas, Nev., had the finances to begin a third in Bridgeport.
Still, at a news conference this afternoon, Gov. John G. Rowland called the two proposals "a tremendous response" and described the two candidates as "great developers with the creativity and capacity to develop a great facility."
"We presume they both are qualified," Governor Rowland said. "We hope to see a casino in Bridgeport in the very near future."
Casino opponents, however, saw the limited response as a sign that the project was not viable.
"The fact that there are only two developers out of all the United States and from around the world is indication that it is not economically feasible," said State Senator James T. Fleming, the Republican majority leader.
A casino in Bridgeport would be only an hour by train from New York City and could draw thousands of gamblers away from the casinos in Atlantic City as well as attracting others in New York who have never wagered.
But any developer other than the Pequots faces a major problem: insuring that the state will not lose any revenue as a result of the casino's being built. The state now receives 25 percent of the slot machine revenue from Foxwoods in return for the tribe's monopoly on slots, but the Pequots have said that the moment the Legislature approves another casino, they will stop the payments.
This means the new casino operator must be prepared to make payments from its line of credit to cover the lost revenue. The $610 million figure was arrived at because it equals the amount the Pequots are expected to pay the state in the next three years.
For most of the prospective developers, including Donald Trump and several major gaming companies, the $610 million was too steep.
Martin P. Boscaccy, vice president of gaming development at Harrah's Entertainment Inc., the nation's largest casino company, said that the $610 million letter was the reason Harrah's withdrew today.
"That is a tremendous amount of credit that you put at risk prior to finding out whether you're getting the license," Mr. Boscaccy said. It takes resources away from other projects the company could be pursuing and it costs a substantial amount in interest payments -- from $400,000 to $700,000 -- to maintain the credit line, he added.
Mr. Brown said he did not believe the tribe was obligated to present a letter of credit since it could guarantee the state would not be losing its monthly payments from Foxwoods slots. In addition to pledging to continue to provide 25 percent of the slot revenue while the new casino is being built, Mr. Brown said that the tribe would pay a 25 percent tax on the revenues from a temporary casino that would operate during the construction.
Once the new casino opened, the tribe would pay whichever was greater: the money from the Foxwoods slots or an agreed-upon tax on the gross win at the casino in Bridgeport.
Mr. Rowland said today that such a guarantee might be sufficient, though lawyers would need to review it.
Still, representatives of other developers said the Pequot proposal violated the terms set by the state. Indeed, two weeks ago, in response to written questions submitted by one developer, John Meskill, the state official overseeing the selection process, responded, "All proposers will be required to submit a letter of credit."
Asked whether the Pequots could offer an alternative, Mr. Meskill answered, "Should the Mashantucket Pequot Indian tribe submit a proposal, or participate in a proposal, it will be required to submit a letter of credit."

HEADLINE: Heileman Says It May Default On January Interest Payment

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON 

DATELINE: DALLAS, Sept. 5

 BODY:
The G. Heileman Brewing Company, burdened with debt as a result of a leveraged buyout by Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst last year, said today that it would probably default on an interest payment due on Jan. 31.
Heileman's situation suggested that for all the pledges by financiers to avoid repetition of the optimistic buyouts rampant in the late 1980's, some recent deals have been risky enough to blow apart even during flush economic times. 
 A default could damage the ability of Hicks, Muse -- one of the nation's largest and busiest buyout firms -- to raise money for future deals. Contrasting itself with New York rivals, Hicks, Muse, which is based here, has boasted of paying reasonable prices and borrowing conservatively.
Heileman, based in La Crosse, Wis., describes itself as the nation's leading regional brewer and the fifth largest over all, with sales last year of $874 million. Its brands include Lone Star, Colt 45 malt liquor, Old Style and Schmidt's.
Faced with shrinking sales in a heavily competitive beer market, Heileman had cut prices and lost money even before its heavy interest expenses. As of June 30, its long-term debt of $317 million overwhelmed its net worth of $34 million.
The company lost $6.3 million in the second quarter before interest expenses and $14.7 million after, in contrast to net earnings of $13.2 million in the second quarter last year. In its most recent quarterly statement, the company said it had failed to comply with earnings and financial ratios required by its lenders as of June 30, but that the lenders had granted waivers. Heileman said last month -- and repeated in today's statement -- that it was likely to cover its Sept. 30 payments.
Today, Heileman said that efforts to bail itself out by finding a new partner or purchaser had failed. Therefore, the company said it determined that it would "undertake a restructuring of the company's balance sheet in order to properly position Heileman from a financial point of view."
Roy Winnick, a spokesman for Heileman and Hicks, Muse, refused to elaborate or translate other than to deny that a bankruptcy filing loomed. "Absolutely not," he said. "Some sort of restructuring is necessary, and we're going to figure out the best way to do it."
Usually, lenders can force a company into bankruptcy if it violates loan provisions or defaults on a payment. Companies often try negotiating instead to stretch or avoid some debt payments. These talks usually become high-stakes games, with each side threatening abrupt action.
Hicks, Muse and its controlling partner, Thomas O. Hicks, now find themselves in an unusual and uncomfortable position. In a record with few blemishes, Hicks, Muse and a predecessor company have strung together successful deals, including the purchase of the companies making 7-Up and Dr Pepper.

HEADLINE: After the Meal, First the Check, Then the Police

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: MASTIC, L.I., Sept. 5

 BODY:
In the last few weeks, Alessandro Nardone became a regular at Paisley's Eatery here, dropping by for dinner several nights a week and often bringing friends.
So when two police detectives stopped in on Sunday night with his picture, staff members were not only able to identify him, they were able to point him out at a table where he was treating 10 friends to dinner. 
 When the $330 check came and Mr. Nardone paid with a credit card in somebody else's name, the detectives charged him with credit card fraud.
"My guys waited for him to finish his meal," Lieut. Denis Caine of the Suffolk County police said. "They watched him sign the credit card receipt and then placed him under arrest."
Dining out was only one of the things that Mr. Nardone did with the American Express card, which was issued in the name of a man from Woodstock, Vt., the police said today. Over the last few weeks, Mr. Nardone, 38, an unemployed chef from Shirley, had charged more than $15,000 worth of goods on the card, including an air-conditioner, a typewriter and a living room set. The police also impounded his Lincoln Continental after determining that he had used the credit card to install a stereo and alarm system.
Mr. Nardone was arraigned today in First District Court in Yaphank on charges of forgery and criminal possession of a forged instrument. The police said he had a history of arrests in New York City on similar charges dating to 1982.
Tom Aufiero, the owner of Paisley's said today: "We knew this gentleman. Within the last month he had been coming in pretty regularly. He was a very loud guy. He got to know all the waitresses by name and liked the attention. He was very flamboyant."
The police said they began their investigation two weeks ago after the Vermont man called them. He said American Express had notified him that someone was running up large bills on his credit card, Lieutenant Caine said, "and he said, 'I don't have a card with you.' "
With the help of American Express, the police were able to track down Mr. Nardone to his home in Shirley. The police said they don't know how Mr. Nardone obtained the credit cards.
Mr. Nardone, who is being held on $25,000 bail, had told Mr. Aufiero that he owned a restaurant in the Hamptons. If convicted, he could be sentenced to up to 20 years in prison.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Securities Rise in Price

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities gained yesterday for the fourth straight trading day, with the long maturities posting the biggest gains.
Since last Friday's economic reports suggested that growth was not fast enough to ignite inflation or to keep the Fed from lowering interest rates, the market has been pricing in a rate cut, even with the latest auto sales showing gains. Analysts say that the auto sales while good should not give rise to inflation. 
 The 30-year bond rose 18/32, to a price of 104 1/32 to yield 6.57 percent, in thin trading, down from 6.61 percent on Friday.
Kenneth J. McCarthy, head of the Economic Intelligence Company, a market research and analysis firm, said almost all of last week's flood of ecconomic data confirmed that the economy would grow solidly in the next several weeks.
"The upshot of all of these reports is a picture of an economy reviving steadily, but not about to explode upward as it did a year ago at this time," he said. "That's critical because it means that inflationary pressures will be nonexistent. There is absolutely no reason to expect inflation to rise above the current 3 percent. That means the Fedederal Reserve can and will lower interest rates again, but not until later this year."
In the futures market, which invariably influences the cash market, prices were mixed in light trading. The December bond contract tested 113 13/32 in the morning and rose to 113 14/32, but it was still below last Friday's high of 113 21/32.
Robin Mesch, chief fixed-income analyst at Thomson Research, Portland Ore., predicted the price of the December Treasury bond contract would go even higher. "This is the real thing, and the swing in price suggests a transition into another trading level, Ms. Mesch said. "You don't buck the move until you see the market begin to move sideways." In overnight trading before the opening of the New York market, the December contract low was 112 27/32, while in the New York session, the low was 112 30/32, with the high at 113 29/32. It closed at 113 26/32, at the top of the day's trading range.
Fed officials at the annual two-day economic conference in Jackson Hole, Wyo., signaled their willingness to cut rates if Congress was able to reduce the budget deficit. Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, said short- and intermediate-term interest rates would fall if there are significant cuts in the budget deficit.
Traders note that there is little fresh news, and taking the market much higher will be difficult at best, with bond prices susceptible to investors taking profits after last week's gains. The light calendar of reports includes the weekly jobless claims on Thursday and second-quarter nonfarm productivity. On Friday the Fed will issue its report on July consumer installment credit. Analysts doubt there is anything in this calendar that would dissuade the Fed from lowering short-term interest rates again this year.
At the Treasury's weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills, rates declined for the third consecutive week, reflecting traders' anticipation of another lowering of rates by the Fed.
The average discount rate for a three-month issue was 5.30 percent, down from 5.34 percent a week ago, while the average rate for a six-month bill was also 5.30 percent, down from 5.34 percent. The identical average rates for both of yesterday's issues suggest that the market is expecting a rate cut soon, analysts said. The last time the Fed reducted rates was early July, when it cut the target for the Federal funds rate it charges banks for overnight loans by 1/4 point, to 5 3/4 percent.
The following are the results of yesterday's Treasury auction of new three- and six-month bills:

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Rises but Then Retreats As Japan Doesn't Act on Rates

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar ended little changed yesterday after retreating from a surge in Asian trading fueled by speculation about a cut in Japanese interest rates.
Expectations for a cut in Japan's discount rate grew after the governor of the Bank of Japan, Yasuo Matsushita, as well as Prime Minister Tomiichi Murayama and Finance Minister Masayoshi Takemura all said yesterday that the economic recovery had ground to a standstill. 
 One way to stimulate growth would be to cut the discount rate -- already at a historic low of 1 percent. Such a cut would hurt the yen by making deposits in Japan less attractive.
The dollar rose as high as 98.28 yen in Asian trading before falling back. In late New York trading yesterday, the dollar settled at 97.68 yen, up from 97.43 yen on Friday. The dollar slipped to 1.4621 German marks from 1.4622 marks. The British pound rose to $1.5577 from $1.5575.
Trading activity was quieter then usual yesterday after the Labor Day holiday in the United States, traders said.
Expectations of a cut in Japanese rates, said Kevin Lawrie, foreign exchange manager at the Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh, "will probably build as the week progresses and that should provide some help for the dollar."
But some traders were skeptical that another rate cut by Japan would be enough to drive the dollar higher.
"Rates are pretty darn low already," said Dave Glowacki, senior currency trader at the NBD Bank in Detroit. "With all this talk about it, a cut is probably somewhat built into the exchange rates already."
The strong yen -- which gained as much as 24 percent against the dollar earlier this year, before retreating in recent months -- made Japanese exports less competitive and helped to stifle the country's long-awaited economic rebound. The yen is still up 2 percent against the dollar this year.
Against the mark, the dollar was underpinned by speculation that Germany's 14-day securities repurchase rate, the country's key money-market rate, will drop again when the Bundesbank conducts its weekly money-market operations today.
The German central bank has cut the repo rate to 4.3 percent from 4.5 percent over the last four weeks. Traders said a further cut of 5 to 10 basis points was likely today. A basis point is a hundredth of a percentage point. The Bundesbank cut two important short-term interest rates by half a point on Aug. 24.

SECTION: Section A; Page 24; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 751 words

HEADLINE: Congress Returns

 BODY:
Though the deadline can be extended, Congress is supposed to complete a budget this month by passing 13 spending bills for discretionary programs and a bill to change tax rates and entitlement programs. The Republicans have set out to use budget cuts to radically shrink Federal programs. How well they succeed will be determined by scores of votes that will take place over the next several weeks. Five of these votes stand out as vital in their own right and for what they signify about the Republican onslaught.
Welfare. Everyone wants to put able-bodied recipients to work. But no one knows how to institute that pleasant-sounding reform and still protect innocent children. The best course is to go slow with welfare-to-work requirements. Instead the Republicans want to end the 60-year-old entitlement program and provide block grants to the states. Some elements of the party, led by Senator Phil Gramm, want to go further, forbidding states to provide cash to teen-age mothers or others the G.O.P. deems unworthy. 
 Turning welfare over to the states is an unprincipled policy because fiscally strapped states will not, and probably could not, protect the poor in bad economic times. Congress could compromise on requirements to put able-bodied recipients to work. The danger is that the G.O.P. will overreach as an election-year ploy and a weak President will be too scared to wield a veto.
Medicare and Medicaid. The Republicans started off in the right direction on Medicare by proposing to give the elderly the choice of preserving Government medical insurance or buying a private policy from a qualified insurer. The idea is to drive costs down and quality up through market competition. But the Republicans have tarnished this sound idea by cutting Medicare by about 25 percent, leaving too little money for insurers to provide high-quality care. The Republicans ought to bend -- by spending more on Medicare and less on, say, corporate subsidies, which they have barely nicked.
The Republicans plan to cut Medicaid, the health insurance for poor people, by about 30 percent. They also propose turning the program over to the states to run without Federal help if Medicaid rolls rise. Without Federal help in bad times, states will be forced to cut benefits or eligibility.
Science and technology. The party of that high-tech junkie Newt Gingrich might have been expected to protect Federal subsidies for scientific research. Not so. Private markets do not produce enough research since individual companies cannot always reap the profit from their discoveries. The Republicans insulate the National Institutes of Health, but otherwise make huge cuts, after accounting for inflation, to most other science programs. These cuts are short-run gain for the budget and a long-run threat to economic growth.
Taxes. Congress should postpone tax cuts until it proves it can balance the budget without victimizing the needy or eviscerating public investment. But Congress has already decided to hand out over $200 billion in tax cuts over the next seven years. The Republicans take this bad idea and make it worse by proposing to eliminate a tax credit for low-paid workers. The Republicans also propose to cut taxes on profit from the sale of investments even if those investments were made before the tax cut was passed. In other words, the G.O.P. wants to raise taxes on the poor at the same time it hands windfall profit to investors for past decisions.
Education and training. The White House estimates that the Republican budget would whack three times more out of education and training programs next year than other discretionary programs. That makes no sense in an economy that cries out for well-trained workers. Sadly, the Republicans also want to eliminate President Clinton's worthy trademark, national service, which offers modest compensation for individuals who do community service.
Beyond these specific votes, the Republicans and the President are headed for a collision. The Republicans intend to pass bills the President has vowed to veto. Unable to override such vetoes, the Republicans would then attach their spending proposals to a bill that is needed to raise Federal borrowing to keep the Government running. Each side ought to be calculating whether it can reach compromises that shrink government, protect the poor and preserve public investments. Instead the two seem to be calculating which side can win the most votes by bringing government to a halt.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial
