HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Don't Kick Sand at Taiwan

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

DATELINE: TAIPEI, Taiwan

 BODY:
During the 1950's Taiwan and China used to shell barren areas of each other's territory every day. It was a ritual that allowed both nations to demonstrate that they were carrying on the ideological struggle, but without any risks. In 1958 the two sides quietly reached a novel agreement to further routinize their conflict and save money: They would shell each other every other day. China would shell Taiwan Monday, Wednesday and Friday and Taiwan would shell China Tuesday, Thursday and Saturday. On Sunday they rested.
It is the proven ability of China and Taiwan to reach such quiet, under-the-table arrangements when it suits their interests that leaves me feeling a glimmer of optimism that Beijing and Taipei will step back from the brink of their current crisis. 
 Be clear about one thing: The breakdown in Taiwan-China relations, which was precipitated by President Lee Teng-hui's June lecture at Cornell University -- the first visit by a Taiwanese President to the U.S. since 1949 -- was inevitable. It was inevitable because Taiwan today is like a man who has been quietly lifting weights and body-building in his basement for 40 years. He's now rippling with muscles and it was only a matter of time before his family was going to insist that he enter the Mr. Universe contest and show off those triceps to the world.
Who could blame them? Taiwan today has the second-largest reserves of foreign currency in the world, $90 billion. It has a computer manufacturing industry that is now the third-largest in the world, it has a per capita income that ranks 25th in the world and a G.N.P. that ranks 19th. It is also the fourth-largest investor in mainland China today, with $20 billion and rising. With those kinds of measurements there was simply no way Taiwan was going to continue with the old status quo that allowed it to flourish economically as long as it pretended to be a diplomatic nonentity. Talking to college students here, I was struck by how all of them had a story about some indignity they had been put through by foreign passport authorities whenever they traveled, and they simply were not going to take it the way their parents did -- especially now that their country is a democracy. That's why Mr. Lee's visit to Cornell was so popular, and so inevitable.
But besides being inevitable this crisis could prove healthy. China's harsh reaction -- two missile tests just 100 miles north of Taipei -- was unnerving to people here. The stock market plummeted to a 20-month low. Land prices sagged. It has provoked some healthy rethinking in Taiwan about just how far and how fast to come out of the basement.
As for Beijing, it should have noticed that its threatening actions produced the following stories in the local press: Japan announced that it was sharply increasing its spending on ballistic missile research a few days after the Chinese missile tests, while many Taiwanese companies announced that they were freezing plans to open new factories on the mainland -- both reminders that Beijing would pay a huge price, at home and abroad, if it ever tried to resolve its Taiwan problem by force.
This would seem to be an ideal moment for some quiet U.S. diplomacy. To Beijing, the message has to be that the U.S. has no intention of recognizing Taiwan as a separate, independent state from China. But Beijing should learn to wink a little more at Taiwan's natural desire to raise its profile a bit. If Taiwan's President were being invited to speak at a joint session of Congress, Beijing would be entitled to go berserk. But it was Cornell University. Cornell is not Congress. It was worth a protest by Beijing, but not a war.
To Taiwan the message has to be: "Yes, your politics and economics have changed in remarkable ways. But one thing has not changed: your geography. You are still a nation of 21 million people living next to 1.2 billion people who claim your country as part of their own. Do the math. If you want to assume a higher profile on the world stage you must do a better job of paving the way first with Beijing. We are not going to clean up your messes."
In 1987, Taiwan and Beijing began a quiet cross-straits dialogue that promoted stability and burgeoning economic exchanges. They need to get back to that dialogue and work out some new rules for a new era. Any two nations that could agree to shell each other every other day for 20 years can find a way out of this crisis as well.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Arctic Refuge Drilling Won't Threaten Wildlife

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"In Alaska, Nature Under Siege" (editorial, Aug. 28), opposing oil exploration and development in Alaska's Arctic National Wildlife Refuge, distorts the effect of such activity on wildlife resources and gives short shrift to legitimate concerns about United States economic security. 
 You cite Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt's canard that tapping a small portion of the refuge's resources would be tantamount to "offering Yellowstone National Park for geothermal drilling."
The area in question -- the 1.5-million-acre coastal plain -- represents less than 8 percent of this vast refuge, and only a minute fraction of the coastal plain itself would be impacted by oil operations.
Moreover, contrary to your assertion that all manner of wildlife would be put "at risk" by oil development, the United States Fish and Wildlife Service has reported that "the evidence generated during years of exploration and development at Prudhoe Bay indicates minimal impact on wildlife resources."
In assessing potential oil development in the refuge, the agency also concluded that "most adverse effects would be minimized or eliminated through carefully applied mitigation using the lessons learned and technology acquired from development at nearby Prudhoe Bay."
The United States Geological Survey said in the late 1980's that the refuge could contain as much as 17 billion barrels of oil and 34 trillion cubic feet of natural gas. Although an oversupply of oil exists in world markets, increasing demand and declining United States production (or actions by foreign oil producers) could lead to tight supplies in a short time.
Without significant new discoveries and intensified development of existing reserves, our nation is likely to be dependent upon foreign sources for 60 percent of its demand by the year 2000.
The Arctic National Wildlife Refuge is not Yellowstone. Nor is it Central Park, Boston Common or the Washington Mall. Such comparisons do little to educate Americans about the public-policy options facing Congress as it considers opening the refuge to responsible resource development.
 
KENT L. BARRY
Naperville, Ill., Aug. 28, 1995

HEADLINE: India Project in the Balance

BYLINE: By JOHN F. BURNS 

DATELINE: NEW DELHI, Sept. 5

 BODY:
In the next month, Rebecca P. Mark will learn whether she is to be remembered as the executive whose perseverance pushed through the largest- ever foreign investment in India, or as the most visible symbol of a corporate vision gone horribly wrong.
Ms. Mark, a 41-year-old Missouri native, heads an Enron Corporation subsidiary -- the Enron Development Corporation -- that has spent three years planning, and starting to build, the largest power plant India has ever seen. As one of the first American companies to explore the opportunities opened up by India's decision to scrap its socialist economic system, Enron was widely hailed as a groundbreaker for the billions of dollars in American investments India has said it needs to help break out of poverty. 
 But after more than 30 trips to put the project together, Ms. Mark was back in India last week fighting a last-ditch battle in talks in Bombay to save the $2.8 billion plant from being scrapped -- and to spare Houston-based Enron from going ahead with what could be one of the costliest compensation suits ever filed by an American company against a foreign government.
In August, five months after Enron began construction on a rocky headland on the Arabian Sea, a new government in Maharashtra state, based in Bombay, "repudiated" the contracts Enron had negotiated with the previous government and with the national Government in New Delhi. The new state leaders vowed not to pay Enron and its partners -- General Electric's GE Capital Corporation and Bechtel Inc. -- so much as a penny in compensation.
Enron's lawyers have already filed papers before an arbitration tribunal in London on a claim against Maharashtra state that company officials said would amount to at least $300 million, and possibly as much as $2 billion, so the Bombay talks took place in a tense and volatile atmosphere.
At stake is far more than this plant. When the Maharashtra politicians made Enron the whipping boy of their election campaign earlier this year, they caught a new wave of nationalist antipathy toward foreign companies that has its roots in the 17th century, when Britain's East India Company began using military force and political guile to establish a vast commercial empire.
Ms. Mark left for Houston on Friday after talks with two of the most powerful figures in the Maharashtra government, including Manohar Joshi, the chief minister, who told reporters only days before that "the Enron chapter is closed."
Both Maharashtra officials and Enron executives say the next few days could show whether the wary exchanges that took place have opened the way for the Enron contracts to be rewritten in ways that take account of some of Maharashtra's objections, as Enron executives have hinted they could be, or if the climate of distrust and xenophobia have proved too strong.
With the costs of keeping the project in mothballs running at $250,000 a day, by Enron's reckoning, Ms. Mark has said the company will have to make a final decision by October on whether the project can be saved. For now, Enron is hoping Maharashtra will accept its offer to renegotiate parts of the contract that involve fuel costs, as well as to take an Indian partner.
"Indians believe in reincarnation, so this too can reincarnate," Ms. Mark said in an interview in New Delhi before meeting with the Maharashtra leaders. "Our attitude is, let's try and make a bad situation better, not worse."
As matters stand, the surprise is that last week's discussions in Bombay took place at all, after Maharashtra's leaders vowed to "throw Enron into the sea" for reportedly padding the plant's costs by more than $700 million and reportedly paying bribes to get the project approved. Enron has vigorously denied both charges, and Maharashtra has failed to come forward with evidence.
How strong the nationalist tide will be is disputed among Indians, many of whom are strong backers of the market-based reforms introduced in 1991 by the Government of Prime Minister P. V. Narasimha Rao. At the center of those reforms has been the effort to draw foreign investment to help India pull itself out of poverty.
Although Western executives have beaten a path to India, and inundated the Government's Foreign Investment Review Board with proposals, the flow of investments has been disappointingly slow -- totaling, according to Indian Government figures, about $1.6 billion between 1991 and the end of 1994.
But for those in India who see the reforms as the only way India can begin catching up with other Asian nations, Enron has served a beacon for the future. The power project was not only by far the largest single foreign investment ever made here. From the start, Enron's commitment was seen by the Rao Government as a pump-primer for other American investments. It sent an official delegation to Houston in 1992 to stir Enron's interest in building a power plant, and gave preliminary clearances for the project within weeks of Ms. Mark's first visit here.
By earlier this year, investment proposals put up for New Delhi's approval by American companies accounted, in value, for nearly three-quarters of all foreign projects. When a delegation of American executives led by the United States Commerce Secretary, Ronald H. Brown, visited New Delhi, Bangalore and Bombay in January, the mood was like that of a college team on a victory roll. As Mr. Brown's aides ticked off the contracts being signed -- at one point, they counted more than $7 billion in trade and investment deals, including the Enron project -- one senior American official told the executives: "India is ours to lose!"
But already, the mood was beginning to sour. Groups that have traditionally resisted foreign influences in India -- left-wingers and political parties that draw support by stirring nationalist passions among the Hindus -- drew huge crowds into the streets of New Delhi and other cities in 1994 in protest against the new world trade agreement. The Rao Government ratified the pact in the face of angry claims that it was a scheme by wealthy nations to lock developing nations into poverty.
In a February election, the most powerful of the Hindu nationalist groups, the Bharatiya Janata Party, or Indian People's Party, teamed with a Bombay-based splinter group, the Shiv Sena, to win power in Maharashtra, ousting a Congress Party government that had been an enthusiastic supporter of the reforms. In the campaign, the Enron project was a major target.
Since the announcement canceling the project, protests against American investments, mostly led by the B.J.P., have gained momentum across the country. Demonstrations have been held in several cities against Pepsico and Coca-Cola. After crowds demonstrated against the first of 30 restaurants that Kentucky Fried Chicken plans to build in India, in Bangalore, city officials raided the restaurant, seized chicken samples, and announced that the samples contained dangerously high levels of monosodium glutamate, said by the Bangalore officials to be cancer-inducing.
The United States Ambassador to India, Frank G. Wisner, who has played a big role in encouraging American investments, has advised American companies to stay cool. But with the Rao Government saying little to help Enron -- Indian newspapers reported that Mr. Rao admonished his power minister, N.K.P. Salve, after he threatened publicly to "blow the B.J.P.-Shiv Sena combine to smithereens" over the Enron cancellation -- Mr. Wisner made a pointed appeal last week for support. "The invitation to invest needs Indian backers," he said in a speech in the central Indian city of Bhopal. "India's partners, past and present, need a strong signal that this is where they should be."
Among American executives in India, the hope is that the Enron flap will blow over. They point to statements by leaders of almost all the groups that have attacked Enron, including the B.J.P., saying they are not hostile to investments they judge to be in India's interests. All the same, these American executives say, there is a risk that attacks on Enron and other high-profile investments like Coca-Cola could carry over into the Indian general election next year, creating a momentum that parties like the B.J.P., which is expected to mount a strong challenge to Mr. Rao's Congress party, may find hard to reverse.
"The message from India now is not what it was a few months ago -- 'This is a country of 900 million people, with a middle class of 200 million people, so come and get it,' " an executive of a large American company that has invested heavily here said. "But the opposite isn't true either, because India won't simply disappear from the radar screen just because Enron went sour. But it's going to be a harder sell."
Meanwhile, Enron has become a symbol of broken hopes. At the project site at Dhabol, known to Indians mostly as a favorite spot for smugglers, the company has deflated a large plastic bubble, the first ever erected in India, that was to have been used to allow construction during summer monsoons. Most of the 2,000 Indians employed on the site have been laid off, leaving a skeleton crew headed by a handful of American engineers.
Among Enron's supporters in India, photographs of the deflated bubble have served as a powerful image of the damage India will have done to itself if the project is not revived. When the Rao Government invited Enron to build the plant, it did so against a background of crippling power shortages across the country. In Maharashtra, many plants have been forced to generate their own power, to work reduced hours, or to operate only at night.
Now, the Enron controversy has already stalled seven other fast-track power projects that were to have kick-started $100 billion in foreign investments.
One reason the Rao Government may have been reluctant to challenge Maharashtra directly over the Enron cancellation, diplomats say, is because another newly elected government, in the eastern state of Orissa, has demanded a full renegotiation of a contract for a plant that was to have been built by another American power company, AES Transpower of Arlington, Va.
In the only move it has made so far to help Enron, the Rao Government circulated a briefing paper among its members of Parliament in New Delhi last week rebutting Maharashtra's case against the project. Citing a battery of Power Ministry figures, the document said there was "basically nothing wrong" with the $2.8- billion cost of the plant, when compared with similar plants elsewhere.
The document noted that Maharashtra had produced no evidence to substantiate its charges of corruption by Enron, and even Mr. Joshi, the Maharashtra chief minister, has backed away from the allegations. Although kickbacks have been a pervasive feature of Indian business life for decades, Enron has said that the former Maharashtra government under Sharad Pawar, a Congress Party rival of Mr. Rao's, never asked for any illegal payments.
"We understand the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act, and we will never expose our officers just to get a contract," said Kenneth L. Lay, chairman of Enron, who was reached by telephone during a vacation in Aspen, Colo. Enron's Indian critics, Mr. Lay said, "were all so convinced that a big project like this couldn't be put together without corruption, they just assumed there had been."
The denials have cut little ice with L. K. Advani, the national president of the B.J.P., the Hindu nationalist party that has sought to make political gains out of the controversy. Mr. Advani, expected to be the B.J.P.'s candidate for prime minister in the 1996 election, acknowledged during an interview a the party's New Delhi headquarters that he had no evidence that Enron had paid bribes. But he added, "The absence of evidence doesn't in any way prevent a political party from taking cognizance of what has become a widespread belief."

SECTION: Section C; Page 11; Column 5; Cultural Desk 

LENGTH: 1146 words

HEADLINE: Some Law Firms Practice Art for Art's Sake

BYLINE: By LISA ANDERSON 

 BODY:
During the 1980's, an art collection became the symbol that separated the in-vogue law firms from the unhip ones. Recession-provoked budget trimmings soon replaced the desire for cachet, and collecting dropped off. But it didn't go away.
Currently, more than 70 American law firms with collections ranging from 50 to 1,400 artworks have listed themselves in the International Directory of Corporate Art Collectors. 
 In some firms the offices have practically been turned into galleries. Most of the collections focus on contemporary artists, some of significance. The collection of Fried, Frank, Harris, Shriver & Jacobson in Manhattan, for example, includes works by Ad Reinhardt, Frank Stella, Roy Lichtenstein, Jim Dine, Berenice Abbott, Jasper Johns, Andy Warhol, Julian Schnabel, David Hockney and Robert Mapplethorpe. Weil, Gotshal & Manges, also in Manhattan, owns work by Claes Oldenburg, Jennifer Bartlett, William Wegman and Cindy Sherman.
Some of the lawyers involved have re-created themselves as curators who provide tours, lend artworks to museums and occasionally accept work from artists in lieu of legal fees.
"It is my passion," said Ed Abramson of Herrick, Feinstein, a firm that collects architectural artifacts from New York City, like the original 1913 copper finial from the Woolworth building, a 1924 brass elevator dial from the Roosevelt Hotel and one of the early ticket booths from the subway. "I take tender loving care of it."
Of course, many of these firms have seen their works increase substantially in value, though for the most part they were reluctant to divulge figures or discuss in detail the financial arrangements for buying and insuring the works. But James A. Dobkin, a partner at Arnold & Porter in Washington, said his firm's 225 works, which were worth $250,000 in 1978, are now valued at more than $1.5 million. And Gregg Thomas, a lawyer who heads the art committee at the Tampa, Fla., office of Holland & Knight, said his firm had allocated "a six-figure sum" to begin its collection in 1989.
Barry Sanders, a lawyer with Latham & Watkins in Los Angeles, said the firm's decision to buy 400 photographs, including works by Ansel Adams, Robert Doisneau, Elliott Erwitt and Henri Cartier-Bresson, was "price effective."
"We could get a lot of money for the prints," Mr. Sanders said, "because they're worth more than what we paid for them, but that's not why we went into collecting."
Indeed, most firms rejected any notion that the decision to buy was a business decision.
"It is really for the employees," said Mr. Dobkin, who oversees Arnold & Porter's collection, which includes works by Sam Gilliam and Gene Davis, and who has shown his own sculptures in 14 solo exhibitions. "We don't buy for investment."
Still, especially for firms that began collecting in the late 70's and early 80's, an art collection has become a valuable asset, particularly for a business that does not have many tangible assets.
Some firms say that collecting art is a way to support local artists or causes. When members of the art committee in the Tampa office of Holland & Knight found out that a local river was drying up and would soon disappear, they commissioned an artist to paint scenes along the river. The office has 91 contemporary paintings, photographs and sculptures by artists who live in Florida or whose works were inspired by the Florida landscape.
"People have forgotten how a lot of art was created," said Neale Albert, a partner in the New York office of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison. "Just going out and buying pieces isn't fun. I find it much more rewarding to get to know an artist and commission something, and when it is done, I feel I am a part of a process."
Mr. Neale commissioned the artist George Deem to paint "The Triumph of Art," based on Mantegna's masterpiece. Mr. Deem's work now hangs in a hallway. But buying art for the workplace often raises questions of taste.
"In some ways, it is like polite society," said Arthur Fleischer of the New York office of Fried, Frank, Harris, Shriver & Jacobson. "You don't discuss sex, religion or politics. You don't want to offend anyone."
A series of 12 prints in which the artist Martha Rofler placed images of Vietnam in the White House caused such a stir at the New York office of Weil, Gotshal & Manges that they were put in storage.
But firms have found that lawyers may become fond of works that at first offend them.
"You have to have a rule," said Carolyn Alexander, a consultant with Cooper Alexander, art dealers who helped partners at Weil, Gotshal & Manges assemble their collection of more than 400 paintings, drawings and photographs. "No one's complaints are answered for at least six months because by and large they do become attached to them."
Ms. Alexander recalled the complaints she received from a lawyer who did not like Richard Bosman's "High Tide, Low Tide," a colored woodcut print of what appear to be two rocks sitting on a beach. Some months after the piece had been moved, Ms. Alexander said, the lawyer came begging to get it back, asking, "Where are my rocks?"
To make their art more accessible, many firms have mounted museum-type placards identifying objects by artist, title and year of creation, in addition to providing catalogues that range from fancy productions to rudimentary photocopies.
Most firms with collections have consultants or art committees that often include members of the legal support staff as well as lawyers, to make selection more democratic. But some lawyers -- those who sit on museum boards, frequent galleries and auctions, and roam through artists' studios in their spare time -- prefer to work alone.
"Committees can't choose art," said Jack Combs of Warner, Norcross in Grand Rapids, Mich. "There are too many tastes. It really has to reside under one person."
In many instances, one lawyer is the impetus for beginning a firm's collection.
"What happens usually in these cases is that a partner takes a particular interest," said Barbara Toll, a consultant who helped lawyers start a collection at Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz in Manhattan.
Even firms that have seen their collections increase in value find that the lawyers with great interest in the art are unwilling to part with it. And though there are Jasper Johnses and Schnabels hanging at many of these firms, financial reality has also driven lawyers to support a host of unknown, "emerging" artists.
"We don't have famous artists," Mr. Combs said. "These paintings are not particularly expensive. "We buy pieces for the enjoyment they bring to our lives."
It is this enjoyment that may be the most compelling reason to support a collection, said Mr. Sanders of Latham & Watkins.
"You live here," Mr. Sanders said. "You work a lot of hours in this business. It should be a place of beauty."

CORRECTION-DATE: September 15, 1995, Friday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Sept. 6 about law firms that collect art misstated the name of the organization that provides information on such collections. It is the Artnews International Directory of Corporate Art Collections.

HEADLINE: Cuba Passes Law to Attract Greater Foreign Investment

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO

DATELINE: HAVANA, Cuba, Sept. 6

 BODY:
Government officials said today that they expected a significant infusion of capital after passing a new foreign-investment law this week, but few observers, including the Cubans, are predicting a huge rush to invest in Cuba yet.
The law, approved by the National Assembly on Tuesday after more than a year of debate, allows foreign investors access to all economic sectors except defense, health care and education and to fully own their businesses in Cuba, either privately or in the form of public stock companies. Currently, most foreign ventures exist through associations with the Government and foreign companies are allowed less than 50 percent ownership. 
 The law also offers guarantees similar to those in other countries for transfer of capital and compensation for expropriations, and allows investors to own housing, offices and other buildings, although it does not address the question of land ownership. It also allows free trade zones and opens the door for Cuban exiles to invest.
The law still leaves the Cuban economy firmly in the hands of a Government that decries capitalism, but it formalizes an ideological shift forced by the dire need for capital after the collapse of the Soviet bloc.
Companies doing business in Cuba say the law legalizes changes already under way. The Cuban Government says 212 foreign-Cuban associations have already invested more than $2 billion in tourism, mining, transportation and other economic sectors, some under majority ownership. Some analysts noted that putting such a law on paper provides reassurance to investors that socialist Cuba is headed toward a more open economy.
"Cuba is changing, and the change is irreversible," said Jaime Pena Vera, director of international affairs for the Domos Group, the Mexican company invested in the Cuban telephone system and plans to build an industrial park near Havana's airport.
The law's broad terms, however, make it unclear how exactly it would be implemented. On Monday, President Fidel Castro told the National Assembly that he envisioned state majority ownership as the rule and 100 percent foreign ownership only in "exceptional cases."
At a news conference today, Ernesto Melendez, Cuba's Foreign Investment Minister, called the law an "instrument" to be used only for the economic and social development of the country and "anything that doesn't benefit that development will be excluded."
He said it was difficult to predict how much investment will now come in, but he expected a "significant" rise this year compared to the total so far, which he called modest.
Some experts noted that the law could have gone much further, saying that early discussions had included more free-market enticements. One debate focused on whether to allow foreign employers to hire their workers directly rather than through Government agencies, which was ultimately rejected. The new law also requires the Government to give case-by-case approval of each project.
Antonio Jorge, professor of economics and international relations at Florida International University in Miami, said the standard formula to attract foreign money calls for rapid privatization and a free-labor market, among other measures. He said the law in the end may be more political than economic.
"I think this is related to Castro's intention to obtain credit from international institutions and restructure his outstanding debt with Western countries," he said.
But John S. Kavulich, president of the U.S.-Cuba Trade and Economic Council, which disseminates information about the island to American businesses, said that the law goes further than many thought possible for Cuba and added that he saw it as a transitional tool for the gradual expansion of commercial opportunities. He said some American businessmen consider it a positive change that merits a review of the United States' trade ban against Cuba -- which many say excludes them from an attractive emerging market. At the same time, Senator Jesse Helms, the North Carolina Republican and Representative Dan Burton, an Indiana Republican, have introduced legislation that would impose sanctions on foreign countries that trade with Cuba.
Among Cuba's leading investors are Mexico, in telecommunications, Spain, in tourism, and Canada, in the nickel industry. These and some 50 other countries with a commercial presence here see in Cuba a virgin market free of American competition as the country undertakes reforms that in recent years have included legalizing possession of dollars and authorizing some forms of self-employment and agricultural free markets.
There was unusually heated debate within the ruling Communist Party over some aspects of the legislation. One of the most controversial issues was the question of whether to prohibit investments by Cubans who left the island. Some Assembly deputies voiced opposition to accommodating exiles but most agreed that the Government still held a prerogative to deny entry to "enemies of the revolution" and that there was no need for wholesale discrimination against all Cubans who left.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Castro Government is to allow foreign ownership of Cuban enterprises, superseding a system restricting foreign concerns to a minority stake in Government-owned projects, like the Melia America, a hotel in Veradero, and the Melia Veradero Hotel in the background. (Angel Franco/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Bay Networks to Buy Xylogics for $330 Million
Bay Networks, a supplier of computer networking hardware and software, moved toward filling a significant hole in its product line by agreeing to acquire Xylogics for $330 million in stock, the latest consolidation in networking. 
 Xylogics produces hardware and software that allow users of laptop computers to dial into corporate networks from hotel rooms, airports or homes. Xylogics stock jumped 32 percent, to $48.875. [Page D3.]
 
U.S. to Monitor Auto Accord
The Clinton Administration will form a team to monitor Japan's compliance with an agreement to open its automotive market to American companies. [D4.]
 
Ford Sales Rose in August
Ford reported a 2.1 percent gain for August in light-vehicle sales, to 317,621, helping the industry post its best seasonally adjusted sales rate so far this year. [D4.]
 
Perot Systems in Partnership
Perot Systems and Swiss Bank announced a partnership that nearly doubles the annual revenue of Perot Systems and, executives say, values Perot Systems at about $1 billion. [D2.]
 
Turner Board Cancels Meeting
Turner Broadcasting was said to have canceled a board meeting scheduled for today to discuss the terms of a sale to Time Warner. People close to the talks said that did not mean the deal was dead, but rather that final terms had not yet been reached. [D6.]
 
PP&L Rejects Bid by Peco
The electric utility PP&L Resources turned down a hostile takeover bid from Peco Energy, a decision that illustrates the difficulties Peco and other high-cost metropolitan utilities face in trying to solve their problems through mergers. Market Place. [D8.]
 
Teradyne to Buy Megatest
Teradyne has agreed to buy Megatest , which makes semiconductor test systems, for about $245 million. [D3.]
 
Repeal Speeded for TV Rule
The F.C.C. accelerated its repeal of the regulations that had impeded television networks from directly entering the syndication market, moving the date to sometime next week from Nov. 10. [D6.]
 
Cuba Eases Investment Rules
Cuba has passed a law that allows foreign investors access to most areas of the country's economy and lets them fully own their businesses. [A12.]
 
MCI Group Wins Mexico Deal
A joint venture between MCI and Grupo Financiero Banamex-Accival has become the first company to win a license to compete in Mexico's long-distance phone market. [D5.]
 
Dyno Nobel Settles Charges
Dyno Nobel of Salt Lake City agreed to pay a $15 million fine, the largest ever assessed a single defendant in a criminal antitrust case, to settle Justice Department charges that it conspired to fix the prices of commercial explosives. [D5.]
 
U.S. Puts Union Under Supervision
The Justice Department has placed the Hotel Employees and Restaurant Employees International under Federal supervision. [B6.]
 
National Semiconductor Up
National Semiconductor stock jumped $2.25, to $32.125, after the company reported that its earnings for the first fiscal quarter rose 25 percent to $73.5 million, or 56 cents a share. Analysts said the strong results indicated the success of the company's strategy to shift the core of its business to chips and circuit boards that can process voice, video and digital signals. [D15.]
 
3DO Looks for New Markets
3DO, the video game maker, said it would look for new markets for its technology, including specialized circuit boards and chips for personal computers. [D6.]

HEADLINE: As High Schools Open, Mayor and Cortines Bicker

BYLINE: By JACQUES STEINBERG 

 BODY:
As New York City's 300,000 high school students returned to their classrooms yesterday, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Schools Chancellor Ramon C. Cortines squared off yet again, blaming each other for the disarray marking the opening of the new school year.
The Chancellor, speaking at an impromptu news conference at Seward Park High School on the Lower East Side of Manhattan, pointed the finger squarely at City Hall, saying the Mayor's aides had delayed talking to the board about school staffing problems, which in turn has left school superintendents scrambling to get teachers in classrooms. More than 1,000 teachers were still without assignments yesterday. 
 "We would not have had the confusion if together we had sat down three months ago," Mr. Cortines told reporters this morning in the school cafeteria.
Asked a few hours later about the Chancellor's remarks, Mr. Giuliani said the responsibility for any opening-day disruptions rested with the board, which threatened mass layoffs of teachers all summer long.
"I generally think the Board of Education drops the ball whenever they get a chance to," Mr. Giuliani said at a City Hall news conference. "I don't think they know how to catch a ball."
In spite of the rhetoric, the city's more than 170 high schools had what the Chancellor described as a relatively smooth opening, with no reports of violent incidents like those that marred past openings, including a shooting at Sheepshead Bay High School in Brooklyn last year and a stabbing at Seward Park High the year before. The city's elementary and junior high schools open today.
Still, the usual opening-day tumult was heightened yesterday by the budgetary dispute that has lingered between the board and City Hall, as the board struggles to make the remaining $230 million in budget cuts ordered by the Giuliani administration.
An early retirement program -- the first in five years -- closed just last week, leaving high school principals throughout the system interviewing prospective replacement teachers yesterday, even after classes had begun. At William C. Bryant High School in Long Island City, Queens, the principal, Rose de Pinto, was still interviewing applicants at 3 P.M.
Teachers were grappling with class sizes that, in some cases, have ballooned to more than 35 pupils. And the students themselves were bemoaning the reduction in choices brought by the budget cuts, particularly in classes like physical education.
"In gym, they told us they weren't giving us bodybuilding, volleyball or basketball, just 'survey gym,' " said Ovel Ortiz, 16, a sophomore at Sheepshead Bay High School. "It's just everything combined together. It's boring."
The friction between the Mayor and the Chancellor, which has centered on the Mayor's bid for more control of the schools, started soon after Mr. Giuliani took office and culminated in Mr. Cortines's announcement in June that he would resign in October. Mr. Giuliani has since trained his sights on the board, arguing with it over the qualities of the next chancellor, the size of the school budget and whether the police should take over school security.
Mr. Cortines complained yesterday that the budget cuts absorbed by the schools had been inordinate, compared with other city departments.
"Yes, we do need safe streets," Mr. Cortines said. "Yes, we do need good hospitals. But unless you have a literate, educated society, there is not going to be the economic base."
Of the Mayor, the Chancellor said: "I think he has not looked at the good in this system."
Asked later if he would agree to cease his personal attacks on the Chancellor and the board president, Carol A. Gresser, Mr. Giuliani said, "I don't think we have to be precious about it." He added: "If youngsters are being victimized in schools, I'm going to get angry. And if the Board of Education is doing little or nothing about the fact that children are being beaten up in schools and being knifed in schools, and wants to continue with the incompetent way in which they've handled it, I'm going to get real angry."
Rosy Rivera, a senior at Sheepshead Bay High, said she saw the impact of the political bickering as soon as she stepped into school yesterday morning. After-school programs, she learned, had been eliminated because of budget cuts, as had most clubs.
"They're thinking about taking out the school store," she said. "It's different. It's changed. It's worse."

HEADLINE: For Baltimore Mayor, A Shaky Incumbency

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: BALTIMORE, Sept. 3

 BODY:
When Kurt L. Schmoke became the first black to be elected Mayor of Baltimore, he seemed too good to be true for a once-vital smokestack city confronting the realities of a vanishing economic base. Educated at Yale, Harvard Law School and Oxford, with credentials as a local prosecutor and star high school quarterback, he was a local politician of instant national stature.
That was eight years ago. But when Mr. Schmoke stopped by the Southwest Senior Center in a struggling, racially mixed neighborhood here last week, few people greeted him with encouragement as he tries for a third term. Instead, they spoke up about filthy, crime-ravaged streets and abandoned buildings. 
 They were polite enough to Mr. Schmoke, who dutifully jotted their complaints in a notebook. But once the Mayor was out of earshot, some past supporters said they would not vote for him again -- and the primary is next week.
"All the money is leaving the city; what do we do?" asked Fannie Fitzgerald, 67, a retired nurse who said that as a black woman she was proud to support Mr. Schmoke four years ago but is too discouraged to vote at all this year. "There's an empty house next to mine. The bricks are falling down. It rains in there. And the drug dealers have taken over. This has been five years. What do we do?"
It is an all-too-familiar refrain for the 45-year-old Mr. Schmoke, who has lost the high hopes and good will that accompanied his arrival at City Hall. He is now in the toughest race of his career, facing a predicament that not even his detractors imagined in 1987: this predominately black city is threatening to throw out its black Mayor and elect a white one. An incumbent black mayor of a major black-majority American city has never been upset by a white opponent.
Voting patterns show that people tend to prefer candidates of their own religion or ethnic group. But the Baltimore contest may signal to politicians around the country that the more people feel dissatisfied with their own lives, the more likely they will be to disregard the background of the candidates and vote for whoever they think can do the most good.
"The era when it was a matter of racial pride to elect a black mayor is gone," said David A. Bositis, a senior researcher for the Joint Center for Political and Economic Studies, a group based in Washington that studies issues facing blacks.
In particular, Mr. Schmoke's difficulties might offer a taste of what awaits black mayors in increasingly hard-pressed cities like Cleveland and St. Louis.
Even if Mr. Schmoke manages to win the Democratic primary on Sept. 12 -- the latest polls show that he is in a virtual dead heat with the City Council president, Mary Pat Clarke -- his erosion of support demonstrates that with cities in such despair, it may not be enough for candidates to be black to draw black voters. The primary here is tantamount to a general election in November since 85 percent of Baltimore's registered voters are Democrats.
"The problem he has is it's not only whites that are fed up with what's happening in the city but blacks as well," said Frank A. DeFelippo, a political commentator here. "What's driving this campaign is the quality of life in Baltimore and whether it has deteriorated."
While prominent black politicians in Baltimore and in the state capital, Annapolis, are not deserting Mr. Schmoke entirely, many are no longer standing by him.
"There seems to be a lot more electricity associated with Clarke's campaign," said Parren J. Mitchell, a black politician and former member of the United States House who is staying neutral. "There's a perception that Schmoke is just not close to the people."
Former Mayor Edward I. Koch of New York said the situation here reminded him of how Jewish voters had resisted backing Jewish candidates just because they are Jewish. "When Hugh Carey and Howard Samuels were running against one another for governor," Mr. Koch said of a New York campaign, "Hugh Carey carried the Jewish vote overwhelmingly because a judgment was made by the Jewish community that it was better to have someone far better who wasn't Jewish."
Mr. Schmoke's troubles in the nation's 14th-largest city, with a population of 700,000, are shared by many other mayors: jobs are down, crime and school dropout rates are up, and the pool of money from Washington is all but depleted. But some of Mr. Schmoke's difficulties reflect his approach. He is cerebral and often aloof in a city that grew accustomed to the 15-year reign of Mayor William Donald Schaefer, an eccentric but indefatigable cheerleader for the city who went on to serve two terms as Governor. Mr. Schaefer transformed Baltimore into a tourist destination with projects like Harborplace, his signature shopping complex at the once-dilapidated waterfront.
Mr. Schmoke, whose advisers say they have set out to shatter "the Schaefer myth," has little patience for the comparisons.
"I dramatically decreased the size of government, and part of that was reducing the P.R. apparatus in City Hall," the Mayor said in an interview. "It was a good government move, but it reduced the ability to portray an image week to week of the Mayor in action. And I paid a price for that."
The Mayor emphasizes his close relationships with Gov. Parris N. Glendening, a fellow Democrat, and with President Clinton, which helped the city win a $100 million grant to combat the urban decay. But those contacts do not impress The Baltimore Sun, which has backed Mr. Schmoke in the past but last week endorsed Mrs. Clarke and described the Mayor as "a sad disappointment even to many of the Mayor's most persistent admirers."
Mr. Schaefer, who was never an ally of either Mr. Schmoke or Mrs. Clarke, is also backing Mrs. Clarke. The persnickety former Mayor, who was known for prowling the streets hunting for potholes that needed attention, said he sometimes could not bear walking through his beloved Harborplace. "It's just sad," he said in an interview. "The Inner Harbor has been neglected. The neighborhoods have been neglected. The city's slipping."
Although Mr. Schmoke drew mostly negative national attention in 1988 for advocating the decriminalization of many drugs, his critics point more to local concerns. They say he has done little to address the loss of nearly 50,000 jobs from the city during his tenure. He has also been accused of surrounding himself with unimpressive appointees and of steering at least $2.4 million worth of the city's legal business to his two closest political advisers.
Most striking about Mr. Schmoke's campaign is that support from white voters is so thin that for the first time he has geared his campaign to blacks. His bumper stickers are red, black and green, the colors of the black liberation movement, and his slogan is "Makes Us Proud." The unmistakable appeal to blacks has infuriated some whites and even some blacks, who accuse Mr. Schmoke of stoking racial tensions.
"I'm not apologetic at all," Mr. Schmoke said. "For the majority population of this city, those colors have traditionally been symbols of pride and empowerment, not division."
But he went on to explain that he never relied on white voters, saying, "I've never gotten higher than 25 percent of the white vote."
Mr. Schmoke's appeal to blacks has put off some white voters and may make it difficult for him even to approach the 25 percent figure this time. After chatting with the Mayor at the Southwest Senior Center, Hazel Downey, a past supporter and a white, said she might go with Mrs. Clarke. "I hate to say it, but I think he is partial to the black areas," said Mrs. Downey, 76, a retired seamstress.
Mr. Bositis, the political researcher, compared Mr. Schmoke to Gen. Colin L. Powell, saying that if General Powell runs for President he may disappoint white voters who have projected their own views onto him.
While Mr. Schmoke is still counting on drawing the bulk of the black voters, who make up about 60 percent of the city's voting-age population, analysts say Mrs. Clarke could win if she picks off about 20 percent of that vote. "She's getting more blacks than he's getting whites, and I suspect that will hold," said J. Bradford Coker, whose company has conducted extensive polling on the campaign.
Mr. Coker said that more whites than blacks would probably defect from Mr. Schmoke but that if the Mayor lost 15 percent to 20 percent of the black vote he received four years ago, he could lose the election.
Mrs. Clarke's skills as an administrator have not been tested, and she is known for her impulsive streak. But the 54-year-old Mrs. Clarke, a former teacher, has been a popular and visible figure in white and black neighborhoods for years. She was a staunch opponent of Harborplace initially, but her frenetic, hands-on style is reminiscent of Mr. Schaefer. In addition, she seems more at ease in the black neighborhoods than the affable but reserved Mr. Schmoke, who with his preppy red suspenders looks as if he would fit in better in the ivy-covered buildings of Cambridge, Mass., than in gritty neighborhoods here with names like Pigtown.
During a walking tour of a mostly black community last week, Mrs. Clarke was greeted excitedly by dozens of residents as she bounded up and down the streets in white sneakers.
"You helped my brother get a job with the city -- he's been in it for nine years," said Carolyn Thomas, who is unemployed. "I remember when you came here and helped with the drug campaign."
Ms. Thomas, 40, said that she had voted for Mr. Schmoke four years ago but that "I feel we need a change." Pointing to boarded row houses, she added: "They've been that way for years. We need help."
Down the street, Robert Gant, 37, who is also unemployed, was even more derisive of Mr. Schmoke. "He hasn't done anything," he said. "Nothing's changed."
Mr. Schmoke dismisses his rival as shallow, a "feel-good, local version of Ronald Reagan" whose proposals would bankrupt the city.
But not breaking her stride as she was asked why she turned on Mr. Schmoke, whom she had supported when he first ran, Mrs. Clarke blurted: "Out of touch. Out of touch."

HEADLINE: Dow Rises 13.73 Points in Broad Advance Led by Airlines

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE 

 BODY:
Stock prices rose yesterday, following through on broad advances in the two previous trading sessions.
"The idea that the Federal Reserve will reduce short-term interest rates this month is being kept alive," said Hugh A. Johnson, senior vice president of the First Albany Corporation. "The economy still appears to be laboring through a soft landing and may need a helping hand from the Fed." 
 Yesterday's report from the Commerce Department that wholesale inventories increased sharply while wholesale sales slid was cited by analysts as indicative of sluggish economic growth. Further evidence of sluggishness that might call for a rate cut came from the Johnson Redbook report that retail sales in the first week of September, a key period for back-to-school selling, increased only two-tenths of 1 percent.
Part of the market rally, moreover, was attributed to overseas buying interest. Cyclical companies whose earnings move in line with economic cycles were among the day's standouts.
The Dow Jones industrial average closed up 13.73 points, at 4,683.81, marking its fourth consecutive gain. In the broader market, records were set by the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, which rose a point to close at 570.17, and the Nasdaq composite index, which closed at 1,044.28, up 4.98 points.
Advancing issues on the New York Stock Exchange topped decliners by 1,315 to 918. Big Board volume increased to 369.5 million shares from 337.1 million shares on Tuesday.
Airline stocks showed increases yesterday, apparently on expectations that fares would be firm and cost-cutting would continue. AMR, the holding company for American Airlines, rose 3/8, to 75 1/8; UAL, the holding company for United Airlines, 2 3/4, to 162; Delta Air Lines, 7/8, to 77 5/8, and USAir, 7/8, to 10 5/8.
Chemical companies also rose, with traders foreseeing higher profitability if the Federal Reserve lowers interest rates. Du Pont closed at 67 1/4, up 1; Monsanto closed at 99 1/2, up 2, and Union Carbide closed at 37, up 1/2.
Some technology stocks moved higher, as the market sorted out those issues likely to maintain their huge first-half earnings gains. Among them were Texas Instruments, up 1 7/8, to 78 5/8; Compaq, up 1 1/4, to 50 5/8; Cisco Systems, up 1 3/8, to 69 1/2; and Dell Computer, up 4 1/2, to 85 1/4. Micron Technology enjoyed a gain of 5 7/8, to 87 1/4 after the Soundview Financial Group raised its earnings estimates for fiscal years 1996 and 1997.
The bond market was mixed yesterday, with the bellwether 30-year Treasury bond down 2/32and its yield unchanged at 6.57 percent. As a result, many utility stocks, which often follow bond prices, fell. Unicom, the parent company of Commonwealth Edison, fell 1/4, to 28 1/8; Central Hudson Gas and Electric, 1/8, to 27 7/8, and Public Service Enterprise, 3/8, to 26 7/8.
Some of the bank issues turned lower after the recent surge in that sector stemming from a rash of mergers. J. P. Morgan closed at 73 5/8,, down 1 5/8, and Wells Fargo closed at 85 1/2, down 1 1/8.
Merger news did affect stocks in other groups. Xylogics, a network-equipment manufacturer that agreed to be acquired by Bay Networks, surged 11 7/8, to 48 7/8. And Megatest, a semiconductor test systems producer that agreed to be purchased by Teradyne, jumped 8, to 32 1/4.
On the down side, Bandag fell 1 3/8, to 58 1/8, after announcing expectations that third-quarter net income would be 5 percent to 10 percent lower than a year earlier.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Securities Are Mixed

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities turned mixed yesterday as investors consolidated recent gains, ending a four-day rally.
Trading was quiet as investors apparently waited for further evidence of slow economic growth and low inflation before commmitting more money. 
 The 30-year bond was down 2/32 , to a price of 10331/32 for a yield of 6.57 percent, unchanged from Tuesday's New York session.
The Treasury entered the market yesterday and saw good investor demand for its auction of $5 billion of 8-day cash management bills at an average rate of 5.65 percent, up from the 5.58 percent it got for a 20-day bill on Aug. 28. Cash-management bills are used to meet short-term borrowing needs beyond the money raised through the Government's regulary scheduled auctions.
Analysts say the outlook on new issue supply remains bright in the weeks ahead, meaning there is not likely to be an oversupply to weigh on prices.
In the futures market, which invariably influences the cash market, trading was choppy, bouncing higher after the Government reported a seven-tenths of 1 percent decline in July wholesale sales and a nine-tenths of 1 percent growth in inventories, suggesting struggling sales and slow growth. The drop in sales was the first decline since the 1 percent in March, and inventories saw their 13th straight monthly rise.
The December bond contract dropped to a session low of 11312/32 and was as high as 11328/32 , before ending at 11322/32 . Robin Mesch, chief fixed-income analyst for Thomson Research, Portland, Ore, said the market was beginning to find the shorter maturities a bit pricey and might back off as a result.
Trading started on an upbeat note as the market reacted to comments from a Fed governor, Janet Yellen. In an interview with the Market News wire service late Tuesday, she expressed her encouragment by the inflation outlook, and said easing could conceivably be justified on that ground alone if growth does not accelerate unexpectedly.
Charles Roden, managing director and head of fixed-income investing at Josephthal, Lyon & Ross, described the market as lethargic yesterday, with no real interest from small investors.
"The only place getting fair value and relative return on investment right now is the short end," Mr. Roden said. "Those who run balanced money portfolios, with cash in short maturities and cash in longer maturies are finding it tougher and tougher each day, he continued, and will soon have to decide how to deploy cash that is building up.
Yields of municipal securities were little changed yesterday, and the Bond Buyer's index of 40 various issues remained unchanged at 6.04 percent.
In the corporate debt market, the General Motors Corporation led three companies that raised $825 million.
The giant auto maker sold $500 million of 30-year bonds through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers. Traders said the 7.40 percent debt was priced at 99.194, to yield 7.468 percent, or about 81 basis points above the 7 5/8 percent Treasury bond due Feb. 15, 2025. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
The bonds, which are rated A-2 by Moody's Investors Service, A- by the Duff & Phelps Credit Rating Company, and BBB+ by the Standard & Poor's Corporation, are noncallable by the issuer through maturity.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
MCI Wins Mexican Long-Distance License

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Sept. 6

 BODY:
An aggressive joint venture between MCI Communications of the United States and Grupo Financiero Banamex-Accival, Mexico's largest financial group, today became the first company to win a Government license to compete in Mexico's long-distance telephone market when the current monopoly ends on Jan. 1, 1997.
The Government is expected to grant concessions to several other new companies over the coming weeks in what is seen as the completion of longstanding promises to encourage open competition in the $4 billion long-distance market and improve Mexico's notoriously poor telephone service. 
 Other big American companies that have filed applications to enter the Mexican market in joint ventures with local partners include GTE, which has teamed up with Grupo Financiero Bancomer, this country's second-largest financial group; Bell Atlantic, which has joined with Iusacell, a Mexican cellular-phone company, and AT&T, which has entered into what is expected to be the dominant long-distance venture with Grupo Alfa, a large corporation in the northern city of Monterrey with interests in steel, prepared food and chemicals.
All three groups are expected to obtain Government approval.
By becoming the first to win approval, the Banamex-MCI venture gained certain advantages, including the ability to begin direct negotiations with Telefonos de Mexico, the current telephone monopoly, and to start construction of a national network. The venture, called Avantel, plans to spend $600 million over three years.
Still, Avantel will have to wait until 1997 to begin offering long-distance service. By that time, other companies are sure to have received permission to also enter the Mexican telecommunications market. While the market could triple in value over the next five years, last year's disastrous devaluation of the peso and the current recession have taken some of the shine off its possibilities.
"It was very logical that Banamex-MCI should get the first concession because they were one of the first ventures that was put together and they've had the most time to prepare their documents," said Jorge Sanchez, a telecommunications analyst at the Vector brokerage firm here. "Being first to hit the ground certainly gives them some advantages, but I think the market has already discounted most of them, and there probably will be no great impulse for the company."
There had been concern that the announcement would damage Telmex, as the monopoly is known, which accounts for about a quarter of the Mexican stock market's value. But investors had apparently taken the announcement into account. Telmex's American depository receipts closed in New York at $33.125, down 37.5 cents, and MCI was 75 cents lower, at $24.125. Banamex-Accival L shares were the big winners, gaining 3 percent in trading here.
In recent weeks, the Mexican Government has accelerated the pace with which it is opening the long distance market. Last Friday, the Communications and Transportation Ministry released details of how the free long-distance licenses were to be awarded. Under the guidelines, each company that applies has to prepare a five-year plan that outlines its investment and marketing strategy as well as its financing.
The Government said in the regulations that it would make decisions within 120 days of receiving the completed documents.
The next application to be granted is expected to be for a company named MarcaTel, a joint venture between IXC Communications and Westel of the United States, Radio Beep S.A. of Mexico and Teleglobe of Canada.
The chairman of MCI, Bert C. Roberts Jr., said in an interview here this afternoon that he expected to see as many as 25 companies or groups competing in Mexico's long-distance market in spite of the country's economic problems. A recession forces companies and families to look for ways to cut costs, and MCI, he said, "generally capitalizes in a situation like this."
Manuel Medina Mora, deputy president of Banamex, said Mexico's economic troubles had not weakened its ability to enter an unfamiliar new field like telecommunications. "As a result of the crisis," he said, Banamex is in "a relatively stronger position in the financial sector in Mexico, given the consolidation and given some of the problems that other banks are facing."

HEADLINE: A Fed Governor Sees Danger in Shift to a National Sales Tax

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6

 BODY:
Switching from the income tax to a national sales or value-added tax would probably plunge the economy into a steep recession, a Federal Reserve Board member said today.
The prediction by one of the 12 Fed governors, Lawrence B. Lindsey, long an advocate of lower income tax rates, was a setback to the retail sales tax championed by Senator Richard G. Lugar of Indiana, an aspirant for the Republican Presidential nomination. 
 It served to bolster the prospects among Republicans of the competing flat-tax proposal advocated by the House majority leader, Representative Dick Armey of Texas, and endorsed in general terms by Senator Bob Dole, the leading Republican Presidential aspirant.
Mr. Lindsey was one of several prominent witnesses who testified today before a G.O.P.-sponsored commission headed by former Housing Secretary Jack Kemp.
Mr. Lindsey, who was a White House economics official under Presidents Ronald Reagan and George Bush, argued that all the major alternatives to the income tax now under consideration would stimulate long-run economic growth and would thus be preferable to the existing tax system. But he pointed to the potential for big problems in any transition from the income tax to a sales or similar value-added tax that would impose levies directly on consumption.
As the day for switching systems approached, Mr. Lindsey said, individuals and businesses would have a great incentive to go on buying sprees to avoid the higher prices that would follow. But once the tax went into effect, he said, consumers would probably reduce spending to rebuild their savings.
"There would likely be a boom," he said, followed by "a bust during which demand was insufficient" to maintain the economy at its level before the boom.
He predicted "a period of protracted instability" and 'significant disruption" of the economy. And he said that a switch to a sales tax or value-added tax -- a European system that taxes goods and services at each level of production and distribution -- would also require a law allowing renegotiation of every labor and commercial contract, which "would be a very messy business."
A flat tax, which would eliminate most, if not all deductions, would also be disruptive to the economy, Mr. Lindsey acknowledged, but could be more easily managed.
The leading proposals advocated by Republicans fall into three categories. One is a flat tax on wages and business earnings with no tax on interest, dividends and capital gains. Another is a graduated income tax with a deduction for all savings. The third is to switch to either a sales tax or a value-added tax.
Mr. Kemp, who favors low tax rates, repeatedly questioned witnesses about the potential impact of the various proposals on economic growth. In an interview, he said he was convinced that a tax system could be designed that would dramatically improve the capacity of the American economy to grow faster without higher inflation.
He suggested that an overhaul of the tax system would be so beneficial that the economy, now generally considered capable of normal real growth of less than 3 percent a year or so, could reach an annual growth rate of 5 percent or more.
Most of the witnesses who testified before the Republican panel, the privately financed National Commission on Economic Growth and Tax Reform, favored a replacement for the current graduated income tax, with its complex rules and its array of exemptions and deductions.
But some warned that the housing market would be heavily damaged if the deductions for interest on home mortgages and property taxes were eliminated.
To avoid unfair comparisons, the Social Security and Medicare taxes paid on wages must be taken into account, other witnesses noted. Wayne D. Angell, chief economist at Bear, Stearns and a former Fed governor, pointed out that the current 15 percent income tax rate on modest wage earners, when combined with Social Security taxes paid by those employees and their employers, meant that at least 30 cents on each dollar of extra earnings was paid by or on behalf of most workers.

HEADLINE: New York Banks' Retreat From Poor Neighborhoods Hurts All

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Bob Herbert's "Power to the Banks" (column, Sept. 1), depicting the lack of banking services in New York City's poorer areas, is fine as far as it goes, but fails to examine the social and economic consequences or pose any pragmatic solutions to this dismal situation. 
 The Lower East Side, South Bronx, Bushwick and Harlem -- once and still the poorest areas of our city -- are littered with abandoned hulks of banks in which the wage-earning poor saved their money, millions-fold. Beyond these institutions' benefits to people who used them, the accumulated capital launched small businesses and built middle-class houses in the city and suburbs.
More important, banks provided lessons to the newly arrived and poor about capitalism and saving for the future. The retreat of banks from these areas -- often prompted by mergers such as the recent Chemical-Chase transaction -- has not only deprived individual citizens of accumulating the sort of capital that once enabled them to move into the middle class, but has irreparably damaged the economy of our urban areas and the nation as a whole.
This situation could be bettered were the New York City government to leverage its business with New York's banks. Billions of dollars are deposited each year in local banks, against which payroll and purchasing checks are drawn. While banks often maintain that, transaction by transaction, they lose money on these functions, the money thus deposited contributes mightily to the "float" available to the banks for short-term loans.
In addition, millions of dollars each year remain on deposit for substantial periods of time because of suppliers' lags in cashing checks, or because checks remain uncashed while employees are on vacation, have been terminated or have even died.
Were the city to require all banks with which it does business toprovide services to now-neglected areas, more would be gained than the ability of an individual to save for a wedding: the city itself and all of its citizens would benefit.
 
STEPHEN E. PHILLIPS
Brooklyn, Sept. 1, 1995

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Hurdles are still high for women who want a career and a family.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
WITH Labor Day just passed and Hillary Rodham Clinton in China to discuss the status of women around the world, it seems a good time to ask how educated American women trying to reconcile careers with family life are faring. The answer, gleaned from long-term survey data by Claudia Goldin, an economist at Harvard University, is not well.
The formal limits that prevented women from combining financially rewarding work with child-rearing are fading. But the practical constraints are proving very durable. Ms. Goldin found that even by a modest definition, just one middle-aged college-educated woman in six with children can claim career success today. 
 While sobering, the conclusion should hardly be surprising. Equality of opportunity, Ms. Goldin argues, is not sufficient to generate equality of result. That goal will remain elusive, she predicts, until offices become more friendly to mothers. And most of the accommodation, she suggests, will have to be by men.
The history of career-oriented women in the workplace is illuminating. Educated women of the turn-of-the-century decade -- the first generation to attend colleges in substantial numbers -- faced a stark choice between family and career. While four out of five women in that period had children, fully half the college graduates remained childless.
No wonder. Ms. Goldin notes that for 60 percent of the female college graduates, a career meant teaching in an elementary or secondary school. And during the 1920's and 1930's, most schools refused to hire married women -- and fired those with the temerity to marry while on the payroll.
Such bald discrimination against career women disappeared during World War II. After the war, far larger numbers of women went to college and a higher proportion of those who graduated married and had children. Just 17 percent of the postwar graduates reached the age of 44 without giving birth. But Ms. Goldin sees a dark lining in this silver cloud.
The trend, she surmises, was largely driven by the changing economic function of college for women. She calculates that relatively few of the new millions of female graduates ended up with jobs that actually compensated for their investment in higher education. Instead, college paid off as a marriage market, a place to meet good providers. College-educated married women often worked -- but typically only before their children were born and after they were well established in school. They rarely held jobs with career ladders.
None of this is much of a surprise. What is shocking, however, is that the experience of women in the early baby-boom generation -- the first to go to professional schools in numbers approaching that of men or to have access to fast-track jobs -- is not as different as you might have thought. Ms. Goldin looked at the experience of women graduates born between 1946 and 1956, relying on data from the National Longitudinal Survey, which tracks tens of thousands of Americans over their entire lives.
Ms. Goldin defines a successful "career" very modestly. Her standard of success requires simply that a person achieved average earnings better than the lowest 25 percent of college-educated men for two of the sample years (1987 and 1988). By definition, 75 percent of male college graduates achieved that status. Among women, 33 percent made the grade. But many of those were childless. Just 17 percent managed both a career and children.
Other definitions of a successful career only marginally brighten the picture. If the standard is lowered to include all college-educated mothers who were employed full time at any wage during 1985, 1987 and 1988, just 22 percent make the hurdle. Nor, for that matter, does a career seem to mesh well with a definition of family life that requires only a man on the premises: In 1985, 53 percent of women with careers were married, compared with 79 percent of the noncareer group.
What is going on here? Women, Ms. Goldinsays, now have a reasonable crack at landing good jobs. Indeed, the pay rates of comparably educated men and women at the starting gate are almost identical. But to stay on the fast track, women must be willing to act just like men: working long hours year after year while carrying what she labels "all the economic baggage of our parents."
Ms. Goldin has little enthusiasm for the northern European approach to easing the burden on career woman -- namely, government-subsidized day care. "I'm not in favor of taxing everyone to cover the cost of raising the children of parents with high incomes," she explains.
But in the American workplace and home, the private alternatives -- changing the demands of fast-track jobs to accommodate mothers or changing the responsibilities of men in child care -- don't seem to be happening. Men and women may now be equal, but apparently one sex remains more equal than the other.
