HEADLINE: Lost Jobs, Found Directions

BYLINE: By TRIP GABRIEL 

 BODY:
WHEN John and Carol Brooks lost their jobs three years ago in a downsizing move at I.B.M., to cut costs they gave up their four-bedroom home in a San Francisco suburb and moved to a smaller house outside Fort Worth. A mechanic recently told them that if they hoped to squeeze more miles from their nine-year-old Lincoln, they had better baby it.
Once, Mr. Brooks, 53, and his wife, 51, earned more than $150,000 together at the International Business Machines Corporation, but now they make less than half that. Yet, they say they do not resent the dizzying drop, because as a result of being shunted off the fast track -- two among the hundreds of thousands of workers displaced by job cuts in recent years -- their values have changed. 
 "I don't think we care about keeping up with the Joneses anymore," said Mrs. Brooks, a former quality manager who runs a small business sprucing up houses for sale. "Going to T.G.I. Friday's is just as good as going to a French restaurant. We don't miss it. In fact, I'm probably more peaceful now than I've been in memory."
The couple cite other changes: there is time to volunteer for their church; get-togethers with friends are now a focus of each week, and sex roles have loosened, with Mrs. Brooks managing the family money and Mr. Brooks doing more cooking and housework.
"We talk more about cosmic realities, I guess," said Mr. Brooks, a former systems designer at I.B.M. and now a struggling consultant. "How are we all linked together? I never gave these questions much thought five years ago. I was too damn busy."
The Brookses are not alone in finding that getting laid off in middle age and mid-career can trigger a reappraisal of bedrock values. Employment experts and psychologists say that while most laid-off white-collar workers strive to regrasp the same rung on the ladder of success, many rethink the ladder itself.
Interviews with former management-level employees around the country revealed that a significant number have experienced life changes, with implications for family structure, communities and perhaps the economy itself. To be sure, losing a job is invariably traumatic, and no more so than when a worker is in mid-career with a mortgage and family to sustain. Psychologists say that laid-off workers commonly experience anger, loss of confidence and depression. Families can split asunder if a spouse fails to understand and support the worker.
Yet, most laid-off employees eventually work again, resolving the financial crisis. And out of the emotional upheaval, many forge a new outlook on life.
Dr. Sharon Coleman, a psychotherapist in Manhattan whose practice includes out-of-work managers, compares the psychic journey to the grief following a loved one's death.
"There's usually denial, then anger and then bargaining," Dr. Coleman said. "People go up and down until finally coming to acceptance, which is healthy. When you get to accepting that the game has changed in the career world, you're ready to move on."
The process usually takes six months to a year, she said.
"They ultimately get to rethinking their priorities," she said.
Like a scimitar, the downsizing trend has cut broadly through the economy in recent years, in bad times and in good. Last week's announced merger of Chemical and Chase Manhattan banks included the news that 12,000 jobs would be cut. In all, American companies cast off 516,000 jobs last year, and 97,000 in the first three months of this year, according to Challenger, Gray & Christmas, a Chicago consulting firm.
A decade ago, the layoffs were mostly on Rust Belt assembly lines, but in the 1990's, downsizing has spread to middle management. Economists say that many of the jobs, which were disproportionately held by men, have disappeared, never to return.
"All of a sudden, white middle-aged men have been falling out of corporations like there's no tomorrow," said Barbara Collins, a senior vice president of Drake Beam Morrin in New York, which advises laid-off workers how to find new jobs.
Experts say that men frequently have a tougher time handling a layoff because, unlike women, they do not have as much to fall back on. Women have frequently broadened their roles to include taking care of children or aging parents. But many men derive their identity and self-worth solely from work.
"When I had a job, it was everything to me, more important than my family," admitted Larry Shane, 41, a former vice president and portfolio manager at Prudential Securities in Rochester. "Everything was income, the country club and cars. Suddenly it's all yanked from under you, and you ask yourself, Where's the meaning now?"
Since losing his job last year, Mr. Shane has given up the country club, withdrawn his children from private school and lost a house in foreclosure. He and his wife struggle to get by on her part-time job at a Gap store and on disability checks from his old employer. The disability payment, he said, is the result of stress related to his job loss.
Yet, even if an offer to return to corporate life arose, he would not accept it, Mr. Shane said. He has concluded that the race for prestige and possessions is a sham. To help learn who he is, he has sought psychotherapy and in the meantime is a stay-at-home father of four.
"I think my values are moving much closer to my wife's," he said. "I was more in tune with the superficial. Whereas now, I say money is important because you have to eat, but what's the difference between making $50,000 or $100,000? I'm not a better person at $100,000. It hasn't been easy. It's been very painful. But I can tell you it was the best thing that ever happened to me."
Many laid-off corporate warriors have lowered their expectations of work itself. They no longer invest themselves emotionally in jobs, experts say, and they look elsewhere for satisfaction.
"At I.B.M., my attitude was 'Never say no,' " said Mr. Brooks, the former systems designer. "Everything was focused on the company. I've come to the conclusion that was not the proper approach. Now, all I think is: Do the best job you can and show up on time, and don't be personally involved in the outcome."
Many have tried to become consultants or entrepreneurs, usually trading off a lower standard of living to be their own captains.
Ken Brynildsen, another former I.B.M.-er, joined his wife in a home business making children's gifts. Unable to afford their old home in Rye, N.Y., they moved to Sandwich, Mass., on Cape Cod. Mr. Brynildsen, 51, a former corporate speech writer, never imagined he would end up selling at crafts fairs around New England. But he counts himself better off.
"To be honest, I did not think I could be this happy," he said. "The quality of time I spend with my 14-year-old son is better. In eight years at I.B.M., I never met an I.B.M. customer, but now I deal with customers all the time, and the pieces we make touch people's lives."
Others find satisfaction in volunteer work, shifting their focus away from careers to civic life. Dave Heitmiller, of Seattle, worked for U S West for 17 years, most recently as a product manager. Now, he is a Big Brother and hammers nails two days a week, unpaid, for Habitat for Humanity, the nonprofit group that builds homes for the working poor.
"To me, it's giving time back to the community," said Mr. Heitmiller, 49. "I believe the planet is in big trouble and there's certain things we can each do to help. When you're working full time, you're either too tired or too burned out to do a lot of those things."
Mr. Heitmiller and his wife, Jacqueline Blix, 46, a former marketing executive at Pacific Telephone, participate in a group that meets regularly to discuss low-stress, low-cost living. The group was inspired by the book "Voluntary Simplicity" by Duane Elgin (Morrow, 1993).
Encouraged by the group, Mr. Heitmiller and Ms. Blix sold their four-bedroom house in a posh Seattle area and moved into a rented apartment in a working-class neighborhood. Once owners of a Jeep Cherokee and an Audi 5000, they now drive a single economy car, a Nissan Sentra, and have pared other expenses to live on investment income of less than half of Mr. Heitmiller's old salary of about $60,000.
"This should never be considered deprivation and poverty," Mr. Heitmiller insisted. "We have most of the comforts we need. We adjusted to a smaller space rather readily. Last year, we traveled in Europe for two months."
Not everybody has the ability to live off savings, especially those with children at home. In many cases, the wives of laid-off men become their families' primary breadwinners, a role-reversal that can produce family stress.
Dominic Arbisi was laid off by the Xerox Corporation in 1978, during one of the earliest downsizing waves, and his wife, who had not worked since the birth of their three children, got a job as a teacher of learning-disabled children.
"There were periods I felt I was fading into the woodwork because I had no means of support, and in our society if you're male and you're not working, you have no value," said Mr. Arbisi, who lives in Minnetonka, Minn.
Now 70, Mr. Arbisi still works, as an inventor and struggling entrepreneur. A line of his salad dressings, Arbisi's, based on old family recipies, is sold regionally.
Mr. Arbisi and others like him, members of a generation whose values were fixed when there were few two-income couples, have had to expand their definition of sex roles, in some cases raising children while their wives work, in others, caring for aging parents.
"While some men appreciate being the stay-at-home partner, a lot don't," said Mitchell L. Marks, a psychologist and the author of "From Turmoil to Triumph" (Lexington Books, 1994), a book about the impact of downsizing on corporations. "It leads to depression for someone whose identity is wrapped around work. On the other hand, some men never knew they could get so much pleasure staying at home being a daddy. I've heard of daddies who don't want to go back to the workplace, or they take a less-demanding job."
In Texas, the Brookses, the couple who used to work at I.B.M., meet regularly with an alumni group of some 125 former I.B.M.-ers at a Lutheran church.
There are participants who remain demoralized about being laid off, Mrs. Brooks said, but a frequent topic of conversation among others is how personal philosophies have changed. Once, they were in thrall to the corporation. Now, many have rediscovered their own identities and a sense of self-reliance.
"I think we haven't begun to see the impact of this on society and business," Mrs. Brooks said. "The entrepreneurial spirit, the women-owned businesses, the people who now have time to volunteer. I think five years from now we're going to see it's changed us as a country an awful lot."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Rises as Japan Intervenes But Backs Off When Fed Doesn't

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar surged yesterday after the Bank of Japan took the currency market by surprise and bought dollars for yen.
The intervention came after Japan announced that its current accounts surplus in July fell 21 percent, to $9.22 billion, from a year earlier. 
 The currency market initially shrugged off the data, but it was brought to attention when the central bank entered the market intent on moving the dollar higher.
The bank's intervention propelled the dollar toward a six-month high against the yen, but after the dollar peaked at 99.20 yen, it backed off.
"It was just seen as an overall dollar-supportive measure," said Dennis Pettit, foreign exchange manager at the Long-Term Credit Bank of Japan.
He said the dollar moved up smartly against the yen and then against European currencies.
The dollar was further bolstered against the German mark after the Bundesbank cut a money market rate for the fourth time in five weeks. At its regular weekly money-market operations yesterday, the German central bank cut the 14-day securities repurchase rate, or repo rate, by one-tenth of a percentage point. In the last five weeks, the repo rate has fallen to 4.2 percent from 4.5 percent.
Still, economists said it was far too early for another cut in either the Lombard rate or the discount rate, both of which the Bundesbank lowered by a half a percentage point two weeks ago. Lower German interest rates would tend to make the mark-based investments relatively less attractive.
In late New York trading yesterday, the dollar rose to 98.88 yen from 97.68 yen on Tuesday. It rose to 1.4762 marks from 1.4621 marks. The British pound fell to $1.5520 from $1.5577.
For much of the day in New York, the market was unnerved by the prospect of the Federal Reserve following Japan and buying more dollars. But dealers gingerly took profits when the Fed did not emerge.
Despite the dollar's inability to burst through to fresh highs against the yen as it butted into significant technical resistance, some dealers saw fresh gains ahead.
"I think we're getting close to liquidating some of those export orders that still lurk up there," said Steve Jonathan, vice president for foreign exchange at Merrill Lynch, referring to Japanese export companies that frequently need to convert their dollar holdings to yen.

HEADLINE: U.S. Is Planning to Monitor Japan Compliance on Autos

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6

 BODY:
Sensitive to those who contend that its hard-won agreement to open the Japanese automotive market would have little tangible result, the Clinton Administration announced a plan today for monitoring Japan's compliance.
Central to the plan, which involves what the Administration called "unprecedented collaboration" with American producers, would be a team headed by the top United States trade official, Mickey Kantor, and the Department of Commerce. Their day-by-day scrutiny of progress in raising sales of American automobiles and parts in Japan would be documented in semiannual public reports, beginning next March. 
 At the same time, Mr. Kantor, the United States trade representative, told a White House conference room packed with industry representatives that "you're the most crucial aspect" of the process, both supplying information to monitors and taking full advantage of new opportunities in a Japanese market that has long resisted inroads by the United States and other foreign producers.
Laura D'Andrea Tyson, a long-time trade specialist who now heads the Administration's National Economic Council, said, "We need a tough, enforceable agreement, and we want to be able to judge that over time."
The automotive agreement was reached on June 28 in Geneva after turbulent, marathon negotiations that brought relations between Japan and the United States to the boiling point. It came just hours before $5.9 billion in United States tariffs against Japanese luxury cars were set to take effect.
In what seemed an early sign that the agreement could be fruitful, a unit of Tenneco Inc. announced today that the Toyota Motor Company would sell its replacement shock absorbers and struts through 5,000 Toyota dealerships in Japan.
Until now, Tenneco said, its Monroe and Rancho brand shocks have been restricted from use as replacements for Japanese-made original equipment because shocks were considered by Japan to be "critical parts."
The Toyota contract calls for an initial shipment of Rancho shock absorbers to be sold as replacement parts for sport utility vehicles.
"This contract provides the first concrete evidence that the Japanese auto market is opening up to U.S. replacement parts as a result of the U.S.-Japan trade agreement," Richard A. Snell, president of Tenneco Automotive, said in a statement.
The size of the deal, which comes more than 20 years after Tenneco began trying to penetrate the Japanese market, was not specified.
The shock absorbers for Toyota would be made in a Paragould, Ark., plant where Monroe employs 1,000 workers.
Alex Trotman, chairman of the Ford Motor Company, pledged strenuous efforts for the Big Three auto makers to reach a goal of 200 new outlets in Japan by next year and 1,000 dealerships by the year 2000, but said "serious constraints" still existed.
The high cost of establishing dealerships in Japan had deterred American auto makers in the past.
The Administration's enforcement team would consist of 10 members, including specialists from the Departments of State, Labor and Transportation; the Customs Service; the Commerce Department, and the trade representative's office.
In addition, the Auto Parts Advisory Committee, an industry group, announced a new mechanism today for data collection and reporting under which an independent firm is to collect, analyze and report company figures on parts, accessories and materials on an aggregate basis.
The Administration has estimated the agreement would generate about $9 billion in sales for the American automotive industry over the next three years, 75 percent of it going to Japanese plants in the United States.
Japan, however, has declined to provide estimates of the effect of the agreement. The agreement, however, has no numerical goals.
Critics like Bob Dole, the Senate majority leader, have called the agreement vague and unenforceable.
What the Administration's enforcement team would watch, according to today's announcement, is a list of 17 items, including changes in the number and value of new foreign vehicles sold in Japan, in the number of new franchise agreements between foreign producers and Japanese dealers, in the value and share of foreign parts bought by Japan for after-market use, Japan's responsiveness to complaints about deregulation of repair or car-modification inspections, and the trend in purchases of American auto parts.
"I am confident that the spotlights have been placed in the right places," said Andrew Card, head of the American Automobile Manufacturers Association.
But William A. Raftery, a North Carolina consultant, said the data to be collected on automotive parts would suffer from failing to adequately include second-tier suppliers.

HEADLINE: Liberals Duck Immigration Debate

BYLINE: By Michael Lind; Michael Lind, a senior editor of The New Republic, is the author of "The Next American Nation: The New Nationalism and the Fourth American Revolution."

 BODY:
New York Mayor Rudolph Giuliani has been praised by liberals for his courage in opposing measures to deter the use of public services by illegal immigrants. The truth is that ignoring the rising costs of mass immigration, legal as well as illegal, is anything but courageous -- or liberal.
While business-class and populist Republicans have engaged in serious debate about immigration, discussion of the subject by Democrats is still governed by taboos. The consensus liberal position rests on two articles of faith. 
 First, while illegal immigration may cost the jobs of low-skilled American workers, no legal immigrant has ever displaced an American worker. Second, any suggestion that the arrival of almost a million legal immigrants a year has any effect on job opportunities and wages in the United States is said to be sinister racist "scapegoating."
Though this viewpoint is appealing, the harmful effects of legal as well as illegal immigration on low-income American workers are real.The Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas has attributed "heavy immigration to border cities" as the reason for unusually high unemployment in cities like Laredo, El Paso and McAllen. The economist George Borjas has calculated that immigration accounted for a third of the decline in the wages of high school dropouts in the 1980's; a major cause is the willingness of foreign workers to accept lower wages.
While economists debate the magnitude of the displacement of native labor by immigrants, the white and black working poor have been fleeing the metropolitan areas of California, where the economic competition with Latin American and Asian newcomers is the most intense.
The downward drag on wages caused by immigration is likely to grow worse. The economy cannot expand rapidly enough to provide decent jobs for the bottom half of the native population, much less for hundreds of thousands of legal immigrants arriving each year. Figures from the Census Bureau and the Bureau of Labor Statistics show that the number of new entrants to the work force will outstrip the number of jobs created by more than a million and a half between 1995 and 2005.
From the point of view of business-class conservatives, the labor supply can never be too large and wages never too low. It is no coincidence that spokesmen for the plutocratic wing of conservatism, like Dick Armey, the House majority leader, and the editorialists of The Wall Street Journal, favor even higher levels of immigration and the abolition of the minimum wage.
Unable to win on the facts, all too many pro-immigration liberals resort to nostalgia. With misty eyes and trembling voice, they invoke the Statue of Liberty and accuse critics of treason not only to American ideals but to the memories of immigrant ancestors. This may be good politics for politicians like Mayor Giuliani, but it is bad history.
The movement to curtail immigration in the early 20th century was opposed by business leaders enjoying access to cheap labor, but was supported by many labor leaders. Samuel Gompers, the American Federation of Labor president, argued that the flood of European immigrants was depressing wages.
He was right. From 1890 to 1920, American wages rose from 1 to 4 percent less than they would have in the absence of immigration, according to the Harvard economist Claudia Goldin.
The many ethnic divisions among native and immigrant workers at the time explain the weakness of the American labor and social democratic movements, compared with those in Western Europe's low-immigration democracies. And cynical employers who pursued a divide-and-rule policy of "balancing the nationalities" exploited these divisions.
The restriction of immigration in the 1920's, by encouraging a tight labor market and a culturally unified work force, was a precondition for the successes of the labor movement and New Deal liberalism from the 1930's to the 1960's.
The liberal taboo against realistic discussion of immigration extends to a refusal to acknowledge its effects on poor blacks. In the 19th century, as Frederick Douglass and Booker T. Washington noted, European immigrants displaced black workers from jobs as longshoremen, artisans, barbers and caterers. Closing the borders in the 1920's opened up job opportunities for blacks in the North, laying the basis for economic gains and the civil rights movement.
Since 1965, however, the black working poor have suffered again from competition, this time with Latin Americans and Asians. There can be little doubt that many employers discriminate against African-American workers and in favor of immigrants, who are more likely to accept low wages and poor conditions without complaint.
Many immigrant groups, once they have moved into professions like taxi service or the grocery business, set up nepotistic networks in hiring and finance from which long-resident urban blacks are frozen out.
Why have liberals been silent about the economic effects of immigration on their natural constituency -- the working poor, and black workers in particular? One reason is the inability of liberals to say no to any apparently generous program, particularly if it aims to help those in poor countries. Another is the influence of Hispanic groups seeking to enlarge their constituencies. Many affluent opinion-makers in politics, the media and academia themselves benefit from a never-ending supply of low-wage immigrant maids, janitors, receptionists and other poorly paid, non-unionized employees.
A few courageous liberals like former Representative Barbara Jordan of Texas have dared to bring up the relationship between mass immigration and falling wages. Ms. Jordan, chairman of the bipartisan Federal Commission on Immigration Reform, called for limiting family-reunification immigration to nuclear families, eliminating the annual allotment of 10,000 visas to unskilled foreign workers, deterring illegal immigration by means of a national identity card, and capping legal immigration at 550,000 a year (down from almost 800,000 a year in 1994).
These sensible reforms do not go far enough. We should also follow most other democracies in making it difficult for employers to hire non-citizens if qualified citizens are available. When many college graduates cannot find good jobs, why are we issuing so many work permits for foreign workers (more than 600,000 last year)? Why should a company be allowed to replace American computer programmers with Indian guest workers in the United States?
The United States can no longer be the world's employment agency and welfare service of first resort. A genuine liberal policy toward immigration would reduce the supply of surplus labor by reducing the supply of immigrants. A tight labor market is the best program for restarting America's stalled engine of upward mobility.
The liberal case for reform is based on numbers -- on the quantity of immigrants, not their quality. Under a rational plan, most immigrants would still come from Latin America and Asia; they would simply arrive in smaller contingents. Unlike conservatives, liberals should insist that legal immigrants, while waiting to be naturalized, should have access to the basic civil rights and entitlements of American citizens.
For 30 years, we have had an immigration policy tailored to the convenience of the American overclass. Pro-labor liberals and non-racist populists on the right should unite to demand an immigration policy that puts the interests of American workers above the interests of the native rich.

HEADLINE: After China, Hillary Clinton Finds Mongolia a Gentler Place

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON 

DATELINE: ULAN BATOR, Mongolia, Sept. 7

 BODY:
Flying from China into this grassy, sparsely populated country, Hillary Rodham Clinton might be forgiven today for feeling as though she had passed through a looking glass.
In contrast with China, Mrs. Clinton found a functioning democracy here. The crowds that clog every Chinese city were nowhere to be found, and Mrs. Clinton's 10-car motorcade seemed to disrupt few Mongolians. In a big change, the security agents seemed friendly. 
 In Beijing for two days this week, Mrs. Clinton irritated her authoritarian hosts with a powerful speech on human rights. She also inadvertently created chaos at a nongovernmental forum, where thousands of women trying to hear her speak clashed with Chinese security forces.
But in Mongolia, when Mrs. Clinton gave another speech about the need for democracy and freedom, Mongolian officials responded with applause, not condemnation.
The visit was to "express support for Mongolian democracy and for Mongolian independence," said Assistant Secretary of State Winston Lord, who accompanied her.
But away from politics, Mrs. Clinton seemed most excited today by getting a taste of the nomadic life that still dominates Mongolia.
Wearing black suede cowboy boots and a maroon shawl she bought last year in India, Mrs. Clinton entered the musty-smelling yurt of a man named Zanabaatar and his wife, Haliun and their six children 20 miles into the grasslands. She stepped carefully past the pail of cow dung used as fuel and gamely tasted mare's milk and horse cheese.
Taken outside to watch one of the family's horses get milked, Mrs. Clinton spied some large animals ambling along the crest of a hill.
"What's that big...? It's a yak!" she exclaimed.
Mrs. Clinton sped off to spend lunch with Mongolia's ever-smiling President, Punsalmaagiyn Ochirbat, and his wife, Tsevelomaa.
"A visit like this can put a spotlight on a country like Mongolia, which Americans pay little attention to," said Mr. Lord. "It's quite a remarkable story."
Mrs. Clinton seemed eager to learn about Mongolia's moves away from one-party control in 1990 , its loss of aid from the Soviet Union, its runaway inflation and how the changes had affected the status of women, meeting with eight women in the residence of the American Ambassador, Donald Johnson.
But despite their new-found freedom to speak, the women -- a doctor, a women's federation leader, a young politician among them -- seemed to respond with rehearsed speeches. Mrs. Clinton's questions went largely unanswered.
At Mongolian National University, Mrs. Clinton emphasized the importance of working together by citing a lesson that Genghis Khan's mother tried to teach her children.
"To make her point, she showed them how easily one arrow could be broken, but how hard it is to break five arrows when they are held together," she said.

Restrained Rebuke From China
 BEIJING, Sept. 7 (By The New York Times) -- China issued a rebuke today directed at Hillary Rodham Clinton for her denunciation here of human rights violations.
A Foreign Ministry spokesman, Chen Jian, said officials had noted "that some people from some countries made some unwarranted remarks or criticism of other countries."
"We would like to caution these people to pay more attention to the problems in their own countries," he said, citing a Chinese proverb.

HEADLINE: THE PACKWOOD CASE: THE OVERVIEW;
PACKWOOD SAYS HE IS QUITTING AS ETHICS PANEL GIVES EVIDENCE

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7

 BODY:
As his colleagues watched grimly, Senator Bob Packwood announced his resignation today, hours after the Ethics Committee released a 10-volume indictment, much of it in his own hand, of his personal and official conduct.
But Senator Bob Dole raised the possibility tonight that Senator Packwood would not leave immediately. Mr. Packwood, an Oregon Republican, did not set an effective date for his resignation. 
 Mr. Dole, the majority leader, told the Senate that Mr. Packwood should be given "a reasonable time." Later, Mr. Dole proposed to the Democratic leadership that Mr. Packwood stay for 90 days, a period that would allow Mr. Packwood, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, to manage critical Republican legislation over the next several weeks.
On "Larry King Live" on CNN tonight, Mr. Dole noted that Mr. Packwood "can certainly vote" until he leaves. Defending a plan to keep Mr. Packwood in place as long as possible, Mr. Dole said it would take time for Mr. Packwood to "get his things in order."
It was not clear whether Democrats -- or indeed many Republicans -- would accept such an unusual arrangement.
In his resignation speech, Mr. Packwood said he was "aware of the dishonor that has befallen me in the last three years." The tearful Senator told the hushed chamber, "It is my duty to resign." Later, he added, "I leave this institution not with malice but with love."
Sinking back into his chair and clutching the hand of his longtime political aide, Elaine Franklin, Mr. Packwood ended his 27-year career as the junior Senator from Oregon. For the last three years, he had been fighting accusations that he had discredited himself and the institution he said he loved.
Until today, most of his colleagues knew only the sketchiest details of the sexual misconduct, obstruction of justice and ethics charges against him. But yesterday the Senate Select Committee on Ethics voted unanimously for his expulsion, and this morning it released 10 volumes of evidence it had collected. Consisting of 10,145 pages and weighing 40 pounds, it described in sometimes startling detail his activities of the last quarter-century as a senator.
"These were not merely stolen kisses, as Senator Packwood has claimed," Senator Mitch McConnell, chairman of the Ethics Committee, said in describing Mr. Packwood's "physical coercion" of toward women. "There was a habitual pattern of aggressive, blatantly sexual advances, mostly directed at members of his own staff or others whose livelihoods were connected in some way to his power and authority as a Senator."
Most disturbing to Senator McConnell, a Kentucky Republican whose committee had been investigating the case for 33 months, was what he called Mr. Packwood's "cover-up" of his criminal activities.
He said that Senator Packwood's "deliberately altering and destroying relevant portions of his diary" -- portions that Mr. Packwood described in the diary itself as "very incriminating information" -- would earn him 10 to 16 months in prison if he were tried in criminal court.
The Ethics Committee said today that it would refer the charges to the Justice Department, where they might prompt an inquiry. "This is a gravely serious offense," Mr. McConnell said.
The Senator whom Mr. McConnell described this morning as guilty of "gross and persistent misconduct" was markedly different from the Senator who was eulogized this afternoon on the floor as his colleagues endured the spectacle of one of their own cut down at the height of his power. Much of the Republican agenda and its promise to overhaul the way government works was riding on Mr. Packwood's shoulders in his position as as chairman of the Senate's pivotal Finance Committee..
His resignation changed the mood of the Senate chamber as his friends, starting with his fellow Oregonian, Mark O. Hatfield, extolled his virtues. Mr. Hatfield, a former professor of political science who once taught Mr. Packwood, hailed him as his "most brilliant student" and declared that the "political nightmare" that Mr. Packwood had suffered was over. Mr. Packwood rose and hugged him. Both were in tears.
Mr. Packwood, who had been telling his top staff as late as noon today that he would not resign, emerged onto the Senate floor about 4:30 P.M. Given his chance to write his own political obituary, he recapped the high points of his career, reminding his colleagues of his successes over the years, including his lonely fight for abortion rights, his championing of Israel and his overhaul of the tax system in 1986. Then he made his tearful farewell.
"The Bob Packwood we heard today is the Bob Packwood we've known over the years," said Mr. Dole, who looked as if a dark storm were playing out over his visage. Indeed, Mr. Dole, whose Presidential campaign has been losing some of its momentum lately, has been relying on Senator Packwood to steer the Republicans' sweeping economic program through the Finance Committee and shepherd it into law.
On the other hand, the prospect of Mr. Packwood's wrangling with his Senate accusers was an unpalatable alternative for Mr. Dole, who is basing his Presidential bid on his "leadership" of the Senate. He concluded his remarks by saying, without elaboration, that Senator Packwood "made the right decision."
The senators listened in silence to Mr. Packwood and to the handful of his colleagues who rose to speak about him.
Senator John McCain, an Arizona Republican, derided the Ethics Committee process, as did Senator Alan Simpson, Republican of Wyoming. The committee was created, Mr. Simpson said, "to avoid a public hanging, frontier justice and vigilante justice" but "something surely has gone awry." Tourists in the gallery applauded.
When Mr. Simpson lauded Mr. Packwood for championing women's rights, Senator Dianne Feinstein, the California Democrat, nodded in assent. By that time, Barbara Boxer, her California colleague, who had agitated for Mr. Packwood's resignation and had tried to force the Senate to hold public hearings in his case, had left the chamber.
Two Democrats joined the eulogizing. The first, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the New York Democrat who is Mr. Packwood's closest friend in the Senate, seemed truly distraught and, for once, at a loss for words. "I haven't prepared remarks because I'm not especially prepared," he said. He rambled briefly, concluded by saying "the greatest of these is love," and sat down.
The second Democrat was Mrs. Feinstein, who unexpectedly delivered a gracious tribute to Mr. Packwood, whom she said she hardly knew. She said her father always told her to remember a man by what he did best, not by what he did last.
"We do make mistakes," she said, "but it is a sign of a wise man and even a giant man who stands and does what needs to be done and goes on to fight another day."
Senator Packwood, apparently surprised and overwhelmed, crossed the floor, clutched her hand and cried.
When the speeches stopped, the few senators who remained in the chamber went up to Mr. Packwood, instead of avoiding him as they had in recent weeks. Senator Larry E. Craig, an Idaho Republican who is a member of the Ethics Committee, sobbed as he hugged Mr. Packwood. Senator Pete V. Domenici, Republican of New Mexico, was also in tears. Mr. Packwood gave a big bear hug to Senator Orrin G. Hatch, Republican of Utah.
In Oregon, both Republican and Democratic contenders began jockeying today to succeed Mr. Packwood in a special election, which Gov. John Kitzhaber, a Democrat, must call under state law. Unlike other states, the Governor is not empowered to name an interim Senator, but must set an election date, possibily before the end of the year.
Representative Peter A. DeFazio, 48, a Democrat from Springfield, Ore., has already declared himself a candidate, and Representative Ron Wyden, 46, a Democrat from Portland, is expected to announce soon.
On the Republican side, the early favorite is Gordon Smith, 43, the president of the Oregon Senate.
In the Senate there were no tears this morning, when senators on the Ethics Committee said that their review of the bales of evidence against Senator Packwood had independently led them to the inescapable conclusion that he should be expelled from the Senate.
Beyond that, the committee members said, Mr. Packwood's behavior toward the committee as his case unfolded over the last 33 months -- they characterized it as defiant, selfish and unrepentent -- contributed to their belief that he deserved the most severe punishment the Senate could exact.
Moreover, they said, as he took to the television talk shows last night and this morning to decry the process as unfair, Mr. Packwood continued to misrepresent his case. He claimed he had been denied the chance to confront his accusers and had not had the chance to give his version of events.
Senator McConnell branded this as patently false, noting that Mr. Packwood had fought against public hearings and had voted against them.
"The victimizer is now claiming the mantle of the victim," Senator McConnell said. "The one who deliberately abused the process now wants to manipulate it to his advantage. That won't wash.
"The committee has heard enough, the Senate has heard enough, the public has heard enough," Mr. McConnell concluded at a news conference extraordinary for its expressions of blanket disgust with a colleague.
With Mr. Packwood's resignation, he seems likely to keep his annual pension of $82,922. The only time a senator automatically loses his pension is if he is convicted of treason or of violations of national security. In this case, Republicans said they would not try to strip Mr. Packwood of his pension since he served for 25 years and is being punished enough.

HEADLINE: St. Maarten Is Left Smashed and Looted After Luis

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK 

DATELINE: SIMPSON BAY, St. Maarten, Sept. 7

 BODY:
Jose Perez strolled casually down the winding hillside road from Philipsburg to Simpson Bay today, pushing a grocery cart loaded with a Hitachi television, a Canon electric typewriter and a roll of Bounty paper towels. Like hundreds of other residents of this devastated island, Mr. Perez had helped himself to the goods after Hurricane Luis demolished dozens of stores.
"Yeah, I took it," he said matter of factly as he gestured at the television set. "And I don't know if it's going to work." 
 Widespread looting, which the police and military authorities have permitted with little resistance since the hurricane blew through on Tuesday night and Wednesday morning, seems to be the least of the problems in what was once a jewel of the Caribbean.
Almost directly in the path of Luis, this island, divided between the Dutch St. Maarten and the French St. Martin, suffered one of the strongest blows from a storm that left its physical, financial and emotional wreckage across a chain of islands that stretches hundreds of miles.
The breath-taking damage caused here by the force of nature stands in stunning contrast to the natural beauty that has long drawn thousands of tourists each year. From a helicopter, the inviting aquamarine of the sea now quickly gives way to brown mountainsides stripped of all vegetation by the wind.
The worst damage occurred on Antigua and its sister island, Barbuda, where the hurricane damaged some 75 percent of the buildings, and on this island, where nine deaths were reported. An American on the French side was washed overboard from his boat, Julie Reside, a State Department spokeswoman in Washington, said today, but she did not know his name or whether he was among the nine confirmed dead. A total of 15 deaths have been linked to the hurricane.
The Government of Antigua and Barbuda declared a national emergency and appealed to the United Nations for financial and technical help. Officials of the United Nations Development Program said the storm had set back development on Antigua by 10 years.
In St. Maarten, residents and the police said many of the dead were sailors who were trying to save their vessels. John Reeves, a Dutch police officer who arrived today from the island of Curacao, said dozens more were injured and about 100 were still missing.
"They haven't dug up the bodies in the lagoons," said Jane H. Alexander, marketing manager of one of the few grocery stores still functioning on the island. "People were trying to keep the boats up until the end, and they went down."
Mr. Reeves said the death count would certainly rise. "We haven't been up in the hills yet to the shacks or into the boats," he said. "There must be people in the shacks and in the boats."
In addition to the deaths here, one man died in Dominica, apparently drowned while trying to save a boat. In Guadeloupe, a French tourist was washed into the sea while photographing the heavy surf. In Puerto Rico, two people were killed, one in a fall from his roof while preparing for the storm and another who was electrocuted by a fallen power cable. Two were reported killed in Antigua.
Up and down the string of islands, from Barbuda to the United States Virgin Islands, some people emerged from homes and shelters today for the first time since Monday night. Electricity, food, fresh water and telephone service remained scarce, if not impossible, to find on most of the hardest-hit islands, residents and officials said.
On St. Maarten, the damage to housing was inestimable. Whole hillsides were transformed into junkyards of multicolored scrap metal as Luis's 130 mile-per-hour winds flattened the shanties of the poor. The villas of the wealthy, although better built, proved only slightly more durable. Many were stripped of their orange tile roofs and wooden siding, with the debris hurled hundreds of yards away. Swimming pools were dark with mud and trash.
Refrigerators and washing machines were tossed by the wind on top of houses. Cars were thrown on their sides. The hood of one was flung through its windshield.
Hundreds of boats, some worth millions of dollars, were tossed aground like so many toys thrown from a bathtub. Many lay on top of others, their hulls torn by jagged holes. In the lagoon here, two sailboat masts, one red and one white, emerged from the sea like lollipop sticks.
The airport on the Dutch side of this island was closed to commercial traffic and the one on the French side was demolished. Two planes were submerged in a pond next to the French airport near Grande Case. For the time being, there is no way out.
While some tourists took the storm in stride, lying in the brilliant sunshine on what was left of Orient Beach, others seemed simply dazed. A woman sitting on the side of the road by her grounded, shattered sailboat could not bring herself to talk to reporters, waving them on when asked for her account of the storm.
A group of American medical students summed up the frustration of many islanders and tourists. "I just want to get the hell off this island," said Michael J. Gagnon, of Oak Brook, Ill., a student at the American University of the Caribbean here.
Help was on the way to several islands. The Dutch have sent a ship here from Curacao to help on their side of the island, while 250 French soldiers arrived on the French side by transport plane from Guadeloupe.
Samantha A. McEvoy, 24, a sailor from Cape Town, South Africa, who has spent the last six months in St. Maarten, said the emotional toll had been extreme.
"My boat is on its side and another is smashed into it," she said. "People have lost their whole lives. The only things they had were their boats." Like many residents, Ms. McEvoy was almost as stunned by the looting as she was by the hurricane.
Much of the stealing was taking place at Rams Cash and Carry, a gigantic food and dry goods warehouse in Philipsburg that had lost its entire roof. From the air, hundreds of people could be seen wandering among the twisted metal framework, picking through boxes of goods like ants on a carcass. A line of cars waited for the thieves to emerge with black plastic garbage bags filled with loot.
"There's so much disaster and pain and suffering going on and those people are making it worse," Ms. McEvoy said.
Jose Lazaro Martinez, a 44-year-old mechanic, explained that the looting "was an opportunity that occurred."
"Everything is broken and people have turned out to grab whatever there is," he said.
The police and soldiers directed traffic on narrow roads, with at least one firing a rifle in the air to emphasize his instructions. But they seemed to have concluded that stores like Rams were a lost cause.
"The Dutch Army is out there, but they're just letting them loot," said Seth B. Parker, 24, a medical student from Fort Worth. "These people don't have any food or water."
Although the clanking of hammers could be heard all across this island of 60,000 today, there is little plywood available to repair the gaping holes in many roofs.
"Seventy percent of the island is homeless," said Ms. Alexander. "They don't have houses, they don't have food, they don't know where to sleep. It's pretty much desperation."

HEADLINE: As Santa Fe's Allure Slips, Boom Times Fade

BYLINE: By GEORGE JOHNSON 

DATELINE: SANTA FE, N.M., Sept. 7

 BODY:
On Friday night, as at this time every year, thousands will gather here to watch the burning of Zozobra, a 40-foot-high puppet popularly known as Old Man Gloom.
As the flames rise to engulf the monster, it will groan in agony, flailing its giant arms. And the audience will cheer as the year's accumulation of fears and anxieties is carried away, or so the legend goes, in a billowing plume of smoke. Fiesta, Santa Fe's weekend bacchanalia, will officially begin. 
 This year, the flames will have to burn especially bright to exorcize some of Santa Fe's demons. For many residents, 1995 has not been the best of years. After soaring throughout the decade with an influx of newcomers, the real estate market has taken a dive. On one stretch of Canyon Road, the most fashionable address in town, the half-dozen "For Sale" signs threaten to become as old and historic as the weathered adobe houses.
At the same time, tourism and housing construction -- the other economic mainstays here -- are showing signs of decline. One of the most arresting sights of the summer was the unusually large number of neon "Vacancy" signs lighting Cerrillos Road, where the city's motels and restaurants are concentrated.
Tensions between Santa Fe's rich and poor are flaring, as they do from time to time. Hardly a week passes without a report of a purse snatching or a mugging on or near the city's historic plaza. The stately stuccoed walls along Santa Fe's most beautiful streets -- Alameda, Acequia Madre, Old Santa Fe Trail, Camino del Monte Sol -- have been attacked again and again by vandals wielding spray cans, leaving garish graffiti like that found in New York or Los Angeles. The marks are quickly removed by the city's new anti-graffiti crew, but, like painting the Golden Gate Bridge, it is a job that never ends.
"Crime is a problem partly because the population is growing," Councilman Cris Moore said. "But there is also a growing sense of resentment. A lot of families are not able to make a living in this economy."
Mr. Moore said the decline in tourism might have as much to do with the national economy as with local problems, "and the fact that no place stays the hot place to visit forever."
"But we should take this as a wake-up call," he added. "The mistake we've made is building an economy that depends so much on the wealthy."
Any slowing of the flood of people coming to Santa Fe to visit or stay might be considered a blessing to those tired of fighting for a table in a restaurant or seeing their downtown turned into what locals derisively call Adobe Disneyland.
"Santa Fe was just becoming too expensive," said Councilman Steven Farber. He said a "welcome correction" was long overdue.
"Mass-production tourism" has dulled some of the city's luster, Mr. Farber said.
"This doesn't mean it is not still beautiful, magical; it's just lost some of the glow," he added. "One can pan Santa Fe because it's not as pristine as some would hope, but we don't have the kind of problems that a San Francisco or a Miami does. We ought to be grateful for that."
Besides tourism and the housing industry, the two other main sources of employment here have long been the state government and Los Alamos National Laboratories, half an hour's drive away. But Los Alamos recently announced that it would lay off 1,500 workers in the next year, and New Mexico's Governor, Gary E. Johnson, a Republican, is waging a campaign to trim the state work force.
Although a few financial service companies have been recently added to the economic mix, efforts to attract clean industry -- electronics, computers, biotechnology -- have not been very successful, partly because of high real estate prices. The main thing Santa Fe has to sell is its ambiance, but as the city grows, that is in shorter and shorter supply.
Through Aug. 31, 44 robberies had been reported in the area of the city that includes the plaza and the Guadalupe Street tourist district; if the pace continues, this year will see twice as many robberies as in 1991, when there were 32. But Capt. Ray Rael of the Santa Fe Police Department said the perception of crime was probably worse than the reality. Santa Fe is still a small-enough town that purse snatchings are written up in the crime column of the daily newspaper, The Santa Fe New Mexican.
More visible to tourists and residents is the graffiti on Santa Fe's subtly hued walls. The city has tried to lower the din of visual noise with a mural project for teen-agers, letting them decorate the traffic-control boxes that are a common target of vandals. The hope was that vandals would be less likely to deface decorated boxes. But graffiti continues to accumulate on traffic signs, mailboxes and utility company junction boxes.
The drop in popularity of Santa Fe as a tourist destination has come to a city that had been riding a crest of publicity of nearly absurd proportions. In a 1992 reader survey by Conde Nast Traveler, Santa Fe was named the No. 1 tourist destination in the world, surpassing San Francisco, Vienna, Florence and Rome. Last year, it was down to No. 9.
Well-heeled refugees have bid up housing prices to the point where a small two-bedroom adobe on a rutted dirt street could easily fetch a quarter of a million dollars. But this spring, the balloon began to leak.
After a record number of houses were sold in 1994, the number sold in the first quarter of 1995 dropped almost 30 percent, to 188 from 266. Bob Dunn, president of the Santa Fe Association of Realtors, said the decline had continued, although he could not give precise figures.
Apartment vacancy rates in the area that includes the plaza and the city's historic core have risen to 10.9 percent in the second quarter, compared with no vacancies two years ago, according to the Apartment Association of New Mexico. Apartment complexes are offering incentives for renters, and cardboard For Rent signs are starting to appear, even on Canyon Road.
Fred Lopez, the investment and cash manager for the city Finance Department, said gross receipts from construction were down 14.5 percent in July and 2.5 percent in August, compared with the same months in 1994.
Faced with these disturbing portents, businesses hoped that the summer would bring an injection of tourist money. But the latest figures from the New Mexico Hotel and Motel Association show Santa Fe's occupancy rates down to 82.1 percent in July, compared with 86.7 percent in the same month last year. Art Bouffard, director of the association, predicted that the August figures would be down from July's.
Some of the decline in tourism and real estate is probably cyclical. Tight occupancy levels and high rental and occupancy rates led to a wave of motel and apartment house construction. Continuing economic problems in California, the source of many of the visitors and newcomers, have rippled to New Mexico. High lumber prices could be depressing housing construction.
But the possibility remains that as Santa Fe grows from a town into a city, it is inevitably losing some of its only real commodity, its charm.
"We're starting to have all the negatives of a big city without the pluses," said Leo Romero, a poet and bookseller who grew up in northern New Mexico and has lived in Santa Fe since 1983. "There has been a big change just within the last year and a half. It's like night and day."
Fiesta will end on Sunday night, as it always does, with a Mass of Thanksgiving at the St. Francis Cathedral downtown and a candlelight procession to the top of a nearby hill where the Cross of the Martyrs commemorates the local Franciscan priests who died in the Pueblo Revolt of 1680. The red and yellow graffiti on the stuccoed base of the monument was painted over today, just in time for the celebration.

GRAPHIC: Photo: As fewer newcomers are drawn by the charm of Santa Fe, N.M., the real estate market is feeling the pinch. A sign outside an adobe wall and gate marks one of several homes for sale on the city's fashionable Canyon Road. (Eliza Wells Smith for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Gunfire and Siege on East Side Lead to an Arrest

BYLINE: By RONALD SULLIVAN 

 BODY:
An unemployed man who the police said threatened President Clinton early last month because he was angry at the Social Security Administration, shot at two Secret Service agents yesterday afternoon. The police said the suspect then barricaded himself in his basement studio apartment on the Upper East Side for more than three hours before surrendering.
No one was injured, though the heavy emergency response to the gunfire at 243 East 81st Street and the tense standoff closed off the block between Third and Second Avenues. While under siege, the suspect managed to get on the telephone with the White House and various radio and television stations, complaining that he was misunderstood and a victim of a cruel system that was denying him Social Security checks. 
 Assistant Chief John J. Hill, the commander of Manhattan detectives, identified the suspect as 48-year-old Paul Nagy, a slightly built, unemployed Romanian immigrant who came to New York City 14 years ago. He said that Mr. Nagy had a history of making threats against Government officials.
Chief Hill said that Mr. Nagy, who moved in the apartment building two months ago, called the White House on Aug. 2 to complain about the Social Security Administration and then "made a threat to a White House receptionist." The Secret Service agents went to Mr. Nagy's apartment yesterday to try to interview him, Chief Hill said.
Mr. Nagy was charged yesterday with harassment and felonious assault of a Federal agent.

HEADLINE: NATO Raids Against Serbs Are Increased

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7

 BODY:
On the eve of crucial American-led talks among the three warring parties in Bosnia, NATO expanded its air campaign against Serb-held positions in Bosnia today, bombing bridges, ammunition dumps, communications centers and air defense radars.
The bombings came as President Clinton met with his senior advisers to discuss how to convince the warring parties to accept the United Nations-brokered partition of the country and enforce an eventual settlement. But President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia warned that Moscow would have to rethink its partnership with NATO if the alliance continued its bombings. 
 NATO warplanes took advantage of a break in rain, fog and clouds before dawn to attack the Bosnian Serbs around Sarajevo, trying to force them to withdraw their heavy weapons from around the Bosnian capital. In one strike, a NATO plane bombed an ammunition dump near the Serbian headquarters in Pale, setting off the explosives with such force that they blackened the skies and damaged neighboring houses.
NATO has vowed to continue the strikes until the Serbs move their heavy weapons at least 12.5 miles from Sarajevo, but in Pale, the Bosnian Serb leader, Radovan Karadzic, insisted, "We have withdrawn as much as we could."
Secretary of State Warren Christopher said today that NATO would continue its air strikes against Bosnian Serb positions despite NATO's failure to force the Serbs to move their heavy weaponry.
 "This campaign can continue for some time," Mr. Christopher said in an interview on the "MacNeil/ Lehrer NewsHour." He also played down differences with Russia over the NATO campaign, saying that he was confident that "we'll be able to stay together with Russia."
The bombing resumed this week even as Assistant Secretary of State Richard C. Holbrooke was preparing for a meeting in Geneva on Friday that will bring together representatives of the three warring parties for their first face-to-face peace talks in more than two years.
Senior officials from France, Germany, Britain and Russia will be part of the Geneva session, which is expected to produce a vague statement of principles but avoid territorial issues that still divide the parties.
Mr. Clinton approved a recommendation from his top national security and economic advisers on the composition of a NATO peacekeeping force should the three sides make peace and agreed to present this idea to other NATO members in Brussels next week, senior Administration officials said.
The United States wants the non-American NATO troops now serving in Bosnia in a rapid-reaction force to be the core of the new peacekeeping force to be established as soon as a settlement is reached, the officials said. The United States will insist that this peacemaking force be well-armed and operating under a NATO command and control structure. Their duties will include enforcing a cease-fire and supervising and enforcing the withdrawal of the warring armies to separate areas.
But Mr. Clinton and his aides are eager to limit the number of American ground troops involved in enforcing a settlement in Bosnia. Without any agreement on how many American troops will be committed, Pentagon planners are assuming that 50,000 NATO troops, including 25,000 Americans, will be required for the plan.
Besides agreeing to the shape of such a NATO peacekeeping mission, Mr. Clinton agreed with his aides that a separate international force should train and equip the Bosnian Army to defend its territory.
On the military front, NATO warplanes from Aviano air base in Italy and the aircraft carrier Roosevelt hit ammunition dumps, communications centers, bridges, barracks and air defense radars in at least six waves of attacks today.
But the Serbs said civilian targets were also hit, and Bosnian Serb television ran a report, without pictures, claiming that 15 civilians including 4 children had been killed in Doboj in western Bosnia.
More than a total of 75 NATO F-18's, F-15's, F-16's and other warplanes attacked many targets in and around Pale that poor weather had prevented pilots from striking.
The NATO commander said warplanes hit new targets as well as old ones that NATO reconnaissance experts determined had not been destroyed and that about two-thirds of the targets had been destroyed or rendered ineffective.
The NATO commander said there was a brief pause tonight between the daytime bombings and later attacks against bridges that could be used to resupply ammo dumps.
"There is a very robust political dimension to this," the officer said. "It's kind of a yo-yo."

HEADLINE: Grim Forecast Is Offered On Rising Juvenile Crime

BYLINE: By FOX BUTTERFIELD 

 BODY:
If current trends continue, the number of arrests of juveniles for violent crimes will double by the year 2010, the Justice Department said today in the most comprehensive report ever assembled on crimes committed by young people.
The report based its projection on a finding that arrest rates among juveniles ages 10 to 17 for violent crimes jumped 100 percent between 1983 and 1992, and the number of teen-agers in the population was expected to increase 20 percent over the next decade. 
 The report also calls into question some of the most popular crime prevention programs adopted by cities, states and the Federal government in the past few years, including curfews and midnight basketball leagues. The report found, for example, that the peak time during which youths age 6 to 17 commit violent crimes was from 3 to 6 P.M., between the end of the school day and dinner.
James Alan Fox, dean of the college of criminal justice at Northeastern University, said the new figures on the time at which young people commit crimes showed that "we can't leave it to families" to solve the problem of juvenile violence. "The families aren't available, and it's often not out of choice," Professor Fox said. "They are off working out of economic necessity and it leaves kids idle, unsupervised with little to do except hang out with their friends."
Professor Fox said the report showed a clear need for more after-school activities at a time that the public and politicians have been cutting financing for athletics and after-school arts and music classes.
The report, "Juvenile Offenders and Victims: A National Report," was put together by the National Center for Juvenile Justice in Pittsburgh. It amounts to an encyclopedia of information on youth criminals, victims and how the juvenile justice system functions.
Among other findings in today's report were these:
*From 1980 to 1992, reports of children abused and neglected almost tripled, to 2.9 million from 1 million. The report cited several studies that showed a clear link between child abuse and neglect, and future juvenile delinquency and adult criminality. But Howard Snyder, one of the authors of the report and director of systems research for the National Center for Juvenile Justice, said it was unclear how much of the increase in cases might be attributed to better reporting of child abuse.
* Between 1984 and 1993, the number of homicides among juveniles involving handguns increased fivefold. Eighty percent of juvenile homicides now are committed with a gun. A spokesman for the White House, Rahm Emanuel, said that President Clinton found the projection of a doubling in arrests for juveniles by 2010 "very disturbing."
The spokesman said that it was because of concerns like this that President Clinton had pressed for money to put 100,000 additional police officers on the streets over the next few years. That program has come under attack by Republicans in Congress, who have pledged to convert the Federal money intended to hire the new officers into block grants for the states.
Attorney General Janet Reno said today that she was particularly dismayed by the finding that the homicide rate among 14- to 17-year-olds had increased 165 percent in the past 10 years.
"This report is a road map to the next generation of crime -- unless we do something now," Ms. Reno said. "This is not the time to let up and it is not the time to turn back."
The report, showing the huge increase in violent crimes by juveniles, comes as many cities, particularly New York and Houston, have reported a sharp drop in their homicide rates over the past three years. The reason that the national violent crime rate has recently declined overall while it is up among young people, Professor Fox said, is that there has been a sharp decrease in homicide by adults. From 1990 to 1993, the homicide rate among people age 25 years and older dropped 10 percent, he said.
Professor Fox has long been among those criminologists who have predicted that the national violent crime rate will go back up as the number of teen-agers begins to increase again after a dropoff in the 1980's. "This is the calm before the crime storm," he said. "Enjoy it while it lasts."
But he questioned whether the stark prediction in today's report of a doubling in arrests for violent crime among juveniles would really be that high. The reason it might not, Professor Fox said, is that after the juvenile arrest rate increased 100 percent from 1983 to 1992 "it would be hard to keep on going straight up."

HEADLINE: Mr. Dole's Bogus Welfare Safeguards

 BODY:
The Senate majority leader, Bob Dole, will bring to a vote, perhaps today, an amendment to his welfare bill that would supposedly soften the blow to the poor. The amendment is a sham. It purports to require states to maintain current spending on programs for low-income families. But the amendment is riddled with loopholes and will not, in fact, force any state to spend a dime.
Mr. Dole has not rounded up enough votes to pass his welfare bill. Conservatives like Senator Phil Gramm complain that the bill is too lenient, permitting states, for example, to put unwed mothers on the dole. Moderates fear that the bill will drive needy families off welfare and into the streets. Mr. Dole's amendment was proposed to sucker moderates into dropping their opposition. 
 Under the Dole bill, Washington would turn over a fixed amount of money, called a block grant, to states for them to spend on the poor. The House has already passed similar legislation. Mr. Dole's block grants would provide states about the same amount of Federal aid that they collected in 1994 for cash assistance, child care and job training programs. But Mr. Dole would eliminate a current requirement that states qualify for Federal aid only if they put up between 20 and 50 percent of the money themselves.
The Dole bill would also eliminate additional Federal aid now provided as welfare rolls rise during a recession, leaving states to meet the needs of burgeoning poverty all on their own. States will be tempted to drop benefits and raise eligibility, in part to avoid attracting an influx of the poor from neighboring states.
True, Mr. Dole's amendment purports to address this threat by requiring a certain level of expenditures on programs for low-income families. But the requirement would expire after two years. Also, states could satisfy the amendment merely by maintaining current spending on Medicaid -- health insurance for the poor -- and eliminating their contributions to cash assistance, child care, job training and other welfare programs.
Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York, one of the country's leading students of welfare, predicts that the Dole bill would create millions of homeless children. The sham amendment would do nothing to mitigate the carnage.

HEADLINE: Don't Blame Nafta for U.S. Job Losses

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Pat Buchanan (Op-Ed, Aug. 25) offers no new reasons to conclude that the North American Free Trade Agreement was a mistake. 
 During 1994 United States exports to Mexico surged, averaging $1 billion per week, up 21.7 percent over the previous year. This was true across every sector, leading to thousands of new jobs. This is what proponents of Nafta predicted, and this is just what happened.
The Mexican economy collapsed at the end of 1994, and with it United States exports to Mexico. This was not a result of Nafta, but of mistakes relating to management of the peso. And the devaluation of the peso accounts for the disappearance of the United States trade surplus with Mexico. To argue, as Mr. Buchanan does, that 340,000 United States jobs have been lost because of Nafta is without foundation. Blame for mistakes in the way the peso was devalued cannot be laid to a fundamentally sound trade agreement.
Mr. Buchanan argues that Nafta has not produced an end to illegal immigration. I know of no friend of Nafta who thought that illegal immigration would disappear within 18 months of its implementation.
Many problems Mexico confronts are serious, and no course of action will fix them immediately. But whether Mexico recovers or enters into a graver crisis, it will remain on our southern border and we will feel the effects of its decisions. This is true in spite of any fence Mr. Buchanan imagines will insulate the U.S.
During the Reagan Administration, Latin America underwent a transformation toward democratic rule and market economics. This transformation represents a real advantage for American security and for the American economy. There will be setbacks along the way, but they are not reason to veer off a course that will strengthen the hemisphere.
 
RICHARD G. LUGAR
Washington, Sept. 5, 1995
 
The writer, U.S. Senator from Indiana, is a candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination.

HEADLINE: Orange County Supervisors Said To Share Blame

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: SANTA ANA, Calif., Sept. 7

 BODY:
The Orange County Board of Supervisors contributed to the county's financial disaster by failing to oversee the operations of the county treasurer, a report released today by the Orange County grand jury said.
Ineffective management played a part in the collapse of the county investment portfolio, according to the report, titled "Safeguards for the Management and Investment of Orange County Funds," which was prepared by Kroll Associates, a private consulting firm, along with the county grand jury. 
 "These losses can be linked to a badly flawed investment strategy," the report said, referring to the strategy used by Robert L. Citron, the county's former treasurer.
"However, the foundations of this financial disaster were clearly built on ineffective management of, and oversight controls over, treasury operations, coupled with a basic absence of a rational investment process," the report concluded.
Orange County declared bankruptcy on Dec. 6 after sustaining investment losses initially estimated at $1.7 billion. It has sued Merrill Lynch & Company, its investment adviser, in an attempt to recover some of the losses and is also expected to seek damages against KPMG Peat Marwick, the accounting firm.
Merrill Lynch, which has denied misleading buyers of Orange County bonds, said the Kroll report showed that the county bore responsibility for the losses. "This report is another blow to Orange County's credibility in its attempt to shift the blame to others," said Timothy Gilles, a Merrill Lynch spokesman.
Another report, by a California State Senate committee, was also highly critical of local officials.
Orange County's investment pool had higher than average interest earnings for many years, but those earnings depended on low interest rates. When rates rose sharply last year, the county's investments suffered heavy losses.
The grand jury is conducting a civil investigation of the financial crisis. It is also hearing evidence related to criminal cases.
In April, Mr. Citron pleaded guilty to six felony counts related to the crisis. The following month, the grand jury indicted the former assistant treasurer, Matthew Raabe, on similar charges. Mr. Raabe is contesting the accusations.
The grand jury report also called for sweeping changes in the county's management structure. It recommended that the treasurer no longer be an elected official and that a strong chief executive and a chief financial officer be appointed by the Board of Supervisors to oversee county finances and investments.
The report asserted that the county supervisors had failed to oversee Mr. Citron, failed to play a role in his investment strategy, and failed to develop an effective audit strategy.
"Responsible county executives, including the Board of Supervisors, failed to adequately oversee the investment activities of the treasurer," it said.
Separately, the Board of Supervisors approved the final terms of the county's recovery plan.
A committee of cities, schools and special districts in the bankruptcy case had approved the plan's terms earlier in the day. The Board of Supervisors then voted 4 to 0 in favor of the plan, with one member absent.
The county said it would be able to raise money -- through the diversion of revenue from a local transit authority and special districts, by importing trash from other counties and by restructuring debt -- to repay note holders. It added that the recovery plan should allow it to emerge from bankruptcy by the end of the fiscal year.
As part of the agreement, Orange County has dropped a controversial demand for participants in the investment pool to pay $18 million to cover certain general fund expenses. The final agreement also alters the distribution of potential litigation proceeds, which may benefit schools and others in the investment pool.
The plan must still be approved by individual cities, schools and special districts. Pool participants are expected to vote on it in the coming week. The plan also requires the California Legislature's approval.

HEADLINE: U.S. Farms Out Compiling of Leading Indicators

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7

 BODY:
In what is thought to be the first privatization of a Government statistical series, the Conference Board will assume custody of the Leading Economic Index and two companion business-cycle gauges, the Commerce Department announced today.
The Conference Board, a business-sponsored research organization based in New York, will begin its compilation of the widely followed monthly figures with data for October for publication on Dec. 6. It beat five other competitors for stewardship of the indicators, which the department has published since 1968. 
Although the content and format of the indexes are expected to show little immediate change, Conference Board officials said, graphics may be added, and an advisory panel is being created to study possible conceptual improvements, according to Gail D. Fosler, vice president and chief economist.
One refinement, she said, may be to devise preliminary figures that could be published sooner than at present. The current timetable involves delays of about five weeks after the end of the month. A rival bidder suggested that the Conference Board might substitute results from its own survey of consumer confidence for those now provided by the University of Michigan.
No money changes hands under the deal. Asked the Conference Board's motivation, Ms. Fosler cited the 79-year-old organization's "long tradition of trying to communicate to the public what's going on in the economy." From 1918 to 1959, for example, the board published figures on the cost of living, she said.
Although the department declined to discuss the losing proposals, a Wall Street economist said the Conference Board narrowly bested a bid by the National Association of Business Economists, under which Michael P. Niemira of the Mitsubishi Bank would have been project director.
Other submissions were said to have come from Columbia University's Center for International Business Cycle Research and from WEFA, a Philadelphia research firm. A proposed collaboration of the National Bureau of Economic Research and the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston collapsed after Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, objected to participation by the regional bank. The Fed did not respond to a request for comment.
Although often derided, the Leading Economic Index is the most popular of the three indexes. It is intended to forecast turning points in the economy and comprises 11 items that normally move before the economy in general, such as the number of building permits issued and the volume of new orders to factories.
The other indexes, the coincident and lagging indicators, are made up of items that tend to move at the same time as the economy or lag behind it.
The Government's motivation in seeking a private-sector steward for the gauges was to free money, about $450,000, for work it considers of higher priority, notably overhauling its broadest national statistics to keep pace with structural changes in the economy.
"Better output measures are now the highest priority for improving our economic statistics," said Everett Ehrlich, the Under Secretary for Economic Affairs. "Transferring the indicators will allow us to shift resources in that direction."
Conference Board officials projected their additional costs would be $250,000, but unlike the department's savings, this figure did not include allocation for office space and other overhead.
The Conference Board's advisory panel will be headed by Janet L. Norwood, a former Commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics. As part of the refinement process, the indexes will be the subject of an annual conference at which sponsored research will be presented.
"Rest assured that the indexes are in good hands," said Jack V. Wirts, acting president of the Conference Board. "We think we are uniquely equipped to carry out our new role."
Had the National Bureau of Economic Research taken over compilation of the indexes, which are based mainly on independently reported data from the Government and industry sources, it would have been resuming work begun under its sponsorship in the late 1930's by Arthur F. Burns and Wesley Clair Mitchell.
