HEADLINE: Tenants in Limbo as New York Stops Foreclosing

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY 

 BODY:
At the end of each workday, as Jyreain Privette crosses the threshold of her apartment building in Harlem, she wonders if the lobby will be filled with drug dealers who come and go at will because the front door has neither a lock nor an intercom. She considers riding an elevator to her third-floor apartment, but the elevator often leaves her stranded between floors. If she chooses the stairway, it will probably smell of urine, and the lights will probably be out.
Her building is one that no one wants. The landlord is in bankruptcy and for all intents has abandoned it. And New York City, which over the last two decades has rescued thousands of buildings in similar distress, no longer considers the process worth the expense. 
 "Things here keep getting worse," said Mrs. Privette, who has lived at 343 St. Nicholas Avenue for almost 48 years. "No matter where we go for help or what we do, things keep getting worse."
In a city with no shortage of decrepit buildings, hers is among the worst. City records show that the 50-unit building has 413 code violations outstanding, more than 50 of them posing an immediate safety threat. And because the landlord, Andonis Morfesis, owes the city $423,000 in back taxes and fines, officials have the right to seize the property immediately.
But the city's protective custody is probably a thing of the past. Beginning in the last months of the Dinkins administration, the city largely stopped the seizure process.
And now, armed with a new consultant's report showing that the city would be spending an average of $2.2 million in repair costs and other expenses for every building it seized, the Giuliani administration is expected to make that moratorium formal soon, ending the city's role as landlord of last resort.
Considering that the average amount of back taxes owed by landlords of those buildings is only $36,000, city officials say it is cheaper to help the owners retain the buildings.
"Managing housing is not only a job the city should not have, it is a job that we can't do very well," said Deborah C. Wright, Commissioner of the Department of Housing Preservation and Development. "Despite the amount we spend, when a building finally comes into city hands it is in terrible condition, often beyond the point of a reasonable repair job."
But to many critics of the city's policy, the issue is not simply a financial one. On 140th Street in Harlem, residents watched the inexorable decline of their building after the landlord defaulted on his taxes and filed for bankruptcy in the late 1980's. Although it was owed $96,000 in back taxes, the city never moved to foreclose on the building, an action that housing advocates say could have put the building in line for repairs.
In March, a rear wall collapsed, and three residents were killed.
Officials are looking for alternatives, such as programs to help prop up landlords having trouble paying taxes and efforts to return the almost 3,000 occupied buildings the city still owns to private ownership.
"Our goal is to reach buildings before they are near collapse," Ms. Wright said. "Rather than put so much money into buildings that are nearly dead, we need an early warning system."
Those options, though, offer little hope for Mrs. Privette and the residents of hundreds of other buildings caught in a similar state of limbo -- people like Margaret Harris in the Crown Heights area of Brooklyn and the Galarza family in the Morris Heights section of the Bronx.
"We've been waiting since April for the landlord to do something about the fire damage in the apartment," said Mrs. Harris, who lives with her daughter and two small grandchildren in a two-bedroom apartment on St. Marks Avenue and whose landlord, H.&L. Realty, owes $300,000 in back taxes.
"We don't have windows; we've lost the bedroom to the fire. I can't let the children play in a room with no windows and where the walls and floors are burned up."
Leonard Gayle, a principal of H.&L., said contractors had broken appointments to measure for the windows. In the meantime, Mrs. Harris has worked with a community organization to arrange for her rent to go toward the cost of new windows and for the repair of the bedroom.
 
The City's Role
Abandonments Up, Vesting Down
 New York City's role as a landlord began in the 1970's when it started using foreclosure to combat the wave of abandonment that blighted many neighborhoods. Through a process known as vesting, the city would take over management of the buildings, make repairs and sell them to private landlords or nonprofit organizations.
As the economy surged in the 1980's, housing advocates say, the city made significant progress in renovating buildings and finding new owners. But as the recession struck in the late 80's and early 90's, thousands of more buildings were abandoned by owners, prompting city housing officials to scale back and eventually halt the vesting process.
Much of the city's intervention in blighted neighborhoods in the last decade was bankrolled through a $4.2 billion housing plan initiated by Mayor Edward I. Koch. But that plan, which created more than 50,000 new apartments and homes in largely vacant buildings, is winding down.
And with the city no longer taking over any additional buildings, advocates for low-income tenants fear that the consequences will be severe.
"The city cannot be allowed to tell the public that not vesting will be a benign action and will not have costs to the public," said David R. Jones, president of the Community Service Society, an nonprofit organization that assists the needy. "The collapse of the low-income rental market was the start of the homelessness crisis. There will be a price to pay downstream if saving money is the only goal and if great care is not taken with this plan."
Frank P. Braconi, executive director of the Citizens Housing and Planning Council, a nonprofit research organization, said the city's moratorium on foreclosures had already worsened the condition of many buildings.
"When foreclosure is delayed," he said, "it makes it harder and harder for anyone -- the city or another owner -- to bring these buildings back."
It is impossible to say precisely how many buildings are on the brink of abandonment because of their owners' financial problems. But housing advocates assume that owners who are not paying their tax bills are not taking care of their buildings either. And tax records show that more owners are finding the going rough. The Community Service Society estimated that at the end of last year about 1,400 buildings were in serious tax arrears.
Moreover, city records show that the tax-delinquency rate for residential buildings has risen from a low of 1.8 percent in 1989 to 5.7 percent as of March.
In some buildings, like the Bronx apartment house at 1898 Harrison Avenue where Sonia Galarza lives, the city has addressed the neglect through court actions. The owner, the Harrison Tremont Realty Corporation, which owes more than $500,000 in taxes and fines, was so negligent that last year the city urged the Housing Court to let an independent administrator step in and run the building.
But things have not improved in the dangerously decaying building, Mrs. Galarza says. Rodents squeeze through holes in baseboards of her apartment, and the bathroom sink that was removed more than a year ago by the superintendent for repair has not been replaced.
"We keep hearing about the money the building is supposed to be getting to fix things up," said Mrs. Galarza, standing in the space where her sink used to be. "The only evidence we have seen has been in the new superintendent's apartment. It really looks nice now."
 
The Building
Doorman to Rats To Bankruptcy
 Life was not always so grim as it is now for tenants in the building at 343 St. Nicholas Avenue where Jyreain Privette lives. When, as newlyweds, she and her husband, James, moved into the building at 127th Street in the late 1940's, it boasted a marble lobby, a doorman and elevator attendants.
"It was so very nice here then," Mrs. Privette said. "The owners didn't live here, but one of them came by nearly every day."
The building started to lose its luster in the 1950's as crime and poverty began to take a toll on the neighborhood. Mrs. Privette recalls that luxuries like the doorman started to disappear in the 1950's. Repair jobs began to take longer and painting and polishing were less frequent. Soon the working men and women were outnumbered by families on welfare. In the 1980's, the owners started filling empty apartments with homeless families whose rents were paid by public funds.
"They took the city's money, but they didn't take care of the tenants," Mrs. Privette said. "Things started to get really bad."
Between 1985 and 1990, when speculation in Harlem was at its most feverish, a dizzying array of owners came and went. The paper value of the property soared, as the mortgage records reflect. In 1985, owners twice took loans against the property for $84,951 and for $110,000. The building took on an additional $105,000 in mortgage debt in 1987, a $754,033 mortgage was added in 1989 and still another for $1.2 million in 1990. So optimistic were investors that in late 1980's there were plans to convert the building to a co-op or a condominium.
By the time the current owner, Half Moon Real Estate, and its principal, Andonis Morfesis, took over in 1990, the mortgage debt was $2.8 million, records show. It is not known how much cash Half Moon or any of the previous investors put into the deal, but as little as 10 percent would not have been uncommon.
Officials say Mr. Morfesis is a notorious housing code scofflaw and owner of at least a dozen other troubled Harlem properties. The city's litigation against him for code violations dates to 1984. The motivation behind the purchase of such a troubled and mortgage-burdened building remains a mystery.
So far, no principals of Half Moon have been willing to discuss their ownership or problems in the building. But Claude Castro, their attorney, said the owners had been thwarted in efforts to maintain the building by tenants who waged a rent strike for three years.
By 1991, city housing officials were well aware of the problems at the building. But in 1993, with the city having chosen not to seize any more buildings, housing officials took Mr. Morfesis to court to force him to provide for his tenants. And when Mr. Morfesis tried to evict the rent-strikers, a Housing Court judge ruled that conditions were so badthat those who refused to pay rent were justified.
Five times since he took ownership, Mr. Morfesis has faced contempt charges for ignoring court orders to repair the building; the few repairs the building has received have come from the city, in response to emergencies like lack of heat or hot water, rat infestation and ceiling collapses. In that time, Mr. Morfesis has paid about $18,500 in penalties to the city while his debt to the city is up to more than $423,000.
"Ownership by people like Mr. Morfesis is a shell game where the ultimate losers are the tenants," said Raymond Brecia, a Legal Aid Society lawyer who has been assisting tenants with court cases against the owner. Mr. Brecia says that , unless the city intervenes in a more forceful manner, the building will slip beyond the point of being repairable.
"If that happens," Mr. Brecia asks, "where will tenants go? Some, I fear, will end up on the streets; others will end up in shelters."
Mrs. Privette said a low point in the building's decline came on a recent sweltering Saturday evening when an ambulance crew had to rescue frightened tenants stranded between floors in the broken elevator.
In recent weeks, the building seems to have gone from limbo to suspended animation. In June, the prospects for improvement became even more remote when Half Moon filed for bankruptcy on the property and a judge put it in a trustee's hands. This month the trustee filed a notice of abandonment. The reason cited: "The building has no value to the estate because of significant liens and other encumbrances, as well as the extremely poor condition of the building."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Moves Above 100 Yen As Japan's Discount Rate Is Cut

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar surpassed 100 yen yesterday for the first time since January after the Bank of Japan halved its discount rate and bought dollars for yen in Asian trading.
The dollar later retreated, settling in New York at 99.65 yen, up from 98.99 yen on Thursday. 
 Still, the rally yesterday left the dollar trading up against the yen on a year-to-date basis for the first time since early February. The dollar is now up nearly one-tenth of 1 percent against the yen since Jan. 1.
Since touching a low of 79.75 in intraday trading on April 19, the dollar has rebounded 25 percent against the yen.
Yesterday's surge came after the Bank of Japan cut its discount rate to half of 1 percent from 1 percent. Lower interest rates reduce investors' return on Japanese deposits, thereby making the yen less attractive.
The central bank then began an aggressive bout of dollar-buying that drove the dollar as high as 100.18 yen, its strongest since Jan. 23.
"B.O.J. intervention was pretty massive, estimated at up to $5 billion," said Jeffrey Yu, senior currency dealer at Sanwa Bank in New York. Some traders put the estimate lower, although all agreed that the central bank bought more aggressively than usual.
Against the German mark, the dollar rose as high as 1.4892 marks, its best showing since Aug. 24, when it touched 1.4962 marks. The dollar settled in New York at 1.4760 marks, down from 1.4787 marks on Thursday. The British pound edged up to $1.5515 from $1.5506.
Speculation that the United States would join Japan in a concerted round of dollar-buying rose after Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin issued an unusual late-night statement half an hour after the Japanese rate cut, traders said.
Mr. Rubin praised Japan's move and said the United States would continue to cooperate closely in the foreign exchange market with the other leading industrialized nations.
But the Federal Reserve and the Bundesbank did not join the Bank of Japan's intervention yesterday as they did on Aug. 15, traders said.
Although the dollar failed to hold above the 100-yen level, many traders said they were optimistic about its prospects in coming days.
"If we take out 100.40 yen, that might make the sub-100-yen dollar a thing of the past," said Steve Flanagan, currency trader at Credit Agricole in New York.

HEADLINE: THE CAPITALIST;
The Bonus Holdup

BYLINE: By MICHAEL LEWIS 

 BODY:
YOU DON'T KNOW the meaning of anarchy until you've seen Wall Street at bonus time. As Labor Day recedes in the rearview mirror and Thanksgiving comes in sight, each firm creates a committee to decide the bonus for each employee while each employee tries in various ways to convince the committee that he is underpaid. The trick here has always been to point out the terrible injustice of the $685,000 you were paid last year without seeming either ridiculous or ungrateful. A rumor that you have received a big offer from a rival firm is helpful, so long as you aren't caught spreading it. It's treasonous to complain too loudly, but it's suicidal not to complain at all. The person who rises above the bonus fray is as Godforsaken as the man who stands back from the luggage conveyor belt at the Calcutta airport. He'll spend the rest of his life waiting for his bags to arrive. (Nice guy. Shame it happened to him.)

MY SPECIFIC MEMORY OF bonus time at Salomon Brothers is of an entire firm rumored to be leaving for Merrill Lynch unless they were paid the fortune they deserved. Around mid-October everyone became artfully disgruntled. That no one wanted to be thought to be poorly paid further complicated the ritual.
You might go into your meeting with the bonus committee disgruntled, but when you came out you were officially pleased (until 10 months later, when once again you became disgruntled). 
 But perhaps the strangest aspect of the bonus wars was that they existed independently of the firm's fortunes. Indeed, the worse the firm fared the more certain the employee that he was about to be gypped, and so the more he scrambled for what was rightfully his.
I recall wondering, after the first time I helped to rob the bank, why the shareholders did not revolt. After all, it was their money we were after. Why did they not march into the firm and say: "Each of you is replaceable. From now on you will be paid huge sums of money as a group only if you succeed as a group"?
NOW WE KNOW. LAST October Warren Buffett, Salomon Brothers' biggest shareholder, announced that the firm's employees would from then on live by the same rules as the employees of normal corporations. The Buffett rules meant that all but a few of the firm's 200 managing directors would be guaranteed a salary of $400,000, but they would receive a bonus only after the firm's profits reached a certain level.
"It is difficult to maintain the Wall Street Entitlement Program," Deryck Maughan, the firm's chairman and chief executive, declared, "where everyone gets paid a million dollars just for coming to work."
Buffett, the second-richest man in America (after Bill Gates), was conducting an experiment in collective living upon people who wanted his money at least as badly as he did. The conditions were ideal. The firm was about to announce a pretax loss of nearly $1 billion for 1994. How could any employee who had helped to rack up these fantastic losses demand a bonus?
EASILY, AS IT TURNS OUT. Within a few months 25 of the firm's managing directors had quit, and more were vanishing in the middle of the day on job interviews. (Most embarrassing headline in The New York Times: "A Salomon Managing Director Will Be Kansas Utility Executive.") One morning five investment bankers up and left for UBS Securities, taking with them a $2 billion corporate merger.
And so this past winter the Buffett rules were bent: a small pot of money was set aside for exceptional performers. More people left. And then a trader who had been made an exception to the new rules, and had been paid $30 million last year, was told, in effect, that the firm could no longer afford exceptions. He left, too. Standard & Poor's cited the mass exodus as a reason for lowering the company's credit rating.
Finally, in late June, the Buffett rules were scrapped. The first attempt to introduce into the modern Wall Street corporation the notion that the individual must sacrifice his short-term interests for the long-term good of the whole has been pronounced a disaster.
WARREN buffett once wittily wrote that he was looking for businessmen who learned their lessons from other people's mistakes rather than their own. In that spirit we proceed.

LESSON NO. 1: Only a fool would buy shares in a Wall Street firm. In good times the employees take a huge chunk of the profits; in bad times they not only refuse to give them back but take more.
LESSON NO. 2: The Wall Street labor market is now so perfectly fluid that a corporation on Wall Street is not so much a group striving to prosper together as a bunch of people who happen to work in the same building. The operative unit in modern finance is the individual -- another reason it makes little sense to invest in groups of financiers.
LESSON NO. 3: The first rule of American capitalism is that the capitalists live by different rules than everyone else. During the leveraged-buyout craze of the 1980's, investment bankers jetted around the country preaching to managers the need to own their firms, while the bankers themselves remained highly paid employees free of the risk of ownership.
Today the great trend in our economy is the drift of bargaining power from workers to owners. Even as corporate profits skyrocket, real wages remain stagnant. American corporations currently are thriving in part because they are able to cut workers out of their gains. By contrast, a Wall Street firm that has just lost $1 billion cannot even reduce bonuses without risking the loss of its entire work force.
LESSON NO. 4: As bonus day approaches, and it looks as if there might not be enough to go around, a feeling rises high in the chest of the Wall Street employee, similar in intensity to the feeling that rises in a bear when a day hiker strolls between her and her cubs. Bet on the bear.

HEADLINE: THE ANNOTATED CALENDAR;
ARCHITECTURE

BYLINE: By HERBERT MUSCHAMP 

 BODY:
Here is a selective guide to cultural events in New York and beyond in the months ahead. As usual, programs change, some events are sold out, and some have not yet scheduled locations or exact opening dates. Unless indicated, all dates listed are for openings, all addresses are in Manhattan, and all telephone numbers have a 212 area code. Addresses for locations in New York City cited more than once appear at the bottom of page 68.
 
 
EXHIBITIONS
September
 "LIGHT CONSTRUCTION" -- Designs by Jean Nouvel, Steven Holl and the Swiss team of Jacques Herzog and Pierre de Meuron are among the more than 30 subjects that illustrate what the curator Terence Riley describes as "an emerging sensibility in contemporary architecture," structures that shed their weight and emphasize transparency and translucency. Sept. 21-Jan. 2. Museum of Modern Art.
 
October
 "MONOLITHIC ARCHITECTURE" -- Organized by the Boston-based architects Rodolfo Machado and Rodolphe el-Khoury, this show features drawings, photographs and models of nine recent projects that share the qualities of simplicity and economy of form. Oct. 1-Feb. 11. Heinz Architectural Center, Carnegie Museum of Art, Pittsburgh. (412-622-3131)
"HUDSON RIVER PARK" -- Five hundred acres of parkland and water, 13 recreation piers and an esplanade are featured in a new plan for a five-mile stretch of Manhattan's West Side waterfront. Prepared by Quennell Rothschild/Signe Nielsenn Associates and the Hudson River Conservancy, the plan is based on meetings and workshops with residents. Oct. 3-Dec. 2. Sponsored by the Municipal Art Society at the Urban Center.
"BEYOND THE BOX" -- Is New York ready for superstores? Can they help the city regenerate rusting industrial zones, or will they wreck local economies that are built on small shops and businesses? These issues will be raised by an exhibition of building designs and neighborhood plans. Oct. 11-Nov. 17. Urban Center.
"ARCHITECTS OF THE IMAGE: PHOTOGRAPHY IN THE HEROIC AGE OF CONSTRUCTION" -- The photographer as architect: that's the premise of this show of 75 photographs of buildings under construction. While the finished buildings may not reveal the dynamic force of their engineering, photographs can capture and preserve the power of a structure going up. The exhibition includes work by Alfred Stieglitz, Berenice Abbott and Walker Evans. Oct. 11-Jan. 14. Canadian Center for Architecture, Montreal. (514-939-7026)
"THE PRAIRIE SCHOOL: DESIGN VISION FOR THE MIDWEST" -- Once you get past the dreary name and the oppressive, reform-school air of wholesome living, the work of the Prairie School offers a rich experience in the making of a distinctly American architectural space: horizontal, open, organic. Designs by Louis Sullivan and Frank Lloyd Wright are featured. Oct. 14-Jan. 7. Art Institute of Chicago. (312-443-3600)
 
November
 "THE ARTS OF REFORM AND PERSUASION, 1885-1945" -- This show about the impact of modernity on architecture and design will inaugurate the new Wolfsonian Museum in Miami. Created by the Wolfson Foundation, publishers of the country's smartest design review, The Journal of Decorative and Propaganda Arts, the museum is housed in a converted warehouse in the Art Deco District. Opens Nov. 11. (305-531-1001)
"CITY SPECULATIONS" -- The New York City Panorama, built by Robert Moses as a feature attraction at the 1964-65 New York World's Fair, is the point of departure for projects by six architectural teams exploring new or alternative visions of urban planning and design. Nov. 16-March 10. Queens Museum of Art, New York City Bldg., Flushing Meadows Corona Park. (718-592-9700)
"WE WILL BE BACK: OKLAHOMA CITY REBUILDS" -- These days, demolished buildings seem to resonate with greater force than many new ones. In recent seasons, architecture shows have focused on vandalized inner-city buildings and the shelled buildings of Sarajevo. This exhibition examines the impact of the Oklahoma City bombing on residents and on the city's redevelopment plans. Nov. 17-March 17. National Building Museum, Washington. (202-272-2448)
"JEAN NOUVEL" -- The first United States show devoted to this leading French architect will feature a new site-specific project along with videos, models, drawings and photographs of his work. Nov. 18-Dec. 30. Storefront for Art and Architecture, 97 Kenmare St., SoHo. (431-5795)
 
December
 "ART, DESIGN, AND BARBIE: THE EVOLUTION OF A CULTURAL ICON" -- Zaha Hadid and Robert A. M. Stern are among the 50-plus architects, artists and designers who will contribute interpretations of America's most famous doll. Barbie dolls, which were introduced 36 years ago and are said to be inspired by the risque German 'Lilli' doll, now outnumber the population of Canada. Dec. 1-Feb. 10. Liberty Street Gallery, World Financial Center. (945-0505)
"WILD DESIGN: DESIGN FOR THE WILD" AND "LEBBEUS WOODS: THE SAN FRANCISCO PROJECT" -- The first show is a display of camping equipment and outdoor gear that explores of recent technology's adaptation to the challenge of surviving in nature. The second, gently related, is a series of drawings that explore the esthetic potentional of architecture designed to work with, rather than against, the seismic activity in the San Francisco Bay area. Dec. 16-Apr. 16. San Francisco Museum of Modern Art. (415-357-4000)
 
February
 "FRANKLIN D. ISRAEL" -- This show, a survey of work by the 50-year-old Los Angeles architect, promises to include "aroma" as one of the features of a special installation designed by Mr. Israel for the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles. Feb. 4-May 26. (213-626-6222)
"LILY REICH: DESIGNER" -- Lily Reich was the professional collaborator and personal companion of Mies van der Rohe from the mid-1920's until the architect's immigration to the United States in 1938. Best known for her exhibition designs, Reich has been credited with influencing Mies's sense of color, materials and space. A small selection of her drawings, all from the Mies van der Rohe Archives, will form the nucleus of this show. Feb. 7-May 7. Museum of Modern Art.
 
BUILDINGS
September
 GEHRY COMMUNICATION AND TECHNOLOGY CENTER -- Yesterday, Los Angeles. Today, the world. With major projects under way in Spain, South Korea, Germany and the former Czechoslovakia, Frank Gehry is a leading shaper of the global city. This building, for EMR, a German electric company, includes public exhibition spaces for the display of new energy technologies, along with a control center for regional power distribution. Opens in Bad Oeynhausen, Germany, on Friday.
 
October
 ARONOFF CENTER FOR ARTS -- If you took away the plazas at Lincoln Center and scrunched all the buildings together, the effect might be something like Cincinnati's new Aronoff Center for Arts, designed by Cesar Pelli & Associates. It will feature a 2,700-seat auditorium for dance and musical theater, along with smaller halls and galleries. Oct. 21.
SKIRBALL CULTURAL CENTER -- Designed by Moshe Safdie, this building will sponsor exhibitions, conferences and other programs that explore the American Jewish experience. Situated in Santa Monica Hills, Calif., the 125,000-square-foot building has been designed to accommodate the challenging terrain. The center's outdoor amphitheater has been designed as an earth buttress, while the museum wing forms a dam. Oct. 21.
THE NEUROSCIENCES BUILDING OF THE SCRIPPS INSTITUTE OF OCEANOGRAPHY
This building, designed by the New York architects Tod Williams and Billie Tsien, should compensate somewhat for the controversial new addition to the best-known landmark in La Jolla, Calif., Louis Kahn's Salk Institute. The new Scripps building has been described as "a scientific monastery."
 
December

SOUTHERN REGIONAL LIBRARY, U.C.L.A.
Books go for heavy ground cover at the Southern Regional Library at U.C.L.A. A new addition by Frank Israel, in association with Leiden, Frost & Horowitz, the design of the Los Angeles library continues the architect's experiments in integrating architecture with landscape design.
 
April
 BUILDING FOR ART, ARCHITECTURE AND PLANNING, UNIVERSITY OF CINCINNATI -- The heartland's love affair with the architectural agitator Peter Eisenman continues, with the opening of Mr. Eisenman's new building for the University of Cincinnati's department of art, architecture and planning. An auditorium, a library and a gallery are among the features of this sinous pastel reptile of an academic building.

SECTION: Section 2; Page 64; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk 

LENGTH: 5029 words

HEADLINE: THE ANNOTATED CALENDAR;
THEATER

BYLINE: By BEN BRANTLEY 

 BODY:
Here is a selective guide to cultural events in New York and beyond in the months ahead. As usual, programs change, some events are sold out, and some have not yet scheduled locations or exact opening dates. Unless indicated, all dates listed are for openings, all addresses are in Manhattan, and all telephone numbers have a 212 area code. Addresses for locations in New York City cited more than once appear at the bottom of page 68.
 
 
September
 "THE ISLAND OF LOST SHOES" -- Even if Imelda isn't in the audience, she should be. Bloolips, the British troupe of high-heeled clowns, extends the season for summer camp with a musical about shipwrecked drag queens. The songs are by Ray Dobbins. Through Sept. 24. Performance Space 122. 
 "SEVEN GUITARS" -- Angels in Pittsburgh in 1948. August Wilson's requiem for a guitarist considers life, death, heaven and jazz in some of the most musical language being written today. This most recent of the Wilson chronicles of black America through the decades (first staged in Chicago by Walter Dallas) is now in the familiar hands of the director Lloyd Richards, Mr. Wilson's enduring collaborator. Scheduled for a March opening in New York, it is a Broadway rarity: a real, new play from a major American playwright. Through Oct. 8. Huntington Theater, Boston. (617-266-7900)
"THE AMERICAN CHESTNUT" -- A marriage between two American icons that simply had to be. The performance artist Karen Finley (of the N.E.A. Four) addresses the subject of Martha Stewart. Tues. to Sept. 17. A part of the Fall Festival at the American Repertory Theater, Boston. (617-547-8300)
"MACBETH" -- Take that, Macduff, ya big palooka! Stacy Keach, the classical actor and television gumshoe, puts up his dukes as the scheming Thane of Cawdor. Joe Dowling, always worth checking out (and the heir apparent at the Guthrie Theater) directs. Previews begin Tues. Opens Sept. 18. Shakespeare Theater, Washington. (202-393-2700)
"A DOLL'S HOUSE" -- That door just won't stop slamming. Grey Johnson directs Henrik Ibsen's tale of the little squirrel who roared. In previews. Opens Sept. 17. Pearl Theater, 80 St. Mark's Pl. (598-9802)
"COMPANY" -- An overdue revival of the musical that made the Me Decade sing. Vintage, sparkling, tart-tasting Sondheim from 1970, with a book by George Furth. Boyd Gaines, Kate Burton and the splendid Debra Monk are among those bringing life to Mr. Sondheim's articulately unhappy urbanites, who complain with peerless wit. Scott Ellis, who successfully resuscitated "She Loves Me," directs. Bet on an extended life in another Broadway house. In previews. Opens Sept. 28. Roundabout Theater Company.
"SIN" -- A new kind of voyeurism (looking at wickedness in San Francisco from a traffic reporter's helicopter), from Wendy MacLeod, a playwright who gave us a new kind of incest (it involved re-creating the Kennedy assassination) in last season's "House of Yes." A welcome return for the skewed at heart. Directed by David Petrarca. Previews begin Tues. Opens Oct. 11. Second Stage Theater.
"MOON OVER BUFFALO" -- Before she ruled prime time as America's Tarzan-yodeling sweetheart, Carol Burnett conquered Broadway as the shy but loud princess of "Once Upon a Mattress." More than 30 years later, she's here to reclaim the old turf in a backstage farce by Ken Ludwig ("Lend Me a Tenor"), with the sterling Philip Bosco. Tom Moore directs this likely hit with matinee audiences. Previews begin Wed. Opens Oct. 1. Martin Beck, 302 W. 45th St. (239-6200)
"THE EMPEROR JONES" -- Another long day's journey into deconstruction from the mixed- media maestros of downtown New York. Elizabeth LeCompte again directs the Wooster Group in O'Neill's study in retro-evolution. The savagery on stage will be balanced by the chicest audience in SoHo. Fri. to Oct. 1. Performing Garage, 33 Wooster St. (966-3651)
"MATHEW IN THE SCHOOL OF LIFE" -- The world is a space station; Christ is a robot. Has Steven Spielberg optioned it? A reprise of the composer John Moran's electronic musical, directed by Bob McGrath. Previews begin Sept. 22. Opens Oct. 5. The Kitchen.
"FUNNYHOUSE OF A NEGRO" and "A MOVIE STAR HAS TO STAR IN BLACK AND WHITE"
Finally, a forum in New York for one of the American theater's most original voices. Adrienne Kennedy's poetic one-acters on psychic strife and movie making (aren't they the same thing?) lead off a Kennedy season at the Signature Theater, which provided memorable showcases for unexplored Albee and Foote. Joseph Chaikin and Caroline Jackson Smith direct. Opens Sept. 22. At the Signature's temporary headquarters at the Joseph Papp Public Theater.
"GARDEN DISTRICT" -- Two one-act companion pieces from Tennessee Williams (who, after last season's "Rose Tattoo," is again flourishing in the city that spurned him), and the occasion for some appetizing casting: In "Suddenly, Last Summer," Elizabeth Ashley is Mrs. Venable, the mental-health expert only a dead son could love, directed by Harold Scott. And Myra Carter, the most formidable of Edward Albee's Tall Women, returns (hooray) in "Something Unspoken," directed by Theodore Mann. (Part of a season of American classics: "Holiday," "The Petrified Forest," "A Moon for the Misbegotten" and "Hughie," given star wattage by Al Pacino.) Previews begin Sept. 22. Opens Oct. 10. Circle in the Square, 1633 Broadway. (239-6200)
"FULL GALLOP" -- Mary Louise Wilson bravely takes on the task of imitating the inimitable Diana Vreeland, the late high priestess of high style. The script, partly adapted from Vreeland's autobiography, is by Ms. Wilson and Mark Hampton. Nicholas Martin directs. Why don't you polish the soles of your shoes, as Mrs. Vreeland always did, before attending? Previews begin Sept. 26. Opens Oct. 17. Manhattan Theater Club, Stage II.
"ENDGAME (FIN DE PARTIE)" -- No, the rules haven't changed. But Samuel Beckett's mordant classic should be worth re-examining with the estimable Kathleen Chalfant as one of the players. With John Seitz. David Esbjornson, who does despair stylishly, directs. Previews begin Sept. 26. Opens Oct. 5. Classic Stage Company, 136 E. 13th St. (677-4210)
"MOONLIGHT" -- Well, there is certainly no longer pause than death, is there? Harold Pinter, the great master of the elliptical drama, interpreted by two fine American actors, Jason Robards and Blythe Danner, in this exploration of a terminally ill man and his family. Sure to be the season's hottest literary ticket. Karel Reisz, better known here for his film work ("Morgan," "Isadora") directs, and Kathleen Widdoes and Paul Hecht co-star. An auspicious opening for the new Laura Pels Theater at the Roundabout. Previews begin Sept. 27. Opens Oct. 17.
"DANGEROUS CORNER" -- Bourgeois facades, hidden romances and an unexplained suicide. Wasn't that what "An Inspector Calls" was about? A shorter work from the same author, J. B. Priestley, whose deconstructed "Inspector" was a surprise hit on Broadway. The question here is whether the director, one David Mamet, can make this one breathe without collapsing a building. Previews begin Sept. 30. Opens Oct. 12. Atlantic Theater Company, 336 W. 20th St. (239-6200)
 
October
 "POMP DUCK AND CIRCUMSTANCE" -- The highest single-ticket price of the season ($150), for three and a half hours of vaudeville and epicurean dining in a 1930's-style Belgian circus tent. Created by a chef, Hans-Peter Wodarz, this interactive, international and inflationary evening is appropriately destined for the MGM Grand Hotel in Las Vegas. Its Manhattan setting, if you please, is DeWitt Clinton Park on 11th Ave. near 53d St., which should make for startling contrasts. Previews begin Oct. 2. Opens Oct. 11. (307-4100)
"VICTOR/VICTORIA" -- How many years have we been waiting for this one? At long last Julie Andrews (a k a Mrs. Blake Edwards), recreating the cross-dressing role she played in Mr. Edwards's 1982 film. Word from the road has been mixed, but who's going to pass up the chance to see Broadway's original fair lady? Tony Roberts plays the good-hearted, hammy homosexual (the Robert Preston part); with Michael Nouri and Rachel York. Music by the late Henry Mancini and lyrics by Leslie Bricusse. Previews begin Oct. 3. Opens Oct. 25. Marquis, 1535 Broadway, at 46th St. (307-4100)
"MOSCOW STATIONS" -- Down and out in Russia, where they really know from down. Still, this one-man account of a train trip through an angst and alcohol haze is said to be a true up, since Tom Courtenay plays the man. (The Brit crits were ecstatic.) Stephen Mulrine adapted Venedikt Yerofeev's novel. Previews begin Oct. 5. Opens Oct. 12. Union Square Theater, 100 E. 17th St. (505-0700)
"PATTI LUPONE ON BROADWAY" -- Silent no longer, the voice that didn't make it to New York's "Sunset Boulevard" is ready to shake the rafters. Even for non-LuPonites, this two-hour concert is worth attending for the privilege of seeing just how hysterical fans can become watching a Broadway diva with a dramatic professional past. Conceived and directed by Scott Wittman. Previews begin Oct. 5. Opens Oct. 12 for a six-week run. Walter Kerr, 219 W. 48th St. (239-6200)
"NORTHEAST LOCAL" -- Portrait of a marriage, portrait of a nation. Tom Donaghy's drama follows a blue-collar family from 1963 to the present. The top-flight cast (Terry Alexander, Eileen Heckart, Anthony LaPaglia and Mary Elizabeth Mastrantonio) is in the very secure hands of the director Gerald Gutierrez ("The Heiress"). Previews begin Oct. 5. Opens Oct. 29. Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater, Lincoln Center.
"BUTTONS ON BROADWAY" -- As in Red Buttons, who definitely still knows how to hold a stage. A return engagement of this summer's exercise in stand-up nostalgia. Opens Oct. 5 at a theater to be announced.
"ALICE" -- Robert Wilson, a theatrical conceptualist who gives deep thoughts the cosmetic form of Vogue layouts, visits Wonderland, which is sure, at least, to look great. A stream-of-consciousness approach to a childhood classic. Tom Waits, who collaborated with Mr. Wilson on "The Black Rider," did the music; Paul Schmidt, the text. Oct. 6-14. Next Wave Festival, Brooklyn Academy of Music.
"SWINGING ON A STAR" -- This musical revue celebrates the songs of Johnny Burke -- Johnny who? -- at least some of whose words are undoubtedly stamped on your memory ("Misty," "Pennies From Heaven"). Michael Leeds wrote and directed this tribute to the prolific lyricist (whose collaborators included Jimmy Van Heusen and Erroll Garner), with choreography by Kathleen Marshall. Previews begin Oct. 6. Opens Oct. 22. Music Box, 239 W. 45th St. (239-6200)
"PICASSO AT THE LAPIN AGILE" -- Proof that being a playwright means never having to say "Excu-u-se me." The actor-author Steve Martin, who is sprouting Off Broadway like goldenrod, introduces Albert Einstein to Pablo Picasso in this "Travesties"-like fantasy set in the Paris of 1904. Directed by Randall Arney. Previews begin Oct. 6. Opens Oct. 22. Promenade, 2162 Broadway, at 76th St. (239-6200)
"MRS. KLEIN" -- The rare presence of the actor's actor Uta Hagen (the original Martha of "Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?") makes this production of Nicholas Wright's psychodrama something like the theater buff's equivalent of Halley's comet. Amy Wright and Laila Robbins co-star in this look at the contradictions in the life of the psychoanalyst Melanie Klein. William Carden directs. Previews begin Oct. 6. Opens Oct. 24. Lucille Lortel Theater, 121 Christopher St. (239-6200)
"NIGHT JUST BEFORE THE FOREST" -- Paris when it drizzles is not lovable in this brooding drama of alienation set on one rainy night. From the European cult favorite Bernard-Marie Koltes, who died at 41 in 1989. Directed by Susan Einhorn. Opens Oct. 10. Ubu Repertory Theater, 15 W. 28th St. (679-7562)
"THE TEMPEST" -- As presented in Central Park, this Shakespeare Festival production was indeed such stuff as pure theater magic is made on. The question is how much a conventional indoor stage will ground George C. Wolfe's enchanted, high-flying take on Shakespeare's valedictory play. Patrick Stewart returns to recreate his charismatically fierce Prospero for Broadway. Previews begin Oct. 10. Broadhurst, 235 W. 44th St. (239-6200)
"HELLO, DOLLY!" -- Thirty-one years later, Carol Channing is still glowing, still crowing, etc., in a clock-stopping reprise of her 1964 triumph. She is, from all accounts on the road, doing an impeccable imitation of Carol Channing. Jay Garner co-stars and Lee Roy Reams, yesteryear's favorite boy hoofer, directs. Previews begin Oct. 11. Opens Oct. 19 for a seven-week run that may be extended. Lunt-Fontanne, 205 W. 46th St. (307-4100)
"THREE PLAYS IN REP" -- Andrei Serban, who was detonating classics when "deconstruction" was still something a contractor did, takes on a heady trio of seldom-performed works from European masters: "Love, the Greatest Enchantment" by Calderon de la Barca, "The Golden Bird" by Carlo Gozzi and "La Dispute" by Pierre de Marivaux. In repertory. Oct. 11-22. La Mama Theater.
"THE MODEL APARTMENT" -- Yes, unhappy families are different, or play-going would be mighty redundant. Donald Margulies, who excelled on the subject in "The Loman Family Picnic," charts the family friction as an elderly couple make plans for their retirement. Lisa Peterson directs. Oct. 11-Nov. 12. Primary Stages, 354 W. 45th St. (333-4052)
"NATHAN THE WISE" -- Searching for religious harmony in medieval Jerusalem in an 18th-century poetic drama that was, not surprisingly, banned by Hitler. From the seminal German playwright Gotthold Ephraim Lessing, directed by Scott Shattuck for the Jean Cocteau Repertory, an enduring forum for forgotten classics. Previews begin Oct. 13. Opens Oct. 15. Bouwerie Lane Theater, 330 Bowery. (677-0060)
"SALOME" -- Steven Berkoff meets Oscar Wilde at his wildest. The director will also be playing King Herod. Be prepared to go over the top -- way over. With music by Roger Doyle. Oct. 17-21. Next Wave Festival. Majestic Theater, Brooklyn Academy of Music.
"NEW ENGLAND" -- Anglo-Americana from a connoisseur. Richard Nelson, an American playwright in residence at the Royal Shakespeare Company, presents English expatriates staring into the culture gap in the States. The flip side of Mr. Nelson's witty "Some Americans Abroad" of several years ago. Howard Davies (an Englishman, of course) directs. Previews begin Oct. 17. Opens Nov. 7. Manhattan Theater Club, Stage I.
"RIFF RAFF" -- Hey, if Steve Martin can make the transition from screen acting to stage writing, why not Laurence Fishburne? The excellent actor sinks into the lower depths of lower New York to portray an uneasy friendship in the shadow of a disastrous drug heist. Mr. Fishburne directs in the maiden offering from the Circle Repertory Company in its first season under the artistic directorship of Austin Pendleton. Previews begin Oct. 18. Opens Nov. 1. Circle in the Square Downtown, 159 Bleecker St. (239-6200)
"BUSKER ALLEY" -- Once known as "Buskers," once known as "Stage Door Charley," this show with a troubled past asks how many lives a musical can have before Broadway. Tommy Tune has the lead (in, believe it or not, a role created by Charles Laughton) in this adaptation of the 1938 film "St. Martin's Lane." With Dulcie Roberts as a star aborning, and music and lyrics by Richard M. and Robert B. Sherman of "Mary Poppins" fame. The director and choreographer is Jeff Calhoun, although many hands are said to have stirred this pot. Previews begin Oct. 19. Opens Nov. 16. St. James, 246 W. 44th St. (239-6200)
"ROBBERS" -- Have you been missing Marshall W. Mason, former head of the Circle Repertory and a director of indisputable emotional depth? In New Haven, he is staging Lyle Kessler's look at how you tell the teller from the tale. Previews begin Oct. 20. Opens Oct. 25. Long Wharf Theater, Stage II, New Haven. (203-787-4282)
"PRIVATE LIVES" -- The dry martini of connubial comedy, with a twist: an all-Asian cast. Directed by John Briggs. Previews begin Oct. 24. Opens Oct. 27. Pan Asian Repertory Theater at Playhouse 46 at St. Clement's, 423 W. 46th St. (245-2660)
"VALLEY SONG" -- Life after apartheid, according to the playwright most able to address the subject, Athol Fugard, from whom the appearance of a new play is automatically an event. This one appropriately finds an old man and his granddaughter trying to reconcile the past with the future. Directed by Mr. Fugard. Oct. 24-Nov. 12. American premiere at the McCarter Theater, Princeton, N.J. (609-683-8000) Previews begin Nov. 28. Opens Dec. 12. Manhattan Theater Club, Stage II.
"SACRILEGE" -- It's a good year for actresses, a bad year for religious orthodoxy (see "Racing Demon"). Ellen Burstyn, who has spiritual glow to spare, stars in Diane Shaffer's tale of a radical feminist nun (no less) battling the Roman Catholic establishment. With John Forsythe and the compelling Giancarlo Esposito. Don Scardino ("A Few Good Men") directs. Previews begin Oct. 26. Opens Nov. 2. Belasco, 111 W. 44th St. (239-6200)
"MASTER CLASS" -- Callas in her twilight, from Terrence McNally, whose enthusiasm for the "Norma" of all times was already evidenced in "The Lisbon Traviata." Zoe Caldwell plays the diva assoluta, who transports star temperament from the stage to a music-school classroom in the 1960's. Audra MacDonald, the exciting Carrie in the recent "Carousel," plays one of her students. Leonard Foglia directs. Previews begin Oct. 26. Opens Nov. 5. Golden, 252 W. 45th St. (239-6200)
"BRING IN 'DA NOISE. BRING IN 'DA FUNK"
Why the beat goes on. An anatomy of the enduring rhythms behind tap, rap, be-bop and hip-hop from an auspicious trio: Savion Glover (the dancer), Reg E. Gaines (the oral poet) and George C. Wolfe (the director). Previews begin Oct. 27. Opens Nov. 15. Joseph Papp Public Theater.
"FOOL MOON" -- Mime that can charm even mime haters. David Shiner and Bill Irwin engage in a magical, wordless battle with the universe in a reprise of their popular 1993 show. With music by the Red Clay Ramblers. Previews begin Oct. 21. Opens Oct. 29. Ambassador, 219 W. 49th St. (239-6200)
 
November
 "RACING DEMON" -- David Hare, a playwright never averse to pulpit pounding, goes head to head with the Church of England in this polemical look at four clergymen. The unobtrusively excellent Richard Eyre, who first staged it for the National Theater, directs Brian Murray, Kathleen Chalfant and Michael Cumpsty. Will this provocative London hit translate for American ears? Don't discount the power of Anglophilia in New York. Previews begin Nov. 1. Opens Nov. 20. Vivian Beaumont Theater, Lincoln Center.
"BLACK GIRL" -- J. E. Franklin's ground-breaking 1971 play about growing up in the ghetto would seem to be wedged in its time. But similar doubts were raised about the revival of Ntozake Shange's "For Colored Girls," triumphantly produced by the same theater in June and still running. Anderson Johnson directs for the New Federal Theater. Nov. 9-Dec. 3. Harry de Jur Playhouse, Henry Street Settlement, 466 Grand St. (598-0400)
"THE MONOGAMIST" -- A comedy to give hope to the unproduced, since this one actually made it out of a slush pile to the main stage of Playwrights Horizons. The 30-year-old author, Christopher Kyle, casts a precocious eye on midlife crises. Directed by Scott Elliott, who so admirably brought Mike Leigh's "Ecstasy" to life. Previews begin Oct. 13. Opens Nov. 6. Playwrights Horizons.
"I AIN'T YO' UNCLE: THE NEW JACK REVISIONIST UNCLE TOM'S CABIN" -- A play with a title that fully expresses its intentions. The slaves in "Uncle Tom's Cabin" wrest the novel from Harriet Beecher Stowe to tell the story their way. Reggie Montgomery directs Robert Alexander's inversion of the 19th-century classic. Previews begin Nov. 11. Opens Nov. 17. Hartford Stage. (203-527-5151)
"SCHOOL FOR SCANDAL" -- Richard Sheridan's prototypical Restoration comedy gets the treatment from the National Actors Theater, which has certainly tried its hands at most other genres in its erratic previous four seasons. Tony Randall (natch) plays Sir Peter Teazle and Gerald Freeman directs. Previews begin Nov. 14. Opens Nov. 19. Lyceum, 149 W. 45th St. (239-6200)
"A CHRISTMAS CAROL" -- An annual reprise for those who like their Yuletide cheer wrapped in big, glitzy packages. Ben Vereen surfaces as the Ghost of Christmas Past. With music by Alan Menken and lyrics by Lynn Ahrens; Mike Ockrent directs. Nov. 20-Dec. 31. The Paramount. (307-7171)
"WASP AND THE MAGIC TRICKS" -- More from Steve Martin, the season's most ubiquitous promising middle-aged playwright (see "Picasso at the Lapin Agile"). Here, one-acters about men versus women and white-bread ethnicity. Directed by Barry Edelstein, who ripped the stuffing out of "The Merchant of Venice" last season. Previews begin Nov. 28. Joseph Papp Public Theater.
 
December
 "THE DUCHESS OF MALFI" -- Politics, revenge and gallons of blood. John Webster's ultimate Jacobean potboiler seethes anew under the ever-inventive direction of Declan Donnellan for the Cheek by Jowl company (whose "As You Like It" was a high point of the last theater season). A must-see for the strong of stomach. Dec. 6-16. Next Wave Festival. Majestic Theater, Brooklyn Academy of Music.
"THE FATHER" -- And you thought your family was dysfunctional. Strindberg in full misogynistic spleen, as interpreted by Robert Falls ("The Food Chain"). Frank Langella, who can storm with the best of them, is the paterfamilias under siege. Previews begin Dec. 13. Opens Jan. 4. Roundabout Theater Company.
"THE UNIVERSE" -- Richard Foreman, lord of New York's theatrical underground, concludes his trilogy about the mysteries of existence. While he is unlikely to solve them, he is likely to provide an invigorating slice of cerebral vaudeville. Previews begin Dec. 27. Ontological Hysteric Theater at St. Mark's Church, Second Ave. at 10th St. (420-1916)
"WONDERFUL TIME" -- Jonathan Marc Sherman, a produced playwright before he was 20 (with "Wallace and Women"), is probably the season's youngest old hand at 27. Here, the articulate author of "Sophistry" follows the course of an impetuous romance across America. WPA, 519 W. 23d St. (206-0523)
 
January
 "MOLLY SWEENEY" -- Brian Friel's exquisite series of monologues about the imponderable realm of the senses comes to New York via Dublin and London. Jason Robards, fresh from his duties in "Moonlight," also stars here with the radiant Catherine Byrne ("Dancing at Lughnasa") in the title role. The season's best bet for sentimental goose bumps. Mr. Friel directs. Previews begin Jan. 3. Laura Pels Theater at the Roundabout.
"TRUE CRIMES" -- Romulus Linney, a playwright for whom evil is never far away, finds it anew in the Smoky Mountains in this anatomy of a rural murder. Directed by the author. Jan. 11-Feb. 4. Theater for the New City, 155 First Ave., at 10th St. (254-1109)
"BED AND SOFA: A SILENT MOVIE OPERA"
The subject belongs to the past, but the musical is new, so who's complaining? Polly Pen, a composer with an elegantly brooding voice, wrote the music and Laurence Klavan the libretto for this adaptation of a 1920's Russian film. Andre Ernotte directs. Jan. 11-Feb. 11.Vineyard, 108 E. 15th St. (353-3874)
"MATA HARI" -- A musical whose very name became synonymous with "turkey." This doomed tale of the spy who loved too much opens itself up for reappraisal. Edward Thomas wrote the score, with a book by Jerome Coopersmith and lyrics by Martin Charnin, who also directs. Previews begin Jan. 12. Opens Jan. 17. York Theater Company, St. Peter's Church, Citicorp Center, 54th St. and Lexington Ave. (935-5820)
"BLUE WINDOW" -- Alone in a crowd once again: the before and after of a New York cocktail party that introduced the melancholy whimsy of Craig Lucas to New York audiences. The worthy Joe Mantello ("Love! Valour! Compassion!") directs the revival of this 1984 play. Previews begin Jan. 16. Opens Feb. 6. Manhattan Theater Club, Stage I.
"RENT" -- "La Boheme," set in the East Village of today. Cool, huh? Jonathan Larson's musical, a hit in workshop incarnations, is presold to a cult audience. Directed by Michael Greif, who is never predictable. Previews begin Jan. 19. Opens Feb. 6. New York Theater Workshop, 79 E. 4th St. (460-5475)
"SPOKE MAN" -- The view from a wheelchair, courtesy of John Hockenberry, a journalist of coruscating eloquence and humor, in a one-man show. Opens Jan. 24. American Place Theater, 111 W. 46th St. (840-3074)
"A FAIR COUNTRY" -- Jon Robin Baitz, the American theater's favorite angry young man of the moment, goes back to South Africa, a country he grilled to a crisp in "The Film Society" (1989), with this study of a diplomatic family undone. An eagerly awaited return from one of the most lionized playwrights of his generation. Daniel Sullivan directs. Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater, Lincoln Center.
 
February
 "FLOTSAM" -- Oh, those wacky East Villagers! The season's second musical in which downtown's hedonists jive to the rhythms of life. The quirkily talented Michael John La Chiusa ("Hello Again") adapts stories by the quirkily talented Deborah Eisenberg. Previews begin Feb. 13. Second Stage.
 
March
 "WORKING TITLE" -- A big-time screenwriter commits the unspeakable Hollywood sin of breaking his formula for success. By the wonderfully strange screenwriter Andrew Bergman ("The Freshman"), who should know about such things. Directed by Max Mayer. Previews begin March 2. American Jewish Theater, 307 W. 26th St. (633-9797)
"A MIDSUMMER NIGHT'S DREAM" -- You may as well get used to seeing it once a year. This version comes from Adrian Noble and the Royal Shakespeare Company and is said to be truly dreamy. How often, in this day, does Shakespeare make it to Broadway twice in one season? Previews begin March 19. Nederlander, 208 W. 41st St. (921-8000)
"THE YOUNG MAN FROM ATLANTA" -- This year's Pulitzer Prize winner, Horton Foote's compassionate study of an aging couple and the dead son they never really knew, returns to Manhattan in glory, with Ralph Waite and Carlin Glynn in the roles they created last season for the Signature Theater Company. Peter Masterson directs still another example of the season's happiest trend: substantial dramas in Broadway theaters. Previews begin March 29 at a theater to be announced.
"THE KING AND I" -- Rodgers and Hammerstein with a high sugar content. But getting to know Donna Murphy, who provided the passion in "Passion," as the "I" of the title should be a treat, as should Jerome Robbins's original choreography. Christopher Renshaw directs, with additional musical staging by Lar Lubovitch. The crucial X factor, his imperious majesty, has yet to be announced.Previews begin mid-March. Neil Simon, 250 W. 52d St. (307-4100)
"WAITING FOR GODOT" -- Estragon and Vladimir's excellent adventure in Yiddish. Part of the 80th-anniversary season of the Folksbiene Playhouse, 123 E. 55th St. (755-2231)
 
April
 "UNDER THE SKIN" -- Corporate attorney meets homeless suspected serial killer. Wasn't that a movie of the week? Susan Yankowitz's drama is, however, being directed by the less than orthodox Melissa Bensussen. Previews begin April 2. Opens April 9. Women's Project at Theater Row Theater, 412 W. 42d St. (765-1706)
"THE SHAWL" -- This is the one everyone swooned for when it was first produced in Sag Harbor, L.I., two seasons back. Cynthia Ozick's drama about memory and the Holocaust comes to New York with its original director (Sidney Lumet) and at least one of its original stars (the delectable Dianne Wiest). April 13-May 5. Jewish Repertory Theater, Playhouse 91, 316 E. 91st St. (831-2000)
"VENUS" -- Suzan-Lori Parks ("The America Play") finds a mirror for colonization and its discontents in the life of Saartjie Baartman, an African who toured Europe as "the Hottentot Venus" in the 19th century. Richard Foreman, who, like Ms. Parks, is stronger on imagination than clarity, directs. Don't be surprised if you leave scratching your head. A co-production with the Yale Repertory Theater. Previews begin April 16. Joseph Papp Public Theater.
"ARTS AND LEISURE" -- A largely unloved species is put under the microscope in this story of a drama critic in an advanced state of existential nausea. The writer and the director, Steve Tesich and JoAnne Akalaitis, have every reason to enjoy his predicament. Previews begin April 26. Opens May 19. Playwrights Horizons.
"THE CHANG FRAGMENTS" -- The lie of the melting pot, as manifested in the experiences of one Asian-American family. From the pen of the often insightful Hang Ong. Previews begin April 30. Joseph Papp Public Theater.
"A FUNNY THING HAPPENED ON THE WAY TO THE FORUM" -- This latest instance of revival mania has two very strong things going for it: its director, Jerry Zaks, and its star, Nathan Lane, who know just how to find a punchy immediacy in well-ridden war horses. (Remember the bliss that was "Guys and Dolls" several years ago?) And for all its leers and nudges, this farce, set in dirty old Rome, from Burt Shevelove, Larry Gelbart and Stephen Sondheim, has a vaudevillian zest that doesn't die. Pretty close to a sure thing. Broadway house to be announced.
"THE SKRIKER" -- A welcome new offering from Caryl Churchill, a truly major playwright who has been too long from these shores. Here, she shuttles between contemporary England and a creepy, mythological underworld ruled by the shape-changing creature of the title. Mark Wing-Davey, who memorably directed Ms. Churchill's "Mad Forest," gets a chance to redeem himself for this summer's unfortunate "Troilus and Cressida." Joseph Papp Public Theater.
"BIG" -- What's this? An honest-to-goodness new musical on Broadway? Hopes are high for this adaptation of the Tom Hanks movie, though much rides on the choice of the lead, which is yet to be announced. Mike Ockrent, who brought enjoyable flash to "Crazy for You," directs. Book by John Weidman; lyrics by Richard Maltby Jr.; music by David Shire. Shubert, 225 W. 44th St. (239-6200)

SECTION: Section 6; Page 14; Column 2; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 197 words

HEADLINE: THE MAN INSIDE BILL CLINTON'S FOREIGN POLICY

 BODY:
It has been clear for some time that America under this Administration has no coherent foreign policy. Jason DeParle's article on Anthony Lake helped me to understand how this could be so. Until I read it I thought that only Batman spent his time actively working to combat "evil" in the world.
Lake is going about in search of monsters to destroy. All in the name of destroying evil so long as it is not too strong, the combat will insure media coverage, and any combat will not test our staying power. This is a good and noble goal for an idealist, but it is not a foreign policy. Certainly it is not a foreign policy for a nation whose vital interests face no all-threatening enemy anywhere in the world, who is a net debtor in the world economy and whose industrial and military strengths on a relative scale are far below what they were in the 1940's. 
 DeParle's article indicates that Lake's desires and demeanor have created his lack of recognition despite his high position. Could it also be that someone recognizes how difficult it would be to defend his positions on national security should they become better known?
 
WILLIAM A. BARRY
Huntsville, Ala.

LENGTH: 1239 words

HEADLINE: YOUR HOME;
Increases In Co-op Rents

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO 

 BODY:
MILDRED FINKLE is incensed about the hardship rent increase she has been ordered to pay on the five-room Manhattan apartment she has lived in for the last 20 years. And while countless other tenants living in rent-regulated apartments have undoubtedly expressed similar sentiments about rent increases, Mrs. Finkle's situation is a bit different.
As a rent-stabilized tenant in a co-op, Mrs. Finkle has been almost immune to hardship rent increases. That immunity -- shared by thousands of other rent-regulated tenants living in unsold co-op apartments -- emanates from the Department of Housing and Community Renewal's steadfast refusal to grant hardship increases to owners of unsold shares in a co-op. 
 Such owners are usually the original sponsors who converted buildings from rental into co-op status; with the real-estate problems of recent years, however, financial institutions, private investors and co-op boards are sometimes owners of unsold shares.
The virtual immunity to hardship rent increases enjoyed by rent-stabilized tenants living in such apartments changed last month, though, when the agency issued a final ruling on a hardship increase it granted last year to the owner of 76 apartments in the building at 203-205 East 72d Street where Mrs. Finkle lives.
The increase, which is retroactive to 1987 and will cost some tenants thousands of dollars, has evoked a wide range of reaction in the real estate community. Tenant advocates, stung by the decision, say it is yet another example of landlords profiteering on the backs of renters. Co-op experts, concerned about it, say the decision can cut both ways, either hurting or helping co-ops depending on the circumstances. Other real estate experts, nonplused by the ruling, say it is an anomaly that will have little or no long-lasting effect.
"This is a significant decision," said Jeffrey Turkel, a lawyer with Rosenberg & Estis, the Manhattan law firm that represented the applicant in the proceedings before the agency. "It means that if you are the holder of unsold shares to a rent-stabilized apartment, and you're losing money on a monthly basis, you can apply for a hardship increase and possibly eliminate a negative cash flow and get into the positive."
The ruling is the result of a decadelong effort by the owner of 76 rent-stabilized apartments in the 150-unit building that was converted to a co-op in 1979, to obtain a comparative hardship rent increase on the rent-regulated apartments. After several denials by the housing agency and a series of court battles, the applicant's estate -- the original applicant, Peter Sharp, died in 1992 -- was ultimately awarded a $5.54 per-room per-month hardship increase last October. The ruling on the increase, which was retroactive to June 1, 1987, was appealed by the tenants. On Aug. 23, however, the agency declared the ruling final and ordered payment of both the prospective increase and the retroactive amounts due.
"This is an outrageous decision," said Michael McKee, director of development of the New York State Tenants and Neighbors Coalition, which is in Manhattan. "What they're doing is allowing sponsors to first profit off the conversion and then make additional profits by squeezing the nonpurchasing tenants."
Mr. McKee said that law allowing hardship increases should not be extended to owners of shares in a co-op. "A legitimate hardship situation should apply to a hard-working landlord who owns a rental building and who is in a hardship situation through no fault of his own," he said.
Original sponsors, he said, are not in that situation. "All kinds of calculations go into a conversion," he said. "And one thing that is always included in the equation is the fact that the sponsor is going to end up owning apartments that are not sold."
As a result, Mr. McKee said, any hardship experienced by an original sponsor -- and for that matter, anyone who acquires unsold shares from an original sponsor -- is a self-imposed hardship. The recent ruling, he said, allows sponsors to recoup their bad investments from their tenants.
Robert Katz, counsel to the Queens League of Tenants in Rego Park, agreed, adding his concern that hardship increases would also be granted to owners who are not original sponsors. "We're afraid that now, anybody who buys three or four apartments in a co-op and claims a hardship will get one," Mr. Katz said. "This decision flags some very dangerous and very vulnerable areas for abuse of the rent laws."
Co-op experts take a different view of the decision.
"It's a double-edged sword," said Stuart Saft, chairman of the Council of New York Cooperatives.
On the one hand, Mr. Saft said, the ruling could help co-ops that have taken back large blocks of unsold shares from sponsors. Many such buildings, he said, are now absorbing significant monthly shortfalls resulting from the difference between the maintenance fees due on unsold apartments and the stabilized rents the occupants are paying. The ruling, he said, might allow such co-ops to eliminate some of that shortfall.
On the other hand, he said, the ruling could exacerbate an existing problem in buildings with a many unsold apartments in the hands of original sponsors or investors.
"One of the biggest problems we've seen in the last few years are sponsors selling 25 or 30 percent of their units and then refusing to convert any more," he said, adding that in many buildings, sponsors or investors were holding unsold units until the original tenant moved out and then renting the apartments out at market rates.
"The people who bought in the building are then unable to sell or get refinancing because a majority of the building is still rental," Mr. Saft said. A hardship increase, he said, may make it even easier for sponsors or investors to hold on to unsold units until the regulated tenant moves out, or may even encourage the tenant to move out sooner, leaving the owner with a lucrative deregulated apartment.
As a result, Mr. Saft said, "the ruling cuts both ways so you have to analyze each situation individually."
Arthur Zabarkes, the director of the real estate institute at New York University, said that concerns about the impact of the ruling were probably exaggerated. "I believe it will be irrelevant," Mr. Zabarkes said, "because a comparative hardship increase is virtually impossible to get."
Mr. Zabarkes, who worked for the owner of 203-205 East 72d Street and shepherded the hardship application through the housing agency, said that it was extraordinarily difficult for an owner to accumulate the documentation necessary for a comparative hardship.
At least six years of records are necessary, he said, so that the agency can compare the required "three-year base period" ( usually the first three years of ownership) with a "three-year test period" (the most recent three-year period) to determine whether the owner is losing money. "Even though we broke ground on a lot of this," he said, "it's still enormously time-consuming and difficult and expensive."
Nevertheless, most experts interviewed for this article said they expected a significant number of hardship applications to be filed.
Still, even successful applicants will ultimately have to deal with tenants like Mrs. Finkle.
"They say I owe them $3,887," Mrs. Finkle said. "Well, let me tell you something: they'll whistle Dixie a long time before I pay that."

HEADLINE: Q. & A.

 BODY:

Paying Interest On Interest
 
Q What is meant by negative amortization? Under what types of purchase money formats will it occur? . . . Erica W. Potts, Manhattan.
 
A Edward T. Braverman, a Manhattan real estate lawyer, said that a negative amortization mortgage is one on which the required monthly payment is less than what would normally result from the actual interest rate being charged. The difference is added to the loan, thereby increasing the principal balance by the amount of unpaid interest, until a predetermined ceiling has been reached. 
 "In effect," Mr. Braverman said, "the borrower is paying interest on interest."
A negative amortization mortgage can be either a fixed-rate or an adjustable-rate mortgage, he said.
With fixed-rate negative amortization mortgages, Mr. Braverman said, the mortgage payments increase over the life of the loan. As a result, he said, the early payments are set at an amount that is less than what the fixed rate would require and the later payments are set at an amount that is higher, eventually amortizing the entire loan.
With adjustable-rate negative amortization mortgages, Mr. Braverman said, although the interest rate is changed periodically, the monthly payment is kept constant and usually below the interest that would otherwise be charged. The difference between what was actually paid and what should have been paid is then added to the principal balance of the loan.
In either case, Mr. Braverman said, such mortgages should be approached with caution.
"It is a product by which lenders entice buyers into the mortgage market at a time when high interest rates might otherwise prevent a buyer from qualifying for a loan," he said.
 
Who Can Own Co-op Shares
 
Q Are individuals the only ones who can own shares in a co-op? Or can other entities such as corporations and limited partnerships also own shares? . . . Mike Lichtman, Manhattan.
 
A Marc J. Luxemburg, president of the Council of New York Cooperatives, said that before 1986, Federal tax laws allowed owners of co-ops to take homeowner deductions on their tax returns only if the shares were owned by "individuals," meaning human beings. Accordingly, he said, virtually all co-ops prohibited corporations, partnerships and trusts from owning shares.
In 1986, however, the tax laws were amended to allow co-op owners to claim homeowner deductions if the owner was a "person," a term that for tax purposes includes "legal entities" such as corporations, partnerships and trusts, as well as human beings.
Notwithstanding that change, Mr. Luxemburg said, most co-ops continue to prohibit "legal entities" from owning shares.
"A cooperative is designed to be an owner-occupied residence," Mr. Luxemburg said. "And by definition, a 'legal entity' cannot physically occupy an apartment as its home."
Co-ops, Mr. Luxemberg said, are not intended to be vehicles for tax, business or estate planning -- they are intended to be cooperatively managed residences for shareholders. Accordingly, he said, most co-ops continue to require that apartments only be owned by individuals.
