HEADLINE: Islander, Insurer and Business Maverick

BYLINE: By BILL RYAN 

 BODY:
THREE three decades ago, Robert S. Weiss of Stamford saw a little ad in the Sunday newspaper. An island in Connecticut was for sale and he was intrigued. He had spent more than four years in the Navy during the Korean conflict, part of that as the captain of a small landing craft, and thought an island would be delightful to have as a refuge from the trials of his fledgling insurance agency.
"I thought it might be be one of the Thimble Islands" south of Branford in Long Island Sound, he says today. He was far off course. The water wasn't even salt. 
 The island was well inland, in Lake Pocotopaug, in the town of East Hampton in eastern Connecticut, sort of a frontier for someone who had grown up in Fairfield County. It was an area so unfamiliar he had to look it up on a map.
As he tells the story, he decided to check the island anyway, piled his wife and three young children in the car over the weekend and drove to East Hampton. He discovered that the five-acre island contained an abandoned Boy Scout camp that was overgrown and pretty much of a mess. The asking price was $150,000.
He decided to make an offer of $25,000 which surely no one would take seriously. Indeed, the offer was greeted by the agent with derision. Mr. Weiss answered that the agent was obligated to at least present the offer to the owners.
Shortly, he said, he heard directly from the Boy Scout council that owned the island. It would take the $25,000. "It was such a suprise," he said, "my wife thought the island might be sinking."
It wasn't, but there was a problem. "I had no money," Mr. Weiss said, and bank after bank looked askance. "They said they didn't give mortgages on abandoned islands."
Finally, he struck pay dirt. The head of Middletown Savings Bank agreed to give him a mortgage of $15,000, which left him only $10,000 short of island buying. He pressed on, returning to the Boy Scout council with a new proposition: that it put up a $10,000 second mortgage on the property. The council agreed. Now he was rolling.
He went back to the Middletown Savings with a new proposition. How about adding a construction mortgage so he could build some rental cottages on the island? The bank said it would finance one cottage and when it was built and rentable, would finance another.
What Mr. Weiss had done was buy an island for no money down at all, with financing to build on it. And over several years, he did. "My kids were told that when we went to the island it was work first and then play," he said. The island was cleared of brush and debris, five rental cottages were erected, and the scout camp's 40- by 80-foot mess hall was converted into a retreat for the Weiss family, with a main room big enough to hold a dance.
To have a base for working on the island, Mr. Weiss bought a tiny cottage on the lakeshore, eventually replacing it with a showplace year-round home, complete with a putting green leading to the water. The putting green is strictly for guests because he has never played golf. He considers that a waste of time.
He seldom wastes time, believing explicitly in the work ethic and that if you really want something it is within reach.
His insurance company is the leading current example of that credo.
Five years ago, in 1990, Mr. Weiss created Connecticut Life and Casualty, the state's first chartered insurance company in more than a century. And he did it at what certainly looked like one of the worst possible times.
The state's insurance industry was in disarray, a condition that has continued since. In Hartford, a city that touts itself as the insurance capital of the world, layoffs became the rule Takeovers and mergers with out-of-staters obscured mainstays like Travelers and Phoenix mutual.
Into this economic stew Mr. Weiss launched Connecticut Life and Casualty, with headquarters in one of the state's more depressed small cities, Meriden.
As Robert Weiss tells it, the secret has been hard work and a zest for competition, things the big insurance companies have not been noted for.
More than half of the insurance sold in the state is sold by independent agents and this implies a good competitive market, he explains. But it isn't competitive, he charges -- the giant insurance companies buy the loyalty of "independent" agents by paying them high commissions, costs that are passed right on to consumers.
Mr. Weiss should know, having run an agency in Stamford for many years, during which time he became progressively disenchanted, and a vocal critic of the way the insurance industry conducted itself.
Particularly, he said, he found the "agents of record" practice odious. This comes into play when one agent sells liability insurance for a town or city, becoming the municipality's agent of record. The agent then feeds off some of the profit to other casualty and property agents in the area.
In Stamford, Mr. Weiss said, "The first time I got a check for $65, then the next year it was more than twice that. I felt it was money for nothing and I sent it back. Then The Stamford Advocate ran a story about the system and said that more than 100 Stamford agents got money from the agent of record. I called them up and said, 'Not me,' and they ran a correction."
What bothered him even more, he said, was that no matter how badly insurance companies were run they could do no wrong.
"If their investments went bad, they just raised their rates to consumers," he said. "If someone had a good driving record, or if someone made sure the house was safe, it made no difference. The rates went up. And there was no competition. The rates all went up at once. What other industry could do this?" It was not really a question.
For years, he said, he had been bothering an old friend, an investment banker in Stamford, with his dismal views of the insurance companies and one day the friend responded with a suggestion: "Why don't you start your own insurance business?' "
So he did. He went to the state's Insurance Commissioner in 1989, to discover that he was the first person to apply for an insurance charter in 103 years.
In 1990, armed with his charter and $2 million in financing from Fleet Bank, he divested himself of his Stamford operation, opened Connecticut Life and Casualty offices in the old International Silver Company building off Route 5 in Meriden and moved to the house with the putting green in East Hampton. The pontoon-boat ride to his island takes less than five minutes.
His is not a traditional insurance company by any means. Mostly it sells its policies over the phone. Then, in an effort to get to know the objects of its insurance -- and cut back on losses -- it sends its inspectors to look over the houses and cars the company is asked to insure.
"When was the last time someone from an insurance company actually showed up to see your house or car?" Mr. Weiss asks.
The inspections, in fact, do startle some people. "A few wives have asked if we could put some job down on the list required for insurance that their husbands have been promising to do but never get around to doing. The first time it happened, I thought someone was kidding."
But overall, he said, customers, "tell us they're grateful when we find deficiences such as leaks in a furnace that could be life threatening."
Today Mr. Weiss is responsible for a weekly payroll of 125 people, including some working in a health care plan, Connecticut HealthPlan, that he he has also started up at his Meriden headquarters. From the start, Connecticut Life and Casualty has aimed at "the middle of the market" in casualty insurance, he said. "We are not looking for the high-priced home but for moderate home owners. And we don't skim."
Skimming, in insurance parlance, means taking only low-risk business. "We underwrite people," Mr. Weiss insists. "People want safe homes and we show them how to make their homes safe. If they meet our qualifications, we give them the lowest insurance rates in the state and then hold the rates there."
And, he added, it did not take a financial genius to work out the system. "If a dummy like me can do it, something's wrong with the industry."
He admits that he is not on exactly friendly terms with other officials in the industry and has complained about being badmouthed by some.
Competitors, he said, have told prospective clients that he is underfinanced, which he denies, and that his company does not have a good rating. The latter charge was particularly insidious, he said, because insurance companies are not rated for their first five years.
When Connecticut Life and Casualty was rated for the first time this year, by A.M. Best, it received a B++, or very good.
Of the other insurers, he says: "I don't go to dinner parties wih them." In fact, in an industry known for its multitude of organizations and associations, he belongs to none. "I'm not interested in joining."
This year, for the first time, a state insurance commissioner, George M. Reider Jr., is holding regular public forums around the state so consumers can criticize insurance company policies and make suggestions for change.
Robert Weiss, business maverick, is all for that.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Robert S. Weiss, head of a five-year-old business called Connecticut Life and Casualty, on the water in East Hampton. (Don Pollard for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Commercial Property: Government Leases;
When Albany Pulls the Plug on the Rent

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
TRINITY REAL ESTATE and a state agency were pretty close to closing a deal for what Walter F. Spardel, Trinity's managing director, calls a "substantial amount of space" at 345 Hudson Street, near King Street. Yes, the state was insisting on the standard executory clause that allows governments to break a lease without penalty if the tenant agency loses its financing. But with no state bankruptcy looming, that seemed pretty remote, so Trinity settled for a modicum of added financial protection if the lease is broken.
But that was before the state lowered the boom on 315 Park Avenue South, the 24th Street building that for two decades has been home to the State University of New York's College of Optometry. This summer the state Legislature passed a bill that ends financing for the rent next July, eight years before the lease expires. Now Mr. Spardel is holding out for wording that says that, if the state ends its lease, Trinity will be reimbursed for any unamortized portion of brokerage commissions and costs of customizing the space. 
 "At best, this will add 30 or 60 days to our negotiations," Mr. Spardel said. "But without this protection, this deal will not go through."
The state's short-term motives are clear. It wants to move the optometry school to 33 West 42d Street, which the state owns. That, in turn, would make it fiscally feasible for the Graduate Center of the City University of New York, that building's sole tenant, to move to condominium space at 371 Fifth Avenue, the former B. Altman building at 34th Street.
The moves will save the state some $7 million a year in rent at 315 Park. But landlords and brokers caution that they will bring some costly problems of their own.
"I wonder if the state factored in litigation costs when it figured what it was saving," said Michael T. Cohen, president of Williams Real Estate, who is certain the owners of 315 Park will sue. "And it has jeopardized its off-balance-sheet financing, since every landlord will be reluctant to lay out money to improve state space now."
In fact, some realtors wonder whether it makes sense to rent to the state at all. "State agencies bring a lot of traffic to a building, and rarely turn out to be upscale tenants that really improve the property," said Bruce Mosler, vice chairman of the Galbreath Company. "Now they've made themselves even more undesirable."
Indeed, across the city, landlords who had welcomed government tenants for their seeming stability are thinking twice about the terms under which they will let them in. They say they always trusted the state to invoke the executory clause only if an agency itself lost its funding, not just because they did not like paying above-market rents. Now, they say, that trust is gone.
"It is a really shortsighted, bad decision for the state to cancel that lease," said Douglas Durst, president of the Durst Organization. "Now we wouldn't rent to a state agency without making sure the provisions for cancellation were ironclad, that technical loopholes were closed as tightly as possible. And we certainly wouldn't give them a big contribution to work now."
EVEN less adamant landlords are less enthusiastic about state tenants now. "You still get a great tenant who you know will be able to pay its rent," said Arthur L. Bocchi, a vice president at Sumitomo Realty who handles leasing at 666 Fifth Avenue, at 52d Street. "But now we'd fight for specific language that says that, if the agency is still in existence, the state can't invoke the right to terminate."
The negative impact on the state economy may extend well beyond its ability to strike real estate deals, said Larry Silverstein, a prominent New York owner who still hopes the state will reconsider its actions.
"This affects the credibility of the state as a place in which to do business as well as an entity with whom to do business," he said. "It can cause businesses to question the merit of coming here or of staying here."
The budding landlord revolt provides cold comfort to Stephen M. Mullins, a general partner in a Chicago group that owns 315 Park Avenue South. The optometry school occupied 70 percent of his 300,000-square-foot building, and its lease was the collateral for its financing.
The state, he says, is paying an annual rent of more than $35 a square foot, rising to $40 before its lease ran out. In this market, he doubts he could get $25 a square foot for the space. And bringing in a new tenant would mean paying new brokerage commissions, as well as $30 or $40 a foot to customize the space. In this situation, Mr. Mullins said, he could be forced to put the building into bankruptcy. "If our lenders don't cooperate, we could lose the building," he said.
Mr. Mullins says that, in the past, he offered to reduce the rent substantially if the state signed a 50-year lease. And he is still willing to sell the state the space as a condominium. He also retains hope that the state will find another agency or department to put into the space for the rest of the lease. But if that does not happen, Mr. Mullins says, he will sue.
State officials say they do not understand what the hoopla is about. While he could not cite a specific incident, Kenneth Goldfarb, a State University spokesman, said that "the executory clause is in all state contracts, and it has been enforced in the past."
Edward C. Sullivan, a state assemblyman who sponsored the definancing bill, insists that the state "researched the lease" thoroughly, and is within its rights in terminating. "Both the optometry school and the Graduate Center need to expand, and this way we are saving money in the process," he said. "The ultimate beneficiaries are the taxpayers of New York."
Not surprisingly, few New York realtors agree with that stance. Several landlords, including Mr. Mullins, say that politics, not economics, guided the state. "The benefactors of this whole deal are the owners of the B. Altman building, and they are highly politically connected," Mr. Mullins said.
In fact, numerous landlords suggest that it was such political clout that kept the Real Estate Board of New York from staging a loud protest on Mr. Mullins's behalf. While Steven Spinola, the board's president, says that is not true, he does say that the Altman building's importance to the city's economy colored his thinking as well as the state's.
"We are not happy with what took place, but my conversations with the state give me confidence that this is a unique situation, not the beginning of a trend towards ending leases prematurely," Mr. Spinola said. "Without this project, we would have had a major white elephant in the middle of 34th Street, the part that really connects the East Side to the West Side."
THAT, of course, is the stance that Peter L. Malkin, the Altman building's general partner, is taking. "The idea that no one wants to offend me is flattering, but it certainly has no basis in fact," he said.
Mr. Malkin also said that executory clauses were exercised to save rent money far more often than most landlords wanted to believe. In fact, he said he got skewered once, too. About five years ago, he says, Congress de-authorized financing to the United Nations for several condominiums it was renting from Mr. Malkin, leaving him with lots of empty residential space in a depressed market. "We'd bought the apartments subject to long-term leases to the U.S. Government figuring, what could be more secure than that?" he recalled.
Whether they engineered the musical space chairs or not, Mr. Malkin and his partners clearly are the major beneficiaries of the state's actions. They have turned the vacant Altman building into a government condominium. The state has bought 110,000 square feet of space for Oxford University Press, and another 213,000 square feet for the New York Public Library's Science, Industry and Business Library. The Graduate Center is scheduled to go into the building's remaining 375,000 square feet.
All the sour notes have not ruined the optometry school's sweet feeling about its impending move. The Legislature has authorized up to $17 million to equip 33 West 42d Street with a diagnostic and treatment center, wet and dry labs, a small-animal facility, all things the Graduate Center never needed. And the building already has a 260-seat auditorium and a big board room suitable for conferences and receptions as well as a broadcast studio, now used by City University broadcasting, that the school hopes to use for "distance education," or broadcasting courses over the airwaves.
"These facilities are real gems," said Dr. Alden N. Haffner, the school's president. "They far exceed what we have now."

Altman building at Fifth and 34th. (Photographs by Ruby Washington/The New York Times)

SECTION: Section 9; Page 1; Column 2; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 1987 words

HEADLINE: Time Shares: New Players Seek to Create A New Image

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO 

 BODY:
BRUCE HESSE is knowledgeable about money matters. He is a certified public accountant and a finance manager for Johnson & Johnson, the huge pharmaceutical concern in New Brunswick, N.J. His background, perhaps, explains the raised eyebrows he encounters when he tells friends and colleagues that three years ago he bought a two-bedroom "time share," in Palm Springs, Calif.
"Some people do think it's unusual," he said. "But I looked at it as purchasing vacation time in the future, and I weighed what a first-class hotel room would cost me over the next 30 years. 
 "I didn't do a formal spreadsheet," he added. "But I did do some calculations, and I figured that I would get my money back after about 15 years."
Time shares, a concept once thought to be little more than a real estate fad (and in many cases a real-estate scam) from the 1970's, appear to be making a comeback of sorts in the 90's, much to the dismay, it must be said, of many time share owners who may still regret their purchases.
"I've definitely been burned," said Laurie Edwards, a marketing consultant in Scarsdale, N.Y., who paid $9,000 for a studio time share in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, eight years ago. "The economics don't really make sense, the maintenance keeps climbing, and you are locked into the same place unless you want to pay extra fees."
Unlike the time shares of the past, however, that were often sold by fast-talking, fly-by-night salesmen, today's time shares often carry the imprimatur of established hotel and resort companies like Hyatt, Westin or the Walt Disney Company, which opened its 496-unit Disney Vacation Club in Orlando, Fla., in 1991 and is building other time share complexes in Newport Beach, Calif., and Vero Beach, Fla.
Marriott International, the hotel chain, was one of the first big names to enter the time-share business and it now owns 20 percent of the worldwide market, a market that has grown from $500 million to $5 billion over the last 15 years. Marriott entered the market in 1984 and now operates 29 resorts in 12 cities and has sold units to 65,000 owners.
"Many people are more comfortable with time shares, and the industry has matured," said George Leposky, director of communications for Interval International of Miami, a vacation exchange service for time-share buyers. "And with well-known brand names, such as Marriott and Hyatt and Disney, involved, people know those names and they are comfortable doing business with them.
"By extension, if those names are involved that must mean the rest of the industry is O.K., too," he added.
Not all time shares are as reliable or quality-oriented as Disney or Marriott, however. Complaints still abound about overselling of units, bait-and-switch tactics, embezzlement and fraud.
"I think they should be illegal with some of the nightmares we have experienced," said Erin Branham of Fort Worth. "My husband bought one in St. Petersburg, Fla., and the owner-manager of the building embezzled the insurance and tax money, and then a hurricane tore up the roof.
"Finally, the owners organized and got rid of this guy, but the state of Florida put a tax lien on the property and of course the roof was not covered by insurance as it was never paid," she added. "The only way to make up for this missing money was with 'special assessments' to the tune of about $1,500 over 3 years -- in addition to the regular maintenance fee of $250 per year.
"My husband, being young and fresh out of college, was duped into buying this place for $7,000 with a 14 percent interest rate over seven years -- all this without ever seeing it," she said. "They promised him a free trip there, but when he tried to use it he was told the airlines or travel agency were bankrupt! They are now selling the same unit for $1,000."
By the mid-80's, though, most states had started regulating time-share sales more stringently. Many states now requiring the salespeople to be licensed, developers registered, bonding an escape clauses in contracts to allow buyers to bail out of a deal if they change their mind.
"What you truly have is an industry that is coming of age," said Tom Franks, president of the American Resort Development Association, a trade group in Washington. "Given the realities of the economy of last five to seven years, with inflation what it has been, what we have been driven to is quality. The product has gotten better and more sophisticated."
Time sharing is a form of ownership in which the buyer spends a designated week or weeks each year in a specific unit at a specific property, usually a one to three-bedroom furnished condominium. Time shares, however, can also be sold for spaces as small as lots at campgrounds or even for shares of boats.
In some cases, the buyer will own an individual interest in the entire complex. Other times, the buyer does not actually own anything but only has a right to use the property for specific period.
Time shares with large companies -- now often called "vacation ownership or interval ownership" rather than time shares -- are sometimes more flexible.
At the Disney Vacation Clubs, for example, buyers purchase points rather than blocks of time. The points can be used at other Disney properties or traded for rooms at other time-share resorts through organizations like Interval International or Resort Condominiums International. The average time-share costs $15,000 for a week at a Disney Vacation Club with annual maintenance fees or dues of $650. (The ownership lasts until 2042.)
If that sounds steep, consider that daily rental rates for the Disney units currently range from $190 to $755 a day depending on the size of the unit and the season.
Season is, perhaps, the most important factor in determining cost. At the Marriott Mountain Valley Lodge in Breckinridge, Colo., a week in summer in a studio or one-bedroom unit costs $7,000 to $9,000. A week at Christmas, however, runs $17,900 to $22,000.
Typically, a week at a time-share resort costs an average of $9,500, according to the American Resorts Development Association, the trade group representing time shares. The term is usually 25 to 50 years, and there is an annual maintenance fee, which can range from $200 to more than $1,000, depending on the resort.
Mr. Hesse's time share with Marriott cost $11,000 with annual fees of $300. The plan includes the ability to accumulate points and exchange them for credit with other Marriott properties.
"We have never been back to Palm Springs," said Mr. Hesse, who lives in Tewksbury, N.J., and vacationed this year in Williamsburg, Va., with his wife, Rosemary, and their children, William, Robert and Edward. "Next year, we're going to Hawaii."
EXCHANGING units is not always so easy, of course. And using a service like Interval International costs money. The 19-year-old firm charges an annual membership fee of $66, and fees of $89 ($109 for foreign) to exchange units.
The biggest complaint, by far, however, is that time shares are difficult to sell. "We bought our time shares in Las Vegas about 10 years ago for $7,500 each, and they are now selling in the same area for $11,500, yet we can not find anyone in the area who wants to handle resale on time shares even though we have said we would be happy to get out only what we have put into these units," said Larry Snyder of Reno, Nev. "They keep telling us they are going to start a resale program, but that been for the past two years."
He added that he will not pay to list his time share, which has a $200 annual maintenance fee, nor pay someone up front to try and sell it. "Once sold, however, I will pay a reasonable fee for that service," he said. "Like maybe six percent of the $15,000 or an agreed-on fee for a lesser amount."
IN recent years, there have been a growing number of swindles involving guarantees to find buyers for time shares. According to the Association of Real Estate License Law Officials in Centerville, Utah, thousands of time-share owners have been duped out of as much as $15 million.
"People will find out where the time shares are that aren't selling and people that have had them for sale for a lot of years and can't sell them," said Charles Heitbrink, president of the association. "Then they will notify them by card that they have have buyers and a national listing service and guarantee them that they will be able to sell it. Of course, there's usually an upfront fee of anywhere from $395 to $1,000 -- and they get it; it's a big business."
He added that are some legitimate brokers who do list and resell time shares and sometimes they require an upfront fee. "The key is that they never guarantee the sale," Mr. Heitbrink said. "No one can guarantee the sale."
Some of the larger time-share companies, like Marriott, have their own resale programs that begin when a resort is sold out, as they are in Orlando and Hilton Head, S.C.
"People can probably expect to get 70 percent to 110 percent of what they paid for them," said Jim Miller, national director of resales for Marriott. "Industrywide, the average is probably 50 percent or less."
Not everyone is interested in selling, though. Mr. Hesse, for instance, said he hopes to hand his unit down to his children. "It is transferable and ours is an actual deed on the property," he said. "It's not just for 30 years. It is good in perpetuity."
A recent survey by the resorts association showed that 80 percent of time-share owners cited the exchange opportunity as a primary motivation for buying a time share. Unlike other real estate transactions, however, time shares should not be considered an investment. Reselling them can be next to impossible, unless one has bought at one of the top resorts in the country.
"There is no question at all that this is a product meant to be used -- we are sternly against investment pitches as most people in real estate are today," Mr. Franks said. "This product is a prepaid vacation package with a lot of nice amenities."
Time sharing began in the French Alps, and was exported to the United States in the 70's. The American Resorts Development Association reports that more the number of households owning time shares has increased from 100,000 in 1978 to 1.6 million today.
The popularity of time shares nowadays comes, in part, because of demographics. The Baby Boom, now ages 32 to 50, is entering what is widely thought to be the prime age group for second or vacation home ownership, 45 to 64.
Many people today, though, are skittish about putting money into real estate, largely because of the decline in prices in the late 1980's and early 1990's, and a small investment in a time share may suit them the best.
Also, because the hotel industry has been so weak in the last few years, it has been aggressively moving into the time-share business.
TIME shares are also making inroads into places not normally known for them, like cities. Time share projects are being planned in Boston and New York, for example.
In New York, developer Ian Bruce Eichner is planning to convert at least 10 floors of the 33-floor Park Central Hotel at 870 Seventh Avenue at 56th Street, across from Carnegie Hall, into the city's first time-share condominiums.
He projected that the units may sell for about $15,000 per week with maintenance fees of about $575 a year. Mr. Eichner bought the hotel last month for $60 million.
In Boston, the Beal Company and Marriott are planning on building time-share condominiums in that city's historic Custom House Tower.
The Disney Company is also contemplating a time-share project at Eighth Avenue and 42d Street, but a go-ahead on that project is still probably several years down the road.
"We have had these urban time-shares in San Francisco for awhile," Mr. Franks said. "And I think we will soon start to see more of them in other cities. I think it will be quite popular with foreign tourists."

HEADLINE: ON POLITICS;
A Contest for Senate With Real Potential

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON; Iver Peterson is the Trenton bureau chief of The New York Times.

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
Representative Robert G. Torricelli reads a good speech, only he's not reading. The stately paragraphs, the deliberate pacing and emphatic pauses make him one of the best arguers in the state delegation, and help explain why so many in New Jersey's Democratic leadership are scurrying to make him the man to defend the Senate seat that Bill Bradley now disdains.
So when Mr. Torricelli announced that he was a candidate on Wednesday -- officially, it was only an announcement about an "exploratory" effort -- he offered an imposing roster of nearly 150 men and women from business, labor, politics and the black arts of fund-raising who have endorsed him. The announcement also offered a glimpse at what a race between Mr. Torricelli and the likely Republican nominee, Representative Dick Zimmer, would be like, and that peek should offer some heart to people who think that political debate is dead in New Jersey just because Ivy Leaguers like Mr. Bradley and former Gov. Thomas H. Kean won't run. 
 On the surface, Mr. Torricelli, of Bergen County, made it clear that he intended to run against Speaker Newt Gingrich as much as against Mr. Zimmer. Mr. Torricelli suggested that Mr. Zimmer, from Hunterdon County, is but a cat's paw for Mr. Gingrich, whose "Deep South, rural agenda" is for the first time creeping like pellagra across the Delaware River.
A Senator from New Jersey, Mr. Torricelli said, "should represent the needs of the State of New Jersey, not any alien ideology, and not the needs of the rural South." And he added, "Dick Zimmer will have to explain to the people of New Jersey why he voted against transportation funding, against environmental standards."
No one knows how popular Mr. Gingrich is in New Jersey, although the Republicans did pretty well running on the Contract With America last fall, when they picked up two House seats. Still, Mr. Zimmer showed early signs of being uncomfortable at being linked to the Speaker, or to the Deep South. He issued a statement calling Mr. Torricelli's announcement speech "sleazy" and a "smear."
It has been common for people to say that politics in the state has become too angry and too simplistic for decent and high-minded people to serve. This view suggests that with Mr. Kean and Mr. Bradley out of the way, we are left with only a bunch of street fighters and name callers, and that we will suffer for it.
Yet there is no reason to lament the prospect of a campaign between scrappers like Mr. Torricelli and Mr. Zimmer. Sure it would be rough, but it would also be about something that has been on the minds of thoughtful Americans since about 1776 -- the proper role of government.
On the right, wearing denim coveralls with the "Dixie" label, Mr. Zimmer has pretty much embraced Mr. Gingrich's fundamental argument that government has become too expensive and too meddlesome, although he protects his green flank by defending some environmental rules that Mr. Gingrich might scorn. On the left, in a sharp suit and loafers with little leather flounces, Mr. Torricelli defends what government alone can do, but he protects his right flank by supporting Mr. Gingrich's Federal income-tax cut. Each supports abortion rights.
Still, Mr. Torricelli is clearly willing to speak up for the things that taxes pay for, and in a state and region where politics has been mostly about how bad taxes are, Mr. Torricelli's stump speech would offer a welcome defense of the state.
"For more than 20 years," he said on Wednesday, "we have been waiting for someone to arrive on a white horse with a new formula for our economic and social problems. I want my campaign to be built around the fact that the only way we are going to build our econony and address our problems is to do it they way our parents and grandparents did it. It is a difficult formula -- giving our children more, not less, higher, not lower, standards. To pay the government's bills so that interest rates are reduced and businesses can afford to expand, to train our workers for the jobs of the future rather than leaving them to their own devices.
"I want to be the guy who says there's no white horse and there's no magic formula."

HEADLINE: NEWS AND TOPICS: ROAD AND RAIL;
On the Waterfront, a 20-Mile Trolley Chugs Closer to Reality

BYLINE: By DAVID W. CHEN 

 BODY:
From the 1890's to the 1930's -- Hudson County's heyday as a booming industrial and commercial center -- commuters and shoppers could hop on a trolley and ride elevated tracks from Hoboken to Jersey City. But as the Hudson River waterfront faded and crumbled, so did the county's transportation system, and the trolleys fell victim to bad times and competition from buses and highways.
Now, the trolley is poised for a comeback. 
 Last month, the Federal Transit Administration granted $50 million to the Hudson-Bergen Light Rail Transit System, a $1.3 billion project to shuttle light-rail cars, or modern trolleys, from Bayonne along the waterfront to the Vince Lombardi park-and-ride lot on the New Jersey Turnpike in Ridgefield. That brings to $108 million the money pledged so far by the Federal Government for preliminary engineering, design and environmental impact studies.
As with any project this ambitious, there are still many obstacles, chiefly the question of continued Federal financing. But New Jersey Transit, the project's sponsor, and other advocates are optimistic that ground can be broken next spring and that the first passengers can be riding by New Year's Day 2000.
"Hudson County has long needed a north-south transportation corridor; it has plenty of east-west," said Robert Janiszewski, the Hudson County Executive, one of the project's biggest proponents.
The 20.5-mile system would be built in two stages. The first, estimated to cost more than $700 million and scheduled for completion in 1999, would start at 34th Street in Bayonne and snake northward through Jersey City to the Hoboken train terminal. The second, at more than $500 million, would continue south to Fifth Street in Bayonne, and north from Hoboken through Weehawken and West New York to the Vince Lombardi lot.
In all, there would be 33 stations, 5 of which would allow transfers to ferries, buses, PATH trains and New Jersey Transit trains. Of the 20.5 miles, 15 would be on existing railroad rights-of-way, 3 would be on surface streets and only 2 would require new rights-of-way.
The hope is that 100,000 people will ride the 92 trolleys each weekday by 2010, said Frank M. Russo, senior director of new rail construction for New Jersey Transit. Fares would be competitive with those of local bus lines, he said, and there would be discounts for using the trolley in conjunction with PATH, buses, trains and ferries.
The project has been 15 years in the making, driven by concerns about air pollution and hopes of encouraging economic development on the New Jersey side of the Hudson. There were hundreds of meetings and dozens of proposals. But in 1993, the mayors of all the Hudson County municipalities, the Hudson and Bergen County executives and state officials signed an agreement committing the entire region to the project and its route.
The trolley project relies heavily on a partnership between public agencies and private companies. Rather than applying the conventional approach of waiting for state and Federal aid and building the project piecemeal, New Jersey Transit plans to encourage contractors to design and build it as quickly as possible. Congress and the State Legislature are much more likely to provide money to a project that is well under way, the reasoning goes, than to one that is in limbo as it awaits financing.
The approach has proved popular with prospective contractors. Even though New Jersey Transit will not request formal proposals until November, five groups have already expressed interest.
Still, this is a time of budget-cutting and general distaste in Congress for public-transportation projects with the word "billion" attached to their names. "In the long run, Federal funding of transit projects is very much in jeopardy," said Chris Miller of the Surface Transportation Policy Project, a nonprofit group in Washington. "When you sift through it all, it's really a fight between the outer suburbs, which are trying to get public subsidies for new highways, and the inner suburbs, which are trying to get money for transit systems."
The trolley system has local critics as well. Some are not happy with route, saying the trolleys should run through different sections of Jersey City. Others say the route should have continued north, through Edgewater and up to Tenafly.
"Down there, they already have the PATH and other rail services; over here, we have nothing," said Albert F. Cafiero, chairman of the Transit Committee of Bergen County, an advocacy group. "It's extremely disappointing."
But other transit advocates have been pleasantly surprised and look forward to the once-familiar sight of trolley cars weaving through old downtowns.
"Among projects, this one has been very smooth because it's got broad bipartisan support and it's a project that makes sense," said Janine Bauer, executive director of the Tri-State Transportation Campaign. "People are going to be option-rich in that territory."

GRAPHIC: Photo: If all goes as planned, trolleys like these, shown in an artist's rendering, will run along River Street in Hoboken by the year 2000. (New Jersey Transit)
 
Map of the proposed trolley route.

LENGTH: 3124 words

HEADLINE: Weekend Escadrille

BYLINE: By ANDREA KANNAPELL 

 BODY:
HIGH noon at Sky Manor Airport in Pittstown, and the breakfast buffet is going great guns. At least 20 people gather around the steam tables with the blue-checked tablecloths, loading and reloading their plates while they keep an eye on the big picture windows, watching the Cessnas and Pipers, and the occasional old-fashioned tail-dragger, take off and land. Nice, confident flying earns knowing nods. Takeoff too low? There is a quick, acerbic remark, a raised eyebrow. Nothing vicious: they'll be facing the same judges when they leave.
The walls are covered with framed photographs and posters of airplanes in flight. The regular menu has items like the "copilot's special" (a hamburger). But the buffet is the main attraction. Mushroom and sausage omelettes, biscuits with sausage gravy, waffles, bacon, sausage, fruit salad, chocolate pudding, whipped cream, orange juice, tomato juice, grapefruit juice, coffee, soda. All you can eat and drink, $7.99. 
 Of course, the main course is outside the big picture windows, between the 2,438-foot runway and the tie-down area, where the fuel pump reads $1.85 a gallon, a bargain price. "I'll burn $50 of fuel to save a nickel," says Ben Diss, 31, a computer expert for Lord & Taylor and a devoted weekend flier.
Boy, is he not alone!
There are about 350 airports in New Jersey. Nearly 50 of them are something like Sky Manor: small, often privately run, with pilot shops and flight schools; some have restaurants, one has a plane-shaped pool. And particularly in these next two months, while the air cools and the sun burns and the weather stays relatively dry and predictable, they are the haunts of a thousand variations on Mr. Diss. These are pleasure-loving but precise-minded men, and a small but growing number of women, who relish the aerial short cut to Block Island or Nantucket -- or who just wake up on a bright morning and feel like bouncing around. In which case, any excuse to take off will do.
 Take last Sunday. Ben Rosenberg, 41, the owner of a Hoboken software company, left the Essex County Airport, in West Caldwell, in his new Mooney for the 45-minute hop to Hershey, Pa., where he would take his 6-year-old twins to an amusement park.
Mr. Diss and his wife, Melodee, borrowed a friend's plane from Teterboro to take a couple of visitors on an air tour of the state.
At Sky Manor, Rich Mosciano, 46, was taking time off from his job as an AT&T vice president to put his aerobatic-certified red-and-white Pitts through some confidence maneuvers: snap rolls, hammerheads, barrel rolls, loops, inversions.
And Marty Kress, who runs a mechanic shop there, and his friend Laura Gloshinski were settling into a home-built aluminum tail-dragger (a small tail wheel instead of nose wheel), heading out for a visit to her family at the Jersey shore.
Jehd Webster and his buddy Steve Smith might have had the slimmest excuse of the day: they left from Greenwood Lake in Mr. Webster's Cessna 172, heading up to Granville, N.Y., near the Vermont border, because Mr. Webster had heard that the water there was exceptional. And he likes water. "I had one glass," he said. "It was good."
This is not a cheap hobby. The pilots make self-deprecating jokes about their "$100 hamburgers," and acknowledge, if not wallow in, the false economy of flying two hours to get cheap fuel. But for most weekend fliers, the destination is simply a flight requirement. The point is to fly. And to talk about flying. And then to fly some more.
 
Safety First
 Sunday, 10 A.M., Teterboro Airport. Ben Diss goes through the preflight checklist. He circles the Mooney 201, checking flaps, eying the bolts, looking for bird nests in the tail. Would that be dangerous? Like most pilots, he speaks deliberately, with a somewhat practical attitude about life-and-death issues: "Uh, that could be terminal."
There is always an oil check, just like one for a car, and a fuel check. Mr. Diss, who has analyzed accident data for Aviation Consumer magazine, says the most common mistakes are running out of gas and flying into a cloud without being trained to fly by instruments. Safety, he believes, is training and proficiency. "The pilot makes the difference," he says.
After 10 minutes or so on the plane's exterior, Mr. Diss climbs inside, then invites his passengers to board. Another checklist, and then he looks around for errant pedestrians. "Clear prop!" he bellows out his window, just like a golfer's "Fore!"
Then a call to the tower for clearance to taxi. Another request for takeoff. A final check of the electrical system, ignition system, propeller controls. And then, in one unbroken sweep, he rolls out to the runway, levers up to full throttle and lets the airspeed hit 60 knots. The nose goes up, the plane follows, and shortly before 11 A.M., his flying day has begun.
 
'It's Exhilarating'
 Melodee Diss, 35, is a biologist who tests polio vaccine before it is distributed. She is enthusiastic about flying, though not about the sharp banks that her husband loves -- they produce what she calls "unpleasant physiological effects." Of New Jersey's private pilots, who number about 6,000, no more than 5 percent are women, according to the Ninety Nines, an international organization of female pilots. Mrs. Diss is working toward her pilot's license, and her role today is pilotage: identifying the plane's location on the topographical maps, called sectional maps, that specify airspace rules.
Today's plan has some definites and some not-so-definites. There's the breakfast fly-in at Sky Manor, with at least two other planeloads of pilot pals expected. After that, some of the breakfast crowd are going to head up to Bar Harbor, Me. But others might find it more fun to cruise around New Jersey. Unlike commercial airliners, which fly according to stringent instrument rules and must preplan their paths, small planes fly on more relaxed visual flight rules.
In the direction of Newark, La Guardia and Kennedy Airports, New Jersey airspace ranks as some of the most complicated and regulated in the world. But heading west and south, the skies empty and the pilot's ironclad attention can throttle down to mere caution. And that is more conducive to the pure joy of flying.
Not that these flying folk are much good at explaining what that joy consists of.
"The freedom," says Mr. Diss, who detests commercial airlines. "You don't have to sit in the cattle car and be at somebody else's mercy."
"It's like a drug," says Markus Buttikofer, a 37-year-old Swiss-born chef who came to the United States 18 years ago and now runs the Mac Dan flight school at the Essex County Airport. He remembers a recent flight above a solid carpet, no, a pillow of clouds, with just the tops of the World Trade Center towers sticking out, set off against a vivid blue sky. "And every 45 seconds, there's an airplane popping out of the pillow from La Guardia. It's one of the greatest memories I have."
"It's an addiction; it's relaxation kind of thing," adds Adam Gnall, 36, a senior flight instructor at Mac Dan and a graduate student in psychology. "I couldn't put my finger on it exactly."
"It's exhilarating, quite frankly," says Mr. Rosenberg.
Sonja Steeves, the 16-year-old daughter of Tom Steeves, who runs a full-service shop at Greenwood Lake, frowns in concentration as she answers. "It's like a different feeling," she says. "It's different from driving a car. You're, like, free. You can go basically wherever you want."
More than one flier points to such chroniclers of flight as Antoine de Saint-Exupery and Charles Lindbergh.
"Night already shadows the eastern sky," Lindbergh begins in "The Spirit of St. Louis," his memoir. "To my left, low on the horizon, a thin line of clouds is drawing on its evening sheath of black. A moment ago, it was burning red and gold. I look down over the side of my cockpit at the farmlands of Central Illinois. Wheat shocks are gone from the fields. Close, parallel lines of the seeder, across a harrowed strip, show where winter planting has begun. A threshing crew on the farm below is quitting work for the day. Several men look up and wave as my mail plane roars overhead. Trees and buildings and stacks of grain stand shadowless in the diffused light of evening. In a few minutes it will be dark, and I'm still south of Peoria."
But that isn't the world the modern recreational pilot sees. When Ben and Melodee Diss leave Teterboro, they fly low, like Lindbergh, between the clouds and the cloud-shadowed earth. They see green fields marked off by lines of trees; farmland in curving sweeps of sandy brown and yellow ; brown-rimmed reservoirs that testify to drought amid mossy-looking expanses of woods. They see the jutting smokestacks of huge factories; stark apartment towers and the spread of suburban geometry, interrupted by aqua patches of backyard pools.
It's not just the view from the air that is treasured. Small airports make great family outings. Neighborhood folks come. They bring their children. They bring their grandchildren.
Sky Manor, in Hunterdon County, has several benches along the runway. Milton Smith, 77, and his wife, Aletta, live nearby. They were there on Saturday. "I'm just enjoying the clouds and the blue skies and the comfortable temperature," he said, hiking up his belt. "I was a pilot in World War II -- B-24 bombers, biggies! And you don't get it out of your system."
 
Brunch or Burgers
 Mr. Diss checks the bright orange windsock at Sky Manor, announces his arrival on a channel monitored by other planes in the area, and banks downwind, then crosswind, before turning into a final approach. Touchdown is smooth, and he gets a round of applause from his passengers. "Thank you," he says, smiling with satisfaction.
He taxis over to the parking area, cuts back fuel until the engine dies, and methodically shuts down the plane. There is a predictable 40-minute wait for Pete McWilliams ("He's always late!" the Disses say), and then a crowd of eight heads indoors for brunch or burgers, and an hour of talk crowded with acronyms and inside jokes.
"Hey, Scotty, did you bring the beast?" Mr. Diss teases Scott Dyer, a bearded 39-year-old in shorts and a golf shirt. "The barge," Mr. Dyer corrects him, referring to his Cessna 210, a six-seater that flies like a truck. Mr. McWilliams rubs at his knee. "Darn! Knelt in the oil again." His girlfriend laughs.
The pilots check out the day's arrivals and departures out the window, tease the waitress, trade updates on what they're flying, who saw a rare plane for sale somewhere. They talk angrily about how the suburbs keep encroaching on small airports, filled with people who don't care at all about flying but care a great deal about peace and quiet.
That's a frustration shared by Governor Whitman, whose administration has been called upon frequently to mediate conflicts between municipalities and small airports. "People who build homes at the end of a runway have to understand the runway was there first," she said over the phone last week. "They really shouldn't complain, but they do."
Her father flew; her brother, Dan Todd, is a devoted flier and has run more than one New Jersey airport. Years ago, under his tutelage, Mrs. Whitman accumulated about 6 hours of flying time.
"I love flying," she said. "I love the perspective it gives you on the state, the freedom it gives you to move around."
She believes small airports are crucial to New Jersey's economy. "First, they open up the state," she explained. "In a state as crowded as this, the ability for business executives to move around freely grants them a great deal of flexibility, and that has made the state attractive for corporations. And then the recreation flier puts a great deal of money into the economy."
Ask pilots to tally the cost, and they count the plane, fuel and oil, maintenance. And then there are food bills. "Aviation is just a way to get from one meal to another," observes Dave Halpern, 32, who declines the breakfast buffet in favor of a copilot special with blue cheese.
 
Swapping Stories
 The day is waning. Some of the crowd head to Bar Harbor. Some head home. Mr. and Mrs. Diss decide to show their visitors a few more airports. At the end of the day, they're back at the northern edge of the state, at the Greenwood Lake airport.
One minute, Jehd Webster is sitting in the shadow of an enormous 50-year-old passenger plane -- a Lockheed Constellation, the last of the four-engine piston-powered airliners. The "Connie" was brought in to be a cocktail lounge in the long-ago days when the place held an amusement park. Now it's a flight shop.
The next minute, Mr. Webster, who flew to Granville for a glass of water, is standing around with three or four pilots, and the stories are flowing. There's the cheap-gas contest: Mr. Diss, who once found fuel once for $1.50 a gallon, was beaten by Mr. Webster, who'd got it for $1.47 in some distant state. A bearded German man joins in. He just landed, dropped off by the friends who just flew him back from a European trip via Iceland, Greenland and the edge of the Arctic Circle. He and Mr. Webster, it turns out, have both flown extensively in Central and South America. They compare notes on a tiny Panamanian strip.
Stories of far alternate with stories of near: there's the wealthy woman who flies out of Greenwood to Hilton Head once or twice a year just to shop. The drug trade has prompted a serious rate of airplane theft in Los Angeles, where Mr. Webster lived until a couple of years ago.
There's a wild story about an 89-year-old student pilot who had a heart attack in mid-flight, and the instructor has to crash-land the plane. But he lands so well that no one is hurt. "The pilot wasn't even hurt," Mr. Webster says. "But he was dead."
Then, while the sun goes down and the Disses get ready to head home to Teterboro, Mr. Webster tells the story of the interesting situation in April, when he and his wife were flying back from Louisiana, and an exhaust valve broke. The engine died. He really didn't want to scare his wife. "I didn't even declare an emergency," he says with the pilot's pride of calm in crisis management. "First, I want to keep her flying. Second, I didn't see the need for one; we had the airport made." Within eight minutes, they were on the ground, safe.
 
IN THEIR OWN WORDS: High-Tech or Open Cockpit, the Sky's the Limit
 Ben Rosenberg
 He concedes that his daughters might be getting a slightly skewed version of reality. "We flew to Cape May, and it took 45 minutes," says Ben Rosenberg, a 41-year-old computer executive who has a touch of Rodney Dangerfield in him. "So Kathryn, she was about 3 then, says, 'Gee, Dad, why so long today?' "
And then he and his wife, Marie, tried taking them on a car trip. "We were in the car half an hour. Rebecca says, 'Are we in Vermont yet?' We weren't even out of New Jersey yet!"
Marie, he says, is "destination-oriented." So last year, when he traded his old plane for a fast, new, sophisticated low-wing Mooney Ovation he let her choose the interior and the plane's colors: it's white-crowned, with a red body and gold stripes, sort of a Marlboro box without the black. He won't say what he paid, but the plane, with all its added avionics, is "probably worth 300K." His running cost, he calculates, is $90 to $100 an hour. But since he owns his own software company, Advanced Systems Concepts Inc., in Hoboken, that isn't a problem. And anyway, Mooney made him a great deal.
His favorite trips include a New Year's Eve jaunt to Portland, Me., to pick up 25 pounds of fresh lobster. ("It's the only time I really felt like a jet-setter," he says. "But the whole way back I had this eerie feeling they were climbing out of the back seat to come and get me.") And then a nice trip in May to take the kids to Disney World; the rent-a-car was delivered directly to the airplane.
He's protective of his passengers, giving them a safety briefing worthy of an international commercial flight. And he's very protective of his plane, which is clear when he points out the air-sick bag. "They say you can't open the plane door in flight," he says. "The speed keeps the door closed -- you don't have that strength. But if you throw up in my plane, I'll have that strength!"
On a quick tour along the Hudson last weekend, he thumbed his nose at stalled highway traffic and joyfully circled the Statue of Liberty. But like any pilot, he trains himself to be "situationally aware," meaning alert to all possible problems.
There seems to be only one topic he doesn't have a light response for.
Has he had any close calls? "Later," he answers.
Is that not something a pilot discusses while in flight? "That's correct," he says, eyes firmly ahead.

Tom Watkinson
 Here's a man who would just as soon throw the high-tech equipment out of his cockpit in favor of a simple joystick and sharp eyesight. "I like the hands-on flying," Tom Watkinson says. He shares two airplanes with his father. One is a 1967 Piper PA 28 Cherokee, the standard family plane of its time. The other is a true classic: a 1946 Piper PA 12 Supercruiser, an open cockpit tail-dragger.
"I like the Supercruiser," Mr. Watkinson says. "All that is is a stick. There's a minimum of instruments. I feel like it's real grass-roots flying." He might fly 200 hours a year, he says, but because his planes are old, slow and boarded inexpensively at the Alexandria airport, it costs him no more than $2,500 a year. That's affordable: Mr. Watkinson, who lives in Short Hills, is the Millburn Township engineer and runs a consulting firm; altogether, he earns $75,000 to $100,000 a year.
"I think I have a little bit of a barnstormer attitude," he says. "I'm not reckless, but when people started flying . . . well, now, you know, people get autopilot, and you don't have to do anything," he says with some disdain. "That's nothin'!"
He has a similar low-key approach to air travel. "I like to just go up in the air," he says. "But you feel stupid if you don't have a destination -- only because other people think you're stupid."
So he takes little jaunts to have lunch with relatives, or flies over buildings he's in the process of inspecting in the course of his work, or heads to the little grass strips that attract like-minded fliers.
"One thing, I would like to take the old plane to Alaska," he says. "Fly cross-country, then follow the old Alaska highway up. Just pack up a sleeping bag and some survival equipment."
Is that his dream trip? "Yeah," he said, "I think so."
Will he do it? "Yeah," he said, laughing, "I think so." ANDREA KANNAPELL

SECTION: Section 13WC; Page 20; Column 1; Westchester Weekly Desk

HEADLINE: ART;
Fantasy in the Bronx and Justice in White Plains

BYLINE: By VIVIEN RAYNOR

 BODY:
FANTASY versus real life: The first can be seen in the Bronx, at the Lehman College Art Gallery, the second in Westchester, at Krasdale Gallery, in White Plains.
Andrea Arroyo left her native Mexico for New York City in 1993, with the purpose of studying dance with Merce Cunningham but has since changed professions. Either that or Ms. Arroyo has found an avocation in art for, at Lehman, she is showing off her paces as a self-taught painter, having already produced a mural for a Bronx school by way of the Percent for Art Program. 
 "Mythologies," as the show is called, consists of many small scenes featuring a nymph in different roles. Here, she is a mermaid served up as part of a sushi meal, complete with chopsticks, there she is Daphne metamorphosing into a tree. Elsewhere she plays the daughters of Lot, one a redhead, the other with purple tresses, and both bearing down on their father for nefarious purposes.
But as Eve or Lilith, the subject is the same demure little nude with rubbery limbs -- an archeype whose setting can be water built up in clay or plaster, landscape similarly embossed with trees or just sky. The atmosphere is always idyllic. Colors are bright and, except where they are embellished with low relief, the surfaces are smooth; frames are painted and some appear to be hand carved. In addition to biblical stories and pagan myths, Ms. Arroyo draws inspiration from her own life as a dancer, as when she portrays a woman on a sofa contemplating Matisse's "Danse," which hangs behind her at the end of a long room carpeted in green. Other departures include faux books, like the one paying tribute to "Alice in Wonderland." This volume stands open to reveal, on one side, a niche papered with text that contains an image of Alice falling and, on the other, a melange of text, watercolor and collage in which the White Rabbit, his pocketwatch and a disproportionately large letter can be discerned. Ms. Arroyo's imagery is charming, playful and wholesome to a fault -- a winning formula these days.
Plans are afoot for the painter to talk about her accomplishment, but time and date have yet to be announced. The number to call for information is (718) 960-8732. Meanwhile, viewers may look forward to the gallery reception scheduled for Oct. 25, from 5 to 7 P.M. The show itself continues through Dec. 16.
Krasdale visitors are justified who recoil from "The Art of Justice," a show organized by Sigmund Balka, Krasdale Foods' general counsel, in collaboration with Susan Hoeltzel, who directs the gallery at Lehman. Still, those who abandon ship will miss an experience that may be without precedent in corporate territory. First, there is the title, which is doubly ironic for designating art that is mostly about injustice while suggesting that justice itself has been demoted to an art form. Second, there is the installations' general tone, which borders on the apocalyptic.
Having conceded in the briefest of introductions that this is not the kind of work displayed in corporate premises, Mr. Balka, in effect, proposes that its beholders not judge a book by its cover. He then pushes home the point by appending questions calculated to focus attention on the content of the show rather than its unprepossessing appearance. For example, he asks visitors to decide if they feel they have ever been unjustly treated, to consider which are the kinds of injustice that can be dealt with most effectively and so on.
Considering that nothing, be it food or news, reaches the consumer unprocessed, Mr. Balka deserves credit for trying to encourage independent thought. Nevertheless, the odds against his succeeding -- long enough to begin with -- are stretched to infinity by art that ranges from so-so to dreadful and by documentation that is, to say the least, spotty.
Admittedly, there have been no Goyas in the 20th century but that hardly excuses the presence of Bert Winsberg's canvases based on photographs and executed in colors that are at best disagreeable. One features Wilbur Mills living it up in a restaurant with his presumed paramour and another man; another depicts a German soldier who lingers, camera in hand, among corpses dangling from a tree like the proverbial "strange fruit." With friends like Mr. Winsberg, justice needs no enemies.
There are artists who raise the show's esthetic level but too often they are represented by inconsequential works. Thus, Elizabeth Catlett's black and white linocuts about repression in Chile, though well done, make about as much impact as a postage stamp. And, dramatic though it is, Nancy Spero's lithograph of an eagle with the head of a soldier superimposed upside down on one wing that is captioned "kill commies" resists detailed interpretation. Even more puzzling are the Mao-shaped openings that Zhang Hongtu cuts in papers coated, respectively, with lipstick and soy sauce and embalmed in epoxy resin. Those seeking help from the catalogue will learn only that the artist believes "in the power of the image" but not in its "authority" and that his holey images, though related to the Taoist concept of nothingness, are actually inspired by the shape of a bagel.
Innocuous as it seems, Stephen Lack's sketchy painting of two men with guns waiting for water is a comment on the meaning of the term "consultant" when it is used in connection with the politics of third-world countries.
Albert Chong draws the onlooker into his black and white photograph of a carved chair on which reposes a still life including another photograph -- of a Jamaican man garlanded with cowrie shells. Unfortunately, the explanation of the image, inscribed on the copper mat that frames it, is all but illegible because of the way the light hits the metal. Other issues addressed include unemployment and lynching, during the Depression, Civil Rights disturbances in the 1960's and, more recent, the Navajo and Hopi land dispute.
"The Art of Justice" could persuade its viewers that Rome is indeed on fire but it leaves them no alternative but to follow the example set by Nero. The show remains on view through Oct. 27, and, as usual, prospective visitors must call (718) 378-1100, extension 2125, for an appointment.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 3; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 2429 words

HEADLINE: A 'Vulture' Looks Skyward

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM 

 BODY:

 Thou shalt not covet trophy properties.
Thou shalt not buy at auction.
Thou shalt not own old, outdated office space. 
 THESE are the commandments according to Sam Zell.
Or rather, these were his commandments. In bidding for control of Rockefeller Center, the grande dame of office developments, Mr. Zell, the feisty Chicago financier, appears to be violating his own cardinal rules.
Those rules laid the foundation for the billion-dollar empire that Mr. Zell and his late partner, Robert H. Lurie, assembled from the junkyards of the real estate industry and corporate America. Classic "vulture" investors, they bought faltering properties or businesses at cents on the dollar, betting that with a little prudent management and upturns in the business cycle, the value of their bargain-basement purchases would rise.
For the most part, their bets paid off. Today, the empire spans 24,500 mobile home sites, 57,250 apartments, 15 million square feet of retail space and 28 million square feet of office space, which makes Mr. Zell and his Equity Group Investments Inc. the country's top owner of office space. Equity has much more than real estate, though, including stakes in oil and gas, insurance, cruise lines and building products to bicycles, radio stations, plastic packaging, drug stores and fertilizer.
But with the exception of the Revco drug store chain and Schwinn bicycles, Equity is a sprawling collection of companies and properties whose names ring few bells: Vigoro, Capsure, Great American Management and Investment, Itel, Equity Residential Properties, Jacor.
Rockefeller Center sticks out among that crowd like the Hope diamond on a rhinestone bracelet, leading some to speculate that Mr. Zell is abandoning his principles in an effort to build a legacy. "Rock Center is an ego property," said David Shulman, former head of Salomon Brothers' real estate group and now its chief equity strategist. "I'm assuming Sam is doing this to make money, but that doesn't mean his ego isn't involved, too."
Could it be? Is the bad boy of real estate succumbing to the folly that lured Japanese bankers into buying Pebble Beach or Donald J. Trump the Plaza Hotel?
The mere suggestion elicits an unprintable four-letter response from Mr. Zell, who subsequently refused to pose for a picture outside the center for fear some would mistake his intentions for what he calls "an edifice complex."
"I don't invest in anything other than economic prospects," the 53-year-old Mr. Zell insisted in his gravelly growl, which enhances his reputation for irascibility. "If it's not economic, I'm not interested."
To hear him tell it, far from being an impractical trophy, Rockefeller Center is one of the few chances left to buy office space at a steep discount in hopes of reaping huge rewards a few years down the road.
Indeed, among real-estate cognoscenti, Mr. Zell's interest in Rockefeller Center -- in spite of its name and age -- is regarded as a clear signal that the bust that has plagued the commercial property business since the overbuilding of the 1980's is fast ending.
"It has become much tougher to execute a strategy of buying distressed real estate these days because there's much less distressed real estate out there to buy," said Mike Kirby, a principal in Green Street Advisers Inc. and a long-time Zell watcher.
Whether Mr. Zell will get the keys to Rockefeller Center should become clearer by Tuesday, when a bankruptcy court hearing about the center's future is scheduled in New York.
In May, the center's owners, the Mitsubishi Estate Company and Rockefeller family trusts, sought bankruptcy protection for the partnerships through which they control the property. In a bid to gain control through foreclosure, Mr. Zell has teamed up with Walt Disney and Merrill Lynch in a tentative partnership with Rockefeller Center Properties Inc., the real estate investment trust, or REIT, that holds the center's $1.3 billion mortgage.
At Tuesday's hearing, the owners are expected to unveil their reorganization plan for the property. Until late last week, they had been working on a plan with a New York development company, Tishman Speyer Properties L.P. But those talks have halted because opposition from the REIT made it certain that the plan would never have been approved by creditors.
Instead, as the deadline for the hearing looms, the owners have been meeting with representatives of the Zell team. The plan under consideration would be designed to lessen the owners' tax liability from a change of control. In exchange for injecting $250 million into the REIT, the Zell group would get a portion of the center's income for five years and then get ownership.
The effort to come up with a plan agreeable to all parties is a hallmark of Mr. Zell's way of doing business. "I'm known as a tough guy and maybe I am," he said late last week, "but I've learned it's a lot more fun to make love than to make war."
On the face of it, Rockefeller Center appears to be the most uneconomic of ventures. Its need for upkeep, improvements and repairs has cost Mitsubishi more than $500 million -- on top of mortgage payments and the $1.4 billion the Japanese real estate giant paid for an 80 percent stake in the center and other midtown Manhattan properties and businesses that it bought from the Rockefeller trusts in 1989. The outlays have far outstripped the center's rents and the prospect of further losses prompted the bankruptcy filing.
Moreover, a month before the filing, Mr. Zell pooh-poohed Rockefeller Center and other "big queens," as he calls old but elegant office buildings, as obsolete piles of brick and mortar.
But a stroll through Rockefeller Center that covered "every square inch" of the property changed Mr. Zell's mind.
First, Mitsubishi and, to a much lesser extent, the Rockefeller trusts have poured hundreds of millions of dollars into improvements.
Additionally, Mr. Zell and others angling for control -- including Goldman, Sachs & Company, a big creditor of Rockefeller Center Properties Inc., and two of the REIT's large shareholders, Gotham Partners and the Leucadia National Corporation -- see unexploited opportunities in the property.
Take the roughly 500,000 square feet in the center devoted to retailing. With the exception of the area around the skating rink, the center's retail space is filled with second-rate restaurants and shops selling T-shirts and souvenirs. Yet the foot traffic is among the heaviest in New York. "The retail space is really a collection of tenants, not a shopping experience," Mr. Zell said.
Like others, he also believes the pieces are worth more than the whole. "Think of what Disney could do with the Guild Theater and Radio City Music Hall," he said.
The General Electric Company likely would pay top dollar for the building New Yorkers call 30 Rock, which houses its NBC studios, among other things. G.E. has sunk at least $1 billion into improvements in the building, and its rent, currently at below-market rates, is scheduled for a hefty increase in October 1997, two good reasons for presuming the company would be interested in buying the building.
But it is his more than quarter-century of wrestling with troubled properties and companies -- and his understanding of the intricacies of the bankruptcy process and the center's tangled ownership structure -- that gives Mr. Zell the best chance of capturing Rockefeller Center, and making it pay off.
"Rock Center is interesting because it has an unending number of players, both real and potential," he said. "It's like a jigsaw puzzle with an enormous number of moving parts, and the person who can see them all and know why they're moving and where they're moving will win."
Finally, there is the more global reason forcing real-estate vultures like Mr. Zell to cast their principles to the wind: properties in the throes of financial distress are increasingly hard to find.
Five years ago, a glut of real estate created a buyer's market, with a shortage of investment capital on the buy side and an endless choice of properties for sale. In short, the market was grossly inefficient -- just the way the vultures like it.
Now, the economy is humming along. Very few new buildings have gone up in the last five years, and the excess capacity left over from the 80's is beginning to fill up. New players -- like Apollo Advisers L.P., Morgan Stanley, the Blackstone Group and Goldman, Sachs -- are making the real estate game more competitive.
Been there, done that, says Mr. Zell, who dismisses most of his new rivals as "slicers and dicers -- they buy up a package of distressed apartment properties, slice them up into smaller pieces and sell them off in two years."
What's more, the increasing balance between supply and demand is making it a less attractive game for players like Mr. Zell. "It's what happened in 1980," he said. "The market got efficient -- and efficiency is my enemy."
BY that time, Mr. Zell had his first fortune. He started amassing it when he was in law school at the University of Michigan in the 1960's and began managing off-campus student housing.
After graduation, he tried his hand at law but found moonlighting in distressed real estate more fun -- and more lucrative. So in 1968, he and Mr. Lurie, a fraternity brother, went into business together, buying insolvent commercial, residential and industrial properties from banks and pension fund and insurance company investors. They put virtually no money down but promised that if things worked out, the lenders would get a slice of the profits.
They did that until the late 1970's, turning huge profits. By 1980, Mr. Lurie and Mr. Zell decided that the distressed real-estate game had run its course. So they turned their attention to the corporate graveyard, acquiring control of Great American Management and Investments Inc., a real estate investment trust with some $500 million in assets. Great American had emerged from bankruptcy protection in 1979 with $120 million in tax credits, which could be used to shelter future profits. They sold off the real estate and began a diversification program, buying up companies and using Great American's net-operating-loss carry forwards to offset earnings.
They liked that investment so much that in 1984, they went after the Itel Corporation, a computer leasing company that had also gone through bankruptcy protection. With more than $400 million in tax credits on its books, Itel fit the Zell-Lurie modus operandi, and they engaged in a battle for control.
Mr. Zell's boardroom behavior after their victory cemented his reputation for mincing few words, taking no prisoners and suffering nary a fool. He sliced middle management jobs, fired the chief executive and scattered cigarette butts and ashes on the white carpeting in the executive suite.
Using Itel's and Great American's tax credits to shelter profits, Mr. Zell and Mr. Lurie went on a buying spree in the 80's. They accumulated more than $2 billion in debt, and when the recession hit in the early 90's, Equity was unable to refinance its many loans, more than $500 million of which were personally guaranteed by Mr. Zell.
Worse than his financial woes was the loss to cancer in 1990 of Mr. Lurie, who had tended to the operational details of their holdings. Mr. Zell describes their relationship as "living out of the same checkbook," and Mr. Lurie's slow deterioration was painful for Mr. Zell. A photo of Mr. Lurie, whose wife and six children retain a 50-percent stake in most Equity deals, is on the wall of Mr. Zell's office.
Sheli Rosenberg, then Equity's general counsel, stepped into Mr. Lurie's role. She has deliberately kept a low profile but intends to increase her public role and the role of other executives as Equity's holdings become more and more public.
Becoming more public was part of the process of bringing Equity out of its financial bind. Since 1990, Mr. Zell has sold stakes to the public in seven companies. Last year, he took his apartment and mobile home holdings public.
"The buoyant equity capital markets have bailed him out," said an investment banker whose firm runs a fund specializing in distressed real estate that often competes with Mr. Zell for properties. "He couldn't have recapped in the private market and gotten values anywhere near what he did in the public market."
And since 1988, when Mr. Zell teamed with Merrill Lynch to coax institutional investors to give him $408 million to plow into troubled property, a big portion of his deals are done with other people's money. Although the first Zell-Merrill Lynch fund started buying into the office market before it bottomed out, thereby depressing returns, Mr. Zell and Merrill have raised more than $1 billion in two subsequent funds and are preparing to start a fourth.
Separately, Mr. Zell, in tandem with Chilmark Partners, an investment firm run by the former Salomon Brothers restructuring expert, David M. Schulte, has raised $1 billion to invest in distressed companies. Until last month, Zell-Chilmark's holdings included 54 percent of Broadway Stores, the West Coast department store chain.
With the sale of Broadway to Federated Department Stores for stock plus the assumption of $1 billion of debt, Mr. Zell pulled a rabbit out of the hat. Although he did not immediately recoup all of Zell-Chilmark's $250 million investment, he did avert the bankruptcy filing that many were predicting. And if Federated stock goes up, it may yet prove to be a winning investment.
He now gleefully displays a miniature Lucite tombstone encasing a clipping from the Aug. 16 issue of Crain's Chicago Business, which predicted that the "grave dancer," the nickname Mr. Zell has chosen for himself, might soon "have a corpse on his hands" -- namely Broadway Stores.
Mr. Zell expects his Rockefeller Center adventure to be commemorated in celluloid -- not Lucite. In his dealings with Peter D. Linneman, chairman of the REIT through which Mr. Zell hopes to gain control of the center, there was one non-negotiable issue.
"I said there was one last thing that could be a deal-breaker, and that's that I get the movie rights to the story about the battle for this great property," Mr. Zell growled.
Mr. Linneman acceded -- but only if he could choose the actor to play Mr. Zell. "Depending on how things turn out, you'll either be Robert DeNiro or Danny DeVito," Mr. Zell recalls Mr. Linneman saying.
Mr. Zell mused for a moment. "I actually like DeVito a lot," he said.
