HEADLINE: INVESTING IT: AT THE GATE;
With New Issues, Small Can Be Beautiful

BYLINE: By REED ABELSON 

 BODY:
IN the dicey world of initial public offerings, many people invest only in headline deals put forth by well-known companies and underwritten by major Wall Street firms. First issues are nail-biters anyway, the thinking goes, so better to play it safe in some respects, going with a Nabisco Holdings, a Netscape or a similar venture backed by a giant that researches, underwrites and markets several billions of dollars in new issues every year.
Sometimes, though, it pays to look at smaller deals done by modest-sized firms far from Wall Street. "Many of the regional houses do very well with these small offerings," said Robert Mascale, a research analyst for New Issues, a newsletter published by the Institute for Econometric Research in Deerfield, Fla. Not only can investors avoid the exorbitant prices that often accompany highly publicized deals, but they also have a better chance of finding a broker willing to sell some shares. 
 Consider Eastbay, a catalogue company in Wausau, Wis., that sells about a tenth as much as its better-known neighbor to the south, Lands' End in Dodgeville. Founded in 1980 by a school coach and a college director of recreational services, Eastbay sells athletic equipment and apparel to high school and college teams and to individuals. It mailed its first catalogue in 1984 and now sends out nearly 40 million copies a year.
Like the company, the offering, for which no date has been set, is modest. Eastbay expects to raise no more than $30 million. The underwriter is a small Milwaukee firm, Robert W. Baird & Company, for which this will be the first I.P.O. of the year. Piper Jaffray of Minneapolis is co-manager.
But, though it isn't a technology play and lacks the name recognition that can make for a hot stock, Eastbay may be worth a long look. During the last three years, its annual earnings have sprinted to $4 million from $1.2 million, for the 12 months ended in June, and in the same period revenues more than doubled, to $98.8 million.
What accounts for these impressive numbers? "The thing about Eastbay is that they have a really strong niche," said Steven Ashley, a retailing analyst with the Milwaukee firm Cleary Gull.
Many people will never find an Eastbay catalogue in their mailboxes. The mailing list consists mostly of 12- to 24-year-olds, many of whom asked to be added to the list after seeing the hard-to-find Nike styles and other items in the catalogue. Eastbay's secret is to focus on rural areas, the inner city and other markets ignored by Foot Locker, Sports Authority and other chains, and to offer a broad selection. The strategy enables Eastbay to sidestep its competition.
And the offering price looks fair. At $12 to $14, the shares would sell at a reasonable multiple of 17 times trailing earnings, which is less than Eastbay's average annual growth rate of more than 25 percent for the last two years. While Eastbay has no direct publicly held competitors, the stock also looks cheaper than that of some indirectly comparable companies. Many catalogue companies are more expensive; for example, at Friday's closing price of $17.50, Lands' End was selling at a price-to-earnings multiple of 20. Shares of Sports Authority, $28.50 on Friday, carried a multiple of 35.
Moreover, while the deal doesn't have the backing of a Wall Street powerhouse, Baird and Piper are both respected regional firms that specialize in companies in their geographic area, like Eastbay. Piper, the lead manager in five initial offerings in 1994, had one of the year's best underwriting records, according to Standard & Poor's.
But small firms do have their drawbacks. Because Baird and Piper don't have as many brokers as larger firms, their deals probably won't see the same jump in stock price on the first day of trading that bigger firms can generate, and might get less backing in the ensuing months.
Eastbay is a small company trying to break into a big and competitive league. Its $98.8 million in revenue looks puny compared with the Sports Authority's nearly $1 billion in sales. It is young, too. Eastbay still hasn't named any of its outside directors, although its founders, Richard Gering and Arthur Juedes, did bring in an experienced manager, Harry Colcord, three years ago. For 10 years before joining Eastbay, Mr. Colcord, president and chief executive, headed a division of Apogee Enterprises, a Minneapolis building products company with $800 million in sales.
Small deals can be beautiful, but they can also be dangerous. Investors should beware of the infamous bucket shops that push whatever offerings are available, and avoid tiny deals done by unseasoned firms. "The lack of experience and inability to really judge a company's worth might prove to be disastrous," Mr. Mascale said.
 
Eastbay Inc.
 
Direct marketer of athletic apparel and equipment, based in Wausau, Wis.
 
Lead Underwriter: Robert W. Baird & Co.
 
Maximum shares offered: 2 million; 35% of company
 
Expected price per share: $12 - $14
 
Sales, year ended June '95: $98.8 million
 
Earnings, year ended June '95: $4 million; 78 cents a share.

HEADLINE: DIARY

BYLINE: By HUBERT B. HERRING 

 BODY:

POLITICS
 
Finance, After Packwood
It's one of the few flattering labels stuck on Bob Packwood lately: "master of detail." He sure is. Just read, amid the more damning diary entries, the blow-by-blow description of a senatorial hairdo. But where that mastery will leave the real void, now that he's resigning, is on the Senate Finance Committee, which he heads. He somehow understands the intricacies of taxes and Medicare -- and, it is said, can explain it in English (quite a trick!). So while one colleague said, "I don't think any senator is indispensable," others said his departure "complicates things" and leaves a "substantial void" in areas where the Republicans crave big changes. What now? Bob Dole is expected to run the committee, from offstage, till yearend.
 
STALKING CHRYSLER
 
This Time, Kerkorian's Serious
When Kirk Kerkorian made noises in the spring about buying Chrysler, people stopped listening after a while, and Mr. Kerkorian seemed to fade into the upholstery. He didn't. He was, apparently, scouting around for an ally who'd be taken seriously, and last week he found one, luring Jerome York, former Chrysler finance chief, away from I.B.M. The markets are taking it very seriously, with Chrysler's stock rising as relentlessly as I.B.M.'s falls. And Chrysler took it seriously -- doubling, to $2 billion, its stock buyback. Mr. York, it is agreed, wants to run Chrysler -- so he probably won't be satisfied with what Chrysler may offer: a board seat.
 
CUBA
 
Island of Capitalism
The official line, still: Cuba is an evil Communist empire, a lurking threat to the very barbecues and bowling leagues of democracy. But each day that image meanders further from reality, as Fidel Castro's once-defiant island looks more and more like a bastion of capitalism -- lacking only American capitalists. Last week Cuba passed a law allowing foreign investment in anything but defense, health care and education. To be sure, the door could have been opened wider -- the Government must give its nod case by case, and "anything that doesn't benefit" Cuba's development "will be excluded." Still, some American businesses -- which would love to get a foot in this fast-revolving door -- saw a golden opportunity to rethink our trade ban.
 
AUTOS
 
Trucks in Cars' Clothing
They're priced like luxury cars. They're filled with luxury-car goodies, like CD players, phone outlets and serious leather. But Jeeps, Explorers and Suburbans drink gas like trucks. How do they get away with it? Because they're "light" trucks, ruled by much looser mileage standards. This is no small matter, for of every 10 new passenger vehicles sold, 4 are light trucks, and this surging popularity has slammed into reverse the nation's solid gains in fuel efficiency. "Outrageous," said a Sierra Club official. "Ridiculous," said Automotive News. Indeed, the Administration might raise mileage standards for trucks -- fiercely opposed by auto makers, of course, and the regulation-busting House.
 
JAPAN
 
Few Jobless, but Few Jobs
In the United States, by the strange math of economists, 6 percent unemployment is often considered "full employment." So Japan, with an official jobless rate of 3.2 percent, would seem a job-seeker's paradise. Far from it. On Monday, as most Americans basked in a Labor Day untainted by labor, more than 12,000 Japanese college students flocked from across the nation to a Tokyo stadium for what was essentially a huge job fair. With Japan stuck in recession, top companies were not exactly clamoring for their talents. Top seniors competed for jobs as clerks and construction workers, others competed for any job at all -- and women were left with the scraps. It was the dark side of lifetime employment -- don't hire in the first place.
 
CHARITIES
 
Rewarded Before Heaven
The men and women who head the nation's nonprofit organizations naturally do so out of dedication to good works, but starvation wages are not usually part of the deal. Even after the president of United Way was sent packing after he lived it up on the charity's money -- a scandal that snapped the public to attention -- salaries are rising steadily. And a survey out last week found that the top salaries, by far, went to the heads of big city hospitals: Mount Sinai, $900,000; Sloan-Kettering, nearly $800,000. The Salvation Army's president, though, made just $58,000, while the president of Philip Morris made nearly $2 million. And Newt Gingrich? $133,600 (without royalties).
 
EDUCATION
 
Mr. Moon Goes to School
Is a university just another business? After all, if it can't pay its bills, it'll be as bankrupt as a failed dry cleaner. So can anyone with ready cash simply "buy" this "business" and do with it what he will? That was the extra-credit question last week as the University of Bridgeport bestowed an honorary degree on the Rev. Sun Myung Moon, who saved the school from bankruptcy by giving it $98 million since 1992. Enrollment has risen from 1,100 to 1,800, but the "Moonies" have not "taken over," said the president -- a 20-year friend of Mr. Moon's. "This is a normal American university with a unique funding source." Critics, though, say Mr. Moon's followers have lured foreign students with big scholarships -- with church training part of the deal.
 
 
PUBLISHING
 
A Magazine, by George!
Government-bashers will love this one: a model as President. Even those irreverent souls who said Ronald Reagan was merely acting the part wouldn't have had such a wildly cynical fantasy. But there she is: Cindy Crawford as a seductive George Washington on the cover -- unveiled last week -- of an odd new magazine called, yes, George. This isn't just any magazine, though. It's "post-partisan," whatever that means. It's the MTV of politics. It's full of Georges, of all stripes: Wallace, Stephanopoulos, Bush (well, Barbara anyway). Oh, and by the way, a fellow named Kennedy edits it (no, not George: that's the actor; this is confusing enough!). This one, if memory serves, is related to some former President. Could that be what the fuss is about?

HEADLINE: Beyond the Couch

BYLINE: By LISA W. FODERARO 

 BODY:
IT was always a one-way love affair. New York City adored Sigmund Freud. Freud hated New York City.
He was here just once, in 1909, and he took in the usual sights: the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Coney Island, Central Park and Chinatown. But as he left the States, he wrote to his sister: "I am very glad I am away from it, and even more that I don't have to live there." 
 As Freud was busy denouncing all Americans as materialistic, superficial, prudish and uncultivated, New Yorkers couldn't get enough of the father of psychoanalysis. The International Psychoanalytic Society set up shop in Manhattan in 1911, and in the 1920's there were "Freuding" parties in Greenwich Village where guests analyzed one another's dreams. Woody Allen's oeuvre has certainly burnished the image.
"Psychoanalysis might have originated in Vienna, but it was copied and Americanized, then marketed, and marketed on a scale immeasurably greater than Europe could offer, in New York," Ann Douglas wrote in "Terrible Honesty: Mongrel Manhattan in the 1920's" (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, 1995), her sweeping portrait of New York City.
Today Freud is still a strong, some would say towering, presence. No matter how many of his theories or techniques have been rejected or modified, he is still the one who created the "talking cure," the foundation of all psychotherapy.
But with changes transforming the health-care industry and managed-care companies looking for ways to cut costs, Freudian analysis is taking a back seat to cheaper and shorter approaches like cognitive-behavioral therapy and group therapy. The image of a couch-bound patient free-associating four or five days a week for years on end, while a bearded analyst sits silently by, is largely a thing of the past.
"There are still therapists out there who believe in sitting on the sidelines and just letting a patient talk and talk and talk," said Dr. Robert M. Naiman, a Manhattan psychiatrist who has practiced for more than 40 years. "That was O.K. back in the classic orthodox days when patients coming into psychoanalysis expected that, but in this day and age I think people should and do expect activity and interaction."
More typical these days is a patient who sees a therapist once a week and sits up. The talk may indeed explore childhood difficulties and last night's dreams. But it will also focus on current problems, self-defeating tendencies, relationships and career goals. The therapist doesn't give advice per se, but is clearly engaged, asking questions, making connections and helping the patient achieve insights and, ultimately, positive changes.
"People who go into therapy know the process is going to take a long time, but they still want instant feedback," said Doug Garr, a Manhattan author and editor who has seen three therapists since 1982. "You don't want to lose your mind before you regain it."
In general, psychotherapy today tends to fall into two broad categories: a highly focused treatment that tackles a specific symptom by directly modifying thinking and behavior versus a more global, psychoanalytical approach that seeks to affect a major personality change by expanding insight.
The first approach zeros in on a particular problem or unwanted behavior -- a phobia or creative block, say -- and attempts to correct it. It does this not by looking into the psyche for root causes but by taking a pragmatic tack, involving homework assignments and mental exercises, to change thinking and behavior right now. Cognitive, behavioral and short-term therapies all work this way, and because they tend to move quickly -- and cost less -- they have become the darlings of the managed-care industry.
Dr. Russ Newman of the American Psychological Association said the public was warming to the swifter style of therapy, too. "Taking the economics out of it, I suspect that people are more immediate results-oriented, more symptom-focused, more behavior-focused today than probably they were 15 or 20 years ago," said Dr. Newman, the association's executive director for professional practice.
But many believe that for permanent, pervasive changes in both outlook and behavior, a deeper, longer-term plumbing of the mind, emotions and unconscious works best. For that, there are seemingly infinite schools and approaches, from the waning orthodox Freudian perspective (where the daily couch is de rigueur and the Oedipus complex looms large) to mainstream Freudian analysis (with couch optional, once or twice a week, and there's more interaction) to a number of distinct offshoots of Freud that drop many of the sexual theories in favor of others. Then there are Gestalt therapy, existential psychology, the humanistic approach, and many others that don't spring directly from Freud but still seek to boost insight into the causes of behavior by exploring repressed thoughts and memories.
But one trend that may make things somewhat easier for the consumer is the evolution over the years of an "eclectic" point of view, in which therapists shed a rigid theoretical orientation and instead draw on several different approaches, depending on the patient's needs.
"Once you are talking about a theory, you are talking about a very specific lens and certain things will be exaggerated and others will be minimized," said Dr. Beverly M. Rubinstein, a Greenwich Village psychologist whose overarching approach is more analytical than behavioral. "To the extent that the patient is respected, all of the theories have to be secondary to the phenomenon. In geology, the phenomenon is the rock. In therapy, it's the patient."
Nonetheless, choosing a therapist can be a bewildering process. There are not only many kinds of therapies, but also different types of therapists: clinical social workers, psychologists and psychiatrists. (Actually, anyone can hang out a shingle advertising "psychotherapy," but only these three professional categories are recognized by New York State's licensing boards, which uphold standards and mete out punishment.)
 
NEW VIEW ON MEDICATION
 Clinical social workers have completed a two-year post-baccalaureate program. Psychologists have Ph.D.'s., usually earned after four to six years of study. And psychiatrists are full medical doctors. None of the three types are limited to any one approach, but psychiatrists are the only ones who can prescribe medications like Prozac, the antidepressant of the decade. However, social workers and psychologists usually have relationships with psychiatrists who will write a prescription after a consultation.
In the last 10 years it has become more common for patients to take medication for depression or anxiety. The thinking used to be that if moods were lifted "artificially," people would be less inclined to explore the causes of psychological pain, but the opposite view seems to hold sway today.
That is especially true of the selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors, or S.S.R.I.'s, like Prozac, Paxil, Zoloft and Luvox, which have fewer side effects than the older generation of tricyclic antidepressants and have proved remarkably effective. For anxiety, Xanax seems to be the drug of choice.
"People take the medication and find they're able to work better in therapy," said Dr. Clark Sugg, a psychiatrist and director of clinical services at the William Alanson White Institute on the Upper West Side. "They begin to have hope and see that things can be different, and it sparks curiosity. It's almost as if you wake up from a dream."
Many health insurance plans do not cover psychotherapy, only psychiatric care in a hospital setting. But those that do usually require some co-payment and authorize a set number of sessions, like 15 or 20. The therapist can request another set of sessions by detailing the patient's inner turmoil; the notes are then reviewed by bureaucrats who often have little or no mental-health training. Therapists commonly warn patients that although those notes are supposed to be confidential, once they leave their offices there is no guarantee they won't come back to haunt the patient.
It is almost impossible to self-diagnose and choose the one therapeutic niche for you. But just about everyone agrees that individuals with phobias respond best to cognitive-behavioral therapy. Individual personality matters, too. Some people are just more comfortable with a pragmatic, focused approach; others may find it absolutely cathartic to speak in great depth.
 
FINDING A GOOD MATCH
 Most therapists suggest the prospective patient get a few names from friends, family members or trusted co-workers and then shop around. Don't hesitate to ask the therapist: What kind of therapy do you do? What does that mean? How does it work? How long will it take? How much will it cost?
The mantra of most therapists, interestingly, is for the prospective patient to find a good personality match. Even if you can't put a finger on it, if the therapist's personality rubs you the wrong way, keep looking. The therapist should seem caring and attentive and should put you at ease. A sense of humor can't hurt. "There are certainly people in my field -- social workers, psychologists and psychiatrists -- who are real zombies socially," one psychiatrist confided.
There are, to be sure, bad therapists out there. One family therapist, Dr. Neil Maron, said he knew of a psychologist who gives her excess patients to her husband, a salesman, for therapy. Group therapy is known among practitioners to attract the occasional aspiring cult leader to its fray. And, yes, there are therapists who fall asleep during sessions, breach confidentiality or become sexually involved with patients.
Even with a competent therapist, the talking cure can be far from a panacea. "Sometimes, when you understand why you're doing things, it makes things worse," said a woman in her 40's who works in the art world and who refused to be identified. "They say that too much knowledge is not necessarily a good thing, and I think that's true of self-knowledge."
Other patients complain of sounding like a broken record, feeling incapable of acting on their insights and growing emotionally dependent on the therapist, afraid to ever end the relationship. Many worry about all the money they're spending, money that could go into savings or into pleasurable -- and possibly even therapeutic -- activities like travel or continuing education.
Even some therapists think the 20th century could take some lessons from earlier eras, when people struggled with painful emotions and awkward personality traits on their own. "I don't think everyone requires therapy in this generation," said Dr. Maron, president of the Center for Marital and Family Therapy in New York City. "In fact, I think people are over-therapized."
When therapy spawns obvious changes, however, it can be exhilarating. Mr. Garr said he had a volatile temper before working on it in therapy. "It hasn't cured it totally, but it has helped," he said. "I can do a lot of self-adjustment in midstream. The smallest thing used to set me off. Now nothing is so bad that I can't cope with it."
 
 
 
How to File A Complaint
 Psychologists and certified social workers in New York State are licensed and disciplined by the state's Department of Education. Psychiatrists are also licensed by the department but are disciplined by the state's Department of Health. In all cases, an investigation begins once an official complaint form is submitted.
A patient may file a complaint against a psychologist or certified social worker by contacting the Education Department's Office of Professional Discipline at (800) 442-8106. Two of the most common complaints are breach of confidentiality and sexual abuse.
Last year the state found substantial evidence of misconduct in 31 cases involving psychologists and 11 cases involving certified social workers. Punishments ranged from a reprimand to revocation of the license.
To file a complaint against a psychiatrist, contact the Health Department's Office of Professional Medical Conduct at (518) 474-8357. Last year the agency took disciplinary action -- usually suspension or revocation of license -- against 30 psychiatrists for violations ranging from sexual abuse to the inappropriate prescription of drugs.

LENGTH: 1032 words

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Japan Catches Up In Bank Failures

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
THOSE who despair that America's economy has surrendered its leadership to Japan can take heart. In at least one big area, Japan is scrupulously imitating one of the landmark American business events of the 1980's: banking disasters.
Nearly five years after Washington came to grips with the full horror of the $500 billion savings-and-loan collapse, Japanese banks and thrifts are following suit as precisely as if executives had studied a how-to manual by Charles Keating Jr. 
 In Japan as in the United States, the biggest culprits are thrift institutions that were originally conceived to promote the conservative goals of saving and home ownership. In both countries, these institutions became go-go banks that attracted large sums by paying high interest rates. And then, in Japan as in the United States, they used these deposits to underwrite dubious shopping malls, vacation resorts and office complexes.
In both countries, government ultimately contributed to the problem by helping hedge the risks through low-priced deposit insurance. Government-backed deposit insurance guarantees that bank or credit union customers will be kept whole, even if a financial institution goes bankrupt. But the American savings-and-loan crisis overwhelmed the industry's insurance fund in the 1980's, and now Japan has temporarily wiped out its own insurance fund with the two recent bailouts.
No one yet knows the full scale of the problem here, but it is Texas-sized at a minimum. Two weeks ago, the Ministry of Finance shut down Kizu Credit Cooperative, the nation's biggest credit union, and a large regional bank; between them, they had roughly $16 billion in uncollectable loans. And those were only a tiny fraction of the total problem: Government officials estimate that Japan's financial institutions have about $400 billion in problem loans, and other analysts suspect the real total is much higher. Even by conservative estimates, the loans now in arrears roughly equal the estimated capital of the country's banks and other financial institutions.
 
Prolonging Recession
 No one thinks Japan's financial system is about to collapse, but the problems are enough to delay the country's recovery from recession, and a few of the biggest banks could be hurt badly.
What is most striking, however, is how similar this debacle is to America's savings-and-loan crisis.
The Osaka-based Kizu Credit Cooperative could have come straight from the S.&L. textbook. It was chartered as an employee credit union and was innocuous until the late 1980's. But then Japan's high real estate prices began to soar to astronomic levels as economic expansion left too much money chasing too few domestic investments.
Meanwhile, the Government decided to give credit unions a break, and let them offer whatever interest rates they wanted. It was a bow to deregulation, somewhat like what occurred in the United States when Congress began letting savings-and-loan institutions invest more freely in order to compete with banks.
Kizu, much like Charles Keating's Lincoln Savings and Loan, began to grow at a blistering pace. It offered top interest rates on big time-deposits, much as Lincoln had attracted money through certificates of deposit. (Lincoln financed splashy resorts with such high-interest securities before the enterprise collapsed; eventually, Mr. Keating was convicted of fraud.)
Kizu's deposits mushroomed between 1988 and 1995, from about $2.2 billion to $12 billion. Its volume of real estate lending climbed at roughly the same rate. But Japan's economy began to stall in the early 1990's. Annual growth slowed to about one percent and real estate prices collapsed. Today, property prices in many areas are less than half what they were; thus, a great many doubtful loans have become uncollectable.
One more similarity between the Japanese and American crises seems likely to emerge: cronyism. The American crisis was replete with cases of self-dealing, in which thrift executives siphoned off money in bonuses and lent to projects sponsored by close friends. In Japan, the Government recently raised alarms about the fact that executives at nearly half the nation's credit unions had outside business interests.
 
Why They Slept
 In hindsight, the dangers were obvious. But why didn't Japanese regulators and bank executives wake up earlier, particularly given the highly publicized American problems? "Objectively speaking, the situations were the same," said Toru Nakakita, professor of economics at Toyo University. But, he said, Japanese experts did not really understand that financial de-regulation would inevitably create both losers and winners. "In Japan, there was this myth that banks never go bankrupt, Professor Nakakita said. "The managers believed that as long as they took the same steps as all the others, they would never go bankrupt."
After remaining quiet for months as signs of trouble became steadily more acute, the Ministry of Finance and Japan's central bank took their first concrete actions by shutting down Kizu and liquidating the Hyogo Bank, based in Kobe.
The Government is now trying to deal with the problem in a classic Japanese attempt at collaboration. Instead of simply bailing out the bad loans with massive amounts of public money, as the United States finally did, Government officials here are leaning on Japan's biggest banks to put up most of the necessary capital. But the big banks are balking, and they have their own problem loans to worry about.
Regardless of who supplies the money, the amount needed will almost certainly make it harder for Japan to bounce back from its recession. That would be bad news for other countries, because it means Japan is less likely to import foreign products or to invest overseas.
But the banking crisis also rebuts the popular wisdom that Japan can somehow defy the laws of economics and of human sense. It turns out that Japanese, like Americans, have been able to fall victim to the same timeless traps: the lure of quick profits and the false certainty that what was true yesterday will be true tomorrow.
Maybe someone else can learn that lesson for the future.

HEADLINE: Yeltsin Foes Use NATO Bombing to Press Him

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Sept. 9

 BODY:
Seeking to turn what they called an international humiliation into a domestic campaign issue, nationalists, Communists and some moderates in the Russian Parliament today demanded that President Boris N. Yeltsin suspend Russia's cooperation agreement with NATO because of its bombing of the Bosnian Serbs over Russia's objections.
In a special session of the lower house called to consider Russia's position on Bosnia, the legislators passed a nonbinding resolution that called for Russia to suspend the NATO agreement and demanded the dismissal of Foreign Minister Andrei V. Kozyrev. 
 The resolution passed by a vote of 258 to 2 in a session boycotted by most of the more liberal politicians in the 450-member lower house. It also called for a unilateral lifting of the trade embargo on Serbia and for a meeting of the United Nations Security Council.
Mr. Yeltsin did not immediately respond, but seems unlikely to suspend Russia's agreement with NATO. It is unclear whether the political pressure might force him to adopt a more confrontational stance in dealing with the United States and its European allies, or whether it might force him to dismiss Mr. Kozyrev, who critics say is too sympathetic to NATO's position on Bosnia. Mr. Kozyrev was in Greece during the parliamentary debate.
The message from the nationalists and Communists, that Russia is being denied its rightful place as a superpower, was a familiar one. But with the campaign for parliamentary elections in December gearing up, a broad array of politicians took the session as an opportunity to apportion blame for Russia's loss of international influence and to establish their nationalist credentials with an electorate that shows little enthusiasm for the current Government.
Gennadi Zyuganov, leader of the Communist Party, called the situation in the former Yugoslavia "an obvious failure of Russian foreign policy" and described Mr. Kozyrev as the "minister of national disgrace."
Mr. Yeltsin has been broadly supportive of the latest American-led peace proposal for Bosnia while sharply criticizing American dominance of NATO and its bombing campaign in what was once a Soviet sphere of influence.
Anticipating the tenor of today's debate, Mr. Yeltsin had used increasingly harsh language to criticize NATO over the last several days, warning on Friday that an eastward expansion of the alliance could bring "a conflagration of war throughout Europe." He also criticized the Foreign Ministry's performance under Mr. Kozyrev. Mr. Yeltsin said "conclusions would be drawn" if the ministry's performance did not improve.
Outside of the parliamentary session, politicians said the electorate might not care about the particulars of the conflict in the former Yugoslavia, and that some of the more extreme statements from the debate could be dismissed as posturing.
But they said the nationalistic fears raised by Russia's isolation over the issue could work powerfully to the advantage of the loose grouping of nationalist, Communist and agrarian parties that dominates the tone of the Parliament and has limited but increasing influence over the Government. At a time of economic and social upheaval, voters are clinging to their pride in Russian power and stature in the world, they said.

HEADLINE: REPUBLICANS DRAW PLAN FOR SLOWING MEDICARE GROWTH

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9

 BODY:
In a Medicare plan to be unveiled next week, Republicans expect to propose increasing most premiums, imposing annual limits on the growth of the program and reducing payments to doctors, hospitals and suppliers.
Republicans said their plan would also propose slowing the growth of Medicare by encouraging elderly people to join health maintenance organizations. 
 In interviews this week, the Republicans provided a fairly full account of their proposals. They said that beneficiaries would have a much wider choice of health plans and that the Government would contribute a fixed amount to the plan chosen by each beneficiary.
Republicans said they had backed away from their initial proposals to create strong financial incentives for elderly people to join H.M.O.'s and other forms of managed care, which seek to control costs by limiting patients' choice of doctors and hospitals. Democrats had said those incentives would amount to financial coercion. Republicans said they would still try to encourage the voluntary use of H.M.O.'s.
Although the political stakes for both parties are immense, Republicans say the risks for them are smaller than they once thought because they believe that many elderly people have been convinced that Medicare is not sustainable in its current form and must be thoroughly redesigned.
Lawmakers say the real battle lies ahead, as Republicans set forth details of their plan to cut projected spending on Medicare by $270 billion, or 14 percent, in the next seven years. Republicans and Clinton Administration officials agree that if there is no change in current law, Medicare's Hospital Insurance Trust Fund, which pays hospital bills for the elderly, will probably run out of money in 2002. That is nine years before members of the huge baby boom generation begin to qualify for Medicare.
But Democrats say the Republican plan goes far beyond what is necessary to preserve the trust fund. They assert that much of the money squeezed from Medicare would be used by the Republicans to help balance the budget and to finance tax cuts for affluent people.
House Democratic leaders say they will not negotiate on Medicare until Republicans abandon the idea of cutting taxes for people with annual incomes of more than $100,000. The Democrats, who failed to pass sweeping health care legislation last year, when they controlled both houses of Congress, have not offered a comprehensive alternative to the Republicans' Medicare proposals this year.
Tony Blankley, press secretary for Speaker Newt Gingrich, said the Republicans would probably introduce their proposals in a comprehensive Medicare bill next Thursday or Friday.
About 10 percent of the 37 million Medicare recipients are in H.M.O.'s, and the Republicans say they still want to encourage the use of such health plans. "But we don't intend to force people into managed care, directly or indirectly," said Representative James C. Greenwood of Pennsylvania, one of eight House Republicans drafting the party's proposals with Mr. Gingrich.
House Republicans are seriously considering several proposals that would directly affect Medicare recipients. One would increase premiums for more affluent beneficiaries. Another would increase premiums for all beneficiaries except those with very low incomes.
"Means-testing is very acceptable," said Representative Dan Miller, Republican of Florida, who suggested that elderly people with incomes over $75,000 would pay the higher premiums. Under current law, all Medicare beneficiaries, except those with very low incomes, pay the same premium, $46.10 a month.
Premiums now account for 31 percent of the cost of Part B of Medicare, which covers doctors' services and is financed mainly with general revenues. Under a quirk in current law, the premium would drop to $43.70 next year. Merely keeping premiums high enough to cover 31 percent of Part B costs would generate $50 billion to $60 billion in additional revenue for Medicare over the next seven years.
Republicans have also drafted proposals that would require beneficiaries to pay some of the cost of home health care and clinical laboratory services and more of the cost of doctors' services and skilled nursing homes. But Republicans said they might shy away from these ideas, knowing that such proposals would make juicy targets for critics.
Political pressures have prompted the Republicans to soften the impact of their proposals on beneficiaries. As a result, more of the proposed savings will be extracted from doctors and hospitals.
"Hospitals don't vote; seniors do," said Thomas A. Scully, president of the Federation of American Health Systems, which represents 1,700 investor-owned hospitals. "Every day," he said, "we learn more about how the Republicans will whack providers and spare beneficiaries. The balance is being skewed."
Some lobbyists for the elderly said they feared that the Republican proposals would encourage doctors, hospitals and health plans to shift costs to beneficiaries by charging them more. But spokesmen for the elderly from more conservative groups, like the Seniors Coalition, welcomed the Republican proposals, saying they would increase the health insurance alternatives available to Medicare beneficiaries.
Returning to Washington after a four-week summer recess, House Republicans said that constituents were surprisingly willing to accept major Medicare changes to guarantee the solvency of the program.
"I found people to be open-minded about what we are doing," said Representative Rob Portman, Republican of Ohio. "I had thought there would be more concern, more protest."
Representative Bill Martini, Republican of New Jersey, said: "In my district, there was very strong sentiment in favor of voluntary participation in H.M.O.'s. Contrary to some of our concerns before we went back home, seniors understand that there is a serious problem."
But Democrats are preparing a full-scale assault on the Republican plan, denouncing it as the latest in a long series of Republican efforts to undermine Medicare.
Representative Frank Pallone Jr. of New Jersey, co-chairman of the Health Care Task Force of the House Democratic Caucus, said, "Seniors will be rightly upset when they understand the Republican proposals because the only way to achieve such big savings is by forcing seniors into H.M.O.'s or by requiring them to spend more out of pocket."
House Republicans said their Medicare plan would be subject to change until it is formally announced. But, they said, these are likely to be its main elements:
* The Government would, for the first time, impose annual limits on the growth of Medicare spending. From 1995 to 2002, average spending for each beneficiary would rise 40 percent, to $6,700 from $4,800. Under current law, it would grow 67 percent, to $8,000 in 2002, assuming the Treasury provided the money to pay the claims and prevent the exhaustion of the hospital trust fund.
* The Government would contribute a fixed amount to the health plan chosen by each beneficiary. Patients would presumably shop for plans offering the best care at the lowest prices because they would receive rebates if they chose plans charging less than the Federal payment.
* Medicare would curb payments to doctors, hospitals and other suppliers of goods and services to save $110 billion over seven years. Congress would, for example, reduce the amounts allowed to hospitals for inflation, graduate medical education, construction of buildings, purchases of new equipment and the special costs of treating large numbers of indigent patients. Such cutbacks have been on the standard list of policy options for more than a decade.
* If Medicare spending exceeded the targets set by Federal law, the Government would further reduce payments to doctors, hospitals and suppliers to save additional amounts, up to $80 billion over seven years. These cutbacks could be made automatically, without further action by Congress.
* Retirees could stay in health plans sponsored by their former employers, and the Government would pay most of the cost. But employers would not have to offer health insurance to current or former employees.
* The Government would encourage beneficiaries to report waste, fraud and abuse in Medicare by calling a toll-free telephone number. If the Government saved money, it would share the savings with informers.
Democrats say the initial reaction to the Republican plan is similar to the early euphoria over President Clinton's health plan in 1993, before people examined the details. Months of criticism by Republicans and health insurers, among others, turned public opinion against the Clinton plan. Democrats hope to block the Republicans' Medicare proposals in a similar way, and early criticism has already led to modifications of the Republican plan.
But the Democrats will have less time to make their arguments. The Medicare proposals will be part of a vast deficit-reduction bill. Republicans say they want to bring the bill to the House floor early next month, with Senate leaders hoping to act soon after that. Weeks of wrangling -- between the House and Senate, and between Congress and the White House -- may follow, so the bill's ultimate fate may not be resolved until November or December.

HEADLINE: Reporter's Notebook;
First Lady in Mongolia: Mare's Milk and Politics

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON 

DATELINE: ULAN BATOR, Mongolia, Sept. 8

 BODY:
In this non-urban capital, where cows and pigs freely roam the streets, few of the inner-city problems so familiar to Americans are readily evident to visitors like Hillary Rodham Clinton, who stopped here on her way home from China.
Yet in the last few years, as Mongolia plunged into economic difficulties due to the sudden disappearance of economic aid from Russia and an inflation rate that reached 400 percent, a new crisis has emerged in Ulan Bator: street children. 
 Abandoned by parents who cannot support them, thousands of young children spend fierce Mongolian winters, when temperatures often dip under 40 degrees below zero, clustered in old box cars in Ulan Bator's train station and begging on the streets, Mongolian officials told Mrs. Clinton today.
During her 28-hour visit here, the First Lady went to a center for homeless children, where a few dozen children are given a place to eat and sleep and, perhaps, treatment for the skin diseases and malnourishment that are common among them.
In a ramshackle schoolhouse, with classrooms and hallways painted green and pink, a dozen young girls and boys assembled for Mrs. Clinton and sang a Mongolian rendition of "If You're Happy and You Know It, Clap Your Hands," clapping, stomping and slapping their thighs.
Mrs. Clinton, followed through the building by a crew of American and Mongolian reporters, used the visit to make a plug for American aid to places like Mongolia.
"I think most Americans, if they knew the facts, would be very proud of our country because of what we're trying to do to help others around the world," Mrs. Clinton said.
She also referred to Mongolia's efforts to introduce democratic politics and a market economy, though evidence of American cultural influence hung on the center's walls as well: one drawing had the names of singers Janet Jackson and Jason Donovan scribbled over an imitation of characters from the Disney movie "The Jungle Book."
Mrs. Clinton announced that the United States would provide $1 million to Unicef to support children's health programs in Mongolia, some of which would go to the center.
 
When in Ulan Bator . . .
 Virtually no visitor to Mongolia can escape noticing the white tent-like dwellings that speckle the country's vast grasslands and that have lasted through the centuries because they can be easily taken down and moved, a major convenience if you're a nomad, as half of Mongolia's inhabitants are.
Known to Westerners as yurts, their Turkish name, they are called "gers" in Mongolia. Mrs. Clinton learned ger etiquette at the first of eight stops on her visit, the home of a typical-looking Mongolian family.
She dutifully circled the ger's hearth clockwise, sipped mare's milk, sniffed a snuff bottle and asked after the family's livestock.
In Mongolia, gers can pop up where you least expect them, even at the seat of Government, where Mrs. Clinton called on Prime Minister Jasrai.
After her 10-car motorcade pulled up at a large Soviet-like structure in the center of town, Mrs. Clinton was led through a towering entrance, down red-carpeted hallways and out a back door to where the Prime Minister awaited her -- in a ger.
About 25 feet in diameter, this ger was richly carpeted and graced with a chandelier and an enormous alabaster bust of Genghis Kahn.
At its center was a silver punch bowl of mare's milk, a drink that, as Mrs. Clinton already knew, has the foretaste of cow's milk and the aftertaste of rank sweat.
Since this was a ceremonial ger, for visiting dignitaries and important meetings, Mrs. Clinton was not offered mare's milk this time. She did not hesitate to tell of her visit to the family ger.
"I liked that ger so much," she told the Prime Minister. "I may have to put one up at the White House."
 
Meet the Mongolian Press
 For the 18 American reporters who accompanied Mrs. Clinton to Mongolia, her overnight visit overflowed with photo opportunities, but did not present much of what journalists call hard news.
But for Mongolian reporters, the First Lady's visit was one of the biggest news stories to come along in a while.
"Very big story, very big story," said Erdenetsogtyn Sonintogos of Ardyn Erkh, a leading Mongolian daily. "Top 10 of the year."
During a meeting at the children's center, Mrs. Clinton invited the reporters to ask questions of the director of the center, Khuushaan Baavgai.
Two American reporters asked about the plight of the children. Then Ms. Sonintogos stepped forward. "Will you run for President when your husband's term is completed?" she asked, evoking a laugh from Mrs. Clinton.
"Reporters are the same the world over," the First Lady said. "It must be something in the water."
Then she changed the subject.

HEADLINE: Gladys Dorman, Education Panelist And Lawyer, 84

BYLINE: By ROBERT McG. THOMAS Jr. 

 BODY:
Gladys M. Dorman, a lawyer who served 20 years on the New York City Board of Higher Education, died on Thursday at her home in Bal Harbour, Fla. She was 84.
As a girl growing up in Flatbush, Miss Dorman, who continued to use her maiden name throughout her professional career, became well acquainted with the law. 
 Her father, Benjamin Dorman, a leading figure in the Democratic Party in Brooklyn, worked his way up through the court system to become chief clerk of the Surrogate's Court in Brooklyn, where Miss Dorman practiced as an estate planner and wills litigator for more than 30 years. She was a partner of Raphael & Dorman with her husband, Benjamin R. Raphael, a Brooklyn Law School classmate whom she married in 1939. He died in 1992.
For all the family precedent, Miss Dorman, who received a bachelor's degree from Cornell University in 1931, intended an academic career. But after she obtained a master's degree in history from Columbia University in 1933, she switched to the law when a post she had been promised as an instructor at Brooklyn College evaporated in Depression economics.
She obtained her degree in 1936, and four years later was one of the first seven women elected to the Brooklyn Bar Association. In 1966, she became the first woman to serve as a trustee.
Miss Dorman's service on the Board of Higher Education, the governing body of the city colleges, began with an interim appointment by Mayor William O'Dwyer in 1949.
Miss Dorman was a member of the board's executive committee and chairwoman of the board's Brooklyn College administrative committee.
She is survived by two sons, both lawyers, Stephen M. Raphael of Brooklyn and Allan H. Raphael of Oak Park, Ill.; five grandchildren, and one great-grandchild.

HEADLINE: Look, Cars! Rare Species Sighted in Laos

BYLINE: By HENRY KAMM 

DATELINE: BOTEN, Laos

 BODY:
The road into this remote Laotian village of thatched huts and wooden shacks cuts through mountains that are home to many of Southeast Asia's tigers and elephants.
This is a region where few people move on wheels, bicycles included, where it is not uncommon to see elephants transporting people or goods, even in the one-street provincial capital. Luang Namtha Province is one of the poorest in a country classified by the United Nations as one of the world's least developed. Electricity is available only in the capital, also named Luang Namtha, for two hours a day on good days. 
 The province's 130,000 inhabitants are splintered into 32 ethnic minority groups that share one trait: they are largely illiterate and hardly take part in the money economy.
So Boten would not seem to be a place for lots filled with new and used cars for sale. Yet it has the largest, perhaps the only, car market in a region that embraces some of the most remote parts of Laos, China, Myanmar and Vietnam.
On a recent visit, lots containing several hundred cars were seen stretching for more than 10 miles along the curving, rutted road from a Laotian customs office to the Chinese border village of Bohan, which begins where Boten ends. At one lot, two teen-agers guarded a few dozen new South Korean and Japanese cars. Carrying air rifles, which they hoped would deter bandits, not unknown in these mountains, the two lamented that business was slow.
Laotian salesmen and customs officials said the Chinese authorities seemed to be getting tough on the freewheeling trade. The only customers are the newly rich of southern China, who can afford to pay $20,000 to $40,000 in American dollars or Chinese yuan for a car -- still in short supply in China -- plus $1,000 to $2,000 to Chinese customs officials, a Laotian seller said.
He pleaded ignorance about whether the customs payment was official duty or a bribe, but a better customs deal is thought to be one of the attractions of the local car mart.
The dealer explained the circuitous route that the cars take. They originate in many places, including the United States, which produces Japanese cars with left-hand steering, suitable for China.
They are all shipped to Bangkok and are driven across Thailand to Vientiane, the Laotian capital. For a transit fee of about $1,360, the cars are admitted into Laos, bearing no license plates. The most difficult trek is over this country's wretched roads to Boten, a two-day, one-night haul that costs the seller about $130 and a few dollars for a plane ticket back to Vientiane for the driver.
The border trade became possible only after the Soviet Union, in its decline, relaxed its stern hold over this weak country. Now the border is open with virtually no formalities for Chinese and Laotians. Bohan, which barely existed a decade ago, has become a booming place of shops offering a wide range of cheap Chinese consumer goods to Laotians, whose country produces few items of daily necessity.
The village resembles a construction site, with a long row of shops newly built and another row nearing completion. So relaxed is life on the border that Laotian officials had no difficulty persuading the Chinese border police to waive their strict regulations and let an American accompanying them spend the day in China even though he had no visa.

HEADLINE: For Gay Zimbabweans, a Difficult Political Climate

BYLINE: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr. 

DATELINE: HARARE, Zimbabwe

 BODY:
"Oh, my God, I can't believe it! I've been ripped off!"
Leonard, a 37-year-old professional man and locally well-known Diana Ross imitator, had discovered that the penalty for letting a young man you barely know stay in your apartment is the same all over the world: his television and CD player were gone. 
 Adding insult to injury, the thief had tacked his picture to the bookcase. Daniel, a good-looking young South African sponger, had fled.
The manhunt that consumed the next two hours was a whirlwind tour of gay Harare's hangouts: hair-dressing salons, florist shops and bars. Throughout it, Leonard agonized about whether he dared go to the authorities: "I can't. I hate the police. Oh, but I should!"
This is no small quandary in a country where the President, whose word carries enormous weight, has recently embarked on a relentless barrage of words against those he calls "sodomists and perverts."
President Robert Mugabe has said publicly that homosexuals have no legal rights. He has called them "worse than dogs and pigs," and sneered at a letter of protest signed by 70 American Congressmen, saying, "Let the Americans keep their sodomy, bestiality -- stupid and foolish ways."
But Mr. Mugabe's campaign has not -- or not yet -- reached the street.
"Gay bashing goes on only at the highest political level," said a local journalist. "There's a good deal of tolerance on the ground."
Mr. Mugabe's startling outbursts are widely assumed to be politically motivated. Even though his ruling party, the Zimbabwe African National Union-Popular Front, has a hammerlock on Parliament, he faces an election next year. And he would love to distract voters' attention from an economy hurt by drought, a swollen military budget and the bleeding of the public purse by corrupt officials. Mr. Mugabe is also a devout Catholic raised in the conservative culture of the Shona people.
Gay-bashing seems to work for him much the way it does for Jesse Helms: the newspapers are full of letters praising his stand. In some ways, Mr. Mugabe and Mr. Helms have similar constituencies: Zimbabwe is a nation of farmers, tobacco is a major crop and American fundamentalist preachers like Pat Robertson have big followings here via radio.
The fear is that Mr. Mugabe's words will inspire violence. In the past, the President has lashed out at stockbrokers and said that wealthy white farmers have "hearts as hard as Jews." But it stopped there. Nothing was nationalized, no one arrested.
But homosexuals are nervous about the party's Women's League, who wear dresses with Mr. Mugabe's picture on them and sing for visiting dignitaries. In black townships during the 1985 and 1990 elections, they broke into the homes of people supporting the opposition, beat them and threw their belongings in the street. Mr. Mugabe has made speeches recently suggesting they tie up homosexuals and bring them to the police.
Zimbabwe's atmosphere was not always anti-gay. There were gay clubs even before the 1980 transition from white-ruled Rhodesia, and in the mid-1980's a gay wedding was on the front pages. Harare has its own Central Park Ramble: the Botanical Gardens are a cruising spot, as is Cecil Square.
(Cecil Rhodes, the founder of Rhodesia, is widely assumed to have been gay. He lived with Neville Pickering, the first secretary of the De Beers Corporation, in a friendship described by the Imperial Secretary of Cape Town as "absolutely lover-like.")
A gay rights group, Gays and Lesbians of Zimbabwe, was formed. Drag fashion shows to benefit people with AIDS were no secret.
Problems arose only when the Government was consulted. State censors refused to let the gay group import "Maurice," a fairly sedate film about a gay man, and it could not advertise dances or counseling because the party controls every paper "except The Financial Gazette, and that's not exactly our target audience," said one gay rights advocate.
In July the climate abruptly worsened. Saying that "they have absolutely no rights whatsoever," Mr. Mugabe banned the gay group's bookstand from an international human rights book fair here. The Minister of Information told the group to take down its banner, saying, "We don't allow protest in our country." The Minister of Home Affairs threatened arrests, though homosexuality is not a crime here. (Sodomy is.)
Interestingly, after the threats, the police stayed calm.
"They said, 'Don't hand out any literature, but you can talk to people,' " said Luke, another drag queen and a protester at the fair.
The questions that visitors to the book fair asked Luke show just how little-known homosexuality is in Shona and Ndebele society, where sex is discussed only with older relatives. "They asked things like, 'How many organs do you have?' " Luke said.
"Africans can accept a feminine man," said Leonard. "They believe that a spirit medium might get into you. But when it comes to the sex part, it becomes confusing."
That ignorance has voters believing Mr. Mugabe when he says homosexuality is a white vice imported with British colonialism.
But Leonard says that most of the 800 or so men in Harare's gay scene are black. And academic evidence undercuts Mr. Mugabe. Shona takes its modern vocabulary from English, but there is a traditional Shona word for homosexuality -- ngochani.
Gay African men are relatively lucky, Leonard said. At least they live in a male-dominated society. "Black lesbians have the hardest time," he said. "They can't earn money to get away."
He said he knew of a lesbian whose family locked her up and had a man rape her so she would get pregnant. After she ran off and had an abortion, they caught her and did it again. "Now she has the baby and is forced to live with this man," he said.
For Leonard, the price of his sexual orientation was not so high.
To his own amazement, he actually caught his thief, pulling him off a bus about to leave for South Africa. Then he lost him: Handing over his suitcase for security, Daniel begged to be allowed to run across the street and get his bus ticket refunded -- and then jogged off into the darkness. His suitcase held only some old clothes and a tape of the last "Mr. U.K." contest.
In the end, Leonard did go to the police. Since he had the picture and Daniel had apparently also sweet-talked the Sheraton Hotel out of hundreds of dollars' worth of room service, the officers treated Leonard as nothing less than a solid citizen.
In Zimbabwe, gay culture is so little known and men stay with male friends so frequently that it probably never occurred to the police that Leonard -- whose mannerisms, clothes and moussed hair would have screamed "gay" to the police in New York -- was one of those "perverts" the President had denounced.

HEADLINE: Conservative Christian Group Ends Conference With a Dual Identity

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9

 BODY:
Looking out with satisfaction at an audience of thousands of churchgoing, politically energized members of the Christian Coalition, Ralph Reed, the group's executive director, declared, "We have gained what we have always sought -- a place at the table."
In fact, the coalition, which ended its two-day conference here today, has reached a pinnacle of power in Republican politics, largely through Mr. Reed's carefully constructed two-pronged strategy. The group has broadened its base and won widespread backing from Republicans in Congress by toning down its oratory in recent years, emphasizing economic issues as much as social ones and even backing moderate Republican candidates. At the same time, the coalition has continued to stir up the faithful in the grass roots with unfettered attacks on President Clinton, homosexuals and abortion rights leaders, through mailed fund-raising appeals. 
 Now, as the coalition, with 1.7 million members, seeks to maintain and expand its political pull, its challenge is whether it can satisfy both constituencies and position itself as a mainstream organization without turning off the loyalists it is counting on to turn out at the polls.
"The Christian right finds itself torn between the pragmatism of its leaders and the purism of its followers," Mark J. Rozell, a political science professor at Mary Washington College, and Clyde Wilcox, a professor of government at Georgetown University, write in a book due out this fall on religious conservatives. "Movement leaders may find it difficult to convince the movement's activist core to volunteer on behalf of moderate Republicans year after year, especially if they receive no more policy payoffs than were offered by Reagan.
"Conversely," the authors continued, "if the movement resorts to the purist strategies of nominating candidates who are closely associated with or members of the Christian right, it is almost certain to lose."
The struggle within the Christian Coalition was evident at the group's annual convention. Mr. Reed and Pat Robertson, who founded the organization after his failed bid for the Republican Presidential nomination in 1988, stayed clear of the brand of militant oratory that had offended many of the more moderate Republicans at the party's 1992 convention in Houston.
As part of that effort to make the organization more palatable to all Republicans, Mr. Robertson -- who has a well-documented history of saying things that his opponents deride as extremist -- has ceded the public stage largely to the polished Mr. Reed, who espouses more mainstream views. One admirer of Mr. Reed's political skills is Lieut. Gov. Mike Huckabee of Arkansas, a Republican who told the convention, "He could sell an N.R.A. membership to Bill Clinton -- that's how good he is."
Like the group's leaders, two Republican Presidential candidates who appeared at the convention today were also tame in their speeches. Senator Richard G. Lugar of Indiana presented himself as having "Cal Ripken-like values" and made a plea "to challenge the morality of gambling."
And former Gov. Lamar Alexander of Tennessee took a mild swipe at a competitor for the nomination, Senator Phil Gramm of Texas, who once said he was running for President, not preacher. Mr. Alexander did not cite the Senator by name, but said, "At this time in our history, I'm not so sure that it wouldn't help if our President of the United States, the first President of the next century, were not a little bit of a preacher."
But any attempt by the coalition to keep contentious social issues from creeping into the program was shattered by other speakers who did not hesitate to charge up the audience with issues like abortion.
Phyllis Schlafly, a longtime leader of abortion opponents, told the group this morning it should demand that a Presidential or Vice Presidential candidate preserve the Republican Party's platform supporting a constitutional amendment banning abortion. Her comments drew an ovation, even though the coalition backed many Republicans in last year's Congressional races who did not support an outright prohibition on abortion.
Though Mr. Reed has called for the Republican ticket to be anti-abortion, Mrs. Schlafly went further and described abortion as "the central moral issue of our time."
"It is not enough that a candidate will tell you they have a pro-life record," she said. On Friday, Mr. Gramm tried to capitalize on such sentiments, reminding the group that Senator Bob Dole, another Republican Presidential candidate, had declined to sign a pledge to maintain the party's commitment to a constitutional amendment banning abortion.
Mrs. Schlafly took on prominent Republicans who favor abortion rights, singling out Gov. Pete Wilson of California and Senator Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania, both Presidential candidates, and Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey, who is often cited as a Vice Presidential prospect. "Even though these people have big names and great access to the media," she said, "we are not going to let the Arlen Specters, the Christine Whitmans or the Pete Wilsons take the pro-life platform out of the Republican platform."
But some analysts note that an aggressively anti-abortion ticket could put off voters in the general election -- or trigger a counter-mobilization from liberal groups.
Another risk facing religious conservative leaders is the nomination of a candidate whom they deem acceptable, like Mr. Dole or Mr. Gramm, but whom their membership will not support enthusiastically. The three Presidential prospects who most excited religious conservatives -- former Vice President Dan Quayle; William J. Bennett, a former Education Secretary and drug policy director, and Jack F. Kemp, a former Housing Secretary -- chose not to run.
Mary Erling, a coalition member from Great Falls, Va., said she did not think Mr. Dole, for example, was passionate enough about the abortion issue. "It makes me a little hesitant," said Mrs. Erling, who is 72. "He's definitely pro-life, but I don't agree that a woman's body is hers -- and I think he once made that statement."
John C. Green, a political science professor at the University of Akron and an authority on religious conservatives, said that in last year's campaign, "the Christian Right probably mobilized 4 million activists and reached 50 million voters -- a performance that rivals such traditional electoral powerhouses as the gun owners and labor unions." He also said that "probably no Republican candidate can win the Presidency without massive evangelical support."

HEADLINE: An Angry Man, Ugly Epithets, a Gun

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN 

 BODY:
It was a scene of terrifying ugliness on a New York City bus: a blustering, apparently drunken man with a beer bottle in a paper bag, pushing his way through the crowd, then confronting a man in a turban, an Indian-born medical doctor with six college degrees, a gentle, level-headed man who had always tried to avoid conflict.
They were aboard the northbound M-15 bus on First Avenue near 42d Street about 8:15 Friday night when the man came lurching and stumbling through the crowd, Dr. Kanwarjit Singh, a 40-year-old internist in residence at New York University Medical Center, recalled yesterday. 
 "As he was weaving his way through the bus, he bumped me, and began to yell at me, 'Respect my space! Respect my space!' " Dr. Singh said in an interview from a bed at Bellevue Hospital Center.
Dr. Singh's wife, Harmeet Dhillon, a lawyer, who relayed some of her husband's version of his encounter with the stranger, said the man finally screamed at her husband: "Get out of my way, you Hindu . . ." ending with an obscenity.
"Of course," Ms. Dhillon said, "my husband is a Sikh, not a Hindu."
The aggressive man, who was black, continued to scream racial and ethnic slurs at Dr. Singh, his wife said, and when her husband silently backed away, the man raised his beer bottle as if to strike him.
That is when someone noticed the bulge in his waistband and shouted: "Gun! He's got a gun!"
The driver immediately pulled the bus to a stop on First Avenue and 45th Street, and riders spilled off in a panic to escape the danger. When the bus had cleared out, Dr. Singh and the man confronting him were left alone at the back, Ms. Dhillon said. The man blocked the doctor's way. The driver watched from the front.
"There was this 'High Noon' moment with him and me and the driver," Dr. Singh recalled.
Ms. Dhillon added: "He kept shouting about how he'd been insulted and wanted an apology. He says, 'Get down on your knees and apologize.' My husband made no attempt to comply. So the guy began to pull his gun and shot himself in the groin. He was very intoxicated, and when he shot himself he became completely infuriated. He emptied his gun at my husband."
All but one of the shots went wild. But one bullet struck Dr. Singh in the left chest, missing his heart but fracturing several ribs, passing through and collapsing his left lung and lodging in several fragments in his back, Ms. Dhillon said.
As Dr. Singh staggered off the bus and lay on the sidewalk, the assailant, bleeding from the groin, ran north on First Avenue and west on 47th Street to Second Avenue, where he was captured by a police officer who had heard his description on a radio and saw the suspect running. A .38-caliber revolver, its serial number filed off, was found in his possession, the police said.
The suspect, identified as 28-year-old Abu Muhammad, of 2110 First Avenue, was taken to Bellevue. Tests of blood samples taken on his arrival had found double the legal limit of alcohol for intoxication, Ms. Dhillon said.
Yesterday, after surgery, the doctor was listed in critical but stable condition, and the suspect, who was charged with attempted murder, was in serious but stable condition.
Little was known yesterday of Mr. Muhammad, who lives in a fourth-floor apartment in the East River Houses, a city project on First Avenue between 108th and 109th Streets. Rennis Wellman, a community advocate in East Harlem, said he had known Mr. Muhammad for 20 years since his family had moved into the neighborhood. He said the family had always been active in community affairs.
"Any time anybody needed anything from him, he was always there," Mr. Wellman said of Mr. Muhammad. "You're never going to hear anything bad about him." Told he had been charged with the shooting aboard the bus, he took a step back, apparently shocked. He said it seemed to him completely out of the realm of possibility.
Dr. Singh, who lives with his 26-year-old wife on East 86th Street, seemed in good spirits, despite his wounds, and said in the that he bore neither his assailant nor the city any ill will.
"I am an enthusiastic resident of New York," he said. "I am a citizen. I love this place. This is just the price of the ticket. It's a broad-shouldered city and we are a small ethnic group. If you live in a city like this, you have to live with a certain risk."
Asked if he had any bitterness toward the man who shot him, he said: "I prefer to think I had a providential escape. Things could have been much worse. I can truthfully say I bear him no bitterness."
Dr. Singh was described by his wife as a strong, athletic man who jogged regularly in Central Park, swam and went biking every week, and was in excellent health: a factor in his survival, for he had lost a great deal of blood when he reached the emergency room, she quoted doctors as saying.
"He's the most educated person I know," said Ms. Dhillon, herself a graduate of Dartmouth College and the University of Virginia Law School. She noted that they had met in 1993, when she was clerk to a Federal appeals court judge in Baltimore, and said she had never heard her husband even raise his voice to anyone.
She said: "He's really level-headed, sensitive, kind, very gentle. Very principled. He was not going to back down because he was challenged, but he avoids conflict. He doesn't ever win an argument with me. So that this could happen to him is shocking. He certainly had nothing to do with provoking it."
Dr. Singh, she said, was born and grew up in Punjab, India, one of three children of parents who were teachers. After high school, he attended St. Stephens College in New Delhi, majoring in physics and graduating in 1975 with a bachelor's degree. He then attended Oxford University in England for three years, and earned bachelor's and master's degrees in politics, philosophy and economics in 1979.
That year, he came to the United States, attended the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and in 1981 earned a master's degree in business administration. After several years working as a business consultant in the Boston area, he came to New York and attended medical school at Columbia University, earning both his medical degree and a master's degree in public health in 1990.
After three years as a resident in surgery at the University of California at San Francisco, he returned to New York last year and began a new career -- a residency in internal medicine at the New York University Medical Center. He married his Ms. Dhillon, a corporate lawyer with Shearman & Sterling, about a year ago.
"He did a surgical residency in San Francisco, but after three years he decided to change his field to internal medicine," Ms. Dhillon said. "He wanted an easier life style. He wanted to settle down."
Ms. Dhillon said his residency in New York began in July last year and would normally have been a three-year term, but because of his previous experience he is to be allowed to complete the residency in two years. In recent months, he had been working at various hospitals, and since Sept. 1 has been working at the Veterans Affairs Hospital at 23d Street and First Avenue.
On Friday night, he called his wife about 7:30 and said he was heading home from the hospital. About 8, she said, he boarded the northbound M-15 bus on First Avenue at 23d Street. He took a seat near the front, but when two elderly women boarded, he gave up his seat and moved to the rear of what was becoming an increasingly crowded bus.
By the time the bus reached 42d Street, where Mr. Muhammad was believed to have stepped aboard, there were about 70 people on the bus, the police said, a situation ripe for conflict. The ensuing confrontation, though ugly with racial and ethnic overtones, was not fatal, and Dr. Singh said he had emerged psychologically unscathed.
"I've enjoyed every moment of New York," Dr. Singh said. "I feel myself a privileged member of this mosaic. It's more sorrow and grief that I feel than anger."

HEADLINE: New Study Rebuts Theory of a 'Brain Drain'

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Sept. 7

 BODY:
Reports of a "brain drain" in Connecticut are unfounded, although the state is one of only four with population losses since 1990, said a study released this week.
Because of the weak economy, fewer people are moving into Connecticut while the number leaving the state has held fairly steady since the 1970's, said the report, which was based on Census Bureau and Internal Revenue Service data. 
 The report rejected "a common misperception in the state that Connecticut has lost population for the past three years due to an overwhelming outflow of residents, including our 'best and brightest.' " It said those leaving the state are neither younger nor better educated than those who have left in the past.
Connecticut is one of four states that have lost population in at least one year since 1990. Two others are Rhode Island and Massachusetts, neighbors of Connecticut that share many of its economic problems. The fourth state is North Dakota.
The study was done by the C.P.E.C. Foundation, an affiliate of the nonpartisan Connecticut Policy and Economic Council.
Despite the report's conclusion that things are not as bad as many believed, the council's president, John J. Carson, warned, "Connecticut is losing economic activity that potentially it will never get back."
He said Connecticut had not recovered from the recent recession as well as the rest of the country and even its neighbor states. Connecticut has recovered only 14 percent of the nonfarm jobs it lost during the recession, compared with 40 to 100 percent in other New England states.
If the new jobs created at the Foxwoods Casino run by the Mashantucket Pequot Indians in Ledyard are not counted, Connecticut has regained none of the jobs it lost, said Stephen A. Clement, a senior researcher for the council.
The report recommended several steps to make Connecticut more attractive to industry, like cutting taxes and investing in education and training programs.
Connecticut's population -- taking into account births and deaths as well as migration -- has decreased three years in a row starting in 1992. In that year, the number of people leaving the state outnumbered those moving in by 31,300 -- roughly the population of Trumbull.
In 1993, the last year for which detailed figures were given, 106,829 people moved out of Connecticut -- only about 0.6 percent more than in 1987, when the economy was still strong. But in 1993, 76,962 moved in -- about 16.5 percent fewer than moved to the state in 1987.
The state's population is now estimated at 3,277,310, compared with 3,287,116 in the 1990 census.
Since at least 1985, the most popular destination of people moving out of Connecticut has been Florida, the report said. The other top destinations were New York, Massachusetts and California.
Polls have found that the most common reason for leaving Connecticut is the economy, said G. Donald Ferree, director of the Connecticut Poll and associate director for the Institute for Social Inquiry and the Roper Center at the University of Connecticut.
The report described the typical persons moving in and out of the state as similar -- about 30 percent have at least a high school diploma, about 35 percent are between 25 and 44, and at least 83 percent are employed. In 1992, those moving out had an average income about 4 percent higher than those moving in, the report found.
State Representative Jefferson B. Davis, who heads the Legislature's Planning and Development Committee, remarked: "One of the strengths of this study is to blast to smithereens the idea that it's just the unemployed and people looking for welfare benefits moving in, and it's the people with high education levels that are moving out."
The report found that cities continued to lose population in the 1980's while suburbs gained.
